The claimant, XXXXXXX, a citizen of India, claims to have a "well-founded fear of persecution"1 by the authorities in India by reason of imputed political opinion. He also claims to be "a person in need of protection"2.
The Minister's counsel intervened in this case, questioned the claimant and submitted that the claimant should be excluded under section 1F (b) of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention3.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
The claimant, a 33-year-old farmer of Sikh origin and alleged member of the Bhartyia Kissan Union (BKU), is a resident of the village of XXXXX, Punjab. He alleges that he was persecuted by the police. He was arrested in XXXX 1995, XXXXX 1998 and XXXXX 2001. Each time, he was tortured and beaten by the police.
The claimant alleges that the reason for harm was his involvement in the BKU, an organisation that voices the demands and needs of Sikh farmers to the government. Concerning the XXXX 2001 arrest, the claimant alleges that the police believed that he had links with militants/terrorists because he was caught in a police blockade transporting "some kind of explosives" on the night of XXXXX, 2001.
DETERMINATION
The panel excludes the claimant under section 1F (b) of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention.
ANALYSIS
1) Identity
The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act places emphasis on the need to have acceptable documentation establishing identity4.
Upon his arrival in Canada, the claimant had two identity documents: a driver's licence and a birth certificate that were seized by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (exhibit A-5). Although the panel has concerns about these two documents, it noticed that the claimant obtained later on and submitted his identity card with a picture issued by the Election Commission of India (exhibit P-4). Hence, the panel contends that the identity of the claimant has been reasonably established.
2) Credibility
The Minister's counsel argued that section 81 (1) (d) (ii) of the Criminal Code applied to the present case:
"81 (1) ?Using explosives? Every one commits an offence who
(d) makes or has in his possession or has under his care or control any
explosive substance with intent thereby
(ii) to enable another person to endanger life or to cause serious damage
to property.
(2) ?Punishment? Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1)
is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
(d) to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years."
After assessing the claimant's testimony and PIF as a whole, the panel is of the opinion that the claimant demonstrated that he is credible on the following facts:
1) On his way to the grain market located in XXXXX, he was intercepted by two armed Sikh terrorists, approximately 2 km from his farm and about 4 km to the market;
2) he had the intention to transport "some kind of explosives"5 to the market and hand them over to the terrorists;
3) after the departure of the two gunmen, realizing that "the toolbox of the tractor is often checked by the police"6, the claimant "hid the items in the paddy bags under the tarpaulin";7
4) the police intercepted the claimant and seized the "some kind of explosives"8 at a police blockade, about 2 km from the market.
Thus, the claimant demonstrated that he intended to transport explosives and deliver them at the market to terrorists and that these explosives were under his care and control.
However, the claimant demonstrated that he is not credible when he stated that he did not know that he was transporting a bomb and that he acted under pressure because the terrorists threatened to kill him and his family.
When asked whether he transported a bomb as he was heading towards the market, the claimant answered that he did not know it was a bomb. Confronted by the Minister's counsel since the claimant wrote in December 2001 in his answer to question 37 of his Personal Information Form (PIF) that "he thought that it was some kind of explosives", the claimant replied that it was wrapped in a piece of cloth. In assessing credibility, the panel is entitled "?...? to rely on criteria such as rationality and common sense"9. Hence, the panel does not find it plausible that the claimant did not know he was transporting a bomb given he was dealing with terrorists, given that he admitted to the Immigration Officer in December 2001 (exhibit A-5) that he knew that it was a bomb, given that he took the precaution to remove the explosives from his toolbox and hide them, and given that he "started to shiver" at the sight of the police blockade10. Questioned, the claimant's defence was that he acted under the threat of himself and his family being killed by the terrorists. However, the claimant declared at some point in the hearing that "if he had known it was a bomb, he would have left his tractor and run away". Given that the terrorists left after handing the explosives to the claimant, hence given that the claimant was never under the constant threat of the terrorists watching his every move, and given the panel's previous conclusion that it did not find plausible that the claimant did not know he was transporting a bomb, the panel concludes that the claimant had the opportunity to leave his tractor where it was and run away. The claimant is not credible when alleging that he acted under duress.
Hence, given that the standard of proof required is less than the balance of probabilities11, the panel comes to the conclusion that it has serious reasons for considering that the claimant "has committed a serious non-political crime" outside Canada prior to his admission to Canada as a refugee, thus should be excluded from refugee protection.
In the present case, the crime was not committed "in the course of and incidental to a violent political disturbance such as a war, revolution or rebellion."12 Documentary evidence indicates that the situation in Punjab is now under control. Acts of violence are now at a low level as the militancy period ended in the mid-1990s.13 Moreover, there is no evidence that the perpetrators were, indeed, members of a militancy group. The claimant's ignorance about the identity of the group casts serious doubts that the act of violence had any political motive. Transporting a bomb in order to deliver it to militants, waiting for it at a market, which bomb can then be used to kill innocent people, is a crime of "an atrocious or barbarous nature."14
In conclusion, under section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act15, a person referred to in section 1F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention, as it is the case of the claimant, is not a "Convention refugee" or "a person in need of protection".
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the panel excludes the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXX, under section 1F (b) of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention. The claimant is not a person who can be protected under sections 96 or 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Philippe Patry
Me Philippe Patry

1 The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. (2001), chap. 27, provides the following definition :
" 96. A Convention refugee is a person who, by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion,
(a) is outside each of their countries of nationality and is unable or, by reasons of that fear, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of each of those countries; or
(b) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of their former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country."
2 The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. (2001), chap. 27, provides the following definition :
" 97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
(a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of that country,
(ii) the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care."
3 The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. (2001), chap. 27, provides the following definition:
"(1) F. The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes;
(b) he has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee;
(c) he has been guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations."

The claimant XXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Poland, bases his claim against Poland upon the grounds of his half-Romani ethnicity. The panel must determine whether the claimant is a Convention refugee as defined by the s 2(1) of the Immigration Act1. The claimant alleges that because of his half Romani ethnicity he has been subjected to attack and has received inadequate state protection in Poland.
The claimant alleges his mother is Polish and his father is a Rom. The claimant alleges that his first language is Romanes. However, when asked by counsel to describe what he did that morning in Romanes, the claimant spoke with hesitation and paused, as opposed to when he was speaking in Polish which he did with apparent fluidity and ease.
The claimant was asked to describe in the Romanes language one of the incidents in 1998 as set out in his Personal Information Form (PIF). He then stated what he had said in Romanes in the Polish language. Under further examination, he admitted that he had said more in Polish than when he had been speaking in Romanes. Also, when the claimant was originally speaking Romanes and describing the incident in 1998, the panel heard the word Canada. At first, the claimant denied having said Canada. He then admitted that he had said he came to Canada to have a better life. The claimant was asked why he had said this since he had been asked to describe the incident from the fall of 1998. The claimant alleged that he had done so but also responded that he wanted to add this about Canada.
The claimant was again asked by his counsel to describe the incident in the Fall of 1998 in the Romanes language and then tell us what he had said in Polish. The claimant again mentioned Canada and admitted that he had said the same thing as before. He then explained in Polish what he had allegedly said in Romanes. The counsel pointed out that he had asked the claimant to describe the incident from thefall of 1998 whereas the claimant had described what had happened in the summer of 1998 according to his Personal Information Form. The claimant tried again and again spoke with less ease and fluidity than when he spoke Polish.
The claimant was confronted with the fact that he had testified that his mother tongue, his first language, was Romanes and yet, he clearly spoke that language with less ease than when he spoke Polish. The claimant responded that this was because they tried to speak Polish as much as they could and his mother did not allow him to speak Romanes too much and preferred him to speak Polish so people would not beat him. However, the claimant had earlier testified that his mother spoke to them at home in Romanes. Also, the claimant is from a small town in Poland where people allegedly knew they were Roma. The panel therefore does not find his argument valid that he would be more or less targeted depending on which language he was speaking.
The panel heard testimony from a witness, XXXXXXXXXX, a Romani citizen of Poland who testified that the claimant is Romani. The witness was excluded while the panel advised the claimant what to speak about in the Romanes language when the witness returned. The witness would then say in Polish what the claimant had said in Romanes. When the witness returned, the claimant spoke in Romanes haltingly and without detail, but was able to get the general story right in accordance with his Personal Information Form.
The panel therefore accepts that he has a certain low level of capability in the Romanes language. The panel notes however that at one point in his discussion in Romanes with this witness, the claimant whispered in Polish to her that his father was not with the group when describing the incident.
In any event, on the basis of the claimant's very limited abilities in Romanes, the panel accepts his testimony that he has this limited capability because his father is a Roma, and thus the claimant has established on a balance of probabilities that he is half-Romani.
The panel then had to turn to the issue of whether the claimant's testimony regarding what he had suffered in Poland was credible and what he might face in the future should he return to Poland.
The panel also heard testimony from another witness, XXXXXXXXX, also a citizen of Poland who is an ethnic Pole. She testified she saw the claimant being harassed and beaten by Polish boys and saw bruises on his face. She testified that it often happened in their hometown that Polish boys would fight with gypsies. She testified she does not know what the police do in these situations and does not know of any Polish boys who have been charged criminally for such beatings.
The panel therefore examined the alleged incident in more detail with the claimant.
The claimant says he was attacked in XXXX 1999, because he is Romani and that he was hospitalized as a result. The police found the attackers but the claimant allegedly received a threatening note in hospital that he would be killed if he did not withdraw the charges. He testified he did not show the police the note because he was afraid and he therefore threw the note away. He testified that he threw the note away before he withdrew the charges. The panel questioned why he would do such a thing. Clearly, it would be useful to keep the threatening note as evidence in case the perpetrators came after him. The claimant responded that he was hoping they would not beat him anymore. This explanation does not adequately respond to the implausibility of the claimant throwing away important evidence even before he had withdrawn the charges from the police.
He testified the police told him not to withdraw the charges. He testified he went home from hospital at the end of XXXXX or the beginning of XXXXXXX 2000. He says he did not withdraw the charges until the beginning of XXXXX. In spite of the alleged death threats that he had received in hospital about withdrawing the charges, the claimant had no problems throughout the month of XXXXXXX. He said he would hide when he saw the perpetrators. However, the claimant was working and continuing to take the bus to work alone. The claimant continued going to work even though there were these alleged death threats against him, he had destroyed the evidence of these threats, and he did not tell the police about these threats even though they had previously acted on his case and had actually found the perpetrators.
This whole sequence of events is simply not plausible. Moreover, if there truly were death threats against the claimant, the perpetrators presumably had ample time and opportunity to have acted on those threats as the claimant continued to live in his home, to work, and to take the bus alone. Furthermore, the claimant has no documentary record of his being in hospital for a month and a half. It is entirely reasonable to conclude if the claimant truly had been hospitalized for a month and a half, a documentary record would have been readily available to him to present as documentary evidence.
The claimant was not a credible witness. Even if the claimant were to be believed that he had been attacked in his hometown, the fact remains that adequate state protection was available to him there. The police had acted upon his complaints and even found the perpetrators. They also encouraged the claimant not to withdraw the charges against the perpetrators. This alleged XXXXXX 1999 incident was the most serious one alleged by the claimant and in the panel's view, the police actions were indicative of adequate state protection. However, even if the panel were mistaken in this conclusion and the claimant did not have adequate state protection in his town, the panel concludes that he had an internal flight alternative to Warsaw, which is about 300 kilometres from his hometown.
The claimant admitted in testimony that he is not physically identifiable as a Roma to a stranger. He is well-educated, and Polish is clearly his first language. The claimant testified that he would eventually be identified as a Roma even in Warsaw when his family or acquaintances visited.
The panel concludes that the chance of him being identified as a Roma in Warsaw are unlikely. However, if he were identified as a Roma, the documentary evidence leads the panel to conlude that adequate state protection would be available to him in Warsaw. The evidence indicates that relations between the police and Roma in Warsaw are quite good.
The claimant indicated that he has two friends in Warsaw, that they moved frequently and that they were being persecuted all the time. The claimant however was short on detail and did not even know if his friends had reported anything to the police. He also admitted that his two Romani friends work in Warsaw.
On the basis of all of this, the panel finds that an internal flight alternative exists in Warsaw and further that it would be reasonable in his circumstances.
The claimant's vague assertions regarding his two Romani friends who allegedly had problems in Warsaw are not sufficient to outweigh the documentary evidence regarding the good relations between the police and Roma in Warsaw.
The panel finds further support in its conclusion that the claimant has not established a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland given the fact that he was in Canada when he was sixteen or seventeen years old and returned to Poland making no refugee claim in Canada. The claimant has three siblings in Canada. He testified they have been here about ten years and two of them are Canadian citizens. As well, when the claimant returned to Canada for this current trip, he made no claim at the Port of Entry which was the airport in Toronto, nor did he make a claim for refugee status while living in Toronto after his arrival. The claimant made his refugee claim in Ottawa about a week later because his family in Toronto allegedly did not know about the refugee process. It is implausible to the panel that his three siblings who have been in Canada for approximately ten years would have family members in Poland allegedly being persecuted and that these siblings would not know about the refugee process in Canada.
The claimant or his siblings could have gone to an immigration lawyer or to the authorities in Toronto to obtain information about how the claimant could be helped if he had a well-founded fear of persecution and in fact, this could have been done when the claimant was here for his first three-month trip to Canada. His actions are not consistent with the claimant having a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland.
On the basis of all of the above, the panel concludes that the claimant has not established a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland. The Refugee Division therefore finds that XXXXXXX XXXXXX is not a Convention refugee as defined by s.2(1) of the Immigration Act.2
Per: "Dale L. Noseworthy"
Dale L. Noseworthy
Dated at Ottawa this 8th day of November, 2002.

INTRODUCTION
This is the decision of the Panel in the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, her children
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. The file numbers of the three claimants respectively are AA1-00073, -00072, -00074.
The hearing was held on the 15th day of October in Ottawa. The designated representative for the minor child XXX was the mother.
ALLEGATIONS
It is the evidence of the claimants as provided by the mother (when the two children were asked if they had anything to add to what the mother had said or testified to in the hearing, they said no) that they are members of a minority clan. In the case of the children, they are Reer Hamar and in the case of the mother, a Sheikhal. And because of this and the civil war in Mogadishu and in Somalia in general, they were forced to flee. They went to Kenya in 1991, lived there for some eight years without any legal status and then came to Canada in the year 2000.
To quote her Narrative, the principal claimant, the spokesperson for the three claimants, says that she fears that if she was to return to Somalia, she
"... would be persecuted by the warlords who belonged to the powerful majority tribes and who are still fighting among themselves, persecuting minority tribes at the same time. My tribe is a minority tribe and we have no political or military means to protect ourselves."
ANALYSIS
The issue in this claim is credibility and the credibility concerns which I will outline are not all major, there are several minor ones, but taken together, they undermine the story that this claimant has told on her behalf and on behalf of her children.
These credibility issues, as I am about to demonstrate, surfaced at the beginning of the hearing when because of some omissions in the Personal Information Form of the principal claimant, I addressed some questions in order to get a complete picture of her education. And when I did so, I found that there were problems right off the bat.
In the Personal Information Form of the principal claimant, we read in question 17, section 1, that she went to high school from 1976 to 1980. But it became clear in oral testimony that this could not be so because if we added up her education prior to going to high school, we would find that she started high school in 1968. Asked which was correct, did she in fact go to school in 1976 or 1968, she said she wasn't sure when she started high school. Then she revised that to say she was sure it was 1976. If 1976, she would be 27 years old when she started high school. This makes no sense whatsoever.
So before the hearing was five minutes old, we had some obvious contradictions and
I cannot understand why there would be this problem with the chronology of her education
if she were telling a true story. If indeed she were telling a true story, there would not be these problems. So immediately, I began to focus on whether or not her story was true and this questioning continued when we came to the only document that she has in support of her identity, and that is her driver's license.
Mindful of the fact that there is a brisk trade in fraudulent Somali documents,
which I know about because of my specialized knowledge having done hundreds of Somali claims, I questioned the claimant very closely on the authenticity of this license. First and foremost, I note that the date of birth on the license is 1951. The claimant's Personal Information Form on the other hand says her date of birth is 1949. When asked which was the correct date, the claimant said it was 1951, but I note here that just a few minutes prior to this questioning, when her Personal Information Form was introduced into evidence, she was asked
if the information contained therein was true and accurate. She said it was.
And yet, a few minutes later, she testified that the 1949 date given in her PIF is wrong and this is a date to which she swore not only when the PIF was introduced into evidence at the hearing but when she signed the PIF, which was on the 29th day of December in the year 2000. So twice she swore to the authenticity of the date that she contradicted at the hearing, twice she swore that she was born in 1949. And then at the hearing, when questioned about the discrepancy on this date between what it says on her alleged license, and what it says in her PIF, she says that 1951 is the correct date.
Further questioning on this document leads me to the conclusion that I can give no weight to it and it is the only document going to her identity. For example, she said that she needed the license for her business but she started the business in 1980. She didn't get the license until 1986. If she needed the license to purchase goods for her store, a store selling food, utensils such as plates and thermos flasks, along with children's clothes, then why would she wait until her business was six years old to buy a car? She said she didn't have the money to buy a car until 1986. But it is hard to reconcile that with the fact that she had an ongoing business, which required a vehicle and didn't get a vehicle until 1986.
Asked how old she was when she got her driver's license, there was a long pause which
I could not understand given that she had just finished testifying that she got it for business purposes and she was in business between 1980 and 1991. Finally, she said she was close to 40 when she got her license. In fact, she would be 37. But the fact that it took her so long to answer the question raises further questions about the authenticity of the license.
Furthermore, the license is in Italian. Anyone knowing anything about the history of Somalia in the south knows that it's true that southern Somalia was an Italian protectorate, but the south declared independence from the Italians in 1960. And yet, the claimant would have us believe that 26 years later, documents are still being issued in the Italian language. Furthermore, the government of Somalia introduced a Somali script in 1973. So the claimant would also have us believe that 13 years later, official government documents were still being issued in Italian.
Counsel in his submissions alluded to the fact and it is plausible that the government was still issuing documents in the language of the colonial power, but it is hard to believe that they would still be doing so some 13 years after Somali script was introduced and some 26 years after independence was declared. That would be a lot of leftover documents in the Italian language.
And finally in this connection, I note that the stamps on the document are in Somali, if not all of them, then certainly a good number of them. It is hard to believe that the stamps would be in Somali and the document itself would be in Italian.
Therefore in summary, for all of the above reasons I can give little or no weight to this document going to identity.
Questions were put to the principal claimant in an effort to find out if there were any other documents that she had at any time that would have assisted us in establishing her identity. Her answer was yes, she did have other identity documents at one time. She had a Somali national identity card, a tessera, and she had a license for her shop. Asked where they were, she said she lost them. Asked where she kept them, she said she kept all three of the documents in her purse.
I find it interesting to say the least that the only document that she didn't lose from her purse was the driver's license and that would be a document that is not the primary document in Somalia that helps to establish one's identity. The tessera is the primary document and the primary document is missing.
The other interesting thing I find about this document that it is a license issued in 1986 and it was not renewed. And yet, she kept it. I cannot imagine why she would need a document such as this, i.e. a license issued in 1986 for 5 years before she left Somalia in 1991 and then for almost 10 years in Kenya once she had fled Mogadishu. When I asked her this, she said she needed it to establish her identity at the refugee camps in Kenya. I asked if she showed it to the authorities and she said whenever she was asked, she showed them this. When asked what was the last time she had to produce it, she said she couldn't remember.
I do not find this testimony to be convincing as a reason why one would keep an out of date document from 1986.
Furthermore, on the issue of identity, we have no documents other than those in Exhibit C-4 to establish that she was ever in a refugee camp or in any refugee camp in Kenya. What we do have in Exhibit C-4 are documents which she says establish that her husband was in a refugee camp, at least the man she portrays as her husband in the Personal Information Form. These are documents issued in 1992 and 1993 with regard to the Utanga Refugee Camp in Kenya but these are not originals. Asked why she had these in her possession, she said she kept them because they reflected well on her husband. But if that were so, I would expect that she would be able to produce the originals. She was unable to do so and I said to her if I had something that reflected well on somebody in my family, I would have the originals and it makes sense that one would have the originals. Here we have only photocopies and I can give very little weight, if any, to photocopies of original documents.
So I am not even assured that the claimants were in the refugee camps that she alleges that they were in and she says from 1991 to 2000, they were in five refugee camps, Libooyeh for seven days, Thika until early 1992, then Utanga until '95, mid-year, then Marafa until 1999, and then Banadiri. Asked if she had any documents from these camps, she said parents were issued with documents saying the number of people living with them and they had a different card for
every camp. Asked where these different cards were, she said she had thrown them away because they were no longer needed. Apparently her license from 1986 was needed but cards from the camps were not.
Her testimony here does not have the ring of truth. One would expect that she could demonstrate that she was indeed in the camps when she said she was with some kind of primary document, which these cards would be.
Furthermore on the issue of credibility, she alleges that she and her family were in Mogadishu in the lead-up to the civil war. So I asked her what was life like and she said it was
a good life. There was a government. There was peace. The economy was good. But then
I asked when one got nearer civil unrest and the subsequent war, what was it like. She was unable to give me any specific answers. And I would expect that someone of her education and business acumen, having been in business for some 11 years, would know that life in 1989 and 1990, before the war started, was not particularly good in Mogadishu and that anybody living there at the time would be able to tell me what I know from reading the history of life in Mogadishu at that time certain specific incidents that happened, public incidents, assassinations, murders, and so on.
She was unable to offer anything except vague and general statements such as there were movements opposed to the regime and things got worse. The war was based on tribalism.
I gave her several opportunities and asked her several times to be specific and she could not do so. Therefore I do not find her testimony to be credible that she was in fact in Mogadishu at the time she says that she was.
Finally, in lieu of the fact that she had no reliable documentary evidence to establish that she is who she says she is and lived where she says she did at the time that she said she did, a witness was brought forward. The witness allegedly is the claimant's brother. His name is XXXXXXXXXXXX.
Unfortunately, I can give little weight to the testimony of such witnesses because their testimony is not in the same realm as objective independent testimony that one would get from documents. It is testimony that can be rehearsed and often is.
However, sometimes it can be reliable if it corroborates what we are told by the claimants. In this case, it did in some respects but not enough to reassure me that it is testimony that I can rely on to establish identity. And in other respects, it was demonstrably unreliable. For example, the claimant told us that she left Galkayo when she was eight years old, which would be 1957. She left this brother, the witness, behind. However, when the brother appeared, he said he was born in 1962. So it was impossible for her to leave him behind.
There are other inconsistencies and contradictions in the testimony of the two with regard to each other that leads me to suspect that they are not related and leads me to find that I can give no weight to the testimony of the witness with regard to the identity of the claimant. For example, when asked if the witness ever visited her store, the claimant said yes, he did. And when I asked the witness what the claimant sold in her store, the witness said she sold food, candies, clothes. He said nothing about utensils which the claimant clearly said she sold.
Furthermore, the witness said that he came to live with an uncle in Mogadishu and his uncle had a German wife. This is such an interesting fact that one would expect the claimant to have told us about this. She said nothing about a German wife married to the uncle whose home she said she visited. She also said she was very close to her brother. So if she was close to her brother, I would expect that she would know about the German wife and would have volunteered this information. It would be the kind of spontaneous testimony that is credible, trustworthy testimony.
And finally, I note that the claimant before me said in her testimony that the rest of her family never moved from Galkayo to Mogadishu permanently, that they maintained their residence in Galkayo. She was the only one that left when she was eight years old.
But her alleged brother said that he left as well when he was seven or eight years old and that's when he ran into his sister in Mogadishu. I would reasonably expect that if that were the case, the claimant would not have testified that the rest of her family, including her brother, the witness, never permanently left Galkayo but just travelled back and forth, which was her testimony.
DETERMINATION
So for all these reasons, the minor ones that I have elucidated and the major ones
that I have elucidated, taken together lead me to the conclusion that the principal claimant is not a believable claimant. And since the claims of her children and her claim are one and the same,
I find that the principal claimant is not a Convention refugee as her two children are not. And since no other ground was put before me on which I could make a decision, I also find that the principal claimant and her two children are not otherwise in need of Canada's protection.
"Gary F. McCauley"

These are the reasons for decision in the claim to be a Convention refugee made by XXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Poland. The claimant is a 33-year-old female who claims a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland on the ground of membership in a particular social group, namely her sexual orientation.
ALLEGATIONS
In her PIF and oral testimony the claimant asserts that she grew up in a Catholic household in a small Polish town and that at the age of 17 she knew that she was not interested in men. She studied carpentry and preferred to dress in men's style of clothing.
As a consequence she was constantly taunted, called names, ridiculed, discriminated against and even became the victim of physical assaults, and expelled from technical school in 1988.
She alleges that her father was an alcoholic and very abusive towards her and she detailed a number of incidents when he had abused her. She asserts that in 1997 he attacked her in the street and knocked out three teeth when he punched her in the face. In 1989 she claims that he had a number of male friends at the apartment and threatened to have them have sex with her to make her a real woman because of her sexual orientation. The claimant alleges that her father continually visited her, abused and harassed her especially from 1997 until she left Poland in February 2001.
The claimant stated that in 1990 she began a one-year relationship with a woman XXXXXX and that they shared the claimant's apartment. This ended when XXXXXXXX could no longer stand all the threats, graffiti and damage to the apartment door and windows, and she moved to Warsaw. The claimant then had a three-year relationship with XXXXX but they never lived together, as the claimant's sick mother had moved in with her. Between 1996 and 2000 the claimant was not in any relationship asserting that she was depressed, stressed and upset by the constant harassment based on her sexual orientation. In March 2000 she began a relationship with XXXXX which lasted until the claimant decided she must leave Poland for her safety in February 2001.
The claimant described her life in Poland as intolerable as she was constantly discriminated against, refused entry to shops, excluded from church, and fired several times from jobs all because of her being perceived as a lesbian. The claimant and her mother applied for visitor's visas after receiving an invitation to visit the sister of the claimant in Toronto, Canada. The mother was issued a visa but the claimant was refused. She then found someone to get her false documents, which she used to travel from Poland, through Holland arriving in Canada on 18 February 2001 in Toronto. She made her claim for refugee status 10 days later in Ottawa, on 28 February 2001.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant submitted a short birth certificate, an identity book and a vocational school certificate, as corroboration of her personal and citizenship identity. The panel accepts her evidence on her individual and citizenship identity as credible and established.
Issues
Issues to be resolved at the outset of the hearing were identified as credibility regarding the claimant's sexual orientation, the agent or agents of persecution, state protection and internal flight alternative.
Sexual Orientation
The panel finds that the claimant failed to establish that she is perceived as a lesbian on a balance of probabilities. The panel noted a number of inconsistencies, contradictions and implausibilities, which were not satisfactorily explained, and therefore finds the evidence not to be credible or sufficient.
The claimant in her PIF alleges she was 17 when she realised her sexual identity. The claimant's sister gave evidence to corroborate the claimant's sexual orientation. She stated that she suspected that the claimant was gay because when the witness would be at home with her girlfriends the claimant would act oddly and her friends would laugh at the claimant because they thought she was different. The claimant had stated that she was 17 when she realised she was gay. The claimant's sister's evidence was confused on this issue. She stated she knew the claimant's sexual orientation about 22 years ago, and then she clarified this to be when she herself was 19 or 20. This would have been approximately 1980, which is not consistent with the claimant's evidence that she knew herself when she was 17, which was approximately 1986.
The witness's attempt to clarify this evidence simply became more confused. When asked specifically when she knew the claimant's sexual orientation, she stated that she left Poland 12 years ago and that maybe it was about 8 years ago that she found out. When asked to clarify the apparent contradiction between knowing for 22 years and knowing for 8 years, the witness explained that she had serious suspicions that her sister was strange and different and that she absolutely knew when she was told by their mother. However the witness's evidence remained contradictory about whether she was told by their mother 8 years ago or as she later stated, she was told when she was leaving the country, which as she stated earlier was 12 years ago. The witness appeared to be trying to make her evidence fit the claimant's assertion that she herself knew she was a lesbian when she was 17.
As a consequence of these unresolved contradictions the panel finds the witness's evidence to be untrustworthy and cannot rely on it regarding the claimant's sexual orientation. In addition the panel notes several other exaggerations in the claimant's evidence and contradictions between the evidence of the witness and the claimant. The witness described her reaction to the claimant's sexual orientation as uneasy but that she had left the country and was therefore not really close to her sister. The claimant's evidence was that she was alienated from her sister. The claimant's sister indicated that she had known about the claimant's bad treatment in Poland and that that was the reason she and her mother wanted to visit Canada. The claimant in a written statement in support of her refugee claim stated that she had come to Ottawa to make her claim rather than stay in Toronto because she did not want her sister to know about the refugee claim.
The panel finds the claimant to have exaggerated the reaction of her sister in her written statement to bolster her claim and does not find the contradictions in the evidence to have been satisfactorily explained. The panel therefore does not find it to be credible. Further the claimant's evidence about not making her claim in Toronto on arrival because she did not want her sister to know about it is also not credible in light of what the claimant's sister said about knowing about her orientation.
The claimant asserts that she was known by everyone in her town to be a lesbian. The claimant's evidence in support of this assertion is not credible.
The claimant stated that her home town is small but when asked for the population the claimant indicated that it had a population of 80,000 people. The panel finds the claimant's evidence to be exaggerated and implausible. A population of 80,000 people is a significant size place even by Polish standards. The panel finds the claimant, in saying it was a small town, to have exaggerated to bolster her assertion that she was known by everyone.
The claimant gave no credible explanation as to how she would be physically identified by everyone in a town of 80,000 people. The claimant asserted that she was constantly thrown out of shops, cafes, church because of her sexual orientation being known by everyone. The panel finds this to be exaggerated and not supported by any credible evidence. The claimant gave no evidence of any position or activity that would have given her any public profile in her town. She also asserted that on one occasion she and her partner held hands on top of the table in a public place. The panel simply finds that such limited public behaviour could not reasonably lead a population of 80,000 people to know the claimant's sexual orientation and to have resulted in being constantly told to get out of shops, being sold bad fruit and other discriminatory treatment.
The panel believes the claimant also exaggerated the incidents directed at her apartment. The claimant was a single woman living with her mother. The fact that on occasion there was another woman living there is insufficient evidence that everyone would perceive the claimant
to be a lesbian.
Other than wearing more manly clothing the claimant was not able to indicate anything about her physical appearance which could lead everyone to perceive her as a lesbian. Given the above findings on credibility, the panel finds this to be insufficient to establish on a balance of probabilities that the claimant was perceived by the general population to be lesbian.
The claimant alleges that she had several relationships with women while in Poland. The claimant's evidence was that they would occasionally hold hands in public, mostly it would be under the table but at least once it was on top of the table. The claimant's evidence was also that she lived in her own apartment, which was owned by her sister who was in Canada. Given that the claimant asserted that she was harassed and discriminated against, and that Polish people are completely intolerant of homosexuality, the panel asked the claimant why she would risk any public displays of affection when she had her own apartment and therefore had the opportunity for complete privacy. The claimant's explanation was that she had a need for spontaneous show of affection and that she was a human being who had the right to be what she was.
The panel does not find the claimant's evidence to be believable. If the claimant's evidence regarding her daily treatment were to be believed then the panel simply does not find it to be credible that she would risk drawing attention to herself by holding hands in public when she had unlimited opportunity for privacy. The claimant's evidence regarding her motivation to exert her rights as a lesbian is also not credible. Her evidence was that she was completely depressed and desperate while living in Poland and that she only began realising how life could be for a lesbian once she was in Canada. The panel finds her evidence in this regard to be contradictory and not credible.
The claimant alleges that she had three relationships with women in Poland. One in 1990 for about a year; the second one was in 1993 for about three years; that she had no relationship between 1996 and 2000; and then in 2000 she had a relationship which lasted until she left Poland in February 2001. The claimant never attended homosexual clubs in Poland. She stated that there were none in her town and that she never attended any in Warsaw because it was too far. Later in her testimony she revealed that she made frequent trips, sometimes 4 in a month, to Warsaw for shopping. Her explanation for not seeking any relationship for 4 years was that she was very depressed. However the claimant gave evidence that she frequently travelled to Warsaw for shopping trips during this period.
She conducted her relationships with these women in private apart from going to cafes. She was not active in any homosexual organisations. The panel notes that for four years there is a complete absence of expression of sexual identity and for a very young woman this is hard to believe.
The panel finds it to be implausible that someone who was making frequent trips to Warsaw where there are homosexual clubs, would not visit these clubs out of curiosity or an interest in meeting other lesbians in a safe environment. Further, the panel does not find it reasonable to believe that someone who was making frequent pleasure trips to Warsaw, would also be too depressed to be seeking a relationship. The panel has already made a number of findings of lack of credible evidence regarding how the claimant was perceived. The panel finds the claimant's assertions that these relationships, conducted almost entirely in private, even if they were sexual in nature, to be insufficient to establish on a balance of probabilities that she is perceived to be lesbian.
The claimant asserts that she had one relationship in Canada which did not last long. The claimant did not bring a partner as a corroborating witness. The panel draws an adverse inference from there being no partner who could be questioned. The claimant asserts that she attended a gay parade in Canada as further evidence in support of her sexual identity. The panel gives the photographs, which establish this attendance, no probative value. The fact of attending a gay parade is not evidence of a sexual orientation. Many heterosexuals attend such parades for a variety of reasons.
The claimant submitted a letter from the Polish Gay and Lesbian Association of Toronto in support of her claim. This letter indicates that the President knows the claimant and that she has been a very active member of the Association, and that the President supports the claimant being allowed to stay in Canada on a humanitarian basis. This letter does not state that the claimant is a lesbian. This letter has little probative value other than indicating that the claimant is presently active in this association. Given all of the other credibility issue raised in this case, those already mentioned and those to follow, the panel believes that the claimant has involved herself in this organisation to bolster her refugee claim.
Exhibit C-2 is a sworn statement from friends of the claimant in Poland in support of her assertions about her sexual orientation and her treatment as a consequence. The panel notes that a detail in this statement is in contradiction to the claimant's evidence. The statement describes the claimant as having been "kicked out" by her father. The claimant's evidence was that her father moved out to be with his lover and that the claimant went at some point to live in her sister's apartment. She never asserted that her father kicked her out. Given that this statement is in contradiction to the claimant's evidence and was solicited by the claimant, the panel finds it to be lacking in credibility as well as self-serving and gives it no probative value.
The claimant was not believed by the visa officer when she applied for a Canadian visitor visa in Warsaw. The mother was believed and was given a visa. The claimant in her PIF and in her oral evidence gave the impression of her mother as ill, frail and somewhat incapacitated and dependent. The panel finds this description difficult to reconcile with the visa officer granting the mother a visa and making no reference in his note to dependency or health problems. The panel finds the claimant to have again exaggerated her evidence to bolster her claim.
Agents of Persecution
The claimant asserts that she is afraid mostly of Polish society and individual Polish people because of their lack of tolerance and their hostility. However, in her PIF and in her oral evidence, the claimant has given evidence which leads to the conclusion that a significant agent of persecution that she is alleging is her father. Counsel in his submissions even asserted that the claimant was more afraid of society than her father quoting the claimant as saying "she could hide from her father but not from society". However in her PIF the claimant clearly states when she was explaining about being fired from her jobs "my father was the main culprit in those actions against me". The panel finds the claimant's evidence regarding who she fears most and why to be contradictory and therefore not credible.
The claimant cited numerous serious physical assaults by her father beginning in 1989 and continuing until she left Poland in 2001. These incidents range from threatening to have his friends rape her, to beating her in the street and to constantly coming to the apartment where the claimant was living, constantly showing up at her workplaces and verbally and physically abusing her. The claimant's evidence is that her father was frequently drunk and that he was extremely angry at the claimant because of her sexual orientation.
The panel found a number of inconsistencies between the claimant's oral evidence and that in the PIF regarding her father. In her PIF the claimant alleges that she moved to an apartment with her friend XXXXXXXX in 1990 and her father found out where she was living and was very angry. Later on in her PIF she states that her father moved to live with his lover in 1990. When asked about the apartment that the claimant lived in the claimant revealed that it was in fact the apartment that was owned by her sister in Canada. It seems that the claimant has lived in this apartment since her sister left Poland.
Again the panel finds the manner in which the PIF is written is deliberately misleading. It is written to suggest that the father was angry to find that the claimant had moved to an apartment with a lesbian friend. Given that the claimant was living with her mother in her sister's apartment, it does not seem reasonable to believe that where she was living and who she was living with would be a surprise to the father.
The claimant in one part of her PIF indicates that her father moved in with his lover. In another part of the PIF the claimant asserts that her father kicked the mother out after she had a stroke. The panel finds that the claimant's evidence was contradictory, exaggerated, misleading and not credible.
The panel cannot believe that the claimant would continue to allow her father to come into the apartment long after he and her mother were estranged. The claimant had been living in her own place since at least 1990 and did not leave Poland till 2001. It seems impossible to believe that the claimant would repeatedly let her father into the apartment to continuously abuse her for more than 10 years while she was living an independent life as an adult woman. The panel does not believe this evidence.
Given the lack of credibility regarding the father's abuse, the panel does not accept as credible that the father was the cause of the claimant losing her jobs.
The claimant provided no medical evidence to explain any psychological condition that could explain her continuing to allow her father to abuse her. When asked questions about seeking assistance the claimant asserted that she saw a medical doctor at some point for psychological problems but that the advice that she got was to be patient with her father and try to find common language. The panel does not believe the claimant with regard to visiting a doctor or the advice she received. The evidence regarding this medical assistance was not in the PIF and appeared to be being fabricated by the claimant when she was being asked extensive questions about why she did not seek police help.
However even if the panel were to believe that the claimant sought medical help, the advice the claimant says she was given is simply not reasonable to believe. On a balance of probabilities, it is not believable that a medical doctor, in a country such as Poland, would tell a single adult woman, who was being abused for more than ten years by a father who was not even living with her, just to be patient and calm and would not advise her to get legal help to have him ordered to keep away from her or charged with something.
State Protection
The claimant did not seek any assistance from any police in Poland for any of the physical or verbal abuse that she suffered at the hands of her father. She never attempted to make any kind of report, official or unofficial, to the police about her father's abuse. Her explanation was that domestic abuse is regarded as a family matter and that police show little or no interest in helping abused women. In her PIF she states that she was contemplating asking the police for help but she realised she would expose herself to more jokes and she could not find enough courage to go to the police. When asked for further explanations as to why she did not more actively seek assistance, the claimant alleged that she knew a policeman who was a long-time friend of her mother and that she actually discussed her problems with him. She further alleged that he subtly discouraged her from reporting any of her problems.
The claimant explained the lack of mention of this police officer in her PIF by stating that she forgot, and that she did not think that it was so important. The panel finds this explanation to be not believable. She mentions in two separate places in her narrative about contemplating seeking police protection. If this police man was a friend of the family and had discouraged the claimant it is hard to believe that the claimant would think mentioning it was not important or connected to what she was relaying in her PIF. Further the claimant asserts that her mother was in poor health and that this policeman was a very good friend. The panel does not find it reasonable to believe that a policeman would do nothing when a good friend was being upset by her former husband constantly forcing his way into the apartment and abusing her daughter.
The panel believes the claimant fabricated the evidence about the friend who was a policeman as she was being questioned regarding state protection, to bolster her claim and does not believe it.
The panel is aware that abuse of women, mostly by their spouses, is a serious social problem in Poland and that police response is in many cases grossly inadequate or in some cases non-existent. Also the panel is aware that housing problems often compound the problem as frequently an abused woman is forced by shortages in housing to continue to live in the same house as her abuser. However this is not the case for the claimant. She was an adult living independently in an apartment. She had her mother living with her, and her father had not lived with either of them since 1990.
In the absence of credible medical evidence to explain this behaviour, the panel does not find it credible that the claimant would continue to allow her father into her apartment over a period of more than 10 years. Further the panel does not find it to be reasonable that she did not ever even make a report to the police against her father for assault. The panel does not find it reasonable to believe that the claimant would continue to endure the abuse by her father, and would never seek the advice of a lawyer about what charges could be brought against him, or how she could force him to stay away from her apartment.
When asked about approaching any support groups who assist abused women or homosexuals, the claimant asserted that she had phoned a help line and had been given the same advice as the doctor had given, namely to try to be calm and find common language with her father and society. The claimant did not specifically call this help line when she was assaulted by her father, giving her mental state as the reason.
The panel does not believe the claimant's evidence. The claimant is alleging her mental state incapacitated her and yet she at the same time describes making frequent trips to Warsaw for shopping and socialising with friends. If she was in such a mental state that she was unable to call a help line then surely she would not be able to be so social. The panel does not find the claimant's evidence regarding the advice she received from a help line to be credible either. It does not seem reasonable to believe that a help line would not have other advice for an adult woman who was being terrorised by her father, who was not living with her.
In a state such as Poland, an elected democracy with an independent judiciary and system of law enforcement, there is a presumption of state protection and it is for the claimant to demonstrate that in her case state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming. In not attempting to ask the police for help with her problem with her father, or not seeking advice from a lawyer as to what exactly she could do legally to get protection, the claimant has not met the burden of proof, and has failed to demonstrate that state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming.
Even if the claimant had provided sufficient credible evidence to establish on a balance of probabilities that she is perceived as a lesbian, and even if she had provided sufficient credible evidence to establish on a balance of probabilities that she suffered such discrimination that it amounted to persecution from either Polish citizens or her father, the panel finds that she has failed to establish on a balance of probabilities that state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming. Her claim must therefore fail.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee as she does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Poland. I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that her removal to Poland would not subject her personally to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that her removal to Poland will subject her personally to a danger of torture.
I therefore reject her claim.
For all of the above reasons, the panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee.
"Eunice Harker"
Eunice Harker

KEYWORDS - REFUGEE PROTECTION DIVISION - WOMEN REFUGEES - GENDER - SEXUAL ORIENTATION - LESBIANS - PARTICULAR SOCIAL GROUP - GENDER-RELATED PERSECUTION - CREDIBILITY - STATE PROTECTION - FEMALE - NEGATIVE - POLAND
The claimant alleged a fear of persecution by reason of her sexual orientation. The Refugee Protection Division found that the claimant failed to establish that she was perceived as a lesbian. There were a number of unexplained inconsistencies, contradictions and implausibilities in her evidence. Her claim of physical abuse over a period of a number of years by her father, who did not live with her, was contradictory and exaggerated. Physical abuse of women is a serious social problem in Poland, and police response is in many cases grossly inadequate and in some cases non-existent. However, it was implausible that the claimant would have continued to let her father into her apartment for those years, and it was not reasonable that she did not report him to the police or contact any of the support groups which assist abused women and homosexuals. The claimant failed to establish that state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming. RPD AA1-00454, Harker, November 1, 2002.

INTRODUCTION
These are the reasons in the refugee protection claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who alleges a fear of persecution by reason of his membership in a particular social group, the family of a man who quit the governing political party and publicly denounced the Fujimori-Montesinos regime.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that his father held a prominent position in the "Cambio 90" political party in Peru. The claimant indicated1 that his father held this position from 1995 to 2000. Following the re-election of Alberto Fujimori in 2000 for a third term, the claimant's father quit his political job as XXXXX of the XXXXXXXX District of the XXXXX Region of Lima. He publicly denounced the Fujimori-Montesinos regime which was at that time besieged by political scandals.
The claimant alleged in his PIF that on XXXXX 2000, his father was ambushed near his home and viciously beaten by unknown assailants. He was taken to a clinic, and a police report subsequently was filed. The claimant's father was told during the attack to refrain from criticizing the government in public. Otherwise, he would, along with his family, suffer the consequences. Following that incident, the claimant's parents moved from Lima to Trujillo and they feared being killed by a paramilitary group.
The claimant remained in Lima to complete his university studies but for security reasons moved to another district to live with his aunt. He went several times to the police station in the district of Ingenieria to enquire if the police learned about the assailants of his father. He did not get a satisfactory answer.
On XXXXXXX, 2001, at 11 p.m. the claimant was returning to his aunt's home when four armed and masked men threw him to the ground, beat and kicked him. These men enquired about the whereabouts of his father, and told him that he and his family would die because they were "considered traitors by the Fujimori-Montesinos government" even though Fujimori was no longer in power in August 2001. The claimant said that the Colina Group were violent supporters of the former Fujimori and Montesinos government and hunted down persons perceived to be "traitors". After hearing gun shots, the attackers fled and the claimant was brought to the hospital and he later filed a police report.
Following this incident, the claimant, with the financial help of his father and a smuggler, known as "XXXXX" in Peru, obtained false documents and took a flight to Mexico and to Canada.
The claimant says that if he returns to Peru, he might be persecuted or killed.
ANALYSIS
Identity
I have seen the claimant's passport and I accept that he is a citizen of Peru.
Credibility
The claimant's testimony goes directly against the documentary evidence. He is saying that his father was being targeted by the supporters of Fujimori-Montesinos
who are still very powerful in Peru. Futhermore, he fled the country in XXXXX 2001 but according to the documentary evidence2, a transition government took over from Fujimori in November 2000. A new government was elected in July 2001. This government is prosecuting Fujimori and his close associates for corruption, human rights violations, killings, and other crimes.
The documentary evidence also reported that Fujimori is in Japan and Peru is demanding his extradition while Montesenos, after fleeing the country, has in fact been extradited to Peru to face charges of corruption and homicide. There is no documentary evidence that the followers of the Fujimori government are hunting down people who had criticized the former regime.
Furthermore, the claimant was vague and evasive in his testimony nor did he provide a reasonable explanation for the contradictions and implausibilities in his testimony and in the documentary evidence.
For example , he said that when the Fujimori followers could not get to his father, they went after him. But if they had been as powerful as the claimant alleges, it is reasonable to infer that they could have killed his father when they assaulted him. They let him go after beating him and warning him to not criticize the government in public. The evidence is that he did not criticize the government after that incident.
The claimant did not provide a reasonable answer as to why the Fujimori followers would attack him almost a year after his father had criticized the Fujimori government. He only stated that they could not get to his father so went after him. But his father was still in Peru when the claimant fled the country. Even though the claimant testified that his parents moved to Trujillo from Lima the Fujimori followers only beat his father once and let him go after a warning.
Moreover, the documentary evidence shows that the Fujimori government was being severely criticized in Peru at the time when the claimant's father was allegedly beaten for criticizing the regime. Since then Fujimori and Montesinos have been thoroughly discredited. Fujimori has fled to Japan and his return is being demanded by Peru. Montesinos is being tried for his crimes after having been extradited to Peru. There is no documentary evidence that the followers of the former government, who themselves are being prosecuted for their actions during the Fujimori regime, are persecuting the former critics of the government - or are in a position to do so.
There were other implausibilities and contradictions.
For example, he wrote in his narrative that he was attacked by four armed men
who fled when they heard gun shots from not too far away. But the police certificate he produced mentions his being attacked by five men and his being helped by two security guards who fired in the air twice to stop more beating.
Similarly, the claimant wrote in his narrative that his father was beaten and took a taxi home. The claimant then took him to a medical clinic. At his hearing also he repeated that his father was alone when he was beaten. But the police report (C-5) stated that the claimant's father and the claimant were beaten together when they were walking by the Peru Avenue.
Nor did he provide a reasonable answer to why a gynecologist would treat his father when he was beaten. He stated that the gynecologist was his mother's doctor and also his family doctor.
These relatively minor contradictions and implausibilities aside, the claimant's testimony is totally at variance with the documentary evidence on Peru. The claimant testified that he did not know if his father is still wanted but that the military people who were in power during the former government are still in control of the country. The documentary evidence makes it very clear that this is just not so.
I find the claimant's testimony unreliable and not trustworthy and not supported by the documentary evidence. I do not believe that he and his father were beaten and that the Fujimori supporters are seeking to kill them.
Conclusion
For all these reasons, I find that XXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee. There is no more than a mere possibility of his facing persecution in his country on a Convention ground. For the same reason, I find that there is no more than a mere possibility that the claimant would be subjected to a risk to his life, or to a risk of cruel and unusual punishment or to a danger of torture in his country.
I therefore reject his claim.
"Azhar Ali Khan"
Azhar Ali Khan
