These are the reasons for decision in the claim for protection made by XXXXXXXX,
a citizen of Cambodia. The claimant is a thirty-year-old male who claims a well-founded fear of persecution in Cambodia, at the hands of the Cambodian government or individual workers defrauded by the claimant's employer, on the grounds of membership in a particular social group and political opinion. The claimant further claims to be a person in need of protection because he would be subjected personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or to a danger of torture in Cambodia.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that he was recruited and subsequently employed for a company XXXX, run by a XXXX national XXXXXXXX. This venture in partnership with XXXX a Cambodian XXXXX agency, with high level connections to the Cambodian Senate, was allegedly recruiting over 1000 Cambodian workers to work in XXXXX projects overseas including the XXXXXXXXX. The whole thing turned out to be a fraud for which XXXXXXXX is now under indictment in XXXXX. The scheme saw the 1000 and more Cambodians paying approximately $1000 for the privilege of being chosen to work and for their travel and medical documents to be issued, but no one ever left Cambodia to work. It appears that XXXXXXXX had also been involved in a similar scheme in Indonesia and Thailand.
The claimant asserts that he and another Cambodian who is also a refugee claimant were brought to Canada with XXXXXXXX to finish paperwork that they had been involved with in Cambodia. Once here they were treated like prisoners by him and forced to make calls to officials in Cambodia on his behalf. When they realised that there was a fraud they escaped from where they were being kept in Montreal and made their way to Ottawa and made their refugee claims.
The claimant was hired as an administrator and was the interface in Cambodia between the company and the workers who had been selected for the project, meeting with groups of them on several occasions to prepare their applications, medical forms and other administrative matters.
The claimant fears that he will be arrested on return to Cambodia as he and the other colleague are the only two people involved in working for XXXX who left the country with
XXXXXXXX. The Cambodian workers are demanding their money back and the Cambodian government is slowly beginning to partly compensate some of them. The claimant fears that he will be charged for being part of the fraud and used as a scapegoat because he does not have any powerful government connections unlike some other Cambodians who were hired by XXXX. The claimant believes that he would not get a fair trial, have no legal representation as he has no money, and would face torture to force a confession.
He further fears that the publicity about them having "escaped" while in Canada that has been in the papers in Cambodia will result in the workers in Cambodia believing that they were part of the fraud along with XXXXXXXX. He believes that these workers have been so hurt financially and are so frustrated about corruption in Cambodia that they will want to extract revenge and that the claimant and his colleague are the perfect scapegoats. The Cambodian government would have no interest or ability to protect the claimant from this vigilante behaviour and as these workers come from all over Cambodia, there would be nowhere in the country that he could find safety.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant's personal identity and as a national of Cambodia are established by his testimony and by the credible identity and education documents presented in support of his assertions.
Credibility
The claimant was a credible witness and provided credible evidence in support of the allegations of his claim. The panel believes that the claimant knew nothing of the actual intentions of XXXXXXXX and actually believed that he was involved in working for a legitimate organization and purpose. No evidence was presented of any criminal charges in Cambodia or elsewhere against the claimant to this date because of his employment at XXXX.
The claimant testified in a straightforward manner, and there were no material inconsistencies or contradictions between his testimony and other evidence before the panel. Further the panel heard the two claims separately to test credibility and found that each of them corroborated the evidence of the other, without the panel believing it had been significantly contrived between them.
Reason for Harm: Nexus
The panel has considered whether the claimant is a Convention refugee. For the claimant to be a Convention refugee, his fear of persecution must be by reason of one of the five enumerated grounds. There was no evidence to assert a claim based on race, religion or nationality. The panel has considered whether political opinion or membership in a particular social group applies. The claimant was never involved in any activities which could have been described or perceived to be political in nature. In examining the perceptions of the agents of persecution, the panel finds that regarding the 1000 or so defrauded workers, any motivation to harm the claimant would be as a consequence of seeking revenge and thus is not imputing a political opinion to the claimant. Regarding the state as the agent of persecution, the motivation of the government to prosecute the claimant would be to prosecute those they believe to be guilty of fraud and is in no way ascribing a political opinion or motive to the claimant.
The panel in assessing what the particular social group is that the claimant belongs to has referred to the Supreme Court of Canada's decision in Ward. The panel finds that the claimant could be described as a member of a group who is falsely accused of a crime and does not have political connections or financial resources in Cambodia. In examining the three categories defined in Ward, the panel finds that the group as defined does not constitute a particular social group.
The panel therefore finds there to be no nexus to a Convention ground, and therefore finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.
Risk to Life or Risk of Cruel and Unusual Treatment or Punishment
The claimant alleges that if returned to Cambodia he will be at risk of being killed by any one of the more than 1000 workers who were defrauded of a considerable sum of money and who have yet to have full compensation from the company involved or the government which, through its connected consulting company XXXX, is held to be partly responsible. These workers have held violent demonstrations that have been reported in the press.
Each one of these workers met on numerous occasions with the claimant to prepare all the papers necessary for them to leave Cambodia to work. They had paid more than $1000 for the privilege of being chosen and had to incur numerous other expenses such as living in the capital while all the paperwork was done. The claimant was known to be XXXXXXXX "right hand" as he also used the claimant as translator with the workers. Each one of these workers knew that the claimant and his colleague were the two coming to Canada to finalise the paperwork and they learned in a newspaper article that the two of them "ran away" when the fraud finally came to light.
The documentary evidence reveals that mob violence in Cambodia is commonplace. There are reports that ordinary citizens take drastic action when they believe someone has engaged in criminal activity. In the U.S. Department of State Report on Human Rights Practices in Cambodia for 2001 it states:
"Police and military continue to acquiesce in or fail to prevent mob violence against suspected criminals, which resulted in dozens of killings, although the number of such killings was lower than in previous years. In April a mob overpowered police and beat two alleged robbers in police custody to death. The Government never has prosecuted anyone for participation in such cases of mob violence."
The claimant fears that any one of these workers individually would hold the claimant responsible for the losses they incurred and would want to kill the claimant. Given the documentary evidence showing the behaviour of the public to those they regard as criminals, and the reports about demonstrations already held by the workers, the panel finds that there is a serious possibility of a risk to the claimant's life from any one of these defrauded workers.
These workers were recruited from all over Cambodia and the claimant asserts that he would be instantly recognizable to any one of them because of the frequent contact he had with them and because of the nature of the contact. The panel accepts the claimant's assertion that there is a serious possibility of a risk to his life and that it extends throughout Cambodia, because the workers came from all over the country. There is no documentary evidence to establish that the attitude to criminal activity is different in any part of Cambodia. I further find because of all the circumstances of this case and the publicity it has received that the risk of harm faced by the claimant is not one faced generally by others in Cambodia.
I have considered the standard of proof to be applied in assessing the risk of harm under section 97(1)(b). In my opinion, the test is whether the claimant faces a reasonable chance or serious possibility of a risk to his life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. The Act is silent as to the appropriate standard of proof to be used in applying section 97(1)(b) and it seems logical that it should be consistent with the standard of proof for establishing a well-founded fear of persecution under the Convention. Both the Convention ground and this ground deal with a prospective risk of serious human rights violations and the harm contemplated under section 97(1)(b) is no less serious than the harm to be protected against under the Convention. Therefore, a claimant should not have to establish the prospective risk to a higher degree of certainty than under the Convention.
It is worth noting that the CIC Guidelines issued for Post-Determination Refugee Claimants in Canada (PDRCC) reviews, the precursor of the section 97(1)(b) provisions, set the standard of proof at "less than a clear probability, or even a balance of probabilities, but greater than a mere possibility."1 In addition, there is a compelling argument that the standard of proof should be consistent among the three grounds as all grounds deal with a prospective fear of human rights violations. In fact, the U.K. Immigration Appeal Tribunal in Kacaj2 noted that the various expressions used in reference to the legal test for asylum cases, namely "reasonable chance," "substantial grounds for thinking" and "serious possibility", were taken to refer to the same degree of risk as a "real risk." In addition, it noted the practical difficulty of applying two legal tests to the same set of facts in a given hearing. I am of the opinion, therefore, that the standard of proof as set out in Adjei3 and as applied to the Convention refugee definition is the standard that should be applied under section 97(1)(b) and I have applied that standard to the facts of this case as follows.
I find there is a serious possibility that the claimant would be subjected personally to a risk to his life should he return to Cambodia for the above-mentioned reasons. In the documentary evidence it is clear given the impotence of the police in the face of mob action, that the state would be unable or unwilling to protect the claimant. Further I find that there is no Internal Flight Alternative for the claimant given that the workers the claimant fears are from all parts of Cambodia and the inability or the unwillingness of the state to provide adequate protection extends to the entire territory of Cambodia.
The panel finds that the risk faced by the claimant is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, nor is it due to inadequate health or medical care.
Danger of Torture
The claimant fears that there is more than a mere possibility of being arrested for the involvement in the scheme to defraud the 1000 or so workers in Cambodia. The Cambodian government wants to have someone to blame for the fact that they are being pressured to pay compensation when they had no involvement. The claimant believes that there is more than a mere possibility of torture as the Cambodian government is widely reported to be a state that allows its police to routinely torture prisoners to obtain confessions. Given the high public profile of the fraud he was caught up in, the claimant believes that he will be subjected to torture in order to extract a confession of complicity in order that the Cambodian government can mollify the disgruntled workers and demonstrate that they have done something.
The issue is whether the alleged harm meets the definition of torture in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture (CAT).
The documentary evidence from the U.S. Department of State Report on Human Rights Practices for 2001 and Amnesty International report that the Cambodian police routinely torture criminal suspects in order to extract confessions.
The U.S. Report states under the section on Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment:
"The Constitution prohibits torture and physical abuse of prisoners; however, torture, beatings, and other forms of physical mistreatment of persons held in police or military custody continued to be a serious problem throughout the country. There were credible reports that military and police officials used physical and psychological torture and severely beat criminal detainees,
particularly during interrogation. The problem was compounded by a climate of impunity, whereby police and security force perpetrators of torture and abuse frequently were protected from prosecution or disciplinary action by local government authorities, despite some central government efforts to curtail or eliminate violations of prisoners' rights and to address problems of accountability.
During the year, the Ministry of Interior was slow to investigate allegations by the UNHCHR of torture and severe abuse of individuals in detention in various parts of the country, including one case in July in Prey Veng province when police beat a prisoner to death. However, provincial prosecutors filed preliminary charges against prison officials in Kampong Cham province for alleged mistreatment of prisoners following an escape attempt in 1999."
The panel finds this documentary evidence from reliable human rights organizations familiar with the meaning of torture in Article 1 of CAT to be persuasive.
The judiciary is not independent, they are poorly trained and compensated, many are not lawyers, and they routinely take money for favourable verdicts. These facts are reported by a number of independent human rights organizations and are regarded by the panel as credible. There is no opposing information to balance.
The panel finds that the claimant has a profile in the whole affair by having accompanied, to Canada, the chief suspect in the fraud and then escaping and making a refugee claim. The documentary evidence reveals extensive corruption and political interference in the Cambodian judicial system. The panel finds that the claimant has established on a balance of probabilities that he would be charged with involvement in the fraud if returned to Cambodia.
Others who worked for XXXX have political connections and have been able to avoid any blame. The highest-ranking person in the XXXX has been fired but given his political connections with the Cambodian Senate he has so far avoided prosecution. The claimant is without any political connections to avoid being held responsible and without money to get proper legal
representation. He and his colleague were the only two Cambodians connected with the fraud to go out of the country with XXXXXXXX. In these circumstances, the panel finds that the claimant has established on a balance of probabilities that he will be used as a scapegoat and arrested and charged for participation in the fraud. Given the documentary evidence the panel finds that there is a serious possibility that the claimant would be personally subjected to acts by which severe pain or suffering would be inflicted by officers of the state in order to extract a false confession.
As the state is one of the agents of persecution, it is clear that state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming. On the evidence contained in the documentary evidence, it is clear that there exist substantial grounds to believe that the claimant would be subjected to torture throughout the territory of Cambodia.
I have considered the issue of the standard of proof expressed by the phrase "a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture" in section 97(1)(a). Is the risk to be assessed on a standard of reasonable chance or serious possibility or on a higher standard? In my opinion, the claimant is not required to establish that it is more probable than not that he would be tortured but rather that there is a serious possibility that he would face torture. I reach this conclusion mainly for two reasons:
1. It is consistent to apply the same standard of proof as in refugee claims since the risk being assessed is also prospective;4 and
2. It is illogical to think that a person would be entitled to the lesser standard of "serious possibility" for a risk of persecution but not for the risk of the aggravated form of harm encompassed by torture.
My view is supported by the approach taken in Canadian and international jurisprudence on this issue.5 The U.N. Committee against Torture and the European Court of Human Rights ("ECHR") have expressed the test of "substantial grounds to believe" as being whether the individual would be exposed to a real risk of suffering ill-treatment. In the case of Kacaj,6 the U.K. Immigration Appeal Tribunal discussed the standard of proof in Article 3 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("European Convention")7 and found that the test formulated by the ECHR is no different from the test applicable to Refugee Convention cases. The various expressions used in reference to the legal test for asylum cases, namely "reasonable chance", "substantial grounds for thinking" and "serious possibility" were taken to refer to the same degree of risk as a "real risk". The tribunal was of the view that it would be surprising to use different legal tests as both the Refugee Convention and the European Convention are concerned with whether future ill-treatment would amount to a breach of an individual's rights. In addition, it noted the practical difficulty of applying two legal tests to the same set of facts in a given hearing.
In my view, similar reasoning may be relied upon in determining the legal test applicable to claims based on a danger of torture under section 97(1)(a) of the Act. In Suresh,8 the Supreme Court of Canada, while not directly addressing the standard of proof issue, concludes that where there is a "serious or substantial risk of torture" or "substantial grounds to believe he or she would be tortured on return", deportation to torture would generally be contrary to section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The expressions "serious or substantial risk" and "real risk" are not significantly different from the expressions "good grounds", "serious possibility" and "reasonable chance" used in Adjei,9 in the context of the Convention refugee definition. In Adjei, the Federal Court of Appeal indicated that "good grounds", "serious possibility" and "reasonable chance" connote more than a mere possibility and less than balance of probabilities. In addition, the French version of "substantial grounds to believe" in section 97(1)(a), "motifs sérieux de le croire" is similar to the expression for the legal test for grounds of inadmissibility in section 33 of the Act (formerly found in section 19 of the Immigration Act10), namely "motifs raisonnables de croire". The legal test "reasonable grounds to believe" in section 19 of the Immigration Act was interpreted as referring to "less than the balance of probabilities".11 Similarly, Section F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention12 contains the expression "serious reasons for considering" which has been interpreted to refer to "less than the balance of probabilities".13 Bearing in mind the objectives set out in the Act with respect to refugees, I do not believe that Parliament intended to make access to protection more difficult for those risking torture than for those risking persecution. In fact, allegations of future ill treatment may meet, within the same claim, the definition of torture by virtue of Article 1 of the CAT and the definition of Convention refugee in section 96 of the Act. Setting the legal test at a standard higher than that applicable in Convention refugee definition claims would result in refusing protection to persons who nevertheless face a serious possibility of torture. Consequently, I am of the opinion that "substantial grounds to believe" refers to a standard of serious possibility of torture and have applied this standard to the facts of this case.
I find that there are substantial grounds for believing that the claimant would be subjected personally to a danger of torture should he return to Cambodia for the following reasons. The Cambodian government is under considerable pressure from all the defrauded workers to provide
compensation and punish those responsible. The claimant's profile with all the workers was significant in that he was seen to be coming to Canada to finalise everything and had been involved in all the details of their selection from the beginning. The claimant remaining in Canada was portrayed in the Cambodian newspapers as "running away" when the fraud came to light. The claimant has no financial resources to pay bribes to defend himself and the judiciary is reported in the documentary evidence to be widely corrupt. The documentary evidence further establishes the routine use of torture by the police to extract confessions before trial. The panel finds that the danger of being subjected to torture as an innocent person to extract a confession does not arise from a lawful sanction and is not inherent to or incidental to a lawful sanction. That danger would rather arise from the widespread recourse by officers of the state to torture detainees as a means of extracting confessions or punishment.
For the foregoing reasons, I find that the claimant XXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection and I therefore accept his claim.
"Eunice Harker"

These are the reasons for decision in the claim for refugee protection of
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Poland. The claimant is a 48-year-old male, who claims a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland on the ground of his race, namely his ethnicity as half Roma.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant asserts that his mother is Roma and his father is Polish and that as they lived in a small village everyone knew them as a Roma family. The claimant speaks almost no Roma, as the language at home and at school was Polish. The claimant asserts that he was perceived to be Roma also because when he was growing up his two best friends were Roma. In addition he was known to be Roma, as his maternal grandparents lived very close to them and he visited with them regularly.
The claimant asserted that he had trouble remembering dates. His PIF narrative was not chronologically constructed and was vague about dates. His PIF details several incidents where the claimant alleges he was attacked because he was either known to be or perceived to be Roma. In 1980 he was attacked by a group of 5 young people and he was beaten and bruised, but had no broken bones. When his daughter was about 7 years old, she and the claimant were at the entrance to a stairwell, when they were attacked by a group of men. The claimant was pushed down the stairs and his daughter was forced to witness the incident. According to the PIF, the claimant did not report either of these incidents to the police.
The claimant applied for and received a visitor's visa and came to visit his brother in Canada between XXXXX and XXXXX 2001. He made no claim for protection during this visit. The claimant then had to return to Poland because he had learned that his daughter was very sick. The claimant asserts that on his return to Poland he was again the victim of an assault by two middle-aged Polish people. They kicked, beat and hit the claimant with a hard rubber instrument, resulting in the need for medical treatment for cuts to his face and back. The claimant reported this incident to the police and was told that they would try to get to the bottom of the incident, but that nothing ultimately came of it.
The claimant asserts that these are only a few examples of what was a lifetime of experiences of being pushed, called names and spat at. He further asserts that his apartment was broken into and the windows of their apartment were broken, but that he had great difficulty remembering dates of these incidents.
The claimant decided that he could no longer live with the constant fear that he might be killed and decided he had to leave Poland after the incident that occurred in XXXXXXX 2001. The claimant used the services of a smuggler and traveled to Canada on a false passport, travelling through Holland and arriving in Canada in January 2002.
ANALYSIS
Identity - Personal and Citizenship
The claimant had used a genuine Polish passport to travel to Canada in XXXXX 2001 but he claims to have given this genuine passport to a smuggler in exchange for a false German passport used to travel to Canada in 2002. He therefore could not produce his Polish passport in support of his identity. He provided the original birth certificates for himself and his wife, and their marriage certificate. The panel therefore accepts that the claimant has established his personal and his citizenship identity.
Identity as Roma
In support of his assertion that he is perceived to be Roma, the claimant's evidence was that he came from a very small village and he was known to be Roma because they knew his mother as Roma. He frequently visited her parents who lived very close to them and were known to be Roma and he also associated with two close friends who were Roma. The claimant provided no independent evidence regarding his identity as a Roma.
In order to successfully base a claim on one's Roma ethnicity, the claimant is required to establish on a balance of probabilities that he is Roma or perceived to be Roma. There was no testing of the claimant's knowledge of the Romani language as the claimant stated that he spoke almost none as his father was Polish and the language he learned at home was Polish. He even spoke only Polish with his two best friends that were Roma.
The issue of speaking the Romani language is an important indicator in determining whether the claimant has established his Roma identity, in light of the documentary evidence that upwards of 90% of Polish Roma speak Romanes. While this is not the only determinative factor, the panel has considered this evidence in light of other factors considered.
The claimant asserted that him having darker skin would cause people to perceive him as a Roma. The panel noted that the claimant's skin was not observably dark. He asserted that his mother looked Roma and that he had problems when he was doing his compulsory military service because she attended a ceremony and people saw she was Roma.
The claimant provided no independent evidence in support of his assertion of his identity as half Roma. He presented no family photographs or affidavit evidence or any witnesses. Given that he was able to get documentary evidence from Poland to present at the hearing, the panel draws a negative inference from the fact that he produced no family photographs of his mother. Again, on its own this would not be the only determinative factor, but considered in light of the lack of ability in the language and other factors mentioned below, the panel finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient evidence to establish on a balance of probabilities that he is perceived as Roma.
The claimant asserted that there were no frictions that he observed or knew of between his mother's family and his father's family. The panel does not find this to be credible evidence in light of documentary evidence that mixed marriage is very rare and not easily accepted by either side but most specifically the Polish side. Acceptance of the Roma culture by a Polish family is highly unusual. The claimant asserted that this was not so in his case.
Regarding knowledge of cultural practices or customs, this is another of a number of factors which is important in establishing ethnicity. The only evidence the claimant provided was his assertion that he liked to be with Roma people because he always felt more comfortable with them as "there was nothing that was not said" and "that it was more peaceful". The panel does not find this to be sufficient evidence to establish any knowledge of Roma customs or traditions.
The claimant had 14 years of school and technical training. He was continuously employed in Poland in a skilled occupation as a XXXXX. Such a level of education and a skilled occupation resulting in continuous employment is not typical of Polish Roma according to the documentary evidence. Unemployment amongst Roma is disproportionately high in Poland and education is an area of huge difficulty resulting in the majority of Roma children attending school for only a very few years. The panel finds that the claimant's educational background and his language skills suggest that he is highly integrated into Polish society and not credible evidence of his Roma ethnicity.
The claimant stated that he came from a very small village and he was perceived to be Roma because he and his family were known. When asked about the population of this very small village, the claimant stated that it was about 50,000 people. A population of 50,000 is a significant size by Polish standards. The claimant did not assert that he had any significant profile in his town other than being a member of one of about 50 Roma families. Given no particular public profile, it seems unreasonable to believe that the claimant would be known throughout his town of 50,000 people. The panel finds that the claimant's evidence that he lived in a very small village to be deliberately misleading and exaggerated, and not credible.
Exhibit C-12 which is a translation in English of Exhibit C-7 regarding alleged injuries to the claimant after an attack does not mention the claimant's ethnicity and therefore the panel gives it no weight in regards to the claimant's ethnicity or perceived ethnicity.
I find the claimant's evidence regarding language and education to support a high level of assimilation, and he does not exhibit any specific physical characteristics that would lead people to perceive him to be Roma. He does not dress differently than any other Polish male. His wife is Polish. I draw an adverse inference from the lack of family photographs and find that the claimant's allegations about his colour of skin and being perceived to be Roma because he associates with Roma people to be insufficient. In considering all of the above, I find the claimant has failed to provide sufficient evidence to establish on a balance of probabilities his ethnicity as part Roma or that he would be perceived to be Roma.
Delay in making claim
The claimant did not make his refugee claim during a 4 month visit to Canada in 2001 despite asserting that he had experienced a lifetime of insults, harassment and violence. When questioned about his state of mind and his intentions when he left Poland at this time, the claimant was very hesitant in the manner in which he gave his evidence. He stated that his intention was to go back to Poland and that he came to see what it was like in Canada. When asked was he not afraid to return given his experiences in Poland, his evidence was that he was afraid, but that he had had to return because his daughter got sick. His PIF states that he did not make a claim at this time as he did not know about the refugee process. He further stated that he returned to help his wife because his daughter was sick. The sickness turned out to be no more serious than a viral infection that responded to treatment. His PIF does state however "I had been afraid most of my life".
The panel finds the claimant's evidence about his intentions when he left Poland for the first time to be deliberately obtuse. The claimant did not satisfactorily explain the contradictions in his evidence as to whether his intention was to find out about protection or to go back. Nor did he satisfactorily explain why if he had been afraid for most of his life why he would not make a claim immediately on arrival. The panel therefore finds the evidence in this regard not to be credible.
A lack of knowledge about the refugee process is not a credible reason for the claimant not seeking protection on arrival. I find the claimant's evidence regarding his motivation for leaving Poland or re-availing himself of the protection of Poland not to be credible and that it is evidence inconsistent with a subjective fear.
The claimant was able to get a Canadian visitor visa in 2001 by applying to the embassy in Poland. The claimant stated that he did not apply a second time after his return in 2001 because he was told by phone by an official that they did not know how long it would take and whether he would get one. The claimant chose to give a smuggler $5,000 and his Polish passport and risk the vagaries of travelling with a false passport rather than make a second visa application and wait to see if it was granted. The claimant did not make his claim on arrival at the airport, rather he traveled to Ottawa and made his claim there. The claimant has no proof therefore that he actually returned to Poland or that he arrived in Canada on the day he alleges.
The panel acknowledges that people in genuine fear and with no legitimate way to leave their country often have to take desperate measures. The panel is not persuaded that this is the case of this claimant. He was able to leave his country legitimately and come to Canada. He did not make a claim for protection. Thus he has not demonstrated behaviour consistent with a subjective fear. Further, the panel finds that the claimant had a reasonable expectation of getting a legitimate visa to visit Canada given that he had already obtained one and demonstrated good faith by returning to Poland. Instead he deliberately decided to engage in expensive, risky, illegal behaviour and has deliberately ensured that his entry into Canada is not verifiable by not making his claim on arrival. I find the claimant's evidence in this regard to be inherently suspect and therefore not credible.
The panel notes that there are additional credibility problems regarding the period the claimant asserts he returned to Poland. The claimant presented a police report1 that was ostensibly relating to an incident detailed in his PIF in XXXXXX 2001, almost as soon as he had arrived back in Poland. On examination of the document and the translation it appears that the police report was relating to an incident that took place on XXXX.2001. Based on an examination of this and another police report, all dates are given using the format of day, month and year. This suggests that this report relates to an incident that took place when the claimant was in Canada.
The claimant's evidence was that the report relates to the incident when he was allegedly attacked by two middle-aged people, and that he himself made the report to the police. When confronted by the contradictory evidence the claimant had no satisfactory explanation.
The panel therefore finds it not to be credible that the claimant was attacked in
XXXXXX 2001 and further finds the police report to have no probative value. Exhibit C-6 is a police report relating to a break-in at the claimant's apartment; however, given the lack of trustworthiness of C-5 the panel finds that it cannot rely on C-6 as it was also provided by the claimant's wife at the claimant's request and find it to be self-serving.
The claimant asserted that the most significant incident that happened to him was the occasion when he was pushed down the stairs and his daughter had to watch. The claimant had to be significantly assisted by counsel's leading questions when describing when this incident occurred. At one point in his testimony he was not sure if it was before he came to Canada or not and was only clear about this when counsel indicated that his PIF stated it was when his daughter was seven.
The panel draws an adverse inference regarding credibility from the claimant's hesitant responses regarding this incident. The claimant did not report this incident to the police even though he asserted that it was the most serious because of how it upset his daughter. His explanation for not doing so was that there was no point.
He asserts that he reported an attack on himself in 2001 and he presented a report that allegedly shows that he reported a break-in and theft at his apartment. If his daughter had been traumatized, it would seem reasonable to believe that the claimant would have regarded this as serious as a theft of a television or an assault on himself when he was on his own. The panel did not find this to be credible.
The claimant presented a sworn affidavit2 from a friend who is a nurse. In this statement, she indicates that she dressed the wounds after the claimant was attacked. The panel has already made a finding regarding the 2001 assault and found it not to be credible as it appears that it occurred while the claimant was still in Canada. The panel gives no probative value to the evidence in C-12 from the claimant's friend as it is not only self-serving, but it is inherently suspect.
When considering all of the above credibility concerns together, the panel concludes that the claimant's testimony was not credible and trustworthy and that there was insufficient credible evidence to establish on a balance of probabilities that he is part Roma or that he is perceived to be Roma in Poland. And the panel finds insufficient credible evidence of a subjective fear. His claim to refugee status therefore fails.
DETERMINATION
For all these reasons, I find XXXXXXXXXXXXXX not to be a Convention refugee as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Poland. I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Poland would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to Poland will subject him personally to a danger of torture. I therefore reject his claim.

The claimant alleged that his mother was Roma and his father Polish, that he was perceived to be Roma and that he was subjected to physical attacks throughout his life. He provided no independent evidence of his Romani identity. He had almost no knowledge of the Romani language. According to the documentary evidence, upwards of 90% of Polish Roma speak Romanes. He did not look Roma. An adverse inference was drawn from his failure to produce any photographs of his mother. The claimant failed to establish on a balance of probabilities that he was perceived as Roma. His claim that there was no friction between his parents' families was inconsistent with the documentary evidence that mixed marriages are very rare and not easily accepted by either side. The fact that the claimant had 14 years of schooling and worked in a skilled occupation was not typical of Polish Roma and suggested that he was highly integrated into Polish society. There was no credible evidence that the claimant was ever attacked. The claimant's failure to make a refugee claim during a four-month visit to Canada in 2001, and his reavailment of the protection of Poland, were inconsistent with a subjective fear of persecution. XXXXXXXXX and her daughters, XXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXX, aged 31, 2 and 8 respectively, are all citizens of Azerbaijan. They allegedly left their country on XXXX, 2001, stayed in Russia for two days and in the United States for one day, and finally arrived in Canada on February X, 2001. They are claiming refugee protection in Canada, stating that they have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of their nationality, religion and political opinion and that they are persons in need of protection because they would be subject to a danger of torture, to a risk to their lives or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
In support of their claims for refugee protection, the principal claimant alleged the following, and her two daughters are basing their claims on hers.
The principal claimant comes from a mixed Azeri-Russian family and, although she is Orthodox, she married a Muslim.
In XXX 1995, she lost her father, who was a XXXX of non-violence and who died after being beaten by nationalists in Baku.
In addition, she obtained a divorce from her Muslim husband, with whom she had violent discussions regarding their differing opinions on the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. She was even beaten on a number of occasions.
She worked in the non-violence organization, and at the New Year's Eve party, nationalists attacked disabled individuals and beat the claimant.
The nationalists then attacked and beat the claimant again. At XXXX in 1999, they vandalized the claimant's apartment and a number of other apartments, and they destroyed the Christ monument on two occasions in 1999.
The claimant was married on XXXX, 1999.
In 2000, the claimant's church was attacked by the nationalists. Complaints were filed but were unsuccessful. In XXXXX 2000, the claimant, then pregnant, was arrested by the police and detained for 24 hours.
On XXXX, 2000, the claimant gave birth to her daughter XXXX.
On XXXX, 2000, the claimant's brother was killed in the army.
On XXXX, the claimant was again arrested, beaten and humiliated. This lasted for 24 hours.
The claimant decided to flee to Russia. However, on XXX, she was attacked and beaten by five skinheads, and later, she was again beaten by Russian nationalists. She did not remain there long, as she was unable to obtain either employment or a propiska.
Back in Azerbaijan, in XX 2000, she was humiliated by Azeris, arrested, hit in the stomach and threatened by the police with imprisonment. In XXX, the claimant's daughter was beaten by students, as was the claimant, who was beaten in XXXX XXXXX XXXX 2000 and received threatening telephone calls.
On XXXX, 2000, she lost her son, who was attacked by five nationalists.
On XXXXX, 2000, her brother's apartment was attacked by nationalists and on that occasion, the claimant's nephew lost his life.
The claimant then worked as a waitress and sold her property in order to obtain a visa for the United States.
It is important to note that the principal claimant has been designated as the representative of her two minor daughters for the purpose of their claims.
ANALYSIS
Identity
In order to establish her identity, the claimant filed the following exhibits:
P-4: claimant's birth certificate
P-5: baptismal certificate
P-15: divorce certificate
P-13: birth certificate for XXXXX
P-6: baptismal certificate for XXXXX
P-16: adoption certificate for XXXXX
P-14: birth certificate for XXXX
P-7: baptismal certificate for XXXX
The panel is therefore satisfied that the claimants have established their identities.
CREDIBILITY
The claimant testified at length regarding the facts that led her to leave her country. The panel found no implausibilities or contradictions between her port of entry documents, her narrative in response to question 37 on her Personal Information Form (PIF) and her testimony.
Among other things, the panel asked her to explain why XXXXX last name is that of the claimant's last husband even though the claimant's first husband is XXXXX father. The claimant explained that her last husband had adopted XXXXX and, as agreed, she later provided the panel with the adoption certificate.
In addition, the panel found that the claimant provided satisfactory explanations concerning the absence of a medical report and a copy of the complaint to the police. The panel was also satisfied with the reasons she gave for taking some time to depart.
The panel therefore finds the claimant credible. Her testimony was spontaneous and direct and she did not exaggerate the events, although there might have been reasons for doing so.
WELL-FOUNDED FEAR
Since the panel found the claimant to be credible, it accepts the facts as alleged in her response to question 37 on her PIF.
Because the claimant speaks primarily Russian although she was born in Azerbaijan, and because she is Christian, she has experienced several tragedies in recent years.
In 1995, the claimant lost her father, who was killed by Azeri-Muslim nationalists because, as XXXXX of a Christian non-violence association, he supported a peaceful resolution of the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict.
Further, the claimant's first marriage was also dissolved because her husband was Muslim.
She was attacked on a number of occasions during demonstrations by her association to protest organized violence.
The claimant's two daughters were also attacked and harassed because of their nationality.
The nationalists attacked the claimant's house on XXXXX, 2000, and during this attack, her son XXXX lost his life.
In addition, the claimant's nephew was killed by nationalists during an attack in XXXXX 2000.
The panel finds that all the tragedies experienced by the claimant are equivalent to persecution.
Moreover, although the documentation does not detail situations similar to those experienced by the claimant, the fact remains that in Azerbaijan, as in the other countries of the former USSR, there was a time when the Russians dominated. Following the dismantlement, Russians and Azeris of Russian origin fled the country and now represent only 1.8% of the population. Acts of vengeance and nationalism continue to occur.
1- A-17 Amnesty International Report 2002, page 1: "Demonstrators and political activists were detained. Allegation of torture and ill-treatment in prison. Correspondents from Russian and Turkish television channels were assaulted..."
The document also states that there is no independent mechanism to investigate complaints against the police.
2- A-18 International Helsinki Federation Report 2002: On page 42, the report describes problems with demonstrations, stating that those trying to demonstrate are immediately prevented from doing so and are often imprisoned. On page 43, the report mentions an engineer who was arrested because he was unable to produce identification and who died in prison; the police officer even tried to obtain a bribe from the man's wife in return for her husband's release.
Even more serious, on page 44, the report states that violations of the rule of law occur even in things that are under the president's personal control.
With respect to charity organizations, the report states on page 45 that in December 2001, the Minister of Justice prohibited the registration of a number of such organizations. This is an example of religious intolerance.
That being said, the panel concludes that the claimant and her daughters have established that they have a serious fear of persecution should they return to their country.
CONCLUSION
Therefore, the Division determines that XXXXXXXXX and XXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXX are "Convention refugees" in accordance with section 96 of the Act.1

INTRODUCTION
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a 28-year-old citizen of the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria. He travelled to Canada via Belgium and arrived at Dorval airport on February 5, 2001 and claimed refugee status the same day. He states that he fears being persecuted in his country by reason of imputed political opinion and membership in a particular social group, as he is a former police officer. He is also claiming refugee protection because he believes that he is subject to a danger of torture, to a risk to his life and to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Summary of alleged facts
In XXX 1994, after a four-month period of accelerated training, the claimant was assigned as an officer of public order (AOP) to the police force of XXXXXX, in the XXXX XXXXX. In the beginning, he was assigned to administrative duties that consisted of receiving citizens, taking down their complaints and referring them to various departments.
On XXXXX, 1994, while on supply duty to get food and cigarettes, the claimant and eight of his fellow officers were caught in an ambush set up by a group of armed terrorists. Two police officers were killed, and seven others were wounded. The claimant took three bullets in the back. He therefore convalesced until early 1996, as a victim of terrorism, following a decision made by the director general of the Sûreté nationale [national police force], produced as Exhibit P-6. Following this attack and during his convalescence, the claimant did not receive any threats from the terrorists. During his period of convalescence, he lived with his sisters. His mother had been in Canada since 1993. His father had remarried and lived alone with his new wife.
In XXXXXXX 1996, the claimant went back to work at the same police station, working in personnel management.
On page 2 of his written statement, the claimant said that the draft legislation on civil concord that the new president had introduced had raised much hope of peace. The claimant went on to say that this hope was dispelled. There was a new outbreak of acts of terrorism, of an intensity never seen before, directed equally against civilians and members of the military and police forces.
The claimant stated that if he had to return to Algeria, he fears being killed by the terrorists, or else being imprisoned by the police for abandoning his position. According to the news that had been sent to him, his father had received a document notifying him that the claimant had abandoned his position. This document, which was allegedly in Algeria, was not led in evidence.
These are, in essence, the facts that were brought before the panel by the claimant, who was the only witness in this case.
ANALYSIS
Having heard the testimony and analyzed all the evidence, the panel finds that the claimant is a citizen of Algeria, as he alleges. His identity has been established by means of the original of his driver's licence, his military service card, his national card, and a copy of his passport, the original of which was seized by the Department of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC).
As far as the credibility of the claimant is concerned, the panel accepts that he was a police officer and that he was a victim of a terrorist attack in XXXXX 1994.
However, the panel does not believe that he was a personal target of the terrorists. If that were the case, the terrorists would have threatened him directly and would even have taken steps to attack him, especially since during the entire period of his convalescence, which lasted 18 months (from XXXX 1994 to XXXX 1996), the claimant lived at home, with his sisters. It should be recalled that he testified to the effect that he had not received any threats from the terrorists, either during his convalescence or afterwards.
The claimant was a victim of the attack indicated above at that specific moment because in his capacity as a police officer, he happened to be in a police van that was involved in an operation to supply a police group with food and cigarettes. Consequently, he was not personally targeted.
In the circumstances, the panel does not believe that anyone called the claimant's father about him, first in 1998 to tell the father that his son was a traitor, and again in 2001 after the claimant had left the country, to remind the father that his son had left for Canada. If the terrorists had never approached the claimant to threaten him, the panel does not see why they would have gone through his father to do so. The claimant has added these facts, which were not indicated in his answer to Question 37 of his Personal Information Form (PIF), and concerning which no amendment was made, for the purpose of maximizing the chances of having his claim accepted.
The fact of the matter is that the claimant left his country not because he was the subject of personal threats that were made after the attack and his return to work, but because he found himself alone after his sisters joined their mother in Canada, as he said in his testimony. When he was asked why he had left Algeria, apart from the fact that he was victim of an attack in 1994, he frankly replied: "[TRANSLATION] I left Algeria because I was alone."
Moreover, the panel cannot accept the refugee protection claim simply because the claimant was a police officer and might have been the target of terrorists in the same way as all police officers, due to the very nature of their work. That cannot, and could not, make him a "Convention refugee"1 because the general risks arising from work as a police officer in Algeria, like the attack of XXXXX, 1994, are part of the risks of the occupation.
As far as the claimant's fear of the future is concerned, there is every reason to believe that he can return to his country and live there with complete peace of mind. In the first place, in the seven years following the attack, and until he left for Canada, he did not have problems with any Islamic fundamentalist group whatsoever. Secondly, he was always assigned to administrative duties, which made him an anonymous figure confined to the office. Thirdly, one of his fellow officers, who had also been a victim of the attack, was transferred to office work and is still working as a police officer, has never had any problems with the terrorists, according to the claimant's testimony. In the circumstances, the panel does not see why the claimant would have problems with the terrorists in future, even though he is a former police officer.
It is unlikely that the claimant would have problems with Islamic terrorist groups in future, especially since he was not personally targeted by these individuals and since for the last two years, terrorism has become a strictly rural phenomenon,2 as can be seen from the following statement:
The violence takes place primarily in the countryside and smaller towns as the security forces have largely forced the insurgents out of the cities.
At the conclusion of his testimony, the claimant stated that he feared returning to Algeria because he had abandoned his position as a police officer and a notice to that effect had been sent to his father. This fear is accessory to the principal fear and cannot form the basis for the panel to accept the claim, since any sanction against a police officer who has abandoned his position must be interpreted as a disciplinary action, not as persecution, as can be seen from the documentary evidence:3
Responsibility for maintaining law and order is shared by the Gendarmerie Nationale and the Sûreté Nationale. Members wishing to be discharged must have their resignation approved by a special police commission and leaving the force without authorisation can incur punishments ranging from a fine to imprisonment.
Danger of torture
The panel has no reason to believe that the claimant would be personally subject to the danger of torture. As discussed above, the most he would face for abandoning his position would be the imposition of a fine or a prison sentence.
Risk to life
There is also no serious possibility that the claimant would be subject to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment since the claimant was not personally targeted in the terrorist attack of XXXXX, 1994. In the mind of the terrorists, the attack was not directed towards an individual in particular, but towards members of the police. The victims could have been members of the gendarmerie, or even of the army.
The fact that the claimant was not bothered following this attack is proof that he was not personally targeted. The panel does not see why he would be targeted if he returned to his country, when he was never targeted during the seven years following the attack.
CONCLUSION
For all these reasons, the panel determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is neither a "Convention refugee" nor a "person in need of protection",4 as defined in sections 96 and 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

These are the reasons for decision with respect to the claim for refugee protection made
by XXXXXXXXXXXXX, who alleges to be a Convention refugee, pursuant to section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, in Lebanon, his country of citizenship.
The evidence adduced by the claimant, his lawyer, the refugee protection officer (RPO) [filing of documents] and the representative of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) essentially consists of the claimant's testimony, his Personal Information Form (PIF), personal documents, and documents related to the socio-political situation in Lebanon, i.e., Exhibits A-1 to A-5, P-1 to P-64, and M-1 to M-12.
THE FACTS
The alleged facts can be summarized as follows:
The claimant was born on XXXX, 1962 in Beirut, Lebanon. Before leaving his country, he worked as a XXX merchant.
In 1983 (according to one version of his testimony) or in 1993 (according to another version of his testimony), the claimant met XXXXXXX, a XXXX merchant in the village of Bent Jbeil, who introduced him in February 1998 to XXXXXXXX, a native of South Lebanon. XXXXXXXX proposed to the claimant that he distribute his merchandise and find him new customers in the security zone. The claimant accepted the offer.
During the course of their business meetings, the claimant discussed the situation in Lebanon and the Hezbollah with Mr. XXXX. These discussions began in May 1998. In August 1998, Mr. XXXX, who shared the same negative opinion of this militia group, suggested that the claimant become an informant in return for US$800 per month. The claimant was to give the information to XXXXXXXX, who would pass it on to the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service. The claimant accepted without hesitation.
He worked as an informant from August 1998 to August 1999, during which time he provided XXXXXXXX with information twice a month. Their meetings took place at his place of business in Beirut and also in Jezzine in South Lebanon and in Aroun.
In XXXXXXX 1998, the claimant travelled to Syria to attend the wedding of one of his friends.
The claimant's problems allegedly began in XXXX 1999, with the withdrawal of the South Lebanon Army (SLA) from the Jezzine region.
In XXXXX 1999, at his last meeting with XXXXXXXX, the latter told the claimant that they would be halting their operations, due to Israel's possible withdrawal from South Lebanon.
Fearing for his safety, the claimant decided in XXXXX 2000 to leave Lebanon. He applied for a Canadian visa in XXXX 1999 (according to one version of his testimony) or in XXXX 2000 (according to another version of his testimony).
On May 8, 2000, the claimant left his country legally without any problem. He stopped over in England before arriving in Canada that same day. However, he did not seek the protection of Canadian authorities until December 24, 2000.
While in Canada, he learned that members of the Hezbollah were looking for him and that they had shown up at his place of business and at his home on XXXXX, 1999 (according to one version of his testimony) or on XXXXX, 2000 (according to another version of his testimony and his PIF, question no. 37). His wife told him about this on XXXXXXX, 2000.
Then, on XXXXX, 2000, he read in an article in an Arabic newspaper published in Montreal that XXXXXXXX had turned himself in to security services in Lebanon and provided information concerning the people who had worked as informants under his direction. That is when the claimant decided to approach the Canadian authorities to seek protection.
If he had to return to Lebanon, the claimant says he would suffer, disappear, be imprisoned or be mistreated by both the Hezbollah and by the Syrian and Lebanese intelligence services because he had acted as an informant for the Mossad.
ANALYSIS
After careful consideration of all of the evidence, I find that the claimant is not credible with respect to certain aspects of his claim for refugee protection; I find that his testimony is implausible and contradictory with respect to major elements of his claim for refugee protection. The claimant was confronted with these implausible and contradictory elements, but the explanations he provided could not be considered credible or trustworthy.
For example, at the hearing of September 12, 2002, the claimant testified to the effect that he had known XXXXXXXXX since 1983. He then changed his testimony and said it had been since 1993. He also mentioned that he had submitted a Canadian visa application in XXXX 1999, but then changed his version of the facts and said he had done so in XXXXX 2000.
Moreover, he mentioned that people from the Hezbollah had come to his home in Lebanon on XXXXX, 1999. He confirmed this particular date twice. However, according to his answer to question 37 in his PIF, this visit took place on XXXXX, 2000. When confronted, the claimant only said that the visit had been in 2000. This explanation did not satisfy the panel, and all the changes in the claimant's testimony have merely served to affect his credibility.
The claimant was asked why he had waited seven months before seeking the protection of the Canadian authorities. He indicated that he had come to Canada to see whether economic conditions were good and whether he could live here, and during his stay, he learned that Israel had withdrawn on May 22, 2000. He alleged that on XXXXXXX, 2000, his wife told him that people from the Hezbollah had come to his home and to his place of business four days earlier and asked questions about him. On XXXXX, 2000, he read in a newspaper in Montreal that XXXXXXXX had been arrested by the Hezbollah. After reading that article, he contacted a lawyer in Canada and made a claim for refugee protection. It should be noted that on September 7, 2000, the claimant went to the U.S. Consulate General in Montreal, to obtain a tourist visa, which was denied.
These explanations are not satisfactory. The claimant's behaviour is difficult to reconcile with that of a person who fears for his safety. His course of conduct negates the very existence of a subjective fear of persecution. In short, I am of the opinion that the claimant came to Canada for economic opportunities, which also affects his credibility.
In this case, the Minister had advised the panel of his intention to participate in the hearing and to raise the issue of the claimant's exclusion under Articles 1F(a) and (c) of the Convention.1 However, in making her submissions, the Minister's representative, Me Shahin, only raised Article 1F(a).
Article 1F(a), set out in the schedule to the current legislation, reads as follows:
F. The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes.
Are there "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, has committed crimes against humanity or acted as an accomplice in the commission of such crimes?
A definition of "crimes against humanity" is found in Article 6 of the Charter of the International Military Tribunal, an excerpt of which is set out in the schedule to the Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status (United Nations High Commission for Refugees [UNHCR], Geneva, January 1992):
Crimes against humanity: namely, murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation and other inhumane acts committed against any civilian population, before or during the war; or persecutions on political, racial or religious grounds in execution of or in connection with any crime within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal, whether or not in violation of the domestic law of the country where perpetrated.
Leaders, organisers, instigators and accomplices participating in the formulation or execution of a common plan or conspiracy to commit any of the foregoing crimes are responsible for all acts performed by any persons in execution of such plan.
It is advisable at this point to review certain important facts in this case.
The claimant began working as an informant for the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service, in XXXX 1998. He allegedly provided information through XXXXXXXX on 24 occasions, i.e., twice a month, between XXXX 1998 and XXXXX 1999. The information was provided in person at his place of business in Beirut, Aroun and Jezzine in South Lebanon.
The information the claimant provided had to do with the Hezbollah, the centres they used, their meeting and prayer locations, the health premises, the makes of cars used, the print shops that handled print jobs for the Hezbollah, the names of persons and the offices located in his residential complex and the cooperative they used. He allegedly handed over Hezbollah forms, which contained some 40 names of members of the organization. He was paid US$800 per month for being an informant.
The claimant told us he had accepted this work because of the hatred and resentment he felt for the Hezbollah and that XXXXXXXX had offered this work to him because of the mutual trust that developed between them. He was not forced to accept the work of an informant. Moreover, he allegedly ended the work in XXXXX 1999 on the advice of XXXXXXXX. At that time, no threats were made against him by XXXX or the Mossad.
However, the documentary evidence on the record indicates the links between the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service, and the South Lebanon Army (SLA). The SLA was therefore no more and no less than a pro-Israeli militia armed, trained, financed and controlled by Israel and its secret service [translation]:
Persons who have served in the ranks of the South Lebanon Army (SLA), the pro-Israeli militia (...)2
The SLA, an Israeli backup militia, operated in southern Lebanon, in the zone occupied by the Hebrew State. It was founded, financed and controlled by Israel.3
The Israelis have a direct presence with numerous soldiers and military security agents. Israel uses the SLA to do its "dirty work and thereby claim its innocence before international opinion". The Israeli authorities attempt to have people believe that the SLA is solely responsible for the Khyiam prison when, in fact, the Israelis "work people over" during questioning, perform the administrative duties, etc. The Israeli secret service has offices scattered throughout several areas in the zone. It is on its orders that the SLA arrests and detains Lebanese. On its own, the SLA does not have enough authority to go ahead with prolonged arrests.4
There is no doubt that the information the claimant passed on to the Israeli intelligence service was thus intended for its SLA militia.
The documentary evidence paints a picture of crimes committed by the SLA and Israel, including the displacement of civilians, hostage taking, the destruction of houses, arrests, detention without trial, forced recruitment, homicide, torture and atrocious crimes committed at the Khiam prison in South Lebanon:
"Israel arms and finances the [South Lebanon Army] SLA, and thus bears ultimate responsibility under international humanitarian law for SLA actions in south Lebanon that violate the rights of the civilian population. The expulsions are grave breaches of the Geneva Conventions and, as such, constitute war crimes, Human Rights Watch said in a letter to Prime Minister Barak made public today.
Article 147 of the Fourth Geneva Convention describes unlawful deportation or transfer of civilians as one of the acts that constitute a grave breach of the convention.
'Since 1985, hundreds if not thousands of Lebanese civilians have been ordered to leave their homes and villages without notice and with no means of appeal. They have been summarily dumped in a no man's land without any possessions save the clothes on their backs,' said Hanny Megally, executive director of the Middle East and North Africa division of Human Rights Watch. 'This cruel and illegal dispossession has destroyed the lives of innocent Lebanese families, and it must stop.'
(...)
Human Rights Watch said that Lebanese were expelled from the occupied zone because they refused to cooperate with occupation intelligence forces, because male relatives deserted or refused to join the SLA, and as collective punishment for known or suspected armed attacks by their relatives against Israeli and SLA military forces."5
"Many parties to this conflict have committed serious violations of international humanitarian law. Where evidence exists of such violations, including grave breaches of the Geneva Conventions, or war crimes, legal proceedings should be initiated in domestic courts or in the courts of other countries, and the individuals found responsible should be brought to justice.
(...)
After the withdrawal, thousands of Lebanese families will want to return to their homes and property, including businesses and agricultural land, in the occupied zone, particularly those hundreds of families who were summarily expelled by the SLA. (As of this writing, residents of the zone continue to be forcibly expelled.) Human Rights Watch has documented cases of SLA militiamen and their families living rent-free in the homes of residents who were expelled.
(...)
Some 140 Lebanese men and women are currently being held without charge in Khiam prison in the occupied zone. Some of the detainees have been imprisoned since 1986. This notorious facility, where torture is endemic, is a joint enterprise of Israel and the SLA.
Israeli human rights lawyers have petitioned Israel's Supreme Court for the release of twenty-five Khiam prisoners, arguing that Israel is ultimately responsible for Khiam. Ha'aretz (April 13) has reported the possibility that some of the prisoners will be transferred to Israel, a step which would violate international humanitarian law.
(...)
Human Rights Watch has documented grave breaches of the Geneva Conventions by SLA forces, including torture and expulsion of civilians from the Israeli-occupied zone.
(...)
Israel, as the Occupying Power in the 'security zone,' is ultimately responsible for its own actions as well as those of its local Lebanese military auxiliary, including grave breaches of the Geneva Conventions. Israel directly arms and finances the SLA. In April 1998, the Israeli Ministerial Committee for National Security, in announcing Israel's acceptance of United Nations Security Council Resolution 425 (1978), referred to the occupied zone as 'territories under IDF control.' The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) Liaison Unit to Lebanon, commanded by an Israeli military officer with the rank of brigadier general, reportedly directs Israeli and SLA military activities in the occupied zone."6
"The events in south Lebanon and northern Israel thus far in 1997 have demonstrated, once again, how the military forces involved in this ongoing international armed conflict disregard the laws of war that prohibit attacks on civilians. In particular, indiscriminate attacks and illegal reprisals against civilians by both sides continue the mark the conflict, and put the lives of both Lebanese and Israeli civilians at risk."7
"Khiam Detention Centre, administered by the SLA, is in the area of South Lebanon occupied by Israel. Although Israel denies being involved in the running of the centre, as occupying power it is ultimately responsible for the area. Moreover, such involvement has been affirmed by Israeli soldiers and General Lahad himself.
Detainees in Khiam appear to be held as hostages for Israeli soldiers missing in action or killed."8
"At least 150 other Lebanese nationals are detained in Khiam Detention Centre, run by the South Lebanese Army, a militia allied to Israel in the part of South Lebanon occupied by Israel. Some have been there without charge, trial or any legal status since 1986. Since September 1997 they have had no access to the ICRC."9
"The SLA practice of forced conscription of teenaged boys has been a long-standing nightmare for families that are opposed to the occupation and despise the SLA."10
"Both sides-Israel and its allied Lebanese militia, the South Lebanon Army, on one side, and guerrillas affiliated with Hizballah and a number of small Palestinian factions on the other-have exhibited a willful disregard for international humanitarian law (also known as the laws of war). Both sides have directly targeted civilians and indiscriminately lobbed shells and fired rockets at civilian population centers during various stages of the conflict. Israel, with its superior firepower, has caused by far the most civilian casualties, and the most damage to residential homes and civilian infrastructure."11
[Translation] "Ms. Ibrahim, who was regularly beaten and questioned during her nine months in detention, was never charged with anything. 'It was a real concentration camp, not a prison', she explained. 'In Khiam, none of the international agreements is observed. I did not have the right to a lawyer and I was not tried.'
[Translation] She was only 24 years old when six soldiers of the South Lebanon Army (SLA, a militia allied with Israel) took her prisoner when she was visiting her parents in Rmeich, a village located in the Israeli-occupied territories."12
[Translation] "The war crimes defined in the Geneva Conventions, which were committed in southern Lebanon, include homicide with intent, illegal deportation, hostage taking, torture and inhuman treatment, illegal detention and the deprivation of a protected person of the right to be tried impartially and in accordance with the law. Several hundred Lebanese were systematically tortured and detained in the Khiam Detention Centre, without being tried, for periods of up to 15 years.
(...)
[Translation] "After the occupation of southern Lebanon and the flagrant violations of human rights committed by Israel and the SLA, a message of justice should be conveyed. This type of process is a denial of justice."13
"The Khiyam Prison
The prison and its adjoining area holds hundreds of Lebanese prisoners in very harsh conditions. Reports suggest that torture is routinely practised in the prison.
The Israelis and the South Lebanese Army (SLA) control the prison.
(...)
Recruitment into the Israeli-controlled South Lebanese Army (SLA) is forced. The SLA and Israel exert strong pressure in recruiting individuals and their families into the SLA. Individuals are threatened with forced expulsion from their homes if they do not join the militia."14
[Translation] "Khiam Detention Centre
Following the Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon and the collapse of the SLA, inhabitants in the region entered the Khiam Detention Centre and released the prisoners. The persons unlawfully detained in Khiam were systematically tortured and mistreated for years. There were 144 inmates left, some of whom had been jailed for 14 years without ever having been convicted or sentenced. Among the prisoners were five women, including two, Cosette Ibrahim and Najwa Samhat, who suffered from illnesses brought on by torture and mistreatment and who were hospitalized in March. During the past 15 years, 16 inmates have reportedly died in Khiam as a result of torture."15
During his testimony, the claimant alleged he did not know the purpose of the information he was providing. However, he did know that it was intended for the Israeli intelligence service who }[translation] "worked on it". He did not try to find out what was meant by "working on it", and absolutely nothing happened to the people about whom he provided information. So why was he paid US$800 per month? He answered that he did not know. He did not attempt to find out about the fate that befell members of Hezbollah at the hands of both the SLA and Israel, and as far as the Khiam prison is concerned, he said he had heard the name before; that was all.
The panel finds it implausible that the claimant, who had worked as an informant for the Mossad for one year, was unaware of the ill-treatment of members or suspected members of the Hezbollah by Israel and its militia, the SLA. I also find that it is not credible that he would not know of the treatment suffered by those detained at the notorious Khiam prison. The claimant said he had accepted the work because of the "hate and resentment" he felt for the Hezbollah. Is it plausible then that someone acting with that kind of motivation would not be aware of what was happening with that organization, about which he seemed to have so much information? I think not.
In this conflict in Lebanon, informants played an important role. The claimant was one such informant. I am of the opinion that the claimant has not told the whole truth and that he attempted to downplay his role and knowledge of the crimes committed by the SLA and Israel. He tried to disassociate himself from the acts the SLA and Israel were accused of committing and attempted to deny any knowledge thereof, to evade any charge of wrongdoing. To that end, he testified about his duties within the organization in a vague and evasive manner.
Consequently, I find that there are "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant is complicit by reason of his personal and knowing participation in crimes against humanity committed by Israel (the Israeli Intelligence Service) and its militia, the SLA, and that in accordance with the decisions in Ramirez,16 Sivakumar,17 Moreno18 and Bazargan19, he is excluded under Article 1F(a).
Finally, it should be emphasized that fighting terrorism is a laudable objective, but this must not be done to the detriment or in violation of human rights, charters and laws. Those who attempt to eradicate terrorism and fight terrorists must, in no way, conduct themselves as they do.
DECISION
The panel finds that there are "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant was complicit in crimes against humanity, i.e., the displacement of civilians, hostage taking, the destruction of homes, detention without trial, forced recruitment, homicide and torture. Pursuant to Article 1F(a), he is excluded from the refugee definition.
Consequently, the claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXX, is not a "Convention refugee"20 or a protected person21 under section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
