The refugee claimant, who was an informer for an individual who was providing information to the Mossad, had provided, among other things, the names of some 40 members of the Hezbollah. The information was for the South Lebanon Army (SLA). According to the documentary evidence, the SLA and the Israeli government were responsible for a number of crimes, including civilian displacements, house demolitions, murders, torture as well as heinous crimes committed in Khiam Prison in South Lebanon. The claimant alleged not to be aware of the purpose of the information he was providing, but knew that it was for the Israeli intelligence service. He said he had heard about Khiam Prison but knew no more. The panel found it implausible that the claimant, who had worked as an informer for the Mossad for a year, would not be aware of the abuses inflicted by Israel and the SLA on people suspected of being members of the Hezbollah. In the panel's view, the claimant had attempted to minimize his role in and knowledge of those crimes. The panel was of the opinion that there were (serious reasons for considering( that the claimant had been an accomplice, because of his personal and conscious participation, in crimes against humanity committed by Israel and the SLA. The panel excluded the claimant under Article 1F(a) of the Convention and found that he was neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection. These are the reasons for decision with respect to the refugee claim of XXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXX, their daughter XXXXX XXXXX, who is of age, and their minor children XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXX, who allege that they are "Convention refugees"1 under section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act) by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution in Israel, because of their German origin and the principal claimant's Christian religion, and because of their membership in a particular social group, namely the family. With regard to the daughter XXXXX, she also alleged a fear of persecution by reason of her true or perceived political opinions, for refusing to do her compulsory military service.
XXXXXXXXX was appointed the designated representative of her minor children.
The evidence presented by the claimants, their lawyer and the refugee protection officer (RPO) [filing of documents] mainly consists of testimony by the adult claimants, their Personal Information Form (PIF) and personal documents, as well as documents related to the socio-political and human rights situation in Israel. This information is in exhibits A-1 to A-9 and P-1 to P-6, filed jointly.
Reading the PIFs and the claimants' testimony revealed the following facts.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGED FACTS
XXXXXXXXX was born in Russia, on XXXXXX, 1959, to a German father and a Russian mother. His wife, XXXXXXXXX, was born in Ukraine to Jewish parents, on XXX, 1964. XXXXX XXXXX was also born in Ukraine, on XXXXX, 1983. XXXXX XXXXX was born in Russia, on XXXXX, 1993, and XXXXXXXXXXX was born in Israel, on XXXXXXX, 2000.
The claimants, benefiting from the "Law of Return" by reason of the Jewish origin of XXXXXXXXX, immigrated to Israel in XXXXX 1997. The events alleged by the claimants took place at the beginning of their stay in the kibbutz, in XXXXXX, in XXXXX 1997. Problems arose because of the principal claimant's German origin, because his German name, XXXXX, allegedly bothered people, more specifically older people, who associated it with the Holocaust. They were allegedly victims of insults and threats from the members of the kibbutz and from the children who supposedly attacked XXXXX. The principal claimant allegedly spoke to the police in XXXX 1998, but he did not receive the protection he requested.
Further, because he allegedly did his military service in Afghanistan, from July 1979 to July 1981, the principal claimant was also threatened at the kibbutz by Muslim workers, "Hamas" militants, who accused him of killing Afghan Muslims there. He also allegedly complained to the kibbutz authorities and to the police about this, but no action was taken.
In May 1998, when he was working with an Arab team, a large piece of metal fell on him. An Arab worker allegedly told him that the next time it would not miss his head. These incidents forced him to move to XXX with his family.
There the claimants allegedly continued to have problems with the authorities, neighbours and religious Jews who insulted and threatened them, again because of the principal claimant's German origin. At school and the day care, the girls, XXXXX and XXXXX, were allegedly victims of assault by their schoolmates, on several occasions. Although the principal claimant supposedly spoke to the teacher and the principal, no action was taken. At the Ministry of Education, he was apparently told that he had to change his surname and that he must convert to Judaism, which he refused to do. In July 1999, he allegedly received threats from the Arabs with whom they had had trouble before.
After the claimants moved to XXXXXX in XXXX 1999, the situation remained the same, because once their neighbours and children learned their surname, they became hostile toward them. XXXXX was sexually harassed at the cafe where she worked. Upon complaining about the sexual harassment, the police allegedly told the family that they must leave Israel or change their name and convert to Judaism, if they wanted to be protected.
In XXXX 2001, when a complaint was made about the behaviour of members of the military recruiting centre toward the daughter XXXXX, the officer at the centre allegedly told the principal claimant that he must leave Israel and that he did not have the right to stay there as he was an undesirable in the country, because of his German origin.
In XXXXX 2001, XXXXX was again summoned to the recruiting office and was supposedly encouraged to denounce some Russian girls who took drugs and trafficked in them. Not being able to handle the situation anymore and concerned for their daughter XXXXX-who would be forced to do her compulsory military service, but was opposed to it because of a conscientious objection-the XXXXX family left Israel on March 22, 2001 for Canada, where, upon their arrival at Dorval airport on the same day, they applied for refugee status.
ANALYSIS
After analyzing all the evidence, oral as well as documentary, the panel finds that the claimants did not demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of the principal claimant's German origin and Christian religion, their membership in a particular social group, namely the family, and because of the true or perceived political opinions of the claimant XXXXX, who refused to do her compulsory military service. Nor did they show that they are "persons in need of protection".
The panel does not believe the claimant's story of fear of alleged persecution. Their credibility was tainted by several factors: omissions and contradictions, of which the examples listed below are not exhaustive, as well as inconsistency with the documentary evidence on Israel.
First of all, the panel noted omissions of important and relevant facts in the answer to question 37 of the claimants' PIF. In fact, the female claimant XXXXX failed to state that the neighbours abused her and her children when they moved to XXX in XXXX 1998. When questioned on the subject, she responded that she had not stated these facts because it did not happen often, just once or twice.
I did not accept these inadequate answers because she contradicted herself on the topic during her testimony. When asked if she personally had problems in Israel, first she responded "no," but that her family did. Later on she stated that she did have problems, because in XXXX she was assaulted by the neighbours. When leaving her house, the neighbour's children allegedly threw rocks that could have hit one of her children or her in the head. She added that she was not hit, but that her children were. Consequently, her credibility was undermined by this contradictory and inconsistent testimony.
For her part, the claimant XXXXX, in her answer to question 37 on her father's form, failed to state that she made a complaint to the person in charge of her class and to the school's principal "XXXXX," after the incessant harassment she suffered from her classmates, who allegedly cruelly beat her on several occasions, because of her father's German origin and her surname.
The panel finds that, by adding information, the claimants tried to give more weight to their refugee claim and, consequently, their credibility was affected.
Under the circumstances, the panel recalls that the Federal Court came to this decision on a similar subject in the Basseghi2 case, when Teitelbaum J stated the following:
It is not incorrect to say that answers given in a PIF should be brief but it is incorrect to say that the answers should not be complete with all of the relevant facts. It is not enough for an applicant to say that what he said in oral testimony was an elaboration. All relevant and important facts should be included in one's PIF. The oral evidence should go on to explain the information contained in the PIF.
The panel does not believe the claimants' story about alleged persecution. I completely rejected the claimants' testimony, which seemed to lack credibility when describing Israel as a country in which discrimination against non-Jewish immigrants is rife and where the authorities refuse to help or protect them.
I do not believe that the State of Israel would have persecuted the claimants or tolerated their persecution. The documentary evidence about Israel presented projects a very different image than the one the claimants seem to have in mind. In fact, this documentation states that the Israeli population has been very kind to newcomers. Some 80% of families have offered to help by giving them furniture, clothing and food, in addition to helping them complete the many procedures required, according to Exhibit A-3, document 1.7(b).3
With regard to the principal claimant's religion, I do not believe that he was a victim of persecution by reason of his Christian religious beliefs. Two sets of documentary evidence, namely Exhibits A-44 and A-3 document 5.5,5 note that Israeli law ensures freedom of religion and that the government respects Christians' rights. According to a representative of the Southern Baptist Church, there is more freedom of religion in Israel than in any other Middle Eastern country.
Nor do I lend any credibility to the principal claimant's allegation that he was a victim of persecution in Israel by reason of his ethnic origin and his German surname or because his Russian nationality is written on his identity card. In fact, neither Amnesty International, in Exhibit A-2 (a) document 1.1a,6 or Human Rights Watch, in Exhibit A-2 (a) document 1.3,7 have reported any hateful or violent attacks or death threats toward ethnic minorities in Israel. On the contrary, on the social level, there are very few inter-community tensions, according to Exhibit A-3 document 1.7(b).8
I do not lend any credibility to the claimants' allegations that they could not rely on the protection of the state by reason of the principal claimant's Christian religion and German ethnic origin. Two sets of documentary evidence, namely Exhibit A-3, documents 1.4 and 1.6 (b),9 indicate that on the contrary, the Israeli police do not take the ethnic origin or religious affiliation of complainants into account when dealing with complaints addressed to them.
In addition, other documentary evidence, namely Exhibit A-3, document 7.7,10 states that the public can apply to the national police complaints unit. This organization has the mission of reviewing complaints made against the police about problems that arise in regular police work, especially concerning out-of-place behaviour that is unacceptable for a police officer.
Consequently, even if I believed that the claimants had experienced such problems with the police, I think they could have sought protection from the state by applying to a higher organization, as pointed out in the Kadenko11 decision.
Nor do I attach any credibility to the claimants' allegations that their children were beaten and assaulted by other children on many occasions at school and in the street, because of the principal claimant's religion and German ethnic origin; and that they were unable to get help or protection from the school as well as the government authorities.
The evidence, namely Exhibit A-3 document 1.7 (b), shows the contrary, that the teachers received specific training, given the arrival of a large number of young people in the former Soviet Union, and that school administrators act quickly once a case of violence is reported to them. Further, the Israeli act, [Translation] An Act regarding the ill-treatment of minors and helpless persons, requires the principal or teacher of an educational institution to report any assaults. If the teacher or principal fails to inform the authorities, the person is punishable by imprisonment, according to Exhibit A-3 document 3.5.12
With regard to the female claimant XXXXX's concern of imprisonment upon her return to Israel because she did not follow up on her notice to report for military service, issued by the Israeli army, according to Exhibit P-6,13 refusing to do it because she has allegedly been against war since her childhood (her father having suffered because of it) and because a woman should not take up arms, the panel recalls that military service in Israel is governed by a law of general application. Further, I do not believe the claimants when they allege that the Israeli recruiting centre in Ukraine did not inform them that their daughters XXXXX and XXXXX would have to do their military service when they turned 18. In fact, the documentary evidence, namely Exhibit A-2 document 2.7,14 is a brochure published by the department of absorption in Israel in order to provide all immigrants and future immigrants information about the various aspects of military service. Further, according to Exhibit A-3 document 2.2,15 brochures about military service in Israel are distributed in large
ex-Soviet Union cities and are available at no cost in repatriation centres with the purpose of informing immigrants of their future military service responsibilities.
Moreover, according to paragraph 167 of the Handbook on procedures and criteria for determining refugee status, a fear of persecution and punishment for desertion or draft evasion (where military service is compulsory) does not constitute a well-founded fear of persecution within the meaning of the definition.
Nor did the claimant XXXXX demonstrate, according to paragraph 169 of the Handbook, that being presumed to be a deserter or draft evader, she would suffer disproportionately severe punishment for the military offence on account of her race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion. According to Exhibit A-3 document 2.1,16 the sentences imposed by Israeli authorities on those who refuse to do military service vary from 7 to 70 days of imprisonment and can go up to one year.
Furthermore, she testified that she did not express her opposition to military service and that she did not ask to do alternative service when she appeared at the recruiting office for her medical examinations in XXXX and XXXXXX 2001. She also added that, to her knowledge, she did not receive other notices to report from the military authorities, despite the fact that she did not appear on XXXXXX, 2001 to begin her 21-month long service, according to Exhibit P-6.
Furthermore, now that she is the mother of a family, since she gave birth to a daughter, Maya XXXXX, in Canada, on XXXXX, 2002, she could possibly benefit from the exemptions under the Act. According to Exhibit A-3 document 2.4,17 section 12 of the national service law states that:
"12. A married woman is exempt from national service. In this section, "married woman" means also the mother of a child, a pregnant woman and a woman who has married during the period of her national service."
Finally, it is possible that the claimants did experience some difficulties in their integration into Israel and that they did feel they were victims of some discrimination; however, I cannot on that account alone conclude that there was persecution or a reasonable fear of persecution. Under the circumstances, the panel prefers to rely on the documentary evidence issued by independent and credible sources that the claimants were shown.
DECISION
The claimants did not discharge themselves of the burden of proving that they have a well-founded fear of persecution in Israel, their country of citizenship. Consequently, the panel concludes that XXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXX, their daughter, XXXXX XXXXX, who is of age, and their minor children XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXX are not "Convention refugees" under section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. Further, as they are not credible, they did not discharge themselves of the burden of proving that they are subject to a danger of torture or a risk to their life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. Therefore, I conclude that the claimants are not "persons in need of protection"18 under section 97(1) (a) and (b) of the Act.
Consequently, these refugee claims are dismissed.

The refugee protection claimants alleged a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of the German origin and Christian religion of the principal claimant and the membership of the wife and children in a particular social group, the family. Furthermore, their eldest daughter also alleged a fear of persecution by reason of her actual or imputed political opinion because she had refused to do compulsory military service. The principal claimant was born in Russia to a German father and a Russian mother. His wife was born in the Ukraine to Jewish parents. They took advantage of the "Law of Return" because of the female claimant's Jewish origin. The claimants stated, among other things, that they had suffered verbal abuse, insults and threats on a number of occasions due to the German origin of the principal claimant. They made a complaint to the police, but the police refused to protect them. The panel was of the opinion that the claimants' testimony contained omissions and contradictions. The female claimant had, among other things, omitted to state that she and her children had been personally assaulted by neighbours. She allegedly made no mention of this fact because it had happened only once or twice. She later contradicted herself in this regard. The documentary evidence indicated, however, that the people of Israel had proven to be friendly towards newcomers. Some 80% of families had volunteered to welcome them by providing them with furniture, clothing and food. According to the documentary evidence as well, Israeli law guaranteed freedom of religion, and the government respected the rights of Christians. No attacks involving hate and violence or death threats against ethnic minorities in Israel were reported. On the contrary, socially, very little tension between communities was reported. The panel did not find credible the claimants' allegations that their children had been beaten and assaulted numerous times by other children at school and in the street because of the principal claimant's religion and German ethnic origin; nor did it find credible that they had been unable to obtain assistance and protection from either school or government authorities. On the contrary, the documentary evidence indicated that teachers had received special training, as a large number of young people were arriving from the former Soviet Union, and that school administrators acted swiftly when a case of violence was reported to them. Furthermore, the law required any principal or teacher at an educational institution to report any assault or face imprisonment for failing to do so. As for the fear of the claimant's eldest daughter of being imprisoned for not responding to the call-up notice for military service sent to her by the Israeli army, the panel referred to, among others, paragraph 167 of the Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status, which states that fear of prosecution and punishment for desertion or draft evasion (where military service is compulsory) does not amount to a well-founded fear of persecution within the meaning of the definition. The claimants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection. RPD MA1-02617 et al., Thibault, September 19, 2002.

The following are the reasons for decision in the claim for refugee protection of Mr. XXXXXXXXXX, citizen of Bangladesh, who alleges to have a well-founded fear of persecution in his country for reasons of his political opinion. He also alleges to be a "person in need of protection", because he would be subjected personally to a danger of torture or to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Bangladesh.
The evidence in this case consisted essentially of the claimant's testimony, his Personal Information Form (PIF), his personal documents, as well as the documents concerning the social and political situation in Bangladesh. The minister's counsel, who raised the issue of exclusion under article 1F of the Convention, participated in the hearing and also submitted evidence.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant is 44 years old. He is married and has two children. His wife and his children are in Bangladesh.
The claimant is a career soldier. In 1976, at the age of 19, he joined the Bangladesh army. In 1987, he was transferred to the office of the Director General XXXXXXXXXXXXX and became part of XXXXXXXXXXX. In the course of his employment, he had the opportunity to become familiar with the top-ranking officers in the army. Some of them were directly involved with the then ruling Jatiya Party and the administration of General Ershad. Some of them were jailed after the Jatiya Party lost power in Bangladesh in 1990.
On XXXXXXX, 1988, the claimant was transferred to the Bangladesh embassy in XXXXX, as an XXXX to the Consular office. Although he was appointed as a civilian employee, part of his duties involved security arrangements and surveillance of the Bangladeshis living in XXXXXX, as well as the members of the Bangladeshi political parties and army officers who used XXXXXXX as their stopover in their travels abroad. The claimant often rendered services to the travelling high officials from the Jatiya Party, who knew about the claimant's allegiance to the Jatiya Party.
On XXXXX, 1993, one of the claimant's co-workers from the XXXX in Bangladesh informed him that he was going to be called back to Dhaka and charged with subversive activities, including assisting forcibly retired officers from the Jatiya Party. The claimant's friend advised him not to go back to Bangladesh, considering the treatment reserved by the XXXXX to the "traitors" such as the claimant. Based on his previous experience, the claimant understood that he would be tortured and "treated as less than an animal". Realizing that his life was in danger, the claimant applied for a US visa.
On XXXXX 1993, the claimant was summoned by his immediate superior, XXXXXXX XXXXX, in charge of the XXXXX Section of the embassy in XXXXX. Mr. XXXXX told the claimant that he knew about his meetings with the generals from the Jatiya Party, and that he was no longer trusted, because he was disloyal to the government in place. The claimant was ordered not to leave his station. The same day, he was instructed by Mr. XXXXX to immediately leave XXXXX and return to Dhaka.
Fearing for his life, the claimant decided not to go back to his country. On XXXX, 1993, he sent his wife and his children to Bangladesh, and he himself travelled to the United States, where he applied for refugee status.
While in the United States, the claimant learned from his family that two security people had come to his home, presenting themselves as his friends. They wanted to know the claimant's whereabouts, and threatened his family.
After the claimant's demand of refugee status in the United States was rejected and after he had exhausted all legal recourses, he came to Canada on XXXXX, 2001, and asked for Canada's protection.
Should he go back to his country, he is afraid that, since he is still on the black list of the XXXXX, he would be arrested, tortured, or even killed.
DETERMINATION
After examining the claimant's written and oral testimony, as well as all the evidence adduced in this case, including the submissions sent after the hearing by the Minister's representative and the counsel, I have come to the conclusion that the claimant is not entitled to refugee protection in Canada, because he is excluded under sections 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Convention, for the reasons which follow.
ANALYSIS
Identity
In order to establish his identity, the claimant produced his Bangladesh passport, his XXXXXX and US driver's licences, and an attestation of his diplomatic status in XXXXX (Exhibits P-2, P-3, P-4, and P-8). I do not have any valid reasons to doubt the authenticity of these documents. Therefore, I conclude that the claimant's identity has been established.
Inclusion
The claimant alleges that while being posted in XXXXX, he learned that he was targeted for persecution by the XXXXX, because of his personal contacts with the high officials and former military high-ranking officers linked to the General Ershad's Jatiya Party, which lost power in Bangladesh in 1990. Knowing what kind of treatment was reserved for him if he went back to Bangladesh and being afraid for his life, he made the early arrangements in order to obtain a US visa. One week after he was officially ordered to return to his country, the claimant sent his family to Bangladesh, and he himself went to the United States.
There were serious credibility problems with the claimant's explanations concerning the circumstances of his desertion from the consular post in XXXX. There was a significant delay in leaving XXXXX after the claimant learned from his friend in Bangladesh, in XXXXX 1993, that he was to be charged with subversive activities, and again after he was ordered by his immediate superior to go back to Dhaka, on XXXXX, 1993. The only independent evidence in support of the claimant's allegations to this respect (besides his testimony) is the Warrant of Arrest (Exhibit P-7). That document, however, does not mention any accusations against the claimant, besides the fact that he did not report to his duties on XXXX, 1993 (Fugitive and absent without leave). It is not dated, which raises more questions about that document and its probative value.
There is also a letter from XXXXXXXXXXXXX (Exhibit P-9), mentioning that the claimant was victimized for his support to the Jatiya Party. However, the claimant's testimony concerning this alleged friend was not credible, which again raises serious doubts as to the probative value of this evidence.
I also find it implausible that the claimant, being a member of the Bangladesh embassy staff in XXXXX and a member of the XXXXX, would have been allowed to continue offering his support, openly and in a more discreet form, to ousted politicians and retired high officers linked to the Jatiya Party, for two and a half years after General Ershad was forced to resign, and was subsequently charged and condemned to a lengthy prison term.
I find it implausible that, knowing about the methods of the XXXXX, the claimant would have stayed on his post after his friend allegedly warned him about the accusations against him, even though he had obtained a US visa and was free to leave. I doubt it even more that after the alleged conversation with XXXXXXXXXX, on XXXXX, 1993, and his order that the claimant should immediately return to Bangladesh, the claimant would have continued coming to his work (as he testified), and would not have left his post immediately, hiding in XXXXX, until he was able to make arrangements for his and his family's travel.
I also find it implausible that after such serious accusations formulated against him, the claimant would be left free by his superior, a high officer of the XXXXXXXX, and not put under a home arrest or detained in the embassy before his eventual transfer to Bangladesh. It does not make sense that after the accusations were spelled out against him, together with a clear threat of torture, the claimant was not even under surveillance, and was left free for one week to make all the travel arrangements for him and his family.
Finally, while in the United States, the claimant went back to the Bangladesh embassy, where he obtained a new passport. I seriously doubt that if the claimant feared with reason being persecuted in his country, he would have availed himself of his country's protection. I also doubt that if there was a valid warrant of arrest still pending against him, he would have been issued a passport.
All the above makes me seriously doubt the credibility of the claimant's testimony concerning the circumstances of his departure from XXXXXXX. It is possible that the claimant was afraid to go back to his country, but I do not believe that it was for the reasons which he alleges. I therefore conclude that the claimant did not establish, on the balance of probabilities, that there is a serious possibility that he would be persecuted in Bangladesh for the reasons which he alleges. He did not establish either that for the alleged reasons, he would be in danger of torture or that there would be a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
However, what was established clearly and without any doubts during the hearing is the fact that the claimant was a career soldier, that he was promoted to the rank of havildar (non-commissioned sergeant), that in the early 1987, he was assigned to work at the Directorate XXXXXXXXXXXXX (XXXXX), and that he worked for the XXXXX for six and a half years in Bangladesh and abroad. That in itself considers a serious ground to raise the issue of exclusion under Section 1F, regardless of whether the claimant has established or not that he needs protection under Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
Constitutional question
In his notice, sent to the parties before the hearing, as well as during the hearing and in his written submissions, the Minister's counsel submitted that the claimant should be excluded from Canada's refugee protection, pursuant to Section 98 of the IRPA. The Minister's counsel submitted that the claimant should be excluded, because there are serious reasons for considering that he has committed crimes against humanity, as described in Section 1F(a), and has been guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations, as per Section 1F(c) of the Convention.
Concerning the application of the exclusion clause in light of the new Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, counsel for the claimant submitted that:
"Section 98 of the IRPA is illegal, ultra vires and not with conformity with Section 7 and 12 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
No person should be allowed to be subject to 'torture' within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention against Torture or be allowed to be subject to a risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment as specifically forseen (sic) in the Charter at Section 12."
According to the counsel, the exclusion clause, being an inherent element of the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, does apply only to Article 96 of the IRPA and should not be applied to Article 97, since exclusion has no basis in international treaties with regards to victims of torture or persons facing risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment. The concept of "person in need of protection"1 is larger than a more restrictive concept of "Convention refugee",2 and its application cannot be restricted by Charter violations such as Section 98 of the IRPA.
The counsel also argues that the Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that a person cannot be deported from Canada should he be subject to a death penalty, regardless of guilt, a death penalty being considered under the Charter cruel and unusual treatment. That implies, according to the counsel, that it is Canada's obligation not to deny protection under Sections 97(1) and (2) of the IRPA to a person facing torture, execution, or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Concerning the arguments based on Sections 7 and 12 of the Charter, pursuant to Rule 59 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules, a party who wants to challenge the constitutional validity, applicability, or operability of a legislative provision must complete a notice of constitutional question. A copy of this notice must be sent to the Attorney General of Canada and the Attorney General of each of the provinces, and must be received by the recipients no later than ten days before the day on which the constitutional argument will be made. If the party fails to provide such notice, the tribunal has no jurisdiction to consider the constitutional argument. Notice of a constitutional question has been considered to be a mandatory requirement, and a decision made without notice may be struck down on this basis alone.3
Exclusion
Considering the application of the exclusion clauses 1F(a) and 1F(c), the tribunal has to determine whether there are serious reasons to consider that the claimant participated, personally or by complicity, in the acts described in that section, whether the activities in which the claimant participated personally or by complicity are considered as crimes against humanity and/or as acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations, and whether the claimant failed to dissociate himself from these activities at the earliest safe opportunity.
Director XXXXXXXXXXXX (XXXXX)
It was established during the hearing that from 1987 to 1993, the claimant was posted at the XXXXX in the rank of sergeant.
The following intelligence agencies operate to protect the internal and national security of Bangladesh: National Security Intelligence (NSI), Director (or Directorate) General of Forces Intelligence (DGFI), Special Branch (SB), Special Security Force (SSF), and Detective Branch (DB).4
In their respective submissions, both the counsel for the claimant and the Minister's counsel agree that the XXXXX has been involved in very serious human rights abuses, such as illegal detention, custodial violence, torture, and murder. The documentary evidence adduced in this case, among others Exhibits A-6,5 M-5,6 and M-9 to M-16,7 clearly supports such a conclusion. The two parties also agree that, although the XXXXX has committed very serious human rights abuses, it should not be qualified as an organization "directed to a limited, brutal purpose".8
As the Minister's counsel points out in her submissions:
"(...) the Directorate XXXXXXXXX (XXXXX) is an intelligence agency which operates in Bangladesh and abroad to XXXXXXXX and national XXXXX. It is used by the government for political purposes."9
And she adds:
"It is one of few agencies which conduct surveillance of political, socio-cultural and human rights organizations. It is accountable only to the Prime Minister and is beyond the reach of the law."
I do agree with the claimant's counsel, that "these activities are not of themselves reprehensible" and that "most if not all nations create similar organizations to protect internal and national security, witness C.S.I.S. in Canada and the CIA in the USA".
However, in the fulfilment of the above-mentioned legitimate mandate, the XXXXX members apply torture, ill-treatment, and custodial violence against detainees, including political activists and students, sometimes resulting in custodial deaths. The reports speak about prisoners being kept incommunicado and being denied access to a lawyer for weeks or months, during which they were allegedly subjected to torture. Among the methods used by various intelligence services, including the XXXXX in their Dhaka Army Cantonment, the reports talk about severe beatings, burning with cigarettes during interrogations, prolonged interrogations of blindfolded and tied prisoners, suspension by arms from the ceiling and threats of further torture, exposure to cold air fans for extended periods, suffocating prisoners by putting a water soaked cloth on their faces, as well as the use of electric shocks.10
The documentary evidence is clear that the ill-treatment and torture has been an endemic problem in Bangladesh under successive governments since the inception of Bangladesh as an independent country in 1971, including the governments of Mujibur Rahman (1971-1975), various military juntas (1975-1982), and the rule of General Ershad (1982-1990), followed by the governments of Begum Khaleda Zia (1991-1996) and Sheikh Hasina (1996-2001).11
It is clear that the XXXXX has been part of that torture network:
"Other forces which create terror among citizenry had been members of XXXXX (Director XXXXXXXXX) and NSI (National Security Intelligence). These are virtually autonomous organizations, operate under little or no supervision.
Police repression has gone on in the country for far too long. Illegal arrests, torture, shootings, corruption and massive violation of human rights must stop."12
According to Section 6(3) of to the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act:
"'Crime against humanity' means murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation, imprisonment, torture, sexual violence, persecution or any other inhumane act or omission that is committed against any civilian population or any identifiable group and that, at the time and in the place of its commission, constitutes a crime against humanity according to customary international law or conventional international law or by virtue of its being criminal according to the general principles of law recognized by the community of nations, whether or not it constitutes a contravention of the law in force at the time and in the place of its commission."
The notion of "crimes against humanity" requires that the crimes be committed in a systematic or widespread fashion.13 The notion of "widespread" has been defined in the literature as "massive, frequent, large scale action, carried out collectively with considerable seriousness and directed against a multiplicity of victims".14
I agree with the Minister's counsel's submission that:
"(...) the documentary evidence establish without doubt that XXXXX has been involved in torture and murder on a large scale, collectively, with considerable seriousness, and that its actions were carried out against a multiplicity of victims."
Since these acts were committed mainly against the civil population, primarily political opponents and students, I therefore conclude that the Minister has established that the reprehensible acts which has been attributed to the XXXXX over the years amount to crimes against humanity, according to the international instruments.
Complicity and failure to dissociate (caselaw)
Since it has been established that the XXXXX, while not being an organization "directed to a limited, brutal purpose", has been involved in crimes against humanity, it is necessary to evaluate the claimant's degree of participation it these crimes, by being a "principal actor" or "an accomplice", as defined by Justice MacGuigan in Ramirez.15
Both parties refer in their submissions to appropriate Canadian jurisprudence, elaborating notions of direct participation and complicity in an international offence leading to the application of an exclusion clause.16
According to Justice MacGuigan in Ramirez,17 mere membership in an organization which from time to time commits international offences is not normally sufficient for exclusion from refugee status. It is therefore very important to establish what complicity is required to be an accomplice or an abettor.
In Penate,18 Madame Justice Reed defines the complicity as follows:
"In order to be complicit in the commission of an international offence the individual's participation must be personal and knowing. Complicity is an offence rests on a shared common purpose.
(...)
As I understand the jurisprudence, it is that a person who is a member of the persecuting group and who has knowledge that activities are being committed by the group and who neither takes steps to prevent them occurring (if he has a power to do so) nor disengages himself from the group at the earliest opportunity (consistent with safety for himself) but who lends his active support to the group will be considered to be an accomplice. A shared common purpose will be considered to exist."
As indicated in Gutierrez,19 three criteria should be considered in establishing complicity:
"Essentially then, three prerequisites must be established in order to provide complicity in the commission of an international offence: (1) membership in an organization which committed international offences as a continuous and regular part of its operation, (2) personal and knowing participation, and (3) failure to dissociate from the organization at the earliest safe opportunity."
The notion of participation was defined by the Federal Court of Appeal in Bazargan:20
"In our view, it goes without saying that 'personal and knowing participation' can be direct and indirect (...) It is not working within an organization that makes someone an accomplice to the organization's activities, but knowingly contributing to those activities in any way or making them possible, whether from within or from outside the organization. (...) 'At bottom, complicity rests... on the existence of shared common purpose and the knowledge that all of the parties in question may have of it'. Those who become involved in an operation that is not theirs, but that they know will probably lead to the commission of an international offence, lay themselves open to the application of the exclusion clause in the same way as those who play a direct part in the operation."
The counsel for the claimant submits that the Minister, who bears the burden of the proof in questions of exclusion, did not establish that the claimant was an accomplice of the crimes committed by the XXXXX, and even less that he was a principal actor. The counsel submits that the claimant was a low-ranking career soldier, without effective authority, and that his duties, both in Bangladesh and in XXXXXX, were essentially of administrative nature. Although he had some knowledge of "questionable activities" carried out by the XXXXX, he himself never participated in or witnessed any crimes committed by the XXXXX. At worst, counsel argues, the claimant was a member of an organization which from time to time commits international offences, but according to him, it is not sufficient to exclude the claimant under Section 1F(a).
The Minister's counsel, on the contrary, submits that the claimant's testimony was not credible, that, faced with the exclusion, he tried to diminish his level of involvement in the XXXXX activities, that he had a full knowledge of torture and other human rights abuses committed by the organisation, and that he willingly contributed to persecution of some people by reporting on their activities when he was in XXXXXX. The Minister also argues that the claimant did not dissociate himself from the XXXXX at the first safe opportunity. The Minister submits that the claimant should be excluded under Sections 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Convention.
Testimony
The claimant testified that he had joined the army as a volunteer in 1976, at the age of 19. After a short basic training, he was assigned as a clerk to work in the office at the Army Headquarter of the XXXXXXXX. In 1982, he was transferred to the Army XXXX Unit. It was difficult to assess, based on the claimant's testimony, if the Army XXXXX Unit was a part of the XXXXX or not. First he testified that from 1982 to 1984, he worked in the XXXXX, in the Army XXXXX Unit. However, later on he insisted that the XXXXX and the Army XXXX Unit are two completely separate entities. His testimony to this respect was confused and contradictory. According to the claimant, the Army XXX Unit only deals with the military personnel and intervenes when soldiers are involved in illegal activities, such as going to prostitutes, taking drugs, and doing in illegal business, while the XXXXX is concerned with civil population and takes care of spying.
During his assignment with the Army XXX Unit, the claimant completed his higher secondary education. In his unit, he worked in accounting, XXXXXXXXX. Two months before his transfer to the Military Academy, he was promoted to the rank of havildar (non-commissioned sergeant).
In 1984, the claimant was transferred for three years to the Military Academy. According to his testimony, he was working as a clerk XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
At the beginning of 1987, the claimant was assigned to the XXXXX headquarter in the Dhaka Military Cantonment. Again, he worked in the administration, XXXXX XXXXXXXX XXX XXXXX XXXX X XXX XXXXXXXXXX XXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX.
After less than two years of administrative work at the XXXXX, the claimant passed an exam and, at the very end of 1988, he was assigned to the embassy in XXXXX. Part of his work involved consular services. Although he was officially a civil consular staff, he remained a member of the XXXXX. His duties also involved embassy security, security of and logistic support for visiting dignitaries, as well as making sure that members of Bangladesh community living in XXXXX do not defame the good name of their country by being involved in criminal activities.
I can agree with the counsel's submissions that, based on the claimant's testimony during the hearing, one could infer that he was simply a low-ranking career soldier, without effective authority, and that his duties, both in Bangladesh and in XXXXXX, were essentially of administrative nature.
However, in his written narrative (answer to question 37 of his PIF), the claimant portraits his role and responsibilities, while working with the XXXXX since 1987, quite differently. He writes:
"I was then part of the XXXXXXXXXX. In the course of my employment, I had the opportunity to become familiar with the top ranking officers in the Arm (sic). Some of these officers were directly or indirectly involved in the political activities of the Jatiya Party or Freedom Fighters Association. A number of them served in the Administration of General Hossain Mohammed Ershad after their retirement."
In December 1988, the claimant was transferred to the Bangladesh embassy in XXXXX as an assistant to the consular office. He writes:
"Although my appointment in the Embassy was one of a civilian employee, part of my duties involved security arrangement and surveillance upon Bangladeshis living in XXXXXX and the members of the Bangladesh political parties and army officers who use XXXXXX as their stopover for onward journey."
It is clear to me that two descriptions of the claimant's career, one in his PIF and the other during his testimony, are quite different. The claimant's written narrative is basically the same as the one presented to the American authorities when he applied for refugee status in the United States. It appears that in the United States, the exclusion clause was not raised. It was obvious to me that the claimant made everything possible during the hearing, after the Minister raised the possibility of exclusion, in order to diminish the level of his involvement and his knowledge. From the person who, in his PIF, was a part of the security network intelligence of the XXXXX, having ample opportunities to fray with top-ranking officers and high-level politicians from General Ershad's Jatiya Party and being sent abroad disguised as a consular civil employee, to conduct surveillance of members of political parties and army officers passing by XXXXX, the claimant became, in his testimony, a modest clerk, doing office work, taking care of XXXXXX XXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXX XX X. The claimant could not reasonably explain the difference between his PIF and his testimony.
He could not reasonably explain it either how a series of simple clerical jobs would have prepared him to pass an exam to become a member of the intelligence staff in XXXXX. His explanation repeated textually several times, that XXXXXX is a friendly country, is not sufficient. In fact, being a friendly country, XXXXX is a place, as indicated in the claimant's PIF and in his testimony, frequented by Bangladeshi ousted politicians and high-ranking military, as well as a crossroad of traffic of drugs and women and children by the Bangladesh nationals.
I do not believe the claimant's testimony to the effect that he was a simple clerk before he went abroad. I rather believe that after initial training and assignment to the XXXXXX, the claimant spent the rest of his military career in Bangladesh in intelligence services. He was assigned to the Army Military Unit. During his assignment, he was able to complete higher secondary education, necessary for further advancement. I believe that, promoted to the rank of sergeant, he was sent for training to the Military Academy (and not to do clerical work, as he testified). After completing his training, he was transferred back to the XXXXXXXXX, this time to the XXXXX. After two years of working in "XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX" in the infamous XXXXX Dhaka Military Cantonment, he was transferred to continue his XXXXXXXX work in XXXXX.
In his PIF, the claimant wrote that while working in the XXXXX, he had the opportunity to become familiar with the top-ranking officers in the army and the officers directly involved in the political activities of Mr. Ershad's Jatiya Party. The claimant was asked when he made these contacts. He said that it was during his assignment to the XXXXX in Dhaka. However, according to his earlier testimony, the claimant worked as a clerk in one of several buildings in the cantonment. Each building was fenced in and the claimant never went into any other building. He did not know what was going on there and what sections of the XXXXX occupied these buildings. How, in such circumstances, could a simple clerk have become familiar with top-ranking officers and politicians from the ruling party? The claimant answered that the top officers sometimes came to the place where he worked. He did not know why they came, maybe to see him working. They were not familiar with what he was doing. They just came to know about it. That explanation simply does not make any sense. It is obvious to me that if the claimant knew well top-ranking officers and Jatiya Party politicians, when he worked in the XXXXX headquarters in Dhaka, it is not because they were curious about a little clerk's job, but because the claimant was involved in what is the main purpose of the XXXXX, namely XXXXXXX of civilians perceived to be political activists:
"The Special Branch division of the XXXXX XXXXXX, and the Directorate XXXXXX XXXXXXXX (XXXXX) employ informers to report on citizens perceived to be political opponents of the Government and to conduct surveillance on them. Political leaders, human rights activists, foreign NGO's, and journalists report occasional harassment by these XXXXX organizations."21
During the hearing, the claimant also testified that he did not know much about the functions of the XXXXX, its composition, and its organisation. I consider that the claimant pretended the lack of such knowledge in his general attempt to diminish his level of involvement with this organization. I found it implausible that after working for 17 years in the army, including six years in the XXXXX in its headquarters and abroad, he would not have such a basic knowledge.
I believe that the claimant knowingly participated in the intelligence work of the XXXXX in Bangladesh, and when faced with the exclusion clause, lied about his real involvement, trying to portray his job as an administrative clerical position, without greater importance.
The same goes concerning his work and involvement in XXXXX. The claimant testified that his job there involved mainly assisting visiting officers and politicians, assuring their security, and helping them to make contacts with Bangladeshi nationals living in XXXXX. He also testified that he had to infiltrate the Bangladeshi community in XXXXX, in order to take care of the development of Bangladeshi there and assure that they were not involved in such activities that would defame Bangladesh. The claimant textually repeated that explanation several times during the hearing, giving the clear impression that he had learned it by heart. According to the claimant, the sole purpose of his spying on the Bangladesh community in XXXXX was to prevent criminal activities, such as drug dealing or trafficking in women and other people.
However, not only this testimony contradicts his written narrative concerning his functions in XXXXX, but also it is contradicted by the documentary evidence. In his PIF, the claimant indicates that XXXXXX was used as a stopover by ousted politicians and top military officers forcibly retired under the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) government, which succeeded the Ershad's regime. These people were even having political activities in XXXXXX.
I do agree with the Minister's counsel when she writes that, in this context and given the mandate of the XXXXX, its reputation and political purposes, as well as the presence in XXXXXX of high officials of the opposition parties involved in political activities, it is unlikely that the claimant would have been concerned only with criminal activities. It is particularly implausible because, according to the claimant's testimony, there were only two XXXXX people stationed in XXXXX, the claimant and his superior, head of the Embassy XXXXXXX Section, XXXXXXXXXX, both disguised as civil consular employees.
Knowledge
What and when did the claimant learn about abuses committed by the XXXXX, and XXXXXX in general?
In his Port of Entry declaration,22 the claimant wrote that he feared persecution from the Army XXXXXX Unit. He was asked to explain why. He testified that when he worked there, he heard, sometimes from the soldiers, sometimes from the newspapers, that people were sometimes persecuted by the Army XXXXXXXUnit and by the XXXXX. He learned that many people were apprehended and persecuted, that they were beaten in such a way that some of them died and some became insane. Later on during the hearing, the claimant testified that he learned that only when he was transferred to the XXXXX in Dhaka. He said that shortly after he was transferred, he heard from the mouth of soldiers about the torture. He also read about it in the papers. He textually repeated his earlier testimony, stating that when XXXXX people caught someone, they tortured in such a way that the person either dies or becomes insane or depressed. He added that once a person is blacklisted in the books of the XXXXX, he could not explain the situation he or she will have to face at the hands of the XXXXX. That is why the claimant knows that if he were apprehended by the XXXXX people, he would be tortured as an animal, and if he died, they would not care.
The claimant also demonstrated in his PIF that he knew that the XXXXX tortured people during investigation. He wrote:
"He also told me that I was lucky that there were no arrangements for interrogation cells in the Embassy (or maybe more appropriately called torture chambers)."
And further down:
"It was thus better for (me) not to come back due to the treatment that is reserved for "traitors" such as me. After receiving these messages, I was scared for my life since as part of intelligence forces, I understood that I would be tortured and treated as less than an animal."
It is clear to me, based on the documentary evidence, that the XXXXX uses torture as a method of interrogation of suspected politicians, students, and other civilians. Based on his testimony and on his PIF, it is clear to me that the claimant was well aware of these practices.
It is also clear to me that not only was he aware of these practices, but he knew that some of the people, including criminals, on whom he was spying in XXXXX and on whom he wrote reports to his superior, had a serious risk of being arrested and tortured by the XXXXX when they went back to Bangladesh. The claimant's testimony as to the treatment of such people was devoid of all credibility and simply did not make sense.
The claimant testified that his role in XXXXX was, among others, to make sure that people doing bad things and defaming the name of Bangladesh would stop doing so. He would tell them to stop doing such bad things, and if they did not, he would write a report on them and submit it to his superior, Mr. XXXXX, who in turn would send it to the headquarter in Dhaka. He was asked if he knew what was happening to these people when they returned to Bangladesh. He testified that most of these people would not return, but that, due to his intervention, they would stop their bad activities. The claimant was also asked if he knew what happened to those who returned to Bangladesh. After several evasive answers, he admitted that they would be investigated by the XXXXX and that the appropriate action would be taken.
However, the claimant insisted that nothing would really happen to these people. They would just be asked by the XXXXX to stop such activities. The claimant said that he did not believe that the XXXXX can put anyone in jail or hang, since there is not enough evidence against these people. I do not give these explanations any credence, particularly considering the reputation of the XXXXX and the methods it uses. It simply does not make sense that hardcore criminals, such as drug smugglers and criminals trafficking in women and other people, would stop their activities just because the claimant told them that it was bad and that it defamed the good name of Bangladesh. I do not believe that such people, when they returned to Bangladesh, would be invited to the XXXXX in order to be nicely told to stop their criminal activities. It is inconsistent with the methods used by the police and security apparatus in Bangladesh, and the claimant knew it very well. He knew that by reporting on these people, he was directly exposing them to a danger to their lives and to a danger of cruel and unusual treatment, which should not be reserved even to the hardcore criminals.
Towards the end of the hearing, when the claimant was asked to explain why he did not leave the XXXXX when he learned about the torture, he suddenly changed his testimony. He stated that he knew about the torture, but that it took place under General Zia, in 1977, and that he did not hear about anybody being tortured and killed when General Ershad was in power. The claimant could not reasonably explain why then he had testified earlier that in 1987, when he learned about torture committed by the XXXXX, he wanted to leave the army, if the crimes had been committed ten years before, under a different government. Altogether, this new and clearly improvised declaration contradicted large parts of his earlier testimony and his written narrative, and simply did not make any sense.
In conclusion, I consider that the Minister has established that the claimant knowingly participated in the surveillance of and spying on political opponents and criminals on behalf of the XXXXX in Bangladesh and in XXXXXX, and by doing so, he was exposing them to a danger to their lives and to a danger of torture. As an informer, the claimant knew all along that the XXXXX tortured and killed people on a regular basis, and that there was a serious possibility that the persons he reported on, would be apprehended, tortured, and even killed.
Failure to dissociate
The claimant was asked why, when he learned about people being tortured by the XXXXX, he did not leave the army. He said that he could not quit, since it would have been considered as desertion, and his life would then have been in danger. The claimant admitted that he could have asked to be dismissed from the army, but he would have had to explain the reasons. However, in 1988, the claimant was sent to XXXXXX. He was asked why he did not quit the army right after he left Bangladesh, but instead he continued working for the XXXXX in XXXXX for four years and a half. The claimant's answer was straightforward and clear:
"I had a wonderful life. I did not want to flee."
This answer explains everything. The claimant was very happy to continue working for the XXXXX as long as it was good for him, regardless of the crimes committed by this organisation, crimes to which he had knowingly contributed. He only decided to leave when he was afraid that he could be subjected to the same treatment to which he had exposed other people, whom he had reported to the XXXXX. What was good for them was not good for the claimant himself. He knew that the XXXXX tortured and even killed people, and did not ask them politely to stop their activities.
The claimant did not dissociate himself from the XXXXX at the earliest safe opportunity (his and his family's arrival in Bangkok in 1988). He had a safe opportunity to flee and he failed to do so. He decided to flee only when he decided that, for whatever reason, his own security was allegedly in danger.
Considering all the above, I conclude that the Minister has met his burden of proof in establishing that there are serious reasons to believe that:
"(...) the claimant has been a full and knowing participant, providing essential support functions to an organisation which is held responsible for large-scale, widespread violations of human rights, more particularly, by reporting on civilians to the XXXXX, which he knew was torturing and killing people as a regular part of its operations, with the knowledge that there was a distinct possibility that harm could be done to these people."
I therefore conclude that the claimant, as an accomplice, must be held responsible of the commission of crimes against humanity, and must therefore be excluded from the benefits of Canada's protection, under Section 1F(a).
The Minister has also established that the claimant should be excluded under Section 1F(c), by being guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations, since he was an accomplice of the XXXXX, who, according to his own testimony and documentary evidence, has been regularly using torture and other cruel, inhuman, and degrading treatments against political activists and other civilians, acts contrary to Article 2 of the Convention Against Torture, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on December 9, 1975.
DECISION
For all the above reasons, I conclude that pursuant to Section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXX, should be excluded from the benefits of Canada's protection, as specified under Sections 96 and 97(1)a) and b), since there are serious reasons to consider that he has committed crimes against humanity and that he has been guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations (Sections 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Refugee Convention), when he was serving at the XXXXX in XXXXXXX and in XXXXXX from 1987 to 1993.

The claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXX, a stateless Palestinian refugee whose habitual residence is in XXXXXXX in the United Arab Emirates, alleges a well-founded fear of persecution in Lebanon by reason of his possible imputed political opinion.
ALLEGED FACTS
The claimant, who is 21 years old, was allegedly born in XXXXXXX on XXXXXX, 1981 of parents who were Palestinian refugees from Lebanon working in the United Arab Emirates. He lived in the Emirates his whole life, and his family still lives there.
Upon finishing his secondary schooling there in 1999, the claimant left XXXXXXX to come study in Canada. After comparing the costs of the private universities in the Emirates with those of the Canadian universities, the claimant decided to register in a Canadian university and chose XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
During his second year of study at XXXXXXX, and after having spent his vacation with his parents in December 2000 and January 2001, the claimant's father told him that he could no longer continue to pay for his studies because of his responsibility to provide for the other children in the family, and because of the failing health of the claimant's sick grandparents living in Lebanon. From then on, the claimant had to support himself and pay for his studies himself.
Suddenly forced to quit his studies for financial reasons, the claimant maintained that he had no choice but to go to Lebanon to live in the Palestinian refugee camp "XXXXXXXX," where his father came from and where his grandparents were living. He maintained that returning would endanger his safety and his life, since the various political factions in the camps would immediately pressure him to take part in their terrorist activities. He maintained that he would have to refuse, and that his refusal would be interpreted as a political stand against the group concerned and in favour of another, which would endanger his life.
The claimant also maintained that he would be persecuted by Lebanon because it discriminates against refugees, providing them with limited employment opportunities and inadequate medical care.
Moreover, the claimant maintained that he could not return to his family living in XXXXXXX in the Arab Emirates because any individual 18 years of age and over who does not hold a work permit or is not registered as a full-time student cannot obtain residence in the country.
The claimant returned to Canada for the third time on January 10, 2001 and claimed refugee status on April 26, 2001.
ANALYSIS
After carefully examining the claimant's refugee claim, the panel has come to the conclusion that he is neither a "Convention refugee" nor a "person in need of protection" for reasons relating to the Convention Against Torture or because he would be subject to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he returned to his country of habitual residence.
Country of habitual residence
The claimant alleged persecution by both the United Arab Emirates and Lebanon. The panel was therefore required to briefly review in the hearing room the principles of the Convention,1 which set out that the term "refugee," when referring to stateless persons, applies to individuals who are outside the country of their former habitual residence due to events that caused them to flee and who are unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country.2
The panel thus pointed out to the claimant and his counsel that, since the claimant had spent most of his life in XXXXXXX and had never really lived elsewhere, the Emirates therefore constituted his habitual residence.3 Moreover, since he had not lived in Lebanon, he could not consider it to be "another" permanent residence4 and claim persecution by this country. The panel therefore examined the grounds on which the claimant alleged persecution because it was impossible to return to the country of his habitual residence, namely, the United Arab Emirates.
Persecution by the United Arab Emirates
The claimant explained that he had no rights in the Emirates, despite the fact that he was born there. He could obtain neither citizenship nor even permission to live there because he was now over 18 years of age, was not registered as a full-time student in any educational institution and did not have a job there. He stated that these combined restrictions were persecutory and prevented him from returning to live with his family.
The panel does not share the claimant's conclusions and does not feel that the conditions of return imposed by the government of the Emirates were persecutory, as the claimant alleged.
Regarding the right to nationality or citizenship, the application of the JUS SANGUINIS or JUS SOLI principle is a legal issue decided by individual countries and is not persecutory. Many countries apply one or the other, or even both. Not automatically obtaining the nationality of a country by being born on its soil is not, in our opinion, a breach of a fundamental right any more than not obtaining it by filiation. On this point, the panel cannot accept the claimant's arguments that his inability to obtain nationality in the United Arab Emirates was a form of persecution against him. These are the laws of the country, and they apply to all foreigners living there, regardless of their origin.
Moreover, contrary to what he indicated in his narrative, the claimant admitted at the hearing that he could return to the country of his habitual residence to see his family, but only on a temporary visitor's visa for a few months. To obtain a residence permit for a longer duration, he would have to be a full-time student or be working for a private or state company. The panel does not feel that these conditions are a breach of a fundamental right of the claimant. They constitute legal restrictions imposed by the country, likely in a legitimate attempt to regulate not only foreigners entering and leaving its territory, but also its attractive job market.
Indeed, the claimant freely chose to come study in Canada, even though he could have stayed in XXXXXXX. He did not leave the country because of persecution. Moreover, he returned there a number of times. On this point, the document that he filed as P-10, namely, the cancellation of his residence permit, merely certified that the claimant had not been living in the country for some time and that he needed to make his own applications in the future, since he had reached adult age. It did not deny him re-entry to the country of his habitual residence on one of the grounds in the Convention and, consequently, does not a priori constitute persecution.5
Moreover, as regards the financial situation of the claimant's family, the panel feels that there was no nexus between this point and any of the grounds in the Convention.6
Consequently, as to the persecution by the country of the claimant's habitual residence, the United Arab Emirates, the panel concludes that the claimant was not subject to any persecution in the past and would not be subject to any if he were to return. The case law is clear on this point. Mr. Justice Cullen's comments apply in the present case:
For stateless persons to be refugees they must be outside their country of habitual residence for the reasons listed in the Convention refugee definition. 7
This is clearly confirmed in the UNHCR's Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status:
It will be noted that not all stateless persons are refugees. They must be outside the country of their former habitual residence for the reasons indicated in the definition. Where these reasons do not exist, the stateless person is not a refugee. 8
The panel consequently does not believe that the claimant was persecuted in his country of habitual residence, or that he would be subject to persecution if he were to return there.
Persecution by Lebanon
As mentioned above, the panel noted that the claimant had never lived in Lebanon. At most, he had vacationed there to visit his grandparents and other family members. In Maarouf, Mr. Justice Cullen expounds on the definition of "country of habitual residence." His remarks read as follows:
In my view, the concept of "former habitual residence" seeks to establish a relationship to a state which is broadly comparable to that between a citizen and his or her country of nationality. Thus the term implies a situation where a stateless person was admitted to a given country with a view to continuing residence of some duration, without necessitating a minimum period of residence. 9
Therefore, regarding the claimant's alleged persecution by Lebanon, since he never established "continuing residence of some duration" in this country, he cannot consider it to be his country of habitual residence. He cannot claim persecution by this country and cannot therefore be considered a "Convention refugee" from this country.
CONCLUSION
The panel finds that, as a stateless person, the claimant did not establish a serious possibility of persecution in his country of habitual residence.
DECISION
The panel consequently determines that the claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXX, is not a "Convention refugee" or a "person in need of protection" for reasons relating to a danger of torture or a risk to his life, or because of a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. The panel dismisses his claim and concludes that there was no credible basis for his refugee claim, pursuant to section 107(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

The claimant alleged a well-founded fear of persecution in Lebanon by reason of imputed political opinion. The son of Palestinian parents who were refugees in Lebanon and working in the United Arab Emirates, the claimant was born in the latter country and lived there his entire life with his family before coming to Canada to study. Forced to abandon his studies for monetary reasons, the claimant stated that he no longer had the right to return to live in the Emirates. He had no other choice but to go and live in a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon, which would put his safety and his life in danger. The panel was of the opinion that, since the claimant had spent most of his life in the Emirates and had never really lived anywhere else, this country was his country of former habitual residence. In addition, since he had not lived in Lebanon, he could not consider it "another" country of former habitual residence and claim persecution against that country. The claimant had testified that he had no rights in the Emirates despite the fact that he had been born there. He could not obtain citizenship or even reside there because he was now over 18 years of age, he was not enrolled in any school and he had no job. He alleged that all these restrictions, taken cumulatively, were of a persecutory nature and prevented him from returning there to live with his family. However, according to the panel, the conditions of return imposed by the Emirates government were not at all of a persecutory nature. They were legal restrictions imposed by the country, certainly with the legitimate purpose of controlling the entry and exit of foreigners to and from its territory. Moreover, the document submitted by the claimant was merely a declaration that the claimant had not lived in the country for some time and would have to make applications on his own behalf in future since he had reached the age of majority. It was not a refusal of return to the country of former habitual residence for a Convention ground and, consequently, was not a priori persecution. The panel determined that the claimant was not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection and that his claim for refugee protection had no credible basis.
