REASONS DELIVERED FROM THE BENCH
These are the reasons in the decision concerning the case of Mr. XXXXXXXX, his wife XXXXXXXXXX and their child XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
You, Sir, are presently 28 years of age, as is your common-law partner, and your daughter is four years of age.
You are all citizens of Romania. You say that you left your country on XXXXX, 2001, and after passing through Hungary, where you stayed for some eight days, you came to Canada to apply for refugee protection.
You are basing your claim for refugee protection on the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees. You, Sir, are invoking your nationality. The female claimant, you, Madam, are citing your nationality and your membership in a social group, namely women victims of violence, and you are basing your daughter's claim on her nationality.
At the beginning of the hearing, you, Madam, were designated to represent your daughter, who is still a minor.
We should point out that at the start of the hearing, the panel, noting that your application for refugee protection only concerned the Convention, drew your lawyer's attention to the opportunity he had to invoke the grounds stipulated in section 97 of the new Act (the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act). However, he saw fit to limit your claim solely to the Convention ground.
We must also say that only you, Sir, produced an answer to Question 37 of your Personal Information Form (PIF). In that answer, you recount not only the incidents that you experienced, but also the incidents that your partner faced since she, like your daughter, is basing her claim for refugee protection on yours.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGED FACTS
In support of your claim, you allege the following facts.
You a citizen of Romania, but of Gypsy origin, as is your common-law partner. This caused you many problems in your country.
You say, Sir, that in the child care centre and the elementary school, you were not wanted. You therefore had to quit school after the fourth grade. During your military service, you never received military training as such. You were limited to maintenance work, and in addition, you were beaten by the soldiers and by the other recruits. You had difficulty finding work. In your life, you were humiliated and beaten on several occasions.
In September 1998, while you were accompanying your common-law partner on the road leading to your home, you were approached by four men. They threatened you, Madam, with knives and raped you, taking turns, while threatening to kill you if you reported the matter to the police.
Your brother was subsequently beaten, and died several days later of his injuries, more precisely in XXXXX 1999. And in March 2001, Molotov cocktails were thrown into your home, causing a fire which simply ruined everything.
These were the circumstances in which you left your country to come to Canada.
The decision that I have rendered concerns three points: your identities, your credibility and the validity of your refugee protection claim.
IDENTITY
In light of the exhibits filed on the record and your own testimony, the panel declares itself satisfied with your identities not only as individuals, but also as persons of Gypsy origin. Your evidence was indeed completed today by Exhibit P-10,1 filed by your lawyer, which was precisely a document missing in your file.
CREDIBILITY
You, Sir, testified at length about the facts that caused you to leave Romania and come to Canada. Your testimony did have some flaws. For example, I did not believe you when you said that you had been refused a passport in 1999 because your father, or you yourself, had tried in the past to leave your country illegally, or because you were of Gypsy origin.
Nonetheless, I did not think that this could taint your testimony to the point that I would reject it. I believe that in your case, you rather chose a Hungarian passport because with such a passport, one does not need a visa to come to Canada.
Consequently, I consider that on the whole, in spite of the reservations I have mentioned, your testimony is credible.
The same may be said of your testimony, Madam, although it was very short.
VALIDITY OF THE CLAIM
You explained how you were beaten on more than one occasion, and how your attempts to obtain a remedy from the police were never taken into consideration or resulted in any investigation. And in your case, Madam, the same thing happened after you suffered a sexual assault in September 1998, in the conditions we have already described.
You, Madam, explained that you went to the police station, where you were referred to an investigator specializing in rape cases. That individual did not even deign to receive your narrative of the facts, regarding you from the outset as a liar and demanding that you provide him with the names of your attackers, and also with witnesses. In the circumstances, this was impossible.
When we look at the documentation on the status of Gypsies in Romania,2 at page 5 of Exhibit A-4, we note that it in fact discusses the many problems that Gypsies must face. Moreover, on page 41 of Exhibit A-5,3 these same problems are mentioned, problems of violence and even of excessive brutality on the part of the police.
Even more important is the fact that Exhibit A-4,4 on page 3, speaks of the apathy, insensitivity or indifference of the police towards crimes committed against Gypsies. I believe that in general, we can say that there is discrimination against Gypsies, and occasionally violence as well.
I believe that in your case, there was violence, not by the police of course. However, there was what we can call apathy or insensitivity on the part of the police, so that you were not able to benefit from the protection of the state in this particular case.
In light of all this, I think that you have proved, for the three of you, that you have a well-founded fear of persecution in the event of a return to your country.
DECISION
Consequently, the Board has determined that you, Mr. XXXXXXXX, Ms. XXXXXXXXXX and your daughter XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are "Convention refugees"5 in accordance with section 96 of the Act.

ORAL REASONS
The principal claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, is a citizen of Mexico, the country that she left in XXXXX 2001, to come to Canada with her minor daughter, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. Her other two daughters, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, came to join her in XXXXX 2001, and in the days and weeks that followed, the claimant filed an asylum claim for herself and her three daughters. She alleged a well-founded fear of persecution in Mexico because they are members of a specific social group, that of the family and of women, who run the risk of family violence.
The claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, was designated as a representative for her minor daughters for the purposes of the hearing.
The evidence revealed that, for at least ten years, the claimant cohabited with her husband at his parents' house. She said she was constantly a victim of harassment, ill treatment and violence. She was considered a servant of sorts.
Unfortunately, her husband was the victim of a car accident about five before, which made him disabled and incapable of working. This increased the dependency of the principal claimant and her family on their in-laws.
This abuse towards the principal claimant became worse when, in June 2001, the claimant caught her father-in-law trying to rape her eldest daughter, XXXXXX. The panel notes that XXXXXX attended the hearing, she is present. She is fourteen, and when her mother testified about the incident, the daughter's emotions corroborated her mother's testimony. Therefore, upon surprising her father-in-law, the claimant reacted as any woman and mother with common sense would. She took an iron and knocked out her father-in-law. Panic-stricken and intent on protecting her daughters, she left the house with the three girls and sought refuge several streets away, at the house of a woman for whom she worked part time as a servant.
The claimant said she received no news about her father-in-law's health, but the decision to leave and flee Mexico was made quite quickly. For economic reasons, the claimant could not buy four plane tickets; therefore, she decided to leave with her youngest daughter. Later on, her husband sold some furniture and found a way to pay for the fare for the two older daughters.
The copies of the passports in the file indicate that the father consented to his minor children's departure. As a whole, the testimony and the evidence indicate that the mother was a victim of violence, as well as the eldest daughter, and that it was with the goal of protecting her daughter that the mother attacked her father-in-law. The mother explained that over the past years, she endured the violence because she was scared of eventually ending up on the street with her three daughters.
Based on the documentary evidence, it is evident that the context of Mexico must be taken into account to understand the fear of the principal claimant of finding herself penniless, with three children to feed, educate and protect.
After analysing all the documentary evidence, hearing the principal claimant's testimony and considering everything, the panel came to the following conclusions.
The first issue is whether or not the objective fear of the claimant is well founded and if, as a member of the social group of women in Mexico, she is right to believe that she risks persecution if she returns there. The panel is of the opinion that, in this kind of case, it cannot analyze all the principles that govern the rights of refugees, without taking into account the claimant's particular problem.
She stated that she did not report the incident to the police over the past years. It is reasonable and completely logical to believe that, after the incident of aggression of the father-in-law towards her daughter, given that the principal claimant had just attacked him, she did not go to the police for protection. The panel is even under the impression that the fear of possibly having killed or severely hurt her father-in-law was probably the claimant's main motivation for leaving the country.
Regarding what arises from the text in response to question 37 of her Personal Information Form (PIF), the claimant was questioned about the way the facts were related. At first glance, the text was submitted before the arrival of her daughters and after the claimant found out that her father-in-law was not dead. However, the panel understands that the claimant wrote her text in Spanish before knowing her father-in-law's state of health. Further, it can definitely be interpreted that, in her text, she described the psychological state she was in when she left Mexico, because at that time she did not yet know what the father-in-law's state of health was after the tremendous blow she had dealt him with the iron.
The claimant now says that the father-in-law has recovered. However, there is no indication that he had made a complaint to the police or that he would if the claimant returned to Mexico.
This element is probably not relevant, because the documentary evidence clearly indicates that about 80% of domestic violence cases, of which this is one, since the claimant lived with her in-laws, are not reported to the authorities.
Exhibit A-6, Country Reports on Human Rights Practices 2001, in the chapter on Women, on page 20, states that only one in six victims seeks help from the authorities. The report also mentions that over 1 million women in Mexico each year seek emergency medical treatment for injuries caused by a spouse or member of the household. Both statistical reports state that there are between fifty and sixty complaints to police stations throughout the country each day. Further, the same documentary evidence and more specifically Exhibit A-11, Response to an information request No. MEX33700.E, from February 2000 (filed jointly), which refers to violence against women-a document that, in my opinion, is still current-addresses the possibility of protection for the victims of spousal abuse. The document states that, although since 1997 Mexican legislation has gone so far as to criminalize crimes of domestic violence, it seems that judges and police are the two main obstacles in implementing these laws and effectively punishing sexual crimes and crimes of violence. The evidence explains that, even today, the police do not seem to take complaints seriously because there is an old prejudice that family affairs are private and do not concern society in general. Furthermore, due most likely to their inherent conservatism, Mexican judges assess the problem in a conservative manner, which would explain why five out of six women do not even report abuse in the home to the police.
Based on these elements, the context allows the panel to conclude that, although protection exists theoretically in the legislation and the rules, in practice, this protection seems rather inadequate and ineffective, especially in disadvantaged environments and working-class neighbourhoods.
Earlier, the panel stated that the claimant's motivation for fleeing was probably the fear of being accused of physically assaulting her father-in-law. At this point, she says that her fear of returning is linked more to the fact that the family would continue to harass her. She says this because she does not want to return to live with that family, with good reason. However, her fear seems less evident because she could no doubt live far away from the family. Nevertheless, the new problem that the claimant would face is the fact that she would be alone with three minor daughters in Mexico, where the general context and conditions of society scare her.
The documentary evidence indicates that there is a very high rate of violence towards women in general. At the end of Exhibit A-11 for example, there is a document entitled Standing Fast in Mexico Protecting Women's Rights in a Hostile Climate, a report by NACLA. This document describes women who are the heads of single-parent families, which is the claimant's case, who are obligated to earn a living to feed their children. It also explains that Mexico is not well equipped with centres and schools to take care of children while the women work and that, at work, they are often the object of discrimination and violence. It states that, since the beginning of the 1990s, some two hundred young women per year are killed in certain industrial cities and that the local authorities do not investigate these murders, as if to say, "just another woman was murdered."
Several incidents of abuse in the workplace are described. Employers will even go as far as to ensure that a woman is not pregnant, and pregnant women are never hired in some industries, because they will eventually have to leave the job. These are all examples of a society to which we could not imagine the claimant returning with three young girls. The chapter on children in Country Reports on Human Rights Practices states that abuse of young children, either in prostitution or trafficking, is a major problem in Mexico.
In other words, the panel is aware of the context, present and past, of the claimant who, I think, must no longer fear being accused of assaulting her father-in-law. Nor should she fear the prospect of finding herself in a fragile situation as a woman with a teenager and two young girls, where she would continue to be the victim of major abuse of her fundamental rights and the rights of her three daughters.
Given that her three minor children are also claimants, the panel emphasizes that the Convention on the Rights of the Child, signed by Canada, stipulates that the decision-maker, whether it is a judicial officer, a police officer, a commissioner or a judge, when it is a question of children's rights, must give primary importance to the interests of the child. Because the three young girls are evidently part of a social group of young women who are members of a single-parent family in Mexico, the panel does not believe that it would be in their interest to return to Mexico in the near future.
For these reasons, the panel concludes that the claimant established the main elements of her claim for refugee protection for herself and her three minor daughters, because the panel found her testimony to be credible on the whole. Her testimony was corroborated by her daughter's non-verbal language, which was also a major element in the decision.
CONCLUSION
For all these reasons, the panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXX and her daughters, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, are "Convention refugees."

Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is an 18-year-old Djiboutian citizen. The claimant seeks "refugee status"1 based on her membership in a social group, namely, women forced into arranged marriages. Furthermore, she maintains that she is a "person in need of protection"2 because her life would be in danger, or she would be subject to cruel or unusual treatment or punishment in the Republic of Djibouti.
THE FACTS
The claimant was born in Ali Sabieh in the Republic of Djibouti on XXXXX, 1984, and is part of the ISSA-FOURLABA ethnic group. The claimant alleges that she was circumcised at age nine. In June 2001, at the end of the school year, her father informed her that she would not return to school because she had been promised in marriage to his long-time friend, XXXXXXXX, age 50. The claimant's father is a XXXXXXX and runs a retail store. He allegedly promised his youngest daughter in marriage to pay off a large sum he owed to his friend, XXXXXXXXX, a loan that he had contracted to buy animals for his business. In order that he not be dishonoured, the claimant's father dismissed all the claimant's protests.
Informed of her husband's plans, the claimant's mother, after trying in vain to change her husband's decision, made arrangements so that her daughter could leave the country and escape the forced marriage planned for her, even though it meant facing her husband's violent reaction.
The claimant left Djibouti on XXXXX, 2001, and arrived in Canada on August 17, 2001, seeking refugee status the same day.
The panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a refugee because there exists a reasonable chance of persecution if she had to return to the Republic of Djibouti.
ANALYSIS
The claimant's testimony was difficult, arduous and very strained, which the panel explains by the claimant's young age and low level of education. The claimant arrived in Canada without papers when she was only 17 years old. One month after her arrival, the claimant contacted her mother in the Republic of Djibouti so that her mother could send her proof of identity. The claimant produced a birth certificate filed as Exhibit P-2. The claimant does not have a valid passport from the Republic of Djibouti, an identity card, or any diploma. The only document that she could produce for the panel was her birth certificate. The Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) asked several questions about the Republic of Djibouti and the claimant's answers were satisfactory. The panel concludes that the claimant is a citizen of the Republic of Djibouti.
The documentary evidence, particularly Exhibit A-16,3 shows that forced marriages exist among the Issas of the Republic of Djibouti. Girls as young as 13 are offered in marriage. It specifically states the following:
[Translation]
"??? Girls who oppose forced marriages find themselves in a tragic situation. According to the counsel, they have no other recourse but to flee the family home to seek refuge with distant relatives, live in dangerous parts of cities, or find employment in the city as cleaning ladies. He added that, in desperation, some young women resort to suicide."
As explained above, the claimant's testimony was laborious, but credible. The claimant was particularly hesitant and nervous when asked about the traditions of her country and the excision that she had undergone in the past. The panel also noted some contradictions when the claimant testified that her sister, XXXXXX, was also forced into an arranged marriage. The panel explains these contradictions by the fact that the claimant was only nine at the time. However, when she spoke of her own meeting with her father, when he explained why he had accepted this arrangement, her testimony became much clearer and more direct. The panel appreciates the claimant's youth and innocence and finds it entirely plausible that, faced with settling a pressing debt, the claimant's father offered the claimant in marriage to his creditor, despite his wife's disagreement. It is also plausible that her mother kept utterly secret all her arrangements to enable her youngest daughter to flee the Republic of Djibouti.
The claimant has been of age since XXXXXX, 2002, but she fled her country when she was a minor. From the claimant's testimony, it is obvious that the parting with her mother was very distressing. It is also evident that she misses her mother enormously. The panel has no reason to doubt what the claimant alleges to have lived through.
To this effect, the panel cites an extract from paragraphs 215 and 216 of the Handbook for Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status:4
"?...? a person of 16 or over may be regarded as sufficiently mature to have a well-founded fear of persecution.
?...? a minor's mental maturity must normally be determined in the light of his personal, family and cultural background."
Furthermore, the panel is of the opinion that the decision in Vidhani5 should be taken into consideration:
"?...? women who are forced into marriages against their will have had a basic human right violated. There are United Nations conventions to which Canada is a party which state that the right to enter freely into marriage is a basic human right."
The panel also wishes to refer to one of the Guidelines Issued by the Chairperson,6 which lists four general categories of women who are at risk of persecution. The fourth category is described as follows:
"Women who fear persecution as the consequence of failing to conform to, or for transgressing, certain gender-discriminating religious or customary laws and practices in their country of origin. Such laws and practices, by singling out women and placing them in a more vulnerable position than men, may create conditions for the existence of a gender-defined social group. The religious precepts, social traditions or cultural norms which women may be accused of violating can range from choosing their own spouses instead of accepting an arranged marriage, to such matters as the wearing of make-up, the visibility or length of hair, or the type of clothing a woman chooses to wear."
The documentary evidence indicates that protection from the State is non-existent. In this regard, Exhibit A-167 states as follows:
[Translation]
"??? in principle, there exist laws against such practices. However, they are not applied and no authority dares to intervene in the traditional practices for fear of "social disruption."
The panel also considers that no internal flight alternative was available to the claimant. In the Republic of Djibouti, a small country where culture and religion are a very important, it is illusory to think that at age 17, the claimant could have escaped from her marriage.
Considering all of the above, the panel determines that Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a "Convention refugee," as defined in section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

The claimant, Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is a 28-year-old citizen of Costa Rica. She claims refugee status on the ground that she risks being killed in her country by a young hoodlum whom she saw commit a murder. She alleges that she belongs to the social group of "women who are victims of threats and violence in Costa Rica," and that, by reason of her membership in this particular group, she risks persecution in her country.
The claimant also claims to be a person in need of protection because of the young hoodlum's death threats against her.
ALLEGED FACTS
The claimant worked in a small XXXX in Cartago. She often finished work very late because she had to close the cash. Around 11:30 p.m. on XXXX, 2001, she was waiting alone at the bus stop, which was two blocks away from the XXXX, for the last bus to take her home.
She saw two young men whom she recognized because they sometimes begged her for stale bread. They had a bad reputation in the neighbourhood, and she described them as "drug addicts." One was named XXXXXX and the other XXXXXX.
Seeing that they seemed to be arguing, the claimant tried to go unnoticed, moving away a few dozen metres. Suddenly, she heard a gunshot. Turning around, she saw XXXXXX fall to the ground and XXXXXX run away.
The claimant went home in a taxi and related to her parents what had happened. They told her not to tell anyone because of the bad reputation of XXXXXX and his gang of hoodlums.
Two weeks later, XXXXXX came into the XXXX and threatened her, telling her to keep quiet if she wanted to ensure she and her family stayed alive.
She stated that she had no further direct contact with XXXXXX, except that he would sometimes pass in front of the XXXXXX. However, in August 2001 she started receiving anonymous threats over the telephone and in letters, ordering her to keep quiet if she did not want her two children to be killed.
The claimant obtained a passport on XXXXX, 2001 and fled Costa Rica on XXXXX, 2001. She arrived in Canada that same day but did not ask for international protection until September 17, 2001.
The claimant stated that she never filed a complaint with the Costarican police because she was afraid that XXXXXX would retaliate. She stated that she could not have lived safely in another part of Costa Rica because it is a very small country and, since she was the sole supporter of her two children and her parents, she did not have the means to leave her house in Cartago and then rent a place in San Juan or elsewhere.
ISSUES TO BE RESOLVED
Are the claimant's statements credible?
Does the claimant belong to a "particular social group" within the meaning given by the Supreme Court of Canada in Ward?i Does she risk persecution by reason of her affiliation with this group?
If not, does she meet all of the criteria set out in section 97(1)ii in order to be recognized as a person in need of protection?
ANALYSIS
1- Identity
The claimant satisfactorily established her identity by submitting her passport and national identity card as evidence.
2- Credibility
The claimant testified convincingly: she gave precise answers and her written narrative did not contradict her oral testimony.
However, at first glance, it did not seem plausible that the young hoodlum, XXXXXX, would have waited two weeks before warning the claimant against any attempt to compromise or expose him. Was it not in the murderer's best interest to quickly ensure the silence of the only eyewitness to his crime? Similarly, it does not seem very logical to believe that he would have waited five months before threatening her again, as there does not seem to have been any reason for a sudden series of threats after such a long time. And this series of anonymous calls and letters on an almost daily basis, between XXXX, 2001 and the date the claimant left the country on XXXXX, 2001 is like a scene from an operetta because this uninterrupted flood of threats, strangely enough, is in stark contrast to the earlier silence of the persecuting agent.
However, taking into consideration the claimant's obvious sincerity, there is reason to give her the benefit of the doubt regarding the alleged facts, despite reservations based on what seem to be exaggerations about the threats.
The panel therefore accepts that the claimant witnessed a murder; that she said nothing to the police and that her life was threatened by a young hoodlum from Cartago, who would certainly not want to go to prison.
3- Membership in a social group
Through her lawyer, the claimant submitted that she was a member of the particular social group of "women who are victims of threats and violence in Costa Rica" and that she risked persecution by reason of this membership.
It is true that the documentary evidence produced indicates to what point violence against women, especially domestic violence, constitutes a serious problem in Costa Rica, a country that is, moreover, highly renowned for its democratic values and the genuine efforts of the authorities and institutions in respecting human rights. Documents A-4 and A-12 provide ample evidence of this.
Nevertheless, even though Costa Rica's situation illustrates the vulnerability of women in a society that is still very chauvinistic, this case has nothing in common with a typical case of domestic violence. Here, the claimant is in danger because a murderer does not want to be betrayed. She is personally targeted because of her actions, because she witnessed a crime being committed.
In considering everything from the persecutor's point of view, one has to conclude that the claimant was targeted simply because she was an unwanted witness, and not because she belonged to a group.
Claiming that the claimant is affiliated with the group of women who are victims of threats and violence in Costa Rica amounts to saying that she risks persecution because she is a victim of persecution, whereas, in Canadian law, it is now well established that the persecution must be based on the affiliation with a social group, and not that the social group must be made up of persecuted persons. It is the membership in the social group that must give rise to the persecution.
Therefore, according to all the evidence, the claimant does not risk being persecuted based on the fact that she is a member of a group, because her problem is too individual in nature.
She is afraid of revenge or criminal pressure directed at her, but not persecution within the meaning of the definition of a refugee.
4- Protection
Even if there existed a nexus with one of the five grounds for persecution, the claimant could not qualify as a refugee because she did not seek the protection that is assumed to have been available in her country, since she never made a complaint to the authorities.
She alleged that she did not do this because she was afraid of XXXXXX, who, she said, was part of the mafia. When she was asked to provide more details about this, she stated that XXXXXX's gang of hoodlums included three girls and five guys.
The panel considers that this is not a mafia and that a gang of delinquent youths such as this did not likely constitute an insurmountable problem for the police in her country.
5- Risk to life
All of the evidence presented by the claimant leads to the conclusion that a number of the requirements of section 97(1)(b) defining a person in need of protection applied in her case, except for the major requirement regarding the need to be subject to a risk to her life in every part of her country, according to subparagraph (ii) of section 97(1)(b) and, as noted above, the fact that she did not seek the protection of her country.
The claimant was personally issued a death threat. Because of this threat, she does not want to return to her country. Other people from her country are not usually faced with such a threat, and it is certainly not the result of lawful sanctions or deficiencies in health or medical care.
However, considering the person who issued the death threat against the claimant, it is very difficult to believe that this threat would exist everywhere in that country. In fact, according to the evidence, this individual is a young drug-using hoodlum from a Cartago neighbourhood who begs for bread, hassles the local people and enjoys scaring young schoolgirls, according to what the claimant said. Of course, he allegedly killed one of his friends, but can we believe that he would be capable of following the claimant all over Costa Rica? The evidence presented is far from being reasonably convincing in this respect, especially as the claimant herself never tried to get protection from the police in her country.
The claimant pointed out that she needed to work at the XXXXXX as the sole supporter of her family, that it would have been difficult to find a well-paying job elsewhere, considering the economic conditions of the country, and that she did not have the financial means to give up her house in Cartago and find rental accommodation in a big city or elsewhere in Costa Rica.
Apart from the fact that she nevertheless undertook an expensive trip to Canada, this argument is not relevant in this case because, with regard to subparagraph (ii) of section 97(1)(b), the real test is to determine whether the claimant faces a risk to her life everywhere in her country. If she does not establish that this is the case, and it turns out that she is not reasonably subject to this risk everywhere in Costa Rica, the claimant will have failed in her claim. On this point, the Act places emphasis on facing a risk to life in every part of that country, and not on whether it was reasonably convenient and safe to seek protection elsewhere in that country.
The evidence does not therefore allow us to conclude that the claimant has discharged the burden of proof on her to establish all the facts required to be recognized as a person in need of protection under section 97(1)(b).
6- Torture
The above determination is strengthened by the fact that nothing in the evidence allows us to conclude that the claimant would risk torture in Costa Rica, within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture.
DETERMINATION
For these reasons, the panel determines that the claimant, Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is not a "Convention refugee" or a "person in need of protection."

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and her daughter, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, both Peruvian nationals, were born on XXXXXX, 1961 and XXXX, 1995 respectively. They claim that they have a well-founded fear of being persecuted in their country by the XXXXXX XXXXX XXXXXXX and his men, for the following reasons: the political opinion imputed to the principal claimant; the membership of the claimants in a particular social group, namely the family; and their membership in a particular social group, namely women. Furthermore, they claim that they are "persons in need of protection" because their life would be threatened or they would be at risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
ALLEGATIONS
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX was a member of the former Fujimori party. A XXXXX affiliated with the police, he was involved in illegal work, practising terror by murdering people. He was a member of the same family as the principal claimant's husband and father of the principal claimant's daughter.
The principal claimant went to the United States to buy merchandise that would have enabled her to set up a business in her country. When she returned, she found XXXXXXXXXXXXXX in her home. According to her husband, XXXXXXXX was going to spend a few days with them. The claimant refused because XXXXXXXX was regarded as a person involved in irregular dealings. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX said disgraceful things to the claimant, declaring that it was his money that she had used in the United States. For his part, the claimant's ex-husband punched her in the face.
The claimant subsequently had other problems. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX's people beat her, and her husband informed her that he was going to leave the country and that she should be on her guard. The claimant then decided to leave her country and go to the United States.
She left Peru on XXXXX 2001 for the United States. She remained there until XXXXXX, 2001 and then arrived in Canada on October 20, 2001.
PRELIMINARY AND INCIDENTAL PROCEEDINGS
The panel designated the principal claimant as representative of her minor daughter.
During the hearing, counsel for the claimants stated that certain questions asked by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) were too vague and that the claimants were unable to answer them properly. The panel allowed counsel the necessary time to produce evidence in support of this statement. Counsel declined the invitation, but when the panel insisted, counsel's concerns were clarified. The panel insisted on this out of a concern for natural justice and transparency. It was important that all the points concerning the claimants be heard.
Furthermore, an important sentence had been omitted in the French translation of Question 37 of the Personal Information Form (PIF), and the panel therefore insisted that the words of the claimant be checked in the original, with the assistance of the interpreter. The paragraph was translated during the hearing, and it was clarified that the claimant had stated, in the original, that she had been beaten and attacked by her husband, but that this fact had not been mentioned in the [French] text of the answer to Question 37.
DETERMINATION
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) has concluded that the claimants have not produced enough evidence to establish that they personally come within the definition of "Convention refugee,"1 pursuant to section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act or of "person in need of protection"2 pursuant to sections 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Act.
ANALYSIS
The identities of the claimants as Peruvian nationals have been established by the copies of their passports and by the principal claimant's identity card. These documents were retained by Immigration.
In her representations, the RPO raised a number of points showing that the principal claimant lacked credibility. Given the concern of counsel for the claimants, who declared that the questions were too vague and that the answers given could thereby be affected, the panel has decided, in making its decision, to take into account, in particular, the questions that the panel itself put to the claimant.
The panel's negative determination is essentially based on two considerations: state protection; and an internal flight alternative within Peru if the claimant really did not feel safe in Lima.
According to the panel's assessment, the documentary evidence establishes that there is a legal and judicial system in Peru capable of protecting the nationals of that country. In particular, there is a police force, an army and courts. While a presumption does exist that states are able to protect their nationals, the claimant was free, in accordance with the law, to rebut this presumption of protection by producing clear and convincing evidence. On the basis of the evidence presented, including the documentary evidence on the current situation in the claimant's country, the panel finds that the claimant has not succeeded in rebutting this presumption. The claimant has not succeeded in establishing, in a clear and convincing manner, that the Peruvian state is unable to grant her the normal protection in effect in her country.
Furthermore, because of the current situation in Peru and the circumstances of the former president, Fujimori, the claimant's persecutor, who was an important source of support for the Fujimori group, is himself in prison. In the panel's opinion, his men surely have better things to do than to go looking for the claimant. They are probably busy trying to hide and save their own lives.
The panel does not see why the claimant could not lay a complaint today against all the persons she fears, to help the government find them. That this is possible seems even more clear from the documentary evidence, which very clearly indicates that the government is offering assistance and protection to anyone who lays a complaint against corruption and against any individuals directly or indirectly involved in illegal business, of the kind in which XXXXXXXXXXXXXX was involved. The claimant was unable to offer any coherent explanations on this point.
There is a wealth of documentary evidence concerning all the individuals who have been prosecuted by the current Peruvian authorities for corruption. Whether these individuals are generals, whether they occupy high-ranking positions-indeed, whatever their position-the government has taken measures to find them and arrest them. Furthermore, all this documentary evidence, which the panel went over with the claimant, also mentions the protection that the authorities are offering to those who are helping, precisely, to find these individuals. The panel cannot rely on the claimant's answers because they are not reasonable.
The claimant alleged that she filed a complaint. In her complaint, however, she did not mention the name of her persecutor, XXXXXXXX, as the source of her problems. The panel does not see how the claimant could avail herself of the protection of the state without naming her persecutor, when she knew him perfectly well. The second complaint that she allegedly laid was against her ex-husband, but here again, the claimant did not indicate that this individual-whose name she in fact gives-is the father of her daughter and the person with whom she lived. There are special laws concerning conjugal violence, and assistance is given to victims of such violence. The panel does not see why the claimant failed to indicate this important fact. The panel does not find the claimant's answers to be satisfactory.
Furthermore, even if the claimant had some fear of her alleged persecutor, her husband, she herself declared in her answer to Question 37 that he had left the country. Consequently, the claimant has not established in evidence that her husband would be a danger to her today if she were to return to her country.
In addition, if the claimant was experiencing some fear in Lima, the fact is that Peru has 25 million inhabitants. The panel estimated that the claimant, who speaks Spanish, who is educated and who wanted to open a shop in Lima, could have taken refuge in another city of Peru. Ms. XXXXX XXXXXX was asked what the second largest city in her country was, and why she could not go and settle there. The claimant stated that Arequipo is the second largest city, but that she could not live there because she did not have any friends there. She wanted to do business on the basis of her circle of friends, who were in Lima.
The claimant also said that she feared the criminal activity in Arequipo. However, at no time did she say that she would fear her alleged persecutors, who might find her in Arequipo. It was instead the general situation that she would fear. She said that in Arequipo, all the houses have iron bars on the windows because of the crime, and she would not want her daughter to be raised in that kind of ambiance.
Given the claimant's profile, the documentary evidence and the answers she gave, which show that she does not fear her alleged persecutors, the panel is of the opinion that the claimant could seek refuge elsewhere in Peru.
Consequently, the panel finds that if the claimant were really afraid, she could not only avail herself of the protection of the authorities of her country, who are vigorously hunting down the ex-Fujimorists-a group to which her agents of persecution belong-but could also very well go and live in Arequipo, given her profile, since there is no indication in the documentary evidence that it is impossible for Peruvians to move around within their country. The claimant speaks Spanish, and because of her level of education, she would not have any problem finding work.
For the reasons stated above, the panel determines that the claimants are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection. Consequently, the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) rejects their refugee protection claims.

THE FACTS
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and his wife, XXXXXXXXX, are citizens of Colombia.
The refugee protection claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXX, worked as an XXXXXXXX in the office of the XXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXX. In the summer of 1999, after he had prepared a report on a drug trafficker, he received a call on his cell phone, the confidential number of which was only known to a few of his colleagues at work. The caller said that he wanted the claimant to alter the file of the drug trafficker in question, an individual by the name of XXXXX, in return for which he would be paid a large bribe. If he did not alter the file, he would die.
The claimant later received other threats, to prevent him from testifying at XXXXXX preliminary inquiry.
The claimant did not dare to talk about these threats to his superiors, as he suspected that some of his colleagues were involved in the affair because his confidential number had been used and because it is well known that police officers are accomplices of drug traffickers in Colombia.
Fearing for his life and that of his wife, he decided to flee to the United States on XXXXX, 1999.
He settled in Florida and worked illegally to survive. However, he did not claim protection from the Americans because he was afraid of being sent back to his country.
In XXXXXXX 2001, he received bizarre telephone calls, in which the caller attempted to confirm who he was. In a panic, he contacted a former colleague who was a refugee in Canada. He set out for Canada and arrived at the Canadian border with his wife on November 6, 2001.
ANALYSIS
Both claimants have established their identity in a satisfactory manner.
Their counsel had failed to produce an official document confirming that the male claimant did indeed work as an XXXXXXXX with the XXXXXXX, although the claimant had given him this evidence in July 2002. This document was finally produced a few days after the hearing.
The male claimant and his wife seemed to me to be sincere and trustworthy. The claimant testified in a direct, frank and spontaneous manner. The claimants were found to be credible.
The only real issue to be determined is whether their lives would be at risk if they returned to Colombia.
The documentary evidence abundantly reveals the very high level of widespread violence that is currently rampant in Colombia. There is no doubt that XXXXXXX working for the XXXXX, like the male claimant, are at risk of being killed by drug traffickers, corrupt police officers or armed groups involved in the drug trade.
Hundreds of assassinations of public officials show that there is no state protection for anyone in Colombia. It therefore appears obvious that the claimant and his wife would be subject to a risk to their lives everywhere in their country.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, I determine that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX are "persons in need of protection", pursuant to section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, and I therefore accept their claim for refugee protection.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are Peruvian nationals. They were born in 1966, 1969, 1991 and 1999 respectively. They maintain that they have a well-founded fear of persecution in Peru by reason of the particular social group to which they belong. In the case of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, this is the particular social group of women. In the case of her husband and her two children, the particular social group is the family.
The claimants also allege that they are "persons in need of protection", pursuant to section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ALLEGATIONS
In 1991, the principal claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, married XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXXXX. She had a series of problems and very quickly realized that this man was violent. In 1995, the couple separated, but after the separation, Mr. XXXXX continued to assault the female claimant. On XXXXX, 1998 the marriage was dissolved.
The female claimant, who got to know her second husband in November 1997, remarried on XXXXXX, 2000. Threats from her ex-husband then intensified. In XXXXX 2001, the claimants were physically assaulted near their home. They made a complaint to the police in XXXXXX 2001, but realized that the police officers had no interest in taking action with respect to their case. They decided to leave their county.
This sums up the alleged facts that were brought before the panel.
DECISION
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) has arrived at the following conclusion:
The claimants are not "Convention refugees"1 because they do not have a well-founded fear of persecution based on one of the Convention grounds.
Furthermore, the claimants are not "persons in need of protection"2 because their removal to Peru would not personally subject them to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. Moreover, there are no substantial grounds for believing that they would be personally subject to a danger of torture if they were to be sent back to Peru.
ANALYSIS
The identity of the claimants as Peruvian nationals has been established through their testimony and by various documents filed in support of their claim, namely Exhibits P-7,3 P-84 and A-3.5
In the first place, the panel cannot consider section 97(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act because the perpetrator of the alleged harm is neither an officer of the public service nor a person acting in an official capacity or at his own instigation or with the expressed or implied consent of the state. The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) will therefore conduct its analysis by taking into account section 96 and section 97(1)(b).
The panel has rejected the refugee protection claim of Ms. XXXXXXXXX and her family because they are not credible with respect to state protection. They are also not credible concerning an internal flight alternative. Finally, the attitude of the claimants is not that of persons who have a serious or reasonable fear of being persecuted or being subject to a risk of death or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
State protection
As for state protection, regardless of whether section 96 or section 97(1)(b) is considered, the claimants had to prove that the state was unable to protect them.
Given the fact that the perpetrator of the harm feared by the claimants is not an agent of the state, but simply the female claimant's ex-husband, XXXXXXXXX, the panel has attempted to assess whether the claimants properly availed themselves of the protection of their country's authorities before claiming international protection. The claimants have not succeeded in establishing, in a clear and convincing manner, that the Peruvian state was unable to accord them the normal protection in effect in their country.
According to the panel's assessment, the documentary evidence has established that there is a legal and judicial framework in Peru that is capable of protecting the nationals of that country. In particular, there is a police force, an army and courts. According to the documentary evidence, even a law on domestic violence has been promulgated. Although states are presumed capable of protecting their nationals, the claimants were free, under the law, to rebut this presumption of state protection by producing clear and convincing evidence. On the basis of the evidence presented by the claimants, the panel can only conclude that the claimants have not succeeded in rebutting this presumption.
The claimants alleged that they have filed complaints on two occasions since they have been together and had problems with XXXXXXX. They said that they filed a complaint for the first time in XXXX 1998, and a second time in XXXXX 2001. The explanations that the claimants gave concerning these two complaints were rather inconsistent.
For example, regarding an attack that they allegedly suffered in XXXXX 2001, the claimants only laid a complaint on XXXXX, 2001, one month later. Furthermore, Mr. XXXXX XXXX, the husband of the principal claimant, declared that on the morning of XXXXX, they received threats, in the sense that the female claimant's ex-husband made death threats against them. However, at 10:30 a.m., when the male claimant went to the police to lay a complaint, he did not mention these threats. He only spoke of the incident of XXXXXX 2001. The panel finds it implausible that he would not have mentioned this incident. Furthermore, immediately after this complaint was filed, the claimants decided to leave their country. The panel is of the opinion that the mere fact that the claimants filed a complaint is insufficient to discharge the burden on them to prove that the Peruvian state was unable to protect them.
Internal flight alternative - Convention refugees
The panel verified whether there was a reasonable internal flight alternative for the refugee protection claimants. This issue was brought to their attention because if they had problems with the principal claimant's ex-husband, they could very well have sought refuge in some other place, even in Lima, since that city has several million inhabitants. According to the panel's assessment of the evidence, the claimants would not face a serious possibility of persecution in another part of the country or in another city of Peru.
The claimants, who alleged that they had had all these problems, stated that since they have been married, they have never moved and have never made any effort to go and live in another quarter of the city or in another city. Given the fact that it is the principal claimant's ex-husband whom they allegedly fear, and not the authorities, the panel does not see any reason why the claimants could not go and settle elsewhere in order to live in peace. They speak Spanish, and there is no restriction on movement within the country.
The principal claimant explained that her ex-husband could find them anywhere in Peru. However, she was unable to satisfy the panel of this or give any valid reason, except to say that she felt safer near her parents and family, while elsewhere, she would not have her family to protect her. After examining conditions in the country and the profile of the claimants and of their alleged agent of persecution, the panel finds that it would not be objectively unreasonable for the claimants to go and live in another quarter of Lima or in another city of Peru, especially since the principal claimant is not a woman alone, but is married.
Internal flight alternative - risk to life and risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment
The panel finds that an internal flight alternative is reasonably accessible to the claimants, since the documentary evidence does not indicate that Peruvians cannot move freely from one region to another.
In the final analysis, the panel has considered the claimants' behaviour throughout these last two years. The claimants all had passports and American visas from the year 2000 on. However, they did not leave their country. The male principal claimant, who had already gone to the United States, went back to Peru and only left Peru on November 8, 2001. Furthermore, the claimants passed through the United States, but did not claim refugee protection in that country.
A number of facts have led the panel to the conclusion that the claimants do not exhibit the behaviour of persons who have the fear they allege. In the first place, the claimants did not move to another neighbourhood, even within Lima, or to some other place in Peru. Secondly, they did not leave Peru earlier. Thirdly, in the case of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, he returned voluntarily to a country where he alleged that he faces a serious possibility or reasonable chance of being persecuted or subject to a risk of death or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. Finally, the claimants did not claim refugee protection in the United States, a country though which they travelled.
The arguments that the claimants made concerning this behaviour cannot hold up because the jurisprudence of the Federal Court is clear on this point. The panel quite simply finds that the explanations given by the claimants are difficult to accept.
Regarding their allegation that they are "Convention refugees", the panel would like to refer to the decision by the Federal Court in Ilie:6
[TRANSLATION] A claimant's failure to claim refugee status in a country that is a signatory to the 1967 Protocol negates the claim of a fear of persecution.
In Leul,7 Mr. Justice Muldoon noted:
Just as I would not wish to send back to his country a person who stood in jeopardy of a reasonable chance of persecution, so I just do not wish to leave in Canada a person who isn't entitled to be here; a person who passed through a country which was a signatory to the convention and did not think to claim refugee status there.
Finally, the panel also refers to the decision in the case of Hibo Farah Mohamed and Ardo Abdi Omer,8 rendered on April 9, 1997, in which Rothstein J. stated the following:
The Geneva Convention exists for persons who require protection and not to assist persons who simply prefer asylum in one country over another. The Convention and the Immigration Act should be interpreted with the correct purpose in mind.
To prove that they are "Convention refugees" or "persons in need of protection", the claimants had to establish that they would face a serious possibility or reasonable chance of being persecuted, a serious possibility or reasonable chance of being tortured, or a serious possibility or reasonable chance of being subject to a risk of death or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if they had to return to their country of origin.
However, the claimants, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, her husband, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and their two children, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, have not presented sufficient credible evidence to establish that they are "Convention refugees", pursuant to section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or that they are "persons in need of protection", pursuant to sections 97(1)(a) and (b) of the same Act.
Their claim is therefore rejected.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 35 years of age, and his wife, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 33 years of age, are both citizens of Venezuela. They arrived in Canada on September 6, 2001 with their four minor children: their eldest daughter, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 10 years of age and a citizen of Venezuela; and their three younger children, who were born in the United States of America and are therefore American citizens, namely XXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 5 years of age, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 3 years of age, and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, who is 2 years of age. The couple were also accompanied by XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Venezuela who is 20 years years old and the brother of the female claimant. The claimants made a claim for refugee protection at the port of entry.
The principal claimant alleges that he has a well-founded fear of persecution in his country by reason of the political opinion imputed to him and his membership in a particular social group, namely citizens who are victims of police corruption. The other claimants allege that they have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of their membership in a particular social group, the family.
All the claimants also maintain that they are persons in need of protection because they would be personally subject to a danger of torture, to a risk to their lives or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if they had to return to Venezuela.
At the beginning of the hearing, the panel designated XXXXXXXXXXXXXX as representative of his minor children for the purposes of the hearing. The principal claimant said that his children, who are American citizens, have no fear of persecution in the United States, but that the family would have to remain together if they had to return to Venezuela.
THE EVIDENCE
The evidence in this case was presented by the claimants, by their lawyer and by the refugee protection officers (RPOs) unit. This evidence consists of the claimants' Personal Information Forms (PIFs), their identity papers, the testimony of the adult claimants, and documents concerning the sociopolitical situation in Venezuela. The principal claimant was practically the only person to testify at the hearing. His wife and brother-in-law merely confirmed his statements. In his PIF and in his oral testimony, the principal claimant alleged the following facts:
Since XXXX 1993, the principal claimant had worked as a police officer in the drug squad in XXXXXXX, in the state of XXXXXXX. He began to suffer persecution from some fellow police officers on XXXXX, 1995, after he had arrested two drug traffickers who were under the protection of the highest-ranking police authorities in the city of XXXXXXX and the state of XXXXXXX, namely Inspector XXXXXXXX and Lieutenant XXXXXXX. After being forced to release his prisoners, and after refusing a bribe of US$2,000 from Lieutenant XXXXXXX, the principal claimant undertook to investigate the relationship between the XXXXXXX duo and the drug traffickers. As a result of his investigation, he realized that a number of fellow police officers were part of the network for protecting the drug traffickers and received generous compensation. On XXXXX 1995 the principal claimant turned down an invitation from Lieutenant XXXXXX to join the network.
On XXXXX 1995 the public prosecutor's office refused to follow up on the principal claimant's information against XXXXXXX and XXXXXXX, for lack of evidence. From that time on, the principal claimant was under constant pressure from members of the network. On XXXXX 1995 a stone with a written note was thrown through the window of his house. The note contained a threat that he would be made to pay for being an informer. The principal claimant attributed this note to XXXXXXX and to XXXXXXX. On XXXXX, 1995, individuals wearing hoods attacked him with daggers. Nineteen stitches were required to close up his wounds, and he was hospitalized until XXXXXX, 1995. When he was released from the hospital, he immediately fled to the island of Margarita with his family, where he started to work as a taxi driver. On XXXX, 1995, three men attacked him in his taxi and attempted to cut his throat. After escaping this last attack, he decided to leave Venezuela.
After arriving in the United States on XXXXX, 1995 with his wife and daughter, the principal claimant attempted to regularize his situation by entrusting his case to an immigration consultant on January 8, 1996. On July 22, 1999, he learned of the arrest of the consultant, who had defrauded several immigrant families.
From XXXXXX to XXXX 2000, his wife made a trip to Venezuela with the children, to visit the family. At the end of this trip, she returned to the United States with her brother, XXXXX. The principal claimant also made a trip to Venezuela on XXXXX, 2001, to assess the possibility of returning there with his family. At that time, he learned that corruption was even more widespread than in the past since his two principal agents of persecution had still more power and influence. Inspector XXXXXXX had been promoted to the position of XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX of the police in the state of XXXXXXX, while XXXXXXXX XXXXXXX had been appointed to the even more prestigious position of XXXXXXX of the National Police of Venezuela, in XXXXXXX, with the title of XXXXXXX Approximately one week after his arrival in Venezuela, the principal claimant received explicit threats from these two individuals, in which they gave him two weeks to leave the country. After attempting to obtain a Canadian visa in XXXXXXX, without success, the principal claimant returned to the United States on XXXX, 2001. Two months later, on XXXXX, 2001, the entire family arrived in Canada and claimed refugee protection at the border.
DECISION
The panel determines that the claimants do not have a well-founded fear of persecution for the reasons they allege. The panel also determines that they are not persons in need of protection because their return to Venezuela would not subject them personally to a risk to their lives, to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
The identities of the refugee protection claimants could be established satisfactorily by means of the documents produced in evidence, namely their passports, birth certificates and national identity cards, and the couple's marriage certificate.
The analysis of all the evidence submitted leads the panel to find that the claimants have not discharged the burden on them of establishing that they have a well-founded fear of persecution in Venezuela. The panel cannot find their story credible because of the inconsistencies, omissions, discrepancies, implausibilities and contradictions noted in the PIF, in the testimony of the principal claimant, and in the documents filed in evidence, for which no satisfactory explanation was given.
In the first place, the panel does not believe that the principal claimant really fled Venezuela on XXXXXXX, 1995 to go and settle in the United States, in order to escape his alleged agents of persecution. According to the notes of the immigration officer, when the principal claimant arrived in Canada on September 6, 2001, he did everything he could to conceal his passport.
Mr. XXXXX presented three US birth certificates for his children... after numerous questions, Mr. XXXXX claimed he had been travelling back and forth from Venezuela to Mexico to USA. After several questions, Mr. XXXXX lied several times during this examination. Mr. XXXXX has stated that his passport was lost in the USA. I was not satisfied with his answers and continued to interview why he submitted an application for a visitor visa to XXXXXXX as notes revealed he had no problems in Venezuela. I, then, asked Mr. XXXXX again for his passport and he replied that "it was lost". I advised Mr. XXXXX that I would search all his belongings..... I gave him one more chance to produce the identity documents and he went to his youngest child's infant seat and under the child was various passports from USA and Venezuela .....
An examination of the principal claimant's passport reveals why he made such an effort to hide it. On page 4 of the passport, it is indicated that he did indeed leave Venezuela on XXXXXX 1995 for the United States; however, he returned to Venezuela on XXXXX, 1995. It is also indicated on page 24 of the passport that he was allowed into the United States for the period from XXXX 2001 to XXXXX, 2001. On pages 26 and 27, it can be seen that his passport was renewed on XXXXX, 2001 in the city of XXXXX for a period of five years, expiring on XXXX, 2006. On page 7 of the passport, there is a stamp attesting to his departure from Venezuela for the United States on XXXXX 2001. In the panel's opinion, this information contradicts the principal claimant's oral testimony and the allegations contained in his PIF.
In his PIF and in his oral testimony, the principal claimant described a single trip to Venezuela, on XXXX, 2001. He tried to explain this trip, and the trip that his wife allegedly made in XXXXX 2000, by saying that he had managed to make use of an American multiple-entry visa by bribing an employee of United States Immigration. The employee had managed to place several stamps in the couple's passports so that it would seem as if the two adult claimants had made several trips to Venezuela. The panel finds this explanation to be unclear and implausible. In any case, a single trip by the claimant to his country would have been sufficient to cast doubt on his fear of persecution. According to the information in his passport, it is clear that he probably spent most of his time in his own country, making sporadic trips to the United States using his multiple-entry visa. In the panel's opinion, this fact irremediably damages his credibility.
On the subject of the alleged agents of persecution, who were supposedly given important positions in 2001, the panel submitted an information request and received the response, XXXXXXXX filed as Exhibit A-17. The information in this response does not support the principal claimant's allegations. The panel does not attach any credibility to the principal claimant's affidavit filed as Exhibit P-21, according to which he felt even more threatened because XXXXXXX had been fired. According to the newspaper article filed as Exhibit P-22, on XXXXX, 2001 XXXX XXXXXXX was removed from his position as XXXXXXXXXXXX of the municipality of XXXXXXX, the city where the principal claimant renewed his passport on XXXX, 2001, contrary to the principal claimant's statements at the hearing that XXXXX XXXXXXX had become XXXXXXX and XXXXXXXX of the police of the state of XXXXXXX, of which the city of XXXXXXX is the capital.
The panel accords no probative value to the document filed as Exhibit P-15, which according to the principal claimant was issued by the Ministry of the Interior and of Justice. This document does not agree with the principal claimant's PIF, according to which the information he laid was rejected due to lack of evidence.
Even if the credibility of the principal claimant had not been so profoundly undermined, he would have had to explain why he did not act diligently to obtain the protection of the United States, a country where he claims he lived for nearly six years, from XXXXXX 1995 to XXXXXX 2001. The misadventure with the immigration consultant, who was supposed to take steps to regularize the family's status, is not enough to justify the principal claimant's failure to claim refugee protection in a country that is a signatory to the Geneva Convention.
Because of the discrepancies, contradictions and implausibilities raised at the hearing, the panel cannot find credible the fear of persecution alleged by the claimants. The panel finds that the words of MacGuigan J. in Sheikh are directly applicable to the present case:
[...] even without disbelieving every word an applicant has uttered, a first-level panel may reasonably find him so lacking in credibility that it concludes there is no credible evidence relevant to his claim [...]. In other words, a general finding of a lack of credibility on the part of the applicant may conceivably extend to all relevant evidence emanating from his testimony.
CONCLUSION
The evidence presented is insufficient to allow the panel to establish that if the claimants returned to Venezuela, they would face a serious possibility of being persecuted within the meaning of the decision in Adjei.
The panel determines that the claimants, XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, his wife, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, their minor children, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXand XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and also the brother of the female claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, are neither Convention refugees under section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act nor persons in need of protection under section 97(1) of the Act. Consequently, their refugee protection claims are rejected.
