XXXXXXXXXXXX is a 25-year-old citizen of the Republic of Mali. He alleges that he has a well-founded fear of persecution in his country of citizenship by reason of his race, namely the fact that he is a member the Soninke ethnic group. He also alleges that he is a person in need of protection because he would be subject to a risk to his life and to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he had to return to the Republic of Mali.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant is a member of the Soninke ethnic group living in the village of XXXXXXX, situated XXX km XXXXXX of Yélimané. The Soninke are known for their agricultural and commercial activities. XXXXXXXX is in the vicinity of the [TRANSLATION] "Peul encampment and village", the Peul being a nomadic and/or sedentary people known for raising animals.
The conflict between these two ethnic groups developed because the herds belonging to the Peul were [TRANSLATION] "ravaging" the fields belonging to the Soninke that were under cultivation. In spite of agreements among [TRANSLATION] "the sages of the villages" to prevent such incidents, the Peul continued to drive their herds into the fields of the Soninke and went so far as to loot Soninke shopkeepers and [TRANSLATION] "eliminate the notables" of the Soninke.
The lack of security experienced by the Soninke drove the young people of the village of XXXXXXXXXX to form an association on XXXXXXXX, 1998. This association, called the "XXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX" (XXXXXXX) [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX] was set up [TRANSLATION] "to watch over the fields under cultivation and security in the villages." The refugee protection claimant was appointed vice-president of the XXXX. The principal objectives of the XXXX were to enforce the agreements made by the [TRANSLATION] "village sages", to prevent the Peul from coming to the village in groups and to impose a curfew at ten o'clock in the evening.
On XXXXXXX, 1999 a Soninke notable from the neighbouring village was murdered by Peul bandits. The next day, the XXXX youth burned down the Peul encampments. The Peul were looking for the claimant following these events, and the claimant therefore left his village on XXXXXX, 1999 and went to Bamako.
At the beginning of the year 2000, the claimant was hired by a shopkeeper by the name of XXXXXXXXXXXX, also a member of the Soninke ethnic group. On XXXXXXX, 2000 the claimant escaped an ambush that the Peul had set up on the way out of Diayecoura, in the circle of Nioro du Sahel more than 400 km northwest of Bamako. In this incident, the claimant had to leave behind his bicycle and his merchandise.
The claimant alleged that on April 3, 2001 he was threatened by Peul shopkeepers and a Peugeot 305 automobile caused him to fall off his motorbike.
On XXXXXX, 2001 the claimant was knocked over by [TRANSLATION] "hooligans", known for their attacks, driving the same type of automobile. Following this accident, the claimant was hospitalized for two days.
With the help of his employer, XXXXXXXXXXXX, the claimant left Mali on XXXXXXX, 2001. He transited through France and arrived in Canada on October 29, 2001. He claimed Canada's protection on November 8, 2001.
ANALYSIS
It has been possible to establish the identity of the refugee protection claimant, who states that he is a national of the Republic of Mali, on the basis of his testimony and documents produced in support of his refugee protection claim, namely a passport (Exhibit M-3) issued by the Malian authorities, bearing number XXXXXXXX, with a Canadian visa. The panel finds that the claimant has produced identity documents that are acceptable within the meaning of section 106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
The facts on which the Minister's allegations are based are to the effect that the claimant should be excluded from Canada in accordance with section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.1 This section incorporates Article 1F(b) of the Convention.2
For the purposes of its analysis, the panel must examine two issues:
1. Was the claimant an accomplice in the acts committed by the XXXX?
2. Does the act committed by the XXXX constitute a serious non-political crime?
As a preamble to the analysis of the facts, the panel here refers to the words of Tremblay-Lamer J. in Zrig:3
[...] a single serious non-political crime suffices for exclusion of the applicant [...]
The claimant's oral and written testimony has shown that he was one of the two principal leaders of the XXXX, which had 55 members including 15 with responsibilities. Decisions were made by the president and by the claimant, as vice-president, and they communicated the information about their decisions to the [TRANSLATION] "organizer".
The claimant testified that he agreed with the president's decision to burn down the Peul encampment. He explained that his role as vice-president did not allow him to [TRANSLATION] "go back on his word", as he had been chosen and not elected by the members of his association. The claimant nonetheless admitted to the panel that even though he had never happened to disagree with a decision of his president, he did not believe that there would have been [TRANSLATION] "any problems" for him if he had expressed his disagreement with the decision to set fire to the Peul huts.
The claimant testified that the camp had between 10 and 15 huts and that a single hut could accommodate an entire family. The claimant explained that the Peul had left the camp to look after their animals. When the Minister's representative confronted the claimant with the fact that those who remained in the camp were women, old men and children, the claimant replied that these individuals fled when they saw the Soninke advancing towards them, armed with sticks.
The claimant testified that he was just an onlooker at the scene and did no more than glance into the huts before they were set on fire. The claimant was then confronted with his answer to Question 37 of his Personal Information Form (PIF) (Exhibit P-1), where in the third paragraph of page 2, he stated:
[TRANSLATION] No longer wanting them in the vicinity of the villages, we (emphasis added by the panel) young people burned down the Peul camps on XXXXXX, 1999, forcing the inhabitants to take refuge far from the villages and fields under cultivation.
The claimant replied that the "we" in this statement meant [TRANSLATION] "our group, and it was our group that was responsible." The claimant alleged that the people who had set the fire were smokers, and he did not smoke. When questioned as to whether this was the only reason that had prevented him from setting the fire himself, the claimant replied: [TRANSLATION] "I did not have the heart to set the fire; I felt sorry for them." When questioned as to whether he had done anything to prevent this action, the claimant replied that he had not because he was [TRANSLATION] "an officer" of the XXXX.
Finally, the claimant was asked whether he had resigned from the XXXX following this event. He replied: [TRANSLATION] "No, because we did not do anything after that." The panel notes that the Peul encampment was burned down on XXXX, 1999 and that the claimant left his village on XXXXXX, 1999. On page 2 of his answer to Question 37 of his PIF (Exhibit P-1), the claimant gave the following account of what happened between these two dates:
[TRANSLATION] A manhunt was carried out against the young people of XXXXXXXXXX in general, and against us leaders in particular. It became impossible for us to go into our own fields; we could no longer fetch wood or grass for our domestic animals. [...] Armed Peul regularly went through our fields, looking for me, so that my parents and uncles were forced to flee and go back to the house. At that time, I no longer went to the village.
In light of this testimony, it is reasonable that the XXXX would have stopped its activities, since the Peul were actively looking for one of its senior leaders. Nonetheless, the claimant did not withdraw from the organization.
The principles to apply in establishing the degree of participation required have been established in Ramirez, Sivakumar and Moreno, and summarized by Nadon J. in Mohammad.4
Even though the claimant alleged that he had not set the fire himself, there is still "personal and knowing" participation, which is "the starting point for the existence of complicity." The claimant held an "important position" in the XXXX and did nothing to try to stop the arsonists. He even "encouraged" them by communicating the president's decision to the organization in "full knowledge" of what was happening. He accompanied the armed group that set fire to the encampment and was thus in "close association with those who committed" this crime. He further encouraged them by first checking to see whether the huts were occupied. In spite of the "knowledge" that the claimant had that the XXXX had committed a crime, he continued to hold the position of vice-president in the association and never resigned.
In light of the preceding, the panel finds that the refugee protection claimant is an accomplice in acts committed by the XXXX.
Does setting fire to the Peul huts constitute a "serious non-political crime"?
The Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status defines what constitutes a serious non-political crime in paragraph 155,5 and in Zrig,6 Tremblay-Lamer J. defines the word "serious" as used in Article 1F(b).
Section 434 of the Canadian Criminal Code deals with the crime of setting fire to property in the following terms:
Every person who intentionally or recklessly causes damage by fire or explosion to property that is not wholly owned by that person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.
The members of the XXXX intentionally set fire to huts that were the property of the Peul and were occupied by individuals, or even entire families, who belonged to the Peul ethnic group.
Regarding the standard of proof that must be applied under Article 1F(b), it was determined in Ramirez7 that this was a lesser standard than that required in criminal law (beyond a reasonable doubt) or in civil law (based on a balance of probabilities, or on the preponderance of evidence8), and is expressed in the phrase "serious reasons for considering."
Following an analysis of all the evidence, considering the very serious punishment imposed under Canadian law for the crime of setting fire to property owned by others, and in line with the jurisprudence mentioned above, the panel finds that counsel for the Minister has discharged the burden on him of proving that there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed a serious non-political crime.
Even if the claimant had not been excluded, the panel would have found that the claimant is neither a "Convention refugee"9 nor a "person in need of protection."10
The claimant testified that he took refuge in Bamako on XXXXXX, 1999, following the events he had experienced in his village. He alleged that he fell into an ambush set up by the Peul on November 18, 2000, more than a year after his arrival in Bamako. This incident allegedly occurred in the circles of Nara and Nioro du Saël, situated more than 400 km northwest of Bamako. The claimant also alleged that he had been the victim of two attacks, the first on April 3, 2001 when a Peugeot 305 automobile struck his motorbike, and the second on XXXXXXX, 2001 when he was knocked over by the same type of automobile, driven by [TRANSLATION] "hooligans", who were young people recruited to assault him.
When the panel asked the claimant whether complaints had been filed with the police, he replied that at the time of the second attack, which resulted in his hospitalization, his employer had gone to file a complaint with the police. When questioned as to what action the police had taken, the claimant replied that he did not know because he was ill and stayed in bed; however, the police did not come to see him. When the claimant was confronted with the fact that he had not mentioned this complaint in his answer to Question 37 of his PIF, he replied that he thought that everything had been written down and that he did not know how to read. When he was confronted with the fact that his PIF had been translated for him and that the translation had been approved on page 11 of the PIF, the claimant became confused and could not provide the panel with a satisfactory answer.
The Republic of Mali is not characterized by a complete collapse of its state apparatus. Consequently, we must presume that the Malian state is capable of protecting its nationals. In this regard, the panel finds that the Ward11 decision applies to the present case:
Absent some evidence, the claim should fail, as nations should be presumed capable of protecting their citizens. Security of nationals is, after all, the essence of sovereignty. Absent a situation of complete breakdown of state apparatus, such as that recognized in Lebanon in Zalzali, it should be assumed that the state is capable of protecting a claimant.
In light of the evidence presented, the panel finds that the claimant has not managed to rebut, by means of "clear and convincing evidence", the presumption that the Malian state is capable of protecting him.
CONCLUSION
Having analyzed all the evidence, the panel excludes the refugee protection claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention. Consequently, the claimant may not benefit from Canada's international protection.
The panel also determines that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee"12 or a "person in need of protection."13

XXXXXXXXXXX is a 31-year-old citizen of Guinea whose education apparently amounts to only 10 years of Koranic school. He claims, first, to have a well-founded fear of persecution in Guinea by reason of his imputed political opinion and, second, to be a "person in need of protection"1 since, as he alleges, he is subject to a danger of torture, a risk to his life and a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
He alleged that he owned an XXXXXXXXXXXXX located in the vicinity of the Alpha Yaya military camp in Conakry.
One day in XXXX 2001, an explosion XXXXXXXX destroyed his XXXXXX. He said that he therefore left Conakry to return to his village. An uncle allegedly encouraged him to seek compensation from the department of XXXXXXX. He claimed that he went there two times without achieving the desired results and that the third time he was simply arrested and thrown into a mobile police cell, where he endured physical and moral torture for two weeks.
The torture took various forms such as undressing the claimant and leaving him exposed to adverse weather. He was also deprived of water. When he asked for some, his torturers handed him an empty cup, forced him to fill it with his urine and then made him drink it. The claimant said that he did this numerous times. They hit him with a braided whip, telling him that he would die soon. He was deprived of food. On several occasions, they allegedly bound his hands to his knees, forcing him to bend over, and then pulled him with a rope like a work animal, causing him the most excruciating pain.
The goal of the torturers was to intimidate him and punish him for holding the State to account.
He said that he managed to escape with the help of his uncle and then went into hiding. The police came after him, tracking him everywhere. On XXXXX, 2001, he headed for exile in Canada, passing through Mali, and carrying a false French passport.
DECISION
The panel determines that the claimant is a person in need of protection because there is a serious possibility that he would be subject personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
Identity
To establish his identity, the claimant presented, in addition to his testimony, his legally obtained identity card and birth certificate. The authenticity of these documents is not at issue in this case.
Based on this evidence, the panel finds that he is a Guinean citizen and that he comes from Guinea.
Credibility
The claimant gave direct and detailed testimony using consistent body language. His testimony did not contradict the information contained in his Personal Information Form (PIF). It made it possible to explain the minor contradictions presented in the evidence of the Minister's representative.
The panel could not therefore make a negative finding regarding the credibility of the refugee protection claimant.
Danger of torture
The refugee protection claimant, aware that he is wanted by the authorities, alleged during the hearing that if he had to return to Guinea, he would be arrested, imprisoned and tortured by the security forces for having fled and defied the State.
In the panel's opinion, it is obvious that the harm feared amounts to torture.
The harm the claimant fears he would suffer resembles the detailed description he gave of the abuse he was subjected to in prison before escaping, in particular, where he was deprived of water and drank his own urine, was bound and dragged like an animal, was deprived of food and beaten, etc.
In any event, the panel is of the opinion that these are acts by which severe pain and suffering, whether physical or mental, are intentionally inflicted for the purpose of intimidation and punishment.
The documentary evidence on the record makes it possible for the panel to conclude that this humiliating treatment is inflicted by members of the security forces, as is indicated by the following passage from Exhibit A-2:2
Serious human rights abuses include: Extrajudicial killings; disappearances; use of torture, beatings, and rape by police and military personnel; and police abuse of prisoners and detainees. (...) Members of the security forces committed abuses with impunity.
It should be noted that if he were to return, the refugee protection claimant would be subject to an extrajudicial procedure that heightens a risk that is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions.
Section 97, subsection 1, paragraph (a) of the Act states the following:
A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally [...] to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture.
Given this, it is appropriate to examine the standard of proof under this section. This involves a consideration of the possible equivalence of the terms "reasonable chance", "serious possibility" and "believed on substantial grounds to exist", since it appears to the panel that the standard to be applied is that of a "serious possibility" and that it is the existence of such a possibility that the claimant must demonstrate.
First, given that the risk involved is a prospective one, the panel is of the opinion that the standard to be applied is the standard that applies in considering claims for refugee protection based on the definition of "Convention refugee". In the present case, the prospective nature of the risk is based on the culture of violence within the Guinean police force.
Second, the panel finds that the standard of a "serious possibility" is bolstered by the fact that the danger of torture is, obviously, an aggravated form of the harm feared by the claimant.
The panel's conclusion with regard to the standard to be applied is based on international and Canadian case law on this subject.
It is worthwhile to refer to this case law, beginning at the international level. In Kacaj,3 it appeared that the expressions "reasonable chance", "substantial grounds for believing" and "serious possibility" indicate the same degree of risk as the term "serious risk". The British tribunal that heard the case concluded that two different legal criteria or standards could not be applied to the same set of facts. There is a requirement for logic and consistency.
With regard to Canadian case law on this subject, it is appropriate to note that in Suresh,4 the Supreme Court of Canada uses as equivalents the expressions "substantial risk of torture" and "substantial grounds to believe" he or she would be tortured on return to the country of destination. Furthermore, it should be noted that the expressions "substantial risk of torture" and "real risk" attest to a meaning equivalent to the meaning of expressions used in Adjei,5 specifically, "good grounds for fearing", "serious possibility" and "reasonable chance" in the context of the definition of "Convention refugee".
Given the objectives set out in the current Act with regard to refugees, the panel does not believe that the intent of Parliament was to make access to protection more difficult for people at risk of torture than for those at risk of persecution. Indeed, allegations of possible ill-treatment can meet both the definition of torture, as set out in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture, and the definition of refugee, as set out in section 96 of the Act. If the legal standard were higher than the standard applied to claims for refugee protection based on the definition of "Convention refugee", people facing a serious possibility of torture would not be protected.
Consequently, the panel finds that the expression "believed on substantial grounds to exist" refers to the existence of a serious possibility of torture, and the panel has applied this standard to the facts of the present case.
DECISION
The panel determines that XXXXXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection; consequently, his claim for refugee protection is accepted.

The refugee protection claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and her three-year-old minor son, XXXXXXXXXXX, are citizens of Iran. The claimant was designated as the representative of her child for the purposes of her claim.
THE FACTS
On XXXXXXXX, 2001 the claimants left their country with a Canadian ministerial residence permit valid until XXXXX, 2001, so that the child could receive free medical care at the XXXX Hospital, a private institution XXXXX. Since birth, XXXXXX has suffered from a very rare bone disease, which makes his bones fragile and likely to break at the slightest shock or awkward movement.
As she did in the visa application she submitted to the Canadian Embassy in XXXXX, the claimant cited medical opinions confirming that Iran does not have the expert physicians and resources required to provide her son XXXXXX with proper care.
A little over a month after the claimant and her son arrived in Canada, she claimed "refugee status" for herself and for him, alleging that she would be at risk of persecution for her political opinion if she ever returned to Iran.
The claimant said that the Iranian doctors had taken a long time to discover what her son was actually suffering from. Most of the time, he did not receive proper care when, as a very young child, he suffered a fracture of one or other of his limbs. The claimant often had heated exchanges with health care personnel, for example, when affluent people were treated ahead of her son in the emergency ward.
Once, in XXXXXX 1999, she was held at the office of the hospital's security service because she was not wearing her veil in the prescribed manner. She had just got out of a taxi with her injured child in her arms and had not had the time-or even the idea-to adjust her veil. She was released with a warning.
Having obtained the name of a physician who could treat her son, she went to XXXX, where she stayed with her husband and child from XXXXXX 1999 to XXXXX 2000. It seems that the vitamin treatment offered there was not as successful as they had hoped. Moreover, the doctor told them that the only hospital in the world that could treat XXXXXX was the XXXXXX Hospital in XXXXXXX.
When they returned to Iran, the claimant and her husband made many efforts to approach the Iranian medical authorities and the Canadian diplomatic corps. After a first refusal for having an incomplete file and other procedures, including the intervention of a member of parliament who is a friend of the family, they finally obtained the necessary documents and authorizations to bring XXXXXX to Canada for treatment.
In this regard, the file of the Canadian Embassy in XXXXXX, produced as Exhibit A-32, reveals the following particular facts: the Government of Quebec gave its consent for XXXXXX treatment on XXXXX, 2001; the letter of the Iranian ministry of health confirming that the treatments required for XXXXXX were not available in Iran is dated XXXX, 2001; the letter of acceptance of free care offered by the XXXXX Hospital is dated XXXXX, 2001; and the Minister's permit to stay in Canada is dated XXXXX, 2001.
However, the claimant alleged that on XXXXXX, 2001 she shouted abuse at people in charge of medical care and people who were part of the state apparatus, in their offices. She accused them and the clerics in charge of the Iranian regime of corruption because she and her husband were not allowed to purchase American foreign currency at the official rate, which was much more favourable than the black market rate, although she urgently needed this foreign currency for her stay in Canada and there was, according to her, a government assistance program for parents who had to have their children treated outside the country.
The claimant said that she was detained for several hours because of the inflammatory comments she had made against the regime. She was released with a warning that she would soon receive a notice to appear in court.
The claimant said that she was finally able to leave Iran with XXXXXX, thanks to the generosity of members of her family. It was only when she arrived here in Canada that her husband told her over the telephone, in XXXXX 2001, that she had received at her home a notice to appear in court. In her narrative, she added that her husband went to the court and was told that his wife absolutely had to return to Iran without delay.
The claimant feared being convicted and mistreated if she ever returned to Iran, and she also feared that the authorities would never allow her or her husband to leave the country again, to come to Canada so that XXXXXX could receive the care he absolutely needed. The claimant therefore decided to seek Canada's protection before her residence permit expired.
Apart from claiming the benefit of protection under the Convention, the claimant cites the fact that being prohibited from leaving Iran would constitute cruel or unusual treatment for herself and her child, or even a threat to the life of her child XXXXXX.
In a letter of XXXXX, 2002, filed on the record as Exhibit P-5, Dr. XXXXXX of the XXXXX Hospital states that the treatment that XXXXXX has taken since XXXXX, 2001 has produced very encouraging results. However, the child is still unable to stand up because of the weakness and deformity of his femurs. Dr. XXXXXX adds that the administration of pamidronate intravenously must be continued to increase the strength of the bones. When the bones have become stronger, surgery will be necessary to straighten out the long bones of the legs. On the basis of the progress observed, the doctor estimates that the surgical procedures could be carried out in early 2003.
Issues
The identities of the claimant and of her child XXXXXX are not in issue as they have been established in an entirely satisfactory manner.
The main issue here is the credibility of the claimant and of her allegations that she fears persecution by reason of her political opinion and risks cruel and unusual treatment in Iran.
At first glance, the child's claim appears to be essentially based on that of his mother. However, given the child's circumstances as a whole and the international conventions applicable to the present case, I find it necessary to analyze his claim more specifically, keeping in mind the fundamental rule that his best interests are paramount.
ANALYSIS
1- Credibility
The credibility of the claimant is a problem because the evidence contains major contradictions concerning essential elements of her claim.
In the first place, concerning the essential element of the notice to appear in court that the claimant allegedly received, she wrote in her PIF-which she swore to be true and accurate-that her husband told her on the telephone, in XXXXX 2001, that a notice to appear in court had been sent to her at their home, that he had gone to tell the court that she was outside the country, and that after being questioned, he was told that his wife had to return to Iran immediately.
In her testimony at the hearing, however, the claimant substantially changed these alleged facts, declaring that she did not have a copy of the notice to appear because her husband had not received one. She rather claimed that representatives of the court came in person to the door of their home to tell her husband that she had to return to Iran and appear before the court. She did not offer any satisfactory explanation for these contradictions.
Again in her PIF, in paragraph 11 of her answer to Question 37, the claimant said that she realized that being able to purchase foreign currency at the more favourable official rate was reserved for friends of the regime. At the hearing, when asked to give more details about what she had learned of this form of corruption, she replied that she knew nothing about it because it was her husband "[TRANSLATION] who looked after these details."
This statement clearly contradicts her written testimony, in which she affirmed:
In the course pursuing this matter I found out that this programme had fallen victim to corruption (sic).
This declaration also makes it implausible that the claimant would have denounced the authorities, accusing them of corruption. How can the panel believe that she uttered the words that she said she uttered when she could not explain how there was corruption in the currency market, as it was her husband who "[TRANSLATION] looked after these details?" To ask this question is to cast doubt on the whole story of political denunciation that would be the reason for the alleged persecution of the claimant.
Furthermore, the claimant added a major element, which was not mentioned in her PIF. This adds to her lack of credibility. After she had declared that it was possible that she would be arrested if she returned to Iran because of what she had said to the authorities in early XXXX 2001, she was asked why, in that case, she had been allowed to leave the country in XXXXX 2001. She first replied that she had not been authorized to do so; then, contradicting herself, she immediately asserted that it was the intervention of a member of the Iranian parliament that had helped her to obtain the authorization to leave the country.
The claimant contradicted herself, not only in the same answer, but also contradicted her written narrative to the effect that after she and her husband met with a first refusal in XXXX 2001, due to insufficient supporting evidence, the member of parliament in question helped them to obtain, from the Medical Council, a letter certifying that the health services of her country were unable to provide XXXXXX with the care that his condition required. According to her written narrative, the intervention of the member of parliament-whose name she was unable to recall at the hearing-was only required to obtain a letter from the Medical Council, not to obtain a visa to leave Iran.
Furthermore, the claimant could not remain credible when she claimed, under oath, that she did not have authorization to leave Iran, although in answer to Question 26(d) of her PIF, she had indicated that her country had granted her an exit visa for an unlimited period of time, as can be seen from her stamped passport.
Since these contradictions concern essential elements of the claimant's allegations, they have dealt a fatal blow to her credibility.
My negative finding in this regard is reinforced by the claimant's attitude and behaviour on arriving in Canada, which indicate that she did not have a real fear of persecution by reason of her political opinion. The evidence shows that the claimant arrived in Canada on September 19, 2001 with the sole purpose of having her son XXXXXX treated in XXXXX. She only filled out the claim documents on October 29. She said that she did so because her husband had called to tell her that she had been given notice to appear before the Islamic court.
Apart from the fact that this allegation of a notice to appear in court has been found not to be credible for the reasons given above, the claimant's allegation that her fear of returning to Iran was triggered by her husband's announcement that she was wanted by the Islamic justice system is not serious because, according to the logic of her own narrative, she had been notified on XXXX, 2001 that she would soon be given notice by the court to appear before it. If she knew more than one month before leaving her country that she faced a risk of persecution, it is not credible for her to maintain that her fear of persecution originated with her husband's call. In this sense, her delay in seeking Canada's international protection allows the panel to find that her fear is not genuine.
Moreover, if what the claimant says is true, she made very serious accusations against the Iranian regime. However, it seems implausible to believe, in the circumstances, that the authorities would only have taken action after her departure, and that the same authorities would have granted her, in the meantime, an exit visa for an unlimited period of time. These implausibilities add to the lack of credibility as a whole.
On the basis of all the facts, I find it reasonable to conclude that the claimant simply invented her story of political persecution in Iran after arriving in Canada, when she realized that the treatment that was to be given to her young son XXXXXX under a more protracted treatment plan would take much longer than the time limit indicated in her Minister's residence permit, due to expire on XXXXXX, 2001.
Moreover, the claimant repeatedly emphasized, in her testimony, that she was not rich, that she and her husband had obtained financial help from their families, and that her stay in Canada had indebted her to them. The claimant's insistence on talking about her financial situation has raised doubts about her real reasons for making a refugee protection claim and has led the panel to believe that her attempt to obtain another status in Canada is motivated instead by economic considerations.
I wish to state here that I am aware of the heavy burden that weighs upon the claimant. Her young son XXXXXXX state of health obliges her to be constantly with him and to seek specialized, experienced care. The last time she entrusted her child to a babysitter, in XXX 2002, the result was another fracture of a femur. Consequently, she no longer dares to place her child in the care of others, and this explains the presence of XXXXX throughout the hearing. This also explains the extreme fatigue that the claimant so obviously suffers from, and no doubt her desire to do anything she can so that her son will be properly treated.
While the claimant's circumstances, so difficult in human terms, help the panel to understand her motives more clearly, they are not sufficient for her to be given the benefit of the doubt regarding the credibility of her allegations in support of her claim.
My negative finding concerning the claimant's credibility and her allegations has a negative impact on her refugee protection claim as a whole. Since I do not seriously believe that she faces persecution in Iran for her political opinion, I cannot conclude that there is a well-founded risk of cruel and unusual treatment that would result from a prohibition on leaving Iran, since the claimant has not shown, in a credible manner, that such a prohibition would likely be imposed on her in future.
Finally, the claimant did not raise the issue of a danger of torture in Iran, and nothing in the evidence-especially given my findings on credibility-would allow me to have serious reasons for believing that she would incur such a risk.
2- The claim of the minor child
The claimant said that the Iranian doctors took a long time to make a correct diagnosis of her son's disease; hence, in her opinion, the child has suffered enormously and to no avail.
In the absence of any clear evidence of wilfully malevolant acts directed against the young claimant, I cannot conclude that he was the victim of any persecutorial acts. It is evident that the attending physicians in Iran did not have the advanced expertise required to recognize and treat the symptoms of a disease that is, moreover, very rare.
The inability of doctors-or of a country-to provide adequate medical or health care, in the absence of evidence to establish that this lack or inadequacy of care is due to discriminatory policies or choices that have as their purpose to harm a claimant or a specific population, in whole or in part, cannot amount to persecution within the meaning of the Convention.
Furthermore, according to section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, where the risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment results from this incapacity, a person is not a "person in need of protection."
In addition, nothing in the documentary evidence filed on the record, with which the claimant was duly confronted both on her own account and in her capacity as designated representative of her son, would allow a finding that her young son XXXXXX is at risk of being persecuted in Iran because he is a child or because he has a disability.
Finally, since the claimant's allegations were found not to be credible in this regard, there is nothing to allow a finding that the Iranian authorities would refuse without due cause to allow the child to leave the country again if he were to require further specialized care not available in Iran.
In conclusion, let me note that in my opinion, the claimant will surely find, with the Minister or his representatives, an attentive ear that will enable her to extend her residence permit in Canada until completion of the treatment plan being followed by the physicians at the XXXXXX Hospital.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, I determine that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXX are neither Convention refugees under section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act nor persons in need of protection under section 97(1) of the Act. Consequently, I reject their refugee protection claims.

XXXXXXXX is a 48-year-old citizen of Guinea whose education apparently amounts to only ten years of Coranic school. He claims, first, to have a well-founded fear of persecution in Guinea by reason of his imputed political opinion and, second, to be a "person in need of protection"1 since, as he alleges, he is at risk of being tortured and of dying as a result of that torture.
In support of his claim, he alleged that he had been a XXX in Gueckedou. He sold XXXXX in bags that had his name on them to facilitate their identification during transportation from Conakry, where he purchased them, to Gueckedou, where he sold them.
In XXXXXX 2000, rebels from Liberia and Sierra Leone raided his shop and stole his bags of XXXX. Fearing for his life in a region where war was being waged between the Guinean army and the rebels, he returned to live in Conakry.
In XXXXXXX 2001, he was arrested and imprisoned by the army, which was seeking out accomplices of the rebel undesirables. The army claimed to have evidence that the claimant was providing rice to the rebels, who had come to destabilize Guinea. Indeed, the army had seized bags of XXXXXX bearing the claimant's name.
During six months of imprisonment, the claimant allegedly endured an intense interrogation. Among other mistreatments, he allegedly had his elbows bound together and was beaten and forced to kneel in the sun. He claims that he was flogged four times a day to make him reveal his ties with the rebels. The more he denied it, the harder his alleged torturers were on him.
He allegedly managed to escape with the help of his friends. After two months of hiding, he left Guinea armed with a Canadian visa.
DECISION
The panel considers that the claimant is a person in need of protection because there is a serious possibility that he would be subjected personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The panel concludes that the claimant has Guinean citizenship. This was established by his passport and a series of documents obtained from the Canadian embassy in Conakry.
Credibility
The claimant gave a direct, detailed testimony in simple words. His testimony did not contradict the information contained in his Personal Information Form (PIF). The panel could therefore not reach a negative conclusion regarding the claimant's credibility.
Danger of torture
The claimant, aware that he is being sought, alleged during the hearing that if he had to return to Guinea, he would be arrested, imprisoned and tortured by the security forces in order to make him admit his complicity with the rebels and give them the names of other people he is assumed to know.
In the panel's opinion, it is obvious that the harm feared is equivalent to torture.
The harm the claimant fears he would suffer resembles the detailed description he gave of the abuse he was subjected to in prison before escaping, in particular the flogging of his hips, his elbows being bound with rope and being exposed to the sun while on his knees and against a wall.
In any event, the panel is of the opinion that these are acts by which severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, is intentionally inflicted for the purpose of obtaining a confession.
The documentary evidence in the file indicates that this humiliating treatment is inflicted by members of the security forces, as is shown by the following passage from Exhibit A-2:2
Serious human rights abuses include: Extrajudicial killings; disappearances; use of torture, beatings, and rape by police and military personnel; and police abuse of prisoners and detainees. (...) Members of the security forces committed abuses with impunity.
It should be noted that if he were to return, the claimant would be subject to an extrajudicial procedure that heightens a risk that is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions.
In view of section 97, subsection 1, paragraph (a) which states that "a person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally [...] to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture", it is appropriate to examine the standard of proof under this section. This involves a consideration of the possible equivalence of the terms "reasonable chance", "serious possibility" and "substantial grounds to believe", since appears to the panel that the standard to be applied is that of a "serious possibility" and that it is the existence of such a possibility that the claimant must demonstrate.
First, given that the risk involved is a prospective one, the panel is of the opinion that the standard to be applied should be the standard that prevails in the examination of claims for refugee protection based on the definition of "Convention refugee". In the present case, the prospective nature of the risk is based on the culture of violence within the Guinean police force.
Second, the panel considers that the standard of a "serious possibility" is increased by the fact that the danger of torture is, obviously, an aggravated form of the harm feared by the claimant.
The panel's conclusion with regard to the standard to be applied is based on international and Canadian case law on this subject.
It is worthwhile to mention this case law, beginning at the international level. In Kacaj,3 it appeared that the expressions "reasonable possibility", "serious reasons to think" and "serious possibility" indicate the same degree of risk as the term "real risk". The British tribunal that heard the case concluded that two different criteria or legal standards could not be applied to the same set of facts. This represents a requirement for logic and consistency.
With regard to Canadian case law on this subject, it is appropriate to note that in Suresh,4 the Supreme Court of Canada uses as equivalents the expressions "substantial risk of torture" and "substantial grounds to believe" he or she would be tortured on return.
Furthermore, it should be noted that the expressions "substantial risk of torture" and "real risk" seem to be equivalent in meaning to those appearing in Adjei,5 specifically "good grounds for fearing", "serious possibility" and "reasonable chance" in the context of the definition of "Convention refugee".
Given the objectives set out in the current Act with regard to refugees, the panel does not believe that the legislative intent was to make access to protection more difficult for people at risk of torture than for those at risk of persecution. Indeed, allegations of possible mistreatment can meet both the definition torture, as set out in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture, and the definition of refugee, as formulated in section 96 of the Act. If the legal standard were higher than the standard applied to claims for refugee protection based on the definition of "Convention refugee", people for whom there is a serious possibility of torture would not be protected. Consequently, the panel considers that the expression "substantial grounds to believe" refers to the existence of a serious possibility of torture, and the panel applied this standard to the facts of the present case.
Internal flight alternative
Following the claimant's testimony, which was deemed credible, the panel considers that the claimant has no internal flight alternative, given that he is being sought by the State regarding a matter of internal security.
CONCLUSION
The panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection; consequently, his claim for refugee protection is allowed.

ALLEGED FACTS:
The claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is a citizen of Argentina. He fled his country on XXXXXX, 2001, for fear of being imprisoned after a formal charge of libeling some directors of the XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXXXX, of which he was an employee from XXXXXX to March XXXX.
According to the claimant, under Argentine law an employer and employee who enter into an agreement about the employee's rights, for example in the case of a cessation of work, must, in order for that agreement to have legal effect, record it in writing and have it examined by a conciliator from the XXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXX before it can be certified.
The claimant said that his role under the law consisted of checking the identity of the parties, whether they were appearing voluntarily, whether the documentation was complete and, above all, whether the employee fully understood all the terms and effects of the agreement. If not, the claimant did not approve the agreement requiring certification.
With the advent of a new government at the end of 1999 and the arrival of a group of new directors at the Department, it seems that the policies and ways of acting of the XXXXXX XXXXX changed considerably. The focus was now on efficiency and faster certification of agreements. The claimant did not approve of that new focus on speed, which according to him was against the workers' interests, as many agreements presented did not grant the employees concerned all the benefits to which they were entitled. According to him, certifying agreements without close perusal meant closing one's eyes to the abuses and malpractices of many employers.
The claimant did not hesitate to give expression to his views on the new service guidelines. He continued to do his work "by the book", as he said, despite being rebuked by his superiors and ostracized by his colleagues. Soon he was being harassed by his superior officer and treated in a high-handed manner because he refused to change his attitude.
On XXXX, 2001, he was dismissed from his post, despite the fact that he was a public servant appointed by ministerial order. He said that by XXXX 2001 he had exhausted all his administrative recourses following what he considered his wrongful dismissal.
In XXXX 2001, he decided to write a notarized letter to the Argentine Minister of Labour to request an interview and reinstatement in his post. He denounced his superiors and the lawyers from the XXXXX XXXXXXX XXXXX in that letter, going so far as to accuse them of fraudulent tactics with regard to employees who had recourse to the Service, to the benefit of some dishonest employers.
At the hearing, the claimant admitted he had no material evidence to support his charges, but said the mere fact that agreements disadvantageous to workers had been accepted proved that there was collusion between the directors of the Service and some employers.
The claimant did not have his interview with the Minister. Then he discovered that an administrative inquiry about him had been ordered, for the purpose, he said, of blackening his reputation for good, thereby preventing him from holding any other position in the public service in Argentina. He does not know when that administrative inquiry took place, but thinks it may have been before his dismissal in XXXXX 2001.
In XXXX 2001, he was ordered to appear before the court to answer a charge of libel. He consulted a former colleague who told him no lawyer would want to defend him against the lawyers appearing for the XXXXXX XXXXXX. As he was due to appear on XXXXX, 2001 and was in a panic at the very idea of finding himself in an Argentine prison, the claimant decided to flee to the United States, as he did not need a visa to go there.
He therefore left his country on XXXXX, 2001. He stayed in the United States until March 2002 without claiming refugee status. He said he had consulted an expert in immigration who told him he risked being imprisoned if he applied for US protection, because he had greatly overstayed his permitted time on American soil. He consequently came to the Canadian border on
March 7, 2002 and claimed refugee status.
The claimant fears imprisonment if he ever returns to Argentina. He knows that under the Argentine Criminal Code the sentence for libeling public servants varies from one to three years. He thinks he might be sentenced to the maximum because he was a public servant himself.
He says the prisons in Argentina are overcrowded, prisoners are brutally treated and torture is common. He thinks that his status as a public servant would make him even more vulnerable to cruel treatment by other inmates and by prison guards famous for their harshness, especially in the Province of XXXXXXXXX where he was charged.
He alleges he will be persecuted because of his political opinion and because he belongs to the social group of "public servants".
ANALYSIS:
1. Exhibits and identity:
At the beginning of the hearing the panel refused to allow the claimant to use certain documents, as he had clearly failed to make reasonable efforts to file them at least twenty days before the hearing in accordance with Rule 29.
However, his identity was satisfactorily established, as his passport and identity cards had been seized by the immigration officers and a certified copy of those documents was filed as Exhibit A-20.
2. Credibility:
The panel did not draw a generally negative conclusion about the claimant's credibility because of his lack of diligence in filing his documents. His lack of concern seems to have been promoted by the inexperience of his counsel, who said it was the first time he had represented a client before the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB).
The claimant testified in a convincing manner, without contradicting himself, giving spontaneous answers to many often-difficult questions. He seemed sincere and was therefore found credible with regard to the facts alleged, which does not mean that the panel shares his interpretation of those facts or the conclusions he drew from them.
3. The questions to resolve:
Should the claimant be excluded because criminal charges are pending against him in Argentina?
If not, does he fear persecution on one of the grounds in the refugee definition or does he not rather fear a criminal charge (fear of persecution or fear of prosecution)?
Finally, if he is not a "Convention refugee", is he a "person in need of protection" because he would personally be subject to the risk of torture, a risk to his life or cruel and unusual treatment if he were deported to Argentina?
A. Exclusion:
The claimant is accused of libeling some directors of the government service that employed him and is liable in Argentina to a maximum sentence of three years in prison.
It is judicial knowledge that, in Canadian law, there is no provision for the crime of "libel" as such. However, certain crimes of a similar nature, such as malicious injury to reputation, defamation or laying false information with the police, which are qualified as public mischief, carry a sentence of less than five years in prison.
The length of the maximum sentence laid down in an Act or a Criminal Code for a crime or offence seems to be the most simple, straightforward and reliable criterion for assessing the seriousness of a non-political crime with regard to the exclusion clause, as the Act is supposed to reflect the values of society, especially in terms of the level of what the law finds reprehensible or unacceptable.
It thus seems justified, especially in light of the other pertinent provisions in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to the admissibility of foreign nationals into Canadian territory, to hold that crimes or offences subject to a sentence of five years or less are not "serious non-political crimes" within the meaning of the exclusion clause in question.
There is thus no serious reason to think that this claimant has committed a serious non-political crime outside Canada. Consequently, the 1F(b) exclusion clause does not apply to him.
B. Fear of persecution or fear or being indicted?
The claimant affirms that he was persecuted by his superiors in the XXXXX XXXXXX XXXXX because of his political opinion and his membership in the social group of "public servants". He considers that the criminal charge of libel pending against him in Argentina is a direct result or continuation of that persecution.
a) Social group:
Firstly, with regard to the alleged social group, nothing in the evidence permits us to conclude that there is a social group of "public servants" in Argentina, whose members are exposed to persecution just because of their membership in the group. After all, members of the public service in that country do not share any innate or unchangeable characteristics just because they are state employees. The claimant's allegation is all the more unrealistic in that his alleged persecutors are members of the same public service as himself.
Clearly, the claimant's problems did not arise from his membership in that group or any other group. The cause of his troubles is too closely linked to his own actions, his personal attitude, his expression of disagreement and his refusal to follow the instructions of his superiors in his work, for us to conclude that he risks persecution because of his membership in a particular social group.
b) Political opinion:
The opinions expressed by the claimant to his colleagues and superiors relate to the application of labour laws and policies and concern the role of the state in protecting Argentine workers' rights. Those opinions can be described as "political", as they obviously relate to "state machinery" in the broad and generous meaning given by the Supreme Court of Canada to the words "political opinion" in Ward.
However, that does not mean that the claimant was persecuted because of his political opinion, or that he risks persecution if he returns to Argentina.
First of all, he was clearly dismissed because he was not performing his duties according to the guidelines he had been given. The whole of the claimant's testimony confirms that way of seeing things. After many verbal confrontations with his superiors and colleagues about how cases should be dealt with, he had a meeting in XXXXX 2000 with the director of the service, who told him to stop repeating that workers were being abused because they were after all receiving some compensation and in any event the orders stating that cases should be dealt with expeditiously came from above and he must comply or face the consequences.
The claimant says he went on doing his work meticulously, without taking any notice of those guidelines. His employer dismissed him for that reason on XXXXX, 2001, thereby exercising his legitimate management rights. That dismissal does not constitute persecution in the circumstances.
c) Fear of prosecution:
More than once, the claimant said he would not have left Argentina but for the criminal charges against him, implying that those charges are the only source of his fear of return.
The charges result from the libelous letter he sent to the Minister of Labour, in which he accused some of his superiors by name of dishonesty, without any proof other than his personal conclusions.
The persons libeled did not threaten him in return; they did not have him beaten up by thugs or take any persecutory action against him in the broad sense. They had recourse to the justice system. So they used legal channels to remedy an attack on their rights by the claimant. This is a far cry from the usual scenario where an agent of persecution takes justice into his own hands.
Furthermore, the claimant is not accused of a political offence. The charge of libel is not a pretext to penalize him for his political opinion, but an act to punish him for his defamatory statements.
According to my analysis of the evidence, the claimant does not risk persecution on any of the grounds in the definition and is consequently not a "Convention refugee".
C. Person in need of protection:
The claimant alleges there are serious reasons to believe that he risks being subject to torture and cruel or unusual treatment if he is imprisoned in Argentina. He points out that the prisons in his country are overcrowded, the conditions of detention are appalling, torture by guards is systematic and the fact that he was a public servant would make him even more vulnerable to cruel and unusual treatment by the guards and the other prisoners.
I was particularly struck by the claimant's pallor when he spoke of his possible incarceration in Argentina. His attitude reflected a genuine state of panic at the mere idea of finding himself in detention there. It must be said that a careful reading of the documentary evidence in the file fully confirms the validity of his apprehensions in that connection.
However, we have to determine if those bad conditions in prison are not simply inherent in or incidental to the legitimate sanctions that would be imposed on him as a result of the charges of libel pending against him. But first, a word on the standard of proof necessary to analyse the evidence in the case.
a) Standard of proof:
With regard to torture and cruel and unusual treatment, I consider the standard of proof to be a "serious possibility", that is to say more than a mere possibility but less than a real probability. In that connection, I agree with the reasoning of my colleague José Tshisungu in his decision of August 7, 2002. The decision was rendered in MA2-00869, reported in the Reflex of September 5, 2002, No. 195, and based on the Act and pertinent Canadian and foreign caselaw. Like him, I think it appropriate to apply the same standard of proof in the case of refugee claimants and persons in need of protection, because, in the objectives of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the Legislator took care to put all claimants on an equal footing.
Furthermore, the same forward-looking assessment process is followed both in assessing whether the risk of persecution is well-founded and in assessing the risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment and, since in all cases a serious violation of fundamental rights is at issue, I feel it would be inappropriate, unjust and inequitable to impose on claimants fearing torture or cruel and unusual treatment a heavier burden of proof than on someone fearing persecution on one of the grounds in the refugee definition.
Keeping that standard of proof in mind, therefore, in concluding whether or not there is a serious possibility that he will be tortured or suffer cruel or unusual treatment if he is deported to Argentina, I shall take into account not only the situation in Argentine prisons but also the claimant's personality.
b) Situation in prisons:
The documentary evidence filed clearly states that torture is very prevalent in Argentine prisons and the problem is very serious. Many international agencies recognized and respected in the defence of human rights have concluded that such is the case and stressed the very poor overall quality of the detention conditions experienced by prisoners in that country.
For example, in Exhibit A-4, the 2001 Country Reports of the US State Department on Argentina, it is stated at page 1:
"Torture and brutality by police and prison guards were serious problems. In some cases the authorities investigated and sanctioned those responsible for abuses, but impunity is a problem."
At page 5, the same report explains:
"The Constitution prohibits torture, and the Criminal Code provides penalties for torture similar to those for homicides; however, torture and brutality by police and prison guards remain serious problems. Human rights organizations described widespread police brutality, the use of torture on suspects, and corruption within the prison and police forces. The Government often investigated reports of police brutality, but in some jurisdictions, such as Mendoza Province and greater XXXXXXXXX, threats to witnesses and advocates made prosecution of abuses and reform more difficult. On January 25, the U.N. Special Rapporteur on Torture released a report that recalled concerns raised in the Commission's 2000 review of the third periodic report of the country under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In particular, it noted concern about allegations indicating that torture and excessive use of force by police officials were a 'widespread problem and that government mechanisms established to address it are inadequate' The U.N. Special Rapporteur expressed concern about prison conditions and cited specifically "the severe overcrowding and the poor quality of basic necessities and services, including food, clothing and medical care.
In August (2001) three federal judges strongly criticized "the generalized practice of torture in all its forms in a systematic way, in the area of investigations and the treatment of detainees, especially in the province of XXXXXXXXX, where there is a history of authoritarian style state violence." One judge described the situation as "very serious". (...) The judges' report was based in part on an 11-month investigation by the XXXXXXXXX provincial public defender, Mario Coriolano, who reported 602 cases of torture in jails and police stations in the province between March 2000 and June 2001. Most of these were punches and kicks to various parts of the body, baton blows, and threats ( some with firearms). There were also cases of applications of electric shock (a habitual practice from the military dictatorship) and "dry submarine"(asphyxia with a plastic bag). The judges, as well as the penitentiary system's own attorney, pointed to the few instances of complaints sustained in the courts because of the difficulty in obtaining proof due to prisoners' fear of reprisals. " (My underlining)
That finding is confirmed by Human Rights Watch in its 2002 report, filed as Exhibit A-5. We read at page 116:
"Ill-treatment was common in police stations where young offenders were held in overcrowded and squalid conditions. Methods of torture reported including beatings, hooding with plastic bags almost to the point of suffocation, and the use of electric shock batons on sensitive parts of the body, techniques in widespread use when Argentina was under military rule. These practices were almost frequently reported in the populous greater XXXXXXXXX area. In July, Mario Coriolano, the chief state defense attorney attached to the criminal appeals court in the province of XXXXXXXXX, issued a report to the provincial Supreme Court giving details of more than six hundred complaints of ill-treatment and torture made from March 2000 until July 2001. By late October the court had information on more than 1,000 cases. In August, four respected federal judges publicly expressed concern about the prevalence of torture, asserting that the practice had become systematic in both police stations and prisons. " (My underlining)
c) Conclusions:
That eloquent documentary evidence from credible international observers permits us to consider the claimant's fears highly plausible, especially as he is charged in the province of XXXXX XXXX.
The acts described in the passages cited certainly constitute torture as they are committed by officers of the state who intentionally inflict severe pain or suffering on prisoners. Furthermore, it is reasonable to believe that the US State Department, Human Rights Watch and the United Nations Rapporteur, when they use the term "torture", are referring to the definition of torture in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture,1 to which section 97(1)(a)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act also refers.
The claimant is right in saying that Argentine prisons are overcrowded, as the Country Reports cited above reveal, at page 6, that, according to the Argentine Minister of Justice, 43,174 prisoners were occupying the 30,703 places available in the country's prisons in April 2001.
Those facts, added to the evidence of the poor detention conditions described by the United Nations Rapporteur, and the climate of violence and corruption prevalent in prisons, especially those in the province of XXXXXXXXX where he would probably be held, make it reasonable to believe that the claimant certainly risks suffering ill-treatment to a point beyond what Canadian public opinion would find acceptable in all conscience.
When Argentine judges state that torture is systematic in prisons in their country, that means it may affect any prisoner. If that prisoner is also a stubborn person who has difficulty following orders, as the evidence shows the claimant to be, the risk of his being tortured certainly meets the standard of a "serious possibility", in view of all the circumstances.
Sentencing the claimant to imprisonment for the crime of libel would certainly be a lawful sanction in his country. But his exposure to cruel or unusual treatment or torture in prison could not be described as arising from, inherent in or incidental to that lawful sanction. That risk would rather arise from the dangerous prison system in his country and the systematic recourse by officers of the state to torture as a means of punishment within the prisons.
The evidence thus permits the conclusion that the claimant would personally be subject to cruel or unusual treatment and even a serious risk of torture, if he returned to Argentina.
For these reasons, I find that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a "person in need of protection" and I therefore accept his claim for refugee protection.

INTRODUCTION
The claimant is a 46 year-old citizen of Sri Lanka, who claims Refugee Protection as a "Convention refugee" for reasons of nationality (Tamil), imputed political opinion, and membership in a particular social group, namely being a Tamil from the north of Sri Lanka. He also claims Refugee Protection for fear of a risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or torture.
The evidence included the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF)1, his examination under oath, and the exhibits provided by both claimant's Counsel and Refugee Protection Officer (RPO), the latter of whom was not present at the hearing.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant is a Tamil farmer who lived his life in XXXXX, northern Sri Lanka, some seven kilometres away from XXXXX town. He has six years of education. He is married with three sons, who presently range in age from 17 to 22 years old. As a result of living in northern Sri Lanka through the 1990s to the present day, the claimant came into conflict with the various combatants in the Sri Lankan Civil War, namely the Sri Lankan Armed Forces (SLAF) and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). The LTTE used to "borrow" the claimant's tractor and attempted to extort funds from him. The army had detained him on several occasions, questioned the claimant and severely assaulted him.
The situation came to a head on the XXXXX 2002. The LTTE took the claimant's tractor, which was found later by the military with boxes of dynamite. The claimant was arrested and tortured by the military in their camp. He was detained until the XXXXX 2002, whereupon a bribe was paid. The LTTE came to see the claimant as they had been made aware that the claimant had given "information" to the army during his detention. Fearing for his life, the claimant went to Colombo and left Sri Lanka of the XXXXXX 2002, making the present refugee claim in Canada upon his arrival on the 18th of March 2002.
DETERMINATION
The panel determines that as the claimant's evidence is lacking in credibility and trustworthiness, he is not a "Convention refugee", nor is he a "person in need of protection" for a risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or torture.
ANALYSIS
The panel finds a general lack of credibility with respect to this claim.
A critical issue in all refugee claims is one of identity. The claimant has an obligation to provide the panel2 with acceptable documentation to establish his identity, and if not to provide reasonable explanations. This was not so in the present case. The claimant' only identification document is a Birth Certificate3, which was issued in 1994. He did not provide any photo identification. He left Sri Lanka with his Sri Lankan National Identity Card (NIC) and Driver's License. According to the claimant, this was taken by the "agent" on the last leg of their flight to New York City. Why was this the case? The claimant testified that the agent advised him that being in possession of this documentation could put the claimant at risk, as he was travelling on a false identity. Where was this Birth Certificate? According to the claimant, it was in his pants pocket in his bag. Why was his Birth Certificate separated from his NIC and Driver's License? The claimant had no explanation. He was therefore asked, when he cleared the American customs at the airport of New York, why the agent did not give him back his documents. The claimant had no explanation; he said that the agent appeared to be in a hurry. The panel does not believe that the claimant is being truthful or that he is a credible witness. He has not met his obligation to provide acceptable documentation or reasonable explanations for their absence.
In other instances, there were also a lack of credibility and plausibility in his claim. For example, the explanation concerning how the claimant cleared customs at the Kennedy Airport in New York. The claimant alleges that he did not have to identify himself at the Kennedy Airport in New York. According to the claimant, the agent did all the talking for him and advised the US Immigration official that the claimant was too drunk to answer questions. His explanation was not believed by Canadian Immigration upon his arrival at the border4, nor is he believed by the panel. In light of September 11th, 2001, the panel does not believe it credible or plausible that an individual would have been able to enter the United States in such a manner, without raising suspicion and further investigation. The claimant is not a credible witness.
The claimant alleges that he lived all his life, until his departure in XXXXX 2001, some few kilometres from XXXXX town. Yet, when the panel asked the claimant what he recalled was going on in the Sri Lankan Civil War in the months of April, May and June of 2000, the claimant testified that there was some "peace talks and then some bombing". The claimant appeared to be completely unaware of LTTE operations and "unceasing waves", serious bombardments and displacements of thousands in and around XXXXX town during that period of time. The claimant's lack of recollection of these details, in the panel's mind, places further doubt on his credibility. The panel does not believe that the claimant was even in Sri Lanka in the year 2000.
The claimant also provided contradictory evidence during the course of his testimony. For example, the claimant was initially asked by the panel with what airline he flew into New York City. The claimant testified that it was American Airlines. The claimant was reminded that he did not tell Canadian Immigration, upon his arrival5, this information. The claimant testified that he was told by the agent not to reveal the airline that was taken to New York City. However, later in his testimony, when the claimant was asked what specific instructions the agent provided him when he left the airport in New York City, the claimant did not mention the issue of American Airlines. When confronted, the claimant had no explanation.
The claimant also provided contradictory evidence with respect to problems his son would have had with the SLAF. The claimant testified initially that on occasion, the army would come to the farm and ask some questions of the boys, and looked to see whether or not they had scars of battle. However, nothing further was done. When the panel (given especially the age of the boys) expressed surprise at this, the claimant then altered his testimony to say that on occasion, the SLAF threatened to take his sons from him. Again, the claimant is providing inconsistent and contradictory evidence. He is simply not a credible witness.
CONCLUSION
For all the above-mentioned reasons, the panel concludes that the claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXX, is not a "Convention refugee" within the meaning of Section 966 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, nor is he a "person in need of protection" as defined in Section 97(1) a) and b)7 of the same Act.
