The refugee protection claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, is a 24-year-old citizen of Peru. He says that he fears for his life in his country because of the political opinion imputed to him by corrupt high-ranking members of the military and by former agents of the government secret services.
The evidence reveals that since XXXXX, 1999 the claimant had worked in the XXXXXXX XXXXXX department of the Bank of XXXXXX XXXX XXX whose majority shareholder was the XXXXXXXXXXXX for XXXXXXX XXXX XXXXX XXXXXX.
In XXXXX 2001, in connection with the investigations that the new government was conducting into the corruption that had been rampant under Fujimori and Montesinos and as part of the fight against laundering of drug trafficking dollars, the Bank's management collaborated with the government by undertaking a full compilation of large international transfers made since 1990.
The work was entrusted to the claimant, who was authorized to access computerized records and data. He resolutely accepted his new duties, as he was convinced of the justice of the fight against the profiteers of the former regime.
In XXXXX 2001, the claimant began to receive anonymous telephone calls at his office, then at his home. His callers, without identifying themselves, told him that they belonged to the intelligence service. They threatened him with death if he refused to hand over to them the originals of the compromising documents contained in the records he had to consult. Then he found himself shadowed when he moved about from place to place.
The claimant was worried because he knew that many civil servants and members of the military were being compromised in the research he was doing. He informed his superior, who told him to be careful, while encouraging him to continue with his work.
On XXXXXXX, 2001, when he had practically finished compiling information, he was intercepted on the road near his house by two individuals who identified themselves as members of the National Intelligence Service (SIN). They beat him and threatened to kill him, demanding that he turn over to them the originals of the records and documents that he was investigating. They searched his vehicle, but were forced to leave him alone when a private surveillance agent arrived, drawn to the scene by the noise of people shouting.
After this incident, the claimant hastened to submit his report to his superior. The claimant was sure that the compelling evidence the report contained against a number of high-ranking individuals would definitely result in charges being laid against them. The claimant feared reprisals from these individuals, especially since he had been identified and had refused to collaborate with their henchman by handing the evidence over to them.
The claimant therefore took a few weeks of holiday-that was the official story-but actually went to hide at the home of a friend. It was there that he made the decision to flee Peru. On XXXXX, 2001 he went to the United States. Since XXXXX 2000, he had been in possession of an American visa, which he had obtained with the idea of possibly going on vacation.
He was therefore allowed into the United States for six months. On XXXXXX, 2002 he applied to have his permit of stay extended for another six months. In the meantime, he consulted three lawyers, who told him that he had no chance of obtaining refugee protection. He did not want to face the possibility of being illegally on American soil, and in surfing the Internet, he learned that he could come to Canada. He therefore came to the Canadian border on March 21, 2002 to seek refuge.
At the hearing, the claimant said that he feared vengeance from the important figures implicated by his report. The report contained a list of approximately 25 individuals and companies: members of the military, public officials, and business people and companies associated with them. The claimant's report was delivered to the Congress Committee, and charges were laid against the individuals in question. Some of them have been arrested, and an active hunt is in progress for others.
The claimant has had news of his family. There have been no calls to his home, but shortly before the hearing, his brother-in-law told him that bizarre individuals were lurking around the house.
The claimant said that he had never asked for the protection of the Congress because he doubted that he could have been, or would be, protected against the powerful personalities targeted by his investigation. The threats and aggression he has suffered lead him to believe that these people have the means to track him down and punish him. They have, he said, connections and contacts everywhere in the country. As evidence of this, he said it is highly probable that they have friends in the Bank because they knew he was responsible for the internal investigation of the Bank's records.
DETERMINATION
After analyzing all the testimony and documentary evidence, I find that the claimant has established that he is in need of Canada's protection.
ANALYSIS
The claimant testified in a frank and direct manner, answering all the questions, which were sometimes difficult, and providing many highly relevant details. He was able to satisfy me of the role he played in the Bank. His explanations concerning the manner in which he conducted his investigation of the Bank's records have persuaded me that what he said was plausible. Consequently, I have found the claimant to be credible.
His identity has been established satisfactorily.
Although the claimant stated that he had agreed to undertake the investigation because he fully supported the government's fight against corruption and money laundering, I am not satisfied, based on the evidence, that the claimant was targeted because of his political opinion. Those who apparently wanted to attack him seem to have been motivated essentially by a desire for vengeance because he had refused to hand over, or to make disappear, evidence that was damning for highly placed individuals, or by their desire to prevent him from possibly testifying in court about the discoveries that had been made as a result of his investigation.
Nothing in the evidence would allow me to find that the claimant publicly expressed his opinion. Consequently, I find that the claimant is not at risk of persecution by reason of the opinion he has expressed or by reason of any political opinion that might be imputed to him.
Moreover, the claimant was targeted by these individuals because of his work-what he did-not because of his membership in any particular social group.
The evidence therefore does permit a finding of a risk of persecution for one of the grounds enumerated in the definition of "Convention refugee."
However, the evidence does permit a finding that the life of the claimant would be at risk if he returned to Peru. The people who hold a grudge against him still have significant means and resources at their disposal, making it possible for them to track him down anywhere in Peru.
In this regard, even Jose Ugaz, the man in charge of the commission of inquiry into corruption, declared in January 2002-according to articles produced as Exhibit A-231-that Montesinos continues to threaten people though his emissaries. This allows me to find that there is indeed a serious possibility that former agents of the SIN and high-ranking military will want to do everything they can to relegate the claimant to the silence of the tomb.
Any consideration of the claimant's long stay of several months in the United States, without claiming the protection of that country, would be irrelevant to these proceedings. The claimant has shown that he had legal status during his stay on American soil; he did not feel that he was in danger at that time because he did not fear being sent back to his country.
Furthermore, the length of time that elapses before a person claims refugee status is always a useful factor in analyzing the existence of a subjective fear of persecution. In the present case, however, which concerns a person in need of protection, the text of section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act does not require a claimant to prove that he has such a subjective fear, since the question of being personally subject to a risk to one's life is an issue to be settled by an objective analysis of the facts and circumstances.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, I determine that XXXXXXXXXXXX is a "person in need of protection" pursuant to section 97(1)(b) of the Act. Consequently, I accept his claim for refugee protection.

On October 29, 2002, the panel heard the claim for refugee protection of Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX. On November 5, 2002, it rendered its oral decision and reasons on tape. In accordance with Article 62 of the Rules for the Refugee Protection Division (RPD), the Minister's counsel requested a copy of the written reasons.
The following is the written version of the oral decision and reasons, edited for grammar and syntax.
These are the reasons for the decision with regard to the claim of Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
The claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is a 20-year-old citizen of Pakistan. He alleges to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of the police and Mujahedin, by reasons of his political opinion. He alleges that he was an active worker of the Jammu and Kashmir People's National Party (JKPNP), at the village level. He alleges that he was threatened and detained by the Mujahedin, and that he was arrested and brutalized by the police on account of his political activities. He claims to have fled Pakistan because the police accused him on false charges, and a warrant is now out for his arrest. In addition, he claims to be a "person in need of protection", in that he fears a risk to his life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or torture in Pakistan.
First, on the issue of identity, the claimant produced a national identity card (NIC),1 a birth certificate,2 a state subject certificate,3 and a school certificate,4 attesting to his identity. He was asked many questions about his birth certificate and state subject certificate. He was familiar with all the information appearing on both documents. He explained, to the satisfaction of the panel, why he had applied for his birth certificate and his state subject certificate, issued by the Azad Kashmir government. There was no question asked about his school certificate, and this document remains uncontested.
Exhibit M-15 is a copy of the claimant's NIC and translation, with analysis of the card from an immigration officer. The immigration officer, after examining the card, concludes that although the card appears to be authentic, it has been subject to alteration, providing certain findings that explained why she arrived at this conclusion. In response to Exhibit M-1, the claimant testified that he had personally obtained the NIC in Azad Kashmir.
The panel is aware that the authenticity of national identity cards from Pakistan has been regularly sent for expertise by Canada Immigration. The verification would normally be analysed by specialists for counterfeit documents. However, in this case, there is a lack of evidence to establish that the immigration officer is an expert or has background in analysing fraudulent documents. Thus, the panel is not prepared to give much weight to Exhibit M-1. Even if Exhibit M-1 raises doubt about the claimant's NIC, the panel finds his other identity documents sufficient to establish his identity.
Overall speaking, credibility is the determinative issue in this claim. The panel finds no major contradictions between the claimant's testimony and his Personal Information Form (PIF),6 or between his testimony and the interview made by the Canadian immigration officer.7
The claimant was asked to describe the manifesto, the background, and the structure of the JKPNP. He was knowledgeable about these aspects of his party. His involvement in the party was corroborated by a membership card8 and a letter issued by the said party.9 He also produced a letter from a lawyer in Pakistan10 and a copy of his warrant of arrest.11 Both documents were examined, and questions were raised. The panel finds the claimant's testimony to be generally credible.
Moreover, it is to be noted that the claimant's allegation of his police problem is not inconsistent with the documentary evidence. Documentation clearly shows that JKPNP is an organization which advocates for the independence of Kashmir, which would be free from the ruling of Pakistan.12 Documents13 also indicate that the Pakistani government and establishment in that country do not want Kashmir to emerge as an independent country. The document continues to say that Pakistan will never agree to an independent Kashmir.
The question here is: what would be the action of the government to the groups which advocate for the independence? Exhibit A-3 16.2314 states that those who believe in independent Kashmir are not in the good books of Pakistan, and when a person is perceived to be a threat to Pakistani interest, the government would implicate this person in local non-political issues, for example drug dealing, theft, robbery, etc.15 This is consistent with the alleged treatment of the claimant.
Further to the lawyer's letter, which gives the Penal Code for the claimant's offences, the claimant testified that the charges that he faces are for "robbery" and "insulting people". As a whole, the panel finds that the objective evidence supports the claimant's allegations.
There were some omissions in the claimant's evidence, particularly in his PIF. For example, in his PIF, he did not talk about the fact that he was beaten on two occasions. Exhibit P-816 does not reflect these incidents either. There was also an omission in the JKPNP letter about the claimant's role of collecting funds for the party at his store. The other issue is the plausibility of the claimant being personally targeted, when the other officials in his party were not having problems. Although the panel is not entirely convinced on this matter, it is willing to grant the claimant the benefit of the doubt, in light of his overall credibility.
For these reasons, the panel believes that the claimant is a credible witness. He has therefore established more than a mere possibility that he would be at risk of persecution should he return to Pakistan.
Having arrived at this conclusion, the panel finds it unnecessary to further evaluate the claim under Section 97(1)a) and b), as a "person in need of protection"17 in Canada.
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) therefore comes to the conclusion that Mr. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a "Convention refugee",18 as defined in Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

The asylum seeker, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (alias XXX), is a 55-year-old citizen of St. Vincent and the Grenadines. He says that death assuredly awaits him in his country because there are no dialysis machines to treat his serious problem of renal failure resulting from high blood pressure.
The claimant lived for 26 years in the United States, where he had permanent resident status. He lost that status because of his criminal convictions and was deported to his country on
XXXXX, 1999.
Being unable to obtain the care required by his medical condition, he left St. Vincent on XXXXXX, 2001 and came to Canada via Trinidad, hoping to receive treatment here. He approached the local community service centre and was told he could not be treated because of his visitor status.
He therefore took a bus to the United States on XXXXX, 2001. He was arrested at Champlain and accused of unlawful entry by the US authorities. During his detention, he became so ill that he had to be treated at a hospital in Plattsburgh from XXXXXXX to XXXXXX, 2001. It was explained to him there that dialysis would now be his only salvation.
Also on XXXXX, 2001, the US immigration authorities returned him to the Canadian border. He has been in detention since his second arrival in Canada and has been receiving dialysis treatment three times a week at the hospital in XXXX.
The claimant completed his refugee claim on January 22, 2002. His application was referred to the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) on April 18, 2002. He filed his PIF on May 17, 2002.
In his PIF, he basically states that the St. Vincent authorities are making approaches to neighbouring countries in the archipelago to group their medical services together, partly with the aim of being able to offer dialysis treatment to citizens who urgently need it.
The claimant referred to documents stating that there is still no dialysis equipment in St. Vincent and his physical condition is such that he needs that treatment on a continuing basis if he is to remain alive.
During his testimony, the claimant affirmed he would go back to his country immediately if dialysis equipment were available.
The claimant alleges he risks persecution in his country because of his membership in a particular social group: persons in St. Vincent suffering from renal failure and requiring dialysis.
The claimant also invoked the new provisions of the Act to the effect that his life will be threatened if he is deported to St. Vincent.
DETERMINATION:
After analysing all the evidence, both oral and documentary, the panel finds that the claimant does not qualify as a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
ANALYSIS:
The claimant established his identity in a satisfactory manner.
The evidence shows that the claimant first came to Canada for the sole purpose of obtaining treatment. The medical data in the file show he is going to die in the absence of regular dialysis treatment. St. Vincent and the Grenadines is a poor country in the Caribbean that does not currently have any dialysis machines. His country thus cannot offer the claimant the treatment his state of health requires, hence the real threat to his life if he returns there.
Does the claimant risk persecution because of his membership in a particular social group?
At first sight, the claimant's situation is rather unique and individual, making it difficult to conclude he belongs to a social group according to the Supreme Court of Canada's analysis in Ward of the meaning of that expression.
However, the claimant stated that about twenty people with renal failure have died in St. Vincent in recent years for lack of dialysis treatment. Consequently, it is permissible to think that a certain number of individuals in that country share some unchangeable characteristics, in that they are all afflicted by chronic renal failure and risk immanent death in the absence of dialysis. It could thus be concluded that they form a particular group as they have certain characteristics in common.
Nevertheless, under Canadian refugee law as established by the Supreme Court in Ward, Canada has no obligation to give unlimited asylum and accept responsibility just because a group exists. The alleged persecution must result from the affiliation or membership in a particular social group, in other words the affiliation itself must render the members vulnerable to persecution. But it is clear in this case that the claimant is not vulnerable because of his affiliation or membership in a group; like all the members of his group, he is in danger because of his illness, his personal medical condition.
Even if one were to conclude that there is a social group consisting of persons in St. Vincent suffering from renal failure and needing dialysis, as about twenty people have apparently died there for lack of kidney dialysis in recent years, there is no evidence to permit the conclusion that those persons are or were victims of persecution by the state or another agent of persecution. The inability of a third world country to offer its population adequate health services does not constitute persecution within the meaning of the "Convention refugee" definition.
It is true that the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 16, 1966, was ratified by St. Vincent and the Grenadines and that, under Article 12 of that Covenant, that state undertook to create conditions which would assure all its citizens of medical service and medical attention in the event of sickness. However, Article 2 of the Covenant reflects the desire of the international community to take into account the difficulties of many economically less developed countries, by indicating clearly that each state's undertaking should be carried out to the maximum of its available resources.
Furthermore, the claimant himself alleges that the authorities in his country have started discussions with neighbouring states with a view to making dialysis treatment available. That indicates the opposite of malicious intent or desire to persecute the members of the social group suggested and defined by the claimant and his counsel.
It should also be pointed out that the claimant has no real fear of persecution, as he says he would return to his country immediately if a dialysis machine were available there.
Having determined that the claimant does not risk persecution in his country, it remains to be determined if he is a person in need of protection within the meaning of the new Act.
It has been established that the claimant risks certain death if he is removed to St. Vincent, as he will not be able to obtain there the treatment he needs. So he does not want to return there because he will be in danger of death anywhere in his country.
However, in view of the requirement in paragraph 97(1)(b)(iv)1 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the claimant is clearly not a person in need of protection, given that the threat to his life is caused by the inability of his country to provide adequate health or medical care.
Although this question was never raised by the claimant or the Minister's representative, it should be stressed that nothing in the evidence permits the conclusion that the claimant risks being submitted in St. Vincent to torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention against Torture.
Claimant's counsel submits that the Act permits the panel to allow this asylum claim on humanitarian grounds. The panel considers it does not have that jurisdiction.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, the panel does not recognize XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (alias XXXXX) as a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.

Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a citizen of Nicaragua. She claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of unknown parties because of her family (who were Sandinistas) and at the hands of the Sandinistas by reason of her political opinion. In addition, she claims to be a person in need of protection because she would be subjected personally to a danger of torture or to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Nicaragua.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges the following.
The claimant's parents were both deeply committed Sandinistas. Both served as messengers for the movement. Her mother was detained in 1979, cruelly mistreated and never heard from again. Her father fled in 1990, possibly to Cuba. The claimant was raised by her grandmother. In 1990, strangers came calling three times asking for her father. Following the last visit, the house was ransacked. The family received threatening notes thereafter.
In September 1999, she was asked by pro-Sandinista students at her university to join in a national student strike. She declined to do so, leading to recriminations that she was a coward. In XXXXXX 1999, her grandmother died. A month after that, she was visited by strangers again, asking about her father and whether she had been involved in the student strike. They left without doing her any harm. The claimant went to stay with a neighbour before deciding to join a relative in Canada. The strangers never identified themselves but allegedly kept the claimant under surveillance for ten years.
ANALYSIS
The claimant fears that these strangers, whose identity is unknown but who are anti-Sandinista, will harm her. However, the simple fact remains that they had ample opportunity to harm her in the ten years following her father's departure. No harm occurred. Can we, knowing this, say that there is a serious possibility of the claimant being harmed upon return to Nicaragua? We cannot.
In addition to the lack of any attempts at harm by the alleged agents of persecution, there is another reason why I do not consider the claimant's fear of serious harm to be well-founded. This reason has to do with state protection.
In Ward,1 the Supreme Court of Canada has linked the well-foundedness of fear to the adequacy of state protection. In its view, a claimant's fear is well-founded if no adequate state protection is available. Conversely, this fear is not well-founded if adequate state protection is available.
I considered this claim not only from the point of view of whether the claimant is a Convention refugee (Section 96) but also whether she is a person in need of protection under Sections 97(1)(a) and 97(1)(b) of IRPA. Since my finding is that state protection exists for the claimant in Nicaragua, my conclusion is that the claimant's fear of serious harm is not well-founded. By serious harm, in the context of this claim, I mean persecution, risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. I do not include torture in the categories mentioned here since there is no evidence of state involvement in the harm feared, as required by Article 1 of the International Convention on Torture.
Following Ward,2 a presumption of adequate state protection exists in every claim unless there is "clear and convincing evidence to the contrary." The claimant has presented no "clear and convincing" evidence of Nicaragua's inability to protect her. Her evidence is that she did not even approach the state police or any other state authority to seek protection. Her Personal Information Form (PIF) states that her grandmother told her not to do so for fear of further problems. In her oral testimony, she said that she had been afraid of going to the police. When asked why she had been afraid, the claimant's initial reply was that the police were corrupt. Instead of helping her, they could have
mistreated her. When pressed further on the matter, she testified that her unseen tormentors had warned her in numerous notes not to go to the police.
I do not believe the claimant with respect to the notes. I do so for a simple reason. She claimed that she received 200 notes a year for 10 years running. This makes it simply too implausible to be accepted. As for police corruption, she produced no documentary evidence to bear this out. Finally, with respect to her fear that the police could mistreat her, she could establish no basis for that fear.
With respect to a claimant's obligation to go to the state for protection, the Federal Court of Appeal has held in Kadenko,3 that
When the state in question is a democratic state...the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the sources of action open to him or her.
The claimant fell far short of what was required of her in terms of seeking protection, considering that Nicaragua is now a democratic state. If it was unreasonable for her to approach the state, she should have been able to show why it was unreasonable.4 She has not done so.
Not having exhausted the avenues of protection available to her in her own country, the claimant cannot turn to the international community (and Canada, specifically) for surrogate protection.
DETERMINATION
Based on the foregoing analysis, I conclude that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection. I therefore reject her claim.
"Harindar Aulach"
Harindar Aulach

These are the reasons for the decision in the matter of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Mexico.
The claimant is a 21-year-old citizen of Chiapas, Mexico, from XXXXXXX. He claims to be a person in need of protection because he would be subjected personally to a risk to his life or to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Mexico. Counsel for the claimant conceded the claimant was not a Convention refugee, as there was no nexus to one of the enumerated grounds.
The claimant alleges the following:
He says that he was cutting wood one day at the end of November 2000 on the XXXXX Ranch where he worked. At that time, six men stopped him, pointing their guns at him. They beat him, threatened to cut his finger off, and told him to get off of their mountain.
After pleading with them for his release, they said that they would forgive him but if he came back to their mountain they would kill him.
He realized that it must be a marijuana plantation and he ran away and went home. He did not report what he saw to the police because he was also afraid of the police. In testimony he alleged that these six men also warned him that if he contacted the police they would kill him.
He moved to Cancun a couple of days later where he remained until XXXX of 2001; some four months.
No problems arose in Cancun but because he was afraid these six men would find him there, he moved from Cancun to the United States where he remained until around XXXXXX of 2001. In XXXXX 2001, he crossed the border into Canada, making his claim approximately two weeks later.
I find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Mexico would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
My reasons are as follows.
IDENTITY
The claimant's identity as a national of Mexico is established by his testimony and the supporting documentation file: a birth certificate, a marriage certificate, and a voter's identity card bearing a photograph of the claimant of his likeness. Consequently, I find that the claimant is who he says he is and he is a citizen of Mexico from the area of Chiapas.
CREDIBILITY
I have found the claimant to be a credible witness and, therefore, believe most of what he has alleged in support of his claim. He testified in a straightforward manner and the inconsistencies in his testimony I will attribute to his lack of sophistication. The claimant has only three years of formal education and gave a very basic presentation of his evidence. I take this into consideration in analyzing the claim.
However, I have found problematic the claimant's conclusion with respect to one material point: the agents of harm seeking him out in Cancun. The claimant has surmised this based upon the threats that he received by these men in XXXXXXXXXX I do not feel that his conclusion is justified in the circumstances, particularly given the fact that he never saw these men again in Cancun or anywhere else after November of 2000.
I accept that the claimant is afraid of these individuals; however, his fear that they will follow him throughout Mexico is not justified on the evidence.
NEXUS
For the claimant to be a Convention refugee, his fear of persecution must be "by reason of" one of the five grounds enumerated in the Convention refugee definition.1 I find, and counsel for the claimant concurs, that the harm feared by the claimant does not fall within one of the five grounds enumerated in the Convention refugee definition. I find, therefore, that the claimant is not a Convention refugee because there is no a connection to any of the five enumerated grounds. In sort, there is no nexus.
Having found that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, I then considered whether the harm allegedly feared by the claimant would amount to a risk to life, or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a danger of torture.
I do not find that what the claimant fears amounts to a risk of danger of torture.
My reasoning for this is that the agents of harm are not public officials or other persons acting in an official capacity. Nor is the purpose of the harm, the severe pain or suffering which may be inflicted for purposes such as obtaining information or a confession, or punishment, intimidation or coercion for any reason based upon discrimination. Therefore, there is no serious possibility or reasonable chance that the claimant faces a danger of torture if he returns to Mexico.
That said, the only remaining ground upon which the claimant could be granted protection is under the category of risk to life, or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
HARM FEARED
The claimant alleged that should he return to Mexico he would be subjected to the following harm: namely, that he would be killed by the six individuals who threatened him in November of 2000. He claims that this constitutes a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. At issue in this claim is whether the harm which the claimant would allegedly face constitutes cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. The terms "cruel and unusual" are not defined in the Act. Canadian jurisprudence has interpreted the phrase "cruel and usual" as punishment or treatment that shocks the conscience.2 Treatment that is inhuman or degrading has been equated with cruel and unusual treatment.3 Inhuman treatment has been described as premeditated, applied for hours at a stretch and causing, if not bodily injury, intense physical and mental suffering. Degrading treatment has been described as arousing in its victims feelings of fear, anguish, and inferiority, capable of humiliating and debasing them, and possibly breaking their physical and moral resistance.4
The claimant fears six individuals who beat and threatened him once. He did as he was told and there have been no further consequences to his family nor to himself. He did not experience any problems in Cancun nor have any further problems been reported to him or to anyone since this incident almost two years ago.
I find, then, that this was an isolated incident not likely to be repeated in the future. The threat by these individuals was predicated upon an act by the claimant. If he did not report this incident to the police and if he did not return to the mountain, presumably, they would not harm him in any way. Nor have they.
INTERNAL FLIGHT ALTERNATIVE
As indicated above, the claimant experienced no problems in Cancun. I accept that he may have been fearful there, but I do not find that his subjective fear has an objective basis.
On the evidence before me, I find that there is no serious possibility of the claimant being subjected to a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Cancun. The claimant moved to Cancun and worked there for four months without incident. While there, he did not see the agent of harm although he remained fearful that he might. He also indicated that he did not consider moving to another part of Mexico because of his fear, but he did not take any reasonable steps that a prudent person might to discover whether or not he would be safe in another part of Mexico.
In the refugee context if I find part of the country where the claimant would not face a serious possibility of persecution, I would go on to consider whether it would be unreasonable, having regard to all of the circumstances of the claim, including those particular to the claimant, for the claimant to seek refuge in Cancun.
I find that I cannot go on to consider the reasonableness of the potential IFA in the context of s. 97(1)(b) for the following reasons. Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Act speaks only of a risk faced by the person in every part of the country. It does not add a reasonableness element to the availability of a safe area in the country; an element that has been extensively interpreted by the Federal Court in the context of Convention refugee cases. In order to find, therefore, that the claimant has an IFA, I must be satisfied that the IFA is in an area of the country (1) which is reasonably accessible to the claimant and (2) where the claimant would not face a serious possibility of a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. I find, however, that the evidence presented in support of the claimant's allegations does not establish a serious possibility that he would be subjected to such harm in the IFA.
For the foregoing reasons, I conclude that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection and I, therefore, reject his claim.
(Signed)
"Paulah Dauns"

This is the decision and the reasons for the decision on the claims to be a Convention refugees and a people in need of protection by XXXXXXXXXXX (XXXXX) and her two minor sons XXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXX. Ms. Salehi is a 34-year-old citizen of Iran and the United Kingdom. Her sons, seven and ten years old respectively, are also citizens of both countries. Claims were made against both countries. The principal claimant was designated as the representative of her two sons.
ALLEGATIONS
The principal claimant alleges that she is the wife of an abusive husband who also abuses their two children. She fears that should they return to Iran she will, at worst, be unable to divorce her husband and that she will continue to be abused by him; if divorce were possible, by Iranian law, the principal claimant would have to leave the children in the care of their abusive father. The principal claimant states that she is afraid to return to and live in the United Kingdom (UK) as her husband would be able to locate her and her sons too easily. Should he do so, the principal claimant fears further abuse to her and her sons, perhaps even the loss of their lives.
EVIDENCE
The written and documentary evidence considered in the claim is listed on the exhibit sheet on file. The claimant also testified orally. It is the claimant's evidence that she was badly abused over the fourteen years or so of her marriage to her present husband. After the two children were born, they too were abused. This was a result of their father's overly zealous attempts at discipline and teaching methods which included hitting, yelling and long periods of study at times past the children's normal bed time. The claimant suffered for a long time and eventually made up her mind to leave her husband. While her husband was on one of his many business trips, the principal claimant sold her jewellery and purchased tickets for her children and her to leave Iran. She already had a multiple exit permit for her and her sons as they travelled frequently with the principal claimant's husband. The claimants fled to England, travelled to Ireland, returned to England and made their way to Canada where they eventually made a claim
for refugee status. Although the claimant is a British citizen she did not remain in that country as she believed her husband would be able to track her down too easily. This fear was born out as her husband visited to two places at which the principal claimant and her children had stayed while in Britain.
DETERMINATION
I determine that the claimants are not Convention refugees or people in need of protection.
REASONS
Clear and convincing evidence that refuted Britain's ability to protect the claimants was not adduced nor was it shown that protection would not have been available to the claimants or that it would have been, or would in the future be, unreasonable to expect the principal claimant to avail herself and her children of that protection in the United Kingdom.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant's travelled to Canada on British Passports. The female claimant also had an Iranian passport. These passports were copied by Canada Immigration and Citizenship (CIC) and certified copies were available at the hearing. I am satisfied that the claimants are the people they claim to be and that they are citizens of Iran and the United Kingdom.
The claimants were outside Iran for just over a month but the principal claimant did not seek protection from any of the places to which she travelled. These places included Italy, United Kingdom, Ireland and the Netherlands. The claimant explained that this was because she could not conceive of being anywhere in Europe and being safe there because her husband travelled often and had his company's assistance to procure visas and any other necessary travel documents. The principal claimant explained that the claimants stay in UK would have been much shorter but she had difficulty getting a flight after the terrorist attack in New York, USA on September 11, 2001. The principal claimant explained that she feels safe in Canada because Iranian companies do not do business with Canada and therefore she believes her husband's company could not assist her husband in getting a visa to come to this country.
The principal claimant and her son are British citizens. The claimants are obliged to have exhausted the protection available to them in any country of which they are citizens before they can expect to obtain protection from another country. Or they must adduce clear and convincing evidence that those countries are unable or unwilling to protect them or that it was and would be unreasonable for them to take advantage of the protection offered the citizens of their country of citizenship.
The principal claimant stated that she believed that protection would not be extended to her in Britain because she has not established residency there. Objective documentation of this belief was not adduced. The claimant further stated that she does not know how life in England is because she left there when she was just a few ears old. Although the claimant's explanation is understandable in her alleged circumstances, her fear does not relieve her of the obligation to seek protection from Britain. The claimant's unwillingness to approach British authorities for protection, no matter how subjectively reasonable given her alleged state of mind and fear at the time she was in Britain in 2001, does not remove the onus on her of rebutting the presumption that the state is capable of providing protection. Documents disclosed in Exhibit 6 reveal that harassment in Britain is governed by the Protection from Harassment Act 1997. This act prohibits harassment and makes harassment an offence. A victim has recourse through either or both criminal and civil law depending on the circumstances. The material speaks of restraining orders, for example. There are crisis lines, citizen advice bureaus and police are required to respond to emergency domestic violence calls. Such organisations cater not to just abused adults but to their children as well. The British Home Office maintains a web site that is dedicated to informing people who experience domestic violence of their rights and there are several organisations in Britain dedicated to the support and guidance of victims of domestic abuse either through providing refuge or through legal and personal counselling. The home office web page information states "There are refuges specifically for women and children from particular ethnic or cultural backgrounds..."
The principal claimant's fear of persecution of herself and her minor children is not objectively well founded in the United Kingdom.
The immigration consultant assisting the claimant pointed out that the information from the British Home Office included in exhibit 6 records that in England and Wales in 1997 47% of the 224 female homicides, or about 105 women, were killed by partners. He submitted that this is evidence that Britain is unable to protect the claimant from her abusive husband. These figures have to be considered in relationship to others. For example in 1995 6.6 million incidents of family violence were recorded and it is estimated that only a quarter of all domestic violence incidents are reported to police. Assuming that those figures remained the same in 1997, although shocking and all too many, 105 deaths are very few in relationship to the total number of domestic violence incidents. In 1998 it was estimated that domestic violence cost Britain about 278 million pounds. This is does not reflect a state unable to protect its citizens.
State protection does not have to be perfect and indeed the immigration consultant pointed out that in Canada women still die as a result of domestic violence. The principal claimant testified that she did not even research or inquire about the possibility of finding protection in Britain. She did not provide clear and convincing evidence that protection would not be available to her and her two children. The claimant's therefore are not Convention refugees or people in need of protection.
As the claimants all are all British citizens and I have conclude that the evidence reveals on the balance of probabilities that Britain is able and willing to protect the claimants, it is reasonable to expect the claimant to seek that protection. No analysis was done on the claims against Iran.
CONCLUSION
Having considered all the evidence, the Gender Guidelines1 and the Update and having heard the immigration consultant's submissions and for the reasons stated above I find that XXXXXXXXXXX (XXXXX) and her two minor sons XXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXX are not Convention refugees and they are not people in need of protection.

These are the reasons of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) in the claim of XXXXXXXXX, the claimant. The evidence reveals that the claimant is a 63-year-old female citizen of India.
SUMMARY OF THE EVIDENCE
The claimant testified that since she married XXXXXXXX in 1954 she has experienced problems. She said that her husband is a heavy drinker who sold six acres of their property to another party and gave 22/23 acres of it for lease to a third party. The claimant was able to recover most of the land that was leased out but in doing so she made enemies of those people from whom the land was taken. Some of these people are related to the claimant's spouse. For years the claimant was harassed, attacked and at times she had to be treated by the doctor. The claimant was able to obtain the assistance of the police or of the Sarpanch of her village. The incidents seemed to stop in 1997, however the claimant testified that she was fearful and always left her house accompanied. Finally, in 2000, the claimant's granddaughter got married in the United Kingdom, where her daughter and son-in-law live, and she was able to obtain a visitor visa that allowed her to go to the wedding. At the same time, the claimant asked for a Canadian visitor visa (CVV). She wanted to also visit her brother who has lived in Canada for 21 years. Armed with the two visas, the claimant first travelled to the United Kingdom where she sojourned with her daughter and family for four and a half months. On October 16, 2000, the claimant left the United Kingdom bound for Canada where she arrived on the same day. She stopped in Toronto, where her brother lives, and on December 12, 2000, the claimant made a refugee claim. Later she decided to move to Vancouver, where there are many people from her village who could help her get settled and find a job.
DETERMINATION
In the determination of the claim I took into consideration the testimony of the claimant and all of the evidence adduced and listed in the Exhibit List. The observations of the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) and counsel's submissions were also taken into consideration.
The determination of the panel is that the claimant is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.
ISSUES
The following issues were identified and explored: third country status, nexus, credibility, delay in claiming, failure to claim elsewhere, objective basis, and state protection. Only the determinative issues will be analyzed.
EVIDENCE AND ANALYSIS
The panel's task is to determine if the claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution and/or if she is a person in need of protection.
Credibility
I find the claimant credible. She testified in a spontaneous honest manner even though at times she tended to exaggerate her story. I, therefore, have no problems with the credibility of the claimant whose testimony was consistent with the content of her Personal Information Form (PIF)1 and with the information she gave to the Immigration Officer (I.O.) when she made her refugee claim at Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC)2. The testimony was also consistent with the information contained in the documents provided by the claimant and contained in exhibit 4.
Nexus
The main issue in this claim is nexus. I note that in Leon,3, the Court stated:
A determination with respect to "nexus" is largely a question of fact and therefore entirely within the tribunal's expertise to make.
The claimant testified that she is afraid of those people with whom she has been in a dispute over her lands. There are two parties: the XXXX family (her husband's relatives) and the people to whom some of the property was leased and from whom she retrieved the land. The panel, in examining the nexus, notes that the claimant is not persecuted in India for any of the grounds contained in the Refugee Convention.4 The panel considered the ground of Membership in a Particular Social Group and notes that in Ward5 the Supreme Court of Canada identified three possible categories of particular social group:
(1) Groups defined by an innate or unchangeable characteristic;
(2) Groups whose members voluntarily associate for reasons so fundamental to their human dignity that they should not be forced to forsake the association; and
(3) Groups associated by a former voluntary status, unalterable due to its historical permanence.
In clarifying the categories, the Court stated that:
The first category would embrace individuals fearing persecution on such bases as gender, linguistic background and sexual orientation, while the second would encompass, for example, human rights activists. The third branch is included more because of historical intentions, although it is also relevant to the anti-discrimination influences, in that one's past is an immutable part of the person.6
None of the above categories applies to this claim. I find that the claimant is a victim of crime and that the only reason why she was harassed by her enemies was because she had taken the land away from them. The claimant admitted that if she had to sell the land to her enemies, the problem would stop but they would not pay enough for the land and her son would not have a job. I also note that in regard to victims of crime, the Federal Court in Leon7 supported the finding of the CRDD that victims of crime do not have a nexus to the Convention refugee definition. The Court found that Mr. Leon was targeted not because he was a union member per se, but rather because of his efforts to protect his father's economic interests. The claimant before me was likewise targeted because she was defending her own economic interests. I, therefore, find that there is no nexus to this claim.
State Protection
The claimant testified that she often went to the police and they almost always helped her. In the case law we find that the protection of a country of which protection is sought is only considered "surrogate protection" and as articulated in Villafranca:8
No government that makes any claim to democratic values or protection of human rights can guarantee the protection of all citizens at all times. Thus it is not enough for a claimant merely to show that his government has not always been effective at protecting persons in his particular situation ... where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens... the mere fact that it is not always successful at doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that the victims ... are unable to avail themselves of such protection.
In Ward the Supreme Court stated that:
... Absent a situation of complete breakdown of state apparatus, such as that recognized in Lebanon in Zalzali it should be assumed that the state is capable of protecting a claimant.9
To rebut the above presumption, the claimant must provide "clear and convincing" proof of the state's inability to protect. This onus has been described by the Federal Court of Appeal as one that is "...difficult, though not insurmountable".10 In this respect, it was stated in Ward that the claimant's burden of presenting "clear and convincing" proof of the state's inability to protect should not be an impossible burden:
... it would seem to defeat the purpose of international protection if a claimant would be required to risk his or her life seeking ineffective protection of a state, merely to demonstrate that ineffectiveness.11
In her testimony the claimant said that the police always assisted her and that only after 1997, was she advised by the Sarpanch to stop going to the police. However, the claimant testified that after 1997 she did not experience any incidents. The claimant also testified that she went to court a few times and the court always ruled in her favour. I, therefore, find that the claimant was not able to rebut the presumption that the state can protect her.
CONSOLIDATED GROUNDS
I also examined the claim to decide whether the new Consolidated Grounds in the new Immigration and Refugee Protection Act12 (section 97(1)(a) or (b) applied to the case and I find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection. The Risk to Life ground does not apply to her claim because she can find state protection. As for Danger of Torture, there was no argument advanced that the claimant fears being tortured.
CONCLUSION
On the totality of the evidence, I find that the claimant has not established a well-founded fear of persecution, that there is no nexus to the claimant's story, that she has not given "clear and convincing" proof that she has no state protection in India and that she does not have a reasonable chance of being persecuted, for the reasons enunciated at the hearing, should she return to India.
In conclusion, although I find that the claimant could be an asset for Canada, as submitted in various letters of support from her community,13 I find that XXXXXXXXX is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.
