These are the accelerated oral reasons by the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board in Vancouver concerning the claims for refugee protection of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. Both claimants are citizens of Costa Rica.
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS
The claimants are both male homosexuals and have cohabited together as a couple in a sexual relationship since 1996, both in Costa Rica and latterly in Canada.
In late 1997, they were evicted from their residence, which they occupied jointly with a friend, because of complaints by some of their neighbours. The claimants then moved to another residential area of San Jose, where they continued to reside together until they left Costa Rica some years later.
In XXXXX 2000, the claimants were assaulted and robbed by policemen in downtown San Jose. In XXXX 2001, they both left Costa Rica and came to Canada. In December 2001, they made refugee claims here.
DETERMINATION
The panel determines that these individuals are not Convention refugees. They are also not persons in need of protection, as they would not personally be subject to a danger of torture or to a risk to their lives or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Costa Rica.
ANALYSIS
The first issue to determine was the credibility of the claimants' evidence. The panel is aware that testimony that is given under oath is presumed to be true, unless there is valid reason to doubt its truthfulness.1 However, there is valid reason to doubt and reject the truthfulness of some of the allegations made by these claimants. Their evidence contained a number of inconsistencies2, contradictions, omissions3 and exaggerations in their Personal Information Forms (PIFs)4, in their statements to Canada Immigration5, and in their oral testimony. In addition, the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, had previously provided incorrect information to the visa officer at the Canadian Embassy in San Jose in his unsuccessful application for a student visa to come to Canada. As well, the documentary evidence was preferred to the claimants' testimony on the basis that the sources were reputable and independent and had no interest in the outcome of these particular claims.6 In these circumstances, the claimants' testimony was also rebutted by the failure of the documentary evidence to mention what one would normally expect it to mention.7
The panel accepted that the claimants are citizens of Costa Rica. It was also accepted that they are both male homosexuals, who have cohabited together in a sexual relationship both in Costa Rica and in Canada.
According to their PIFs, their first real problems arose in late 1997. For the following reasons, the panel does not find their evidence about those allegations to be credible or trustworthy. According to their PIFs and their testimony, unknown individuals put excrement on their doorstep and broke a window in their home, motivated by their opposition to the claimants' sexual orientation and that
of their fellow roommate. However, both claimants gave different versions of what had happened to them in Tres Rios in their separate interviews8 with Canada Immigration when they initially commenced their refugee claims. XXXX version was that some people in their neighbourhood insulted them. They also had "thousands" of messages left on their telephone. He said that they moved from that area in XXXXX 1998/XXXXX 1999. XXXX's version was different. He said that the "neighbours took reprisals against them. They put excrement on the walls [emphasis added] and threw rocks at them." He did not mention insults, telephone calls, or a broken window. He also stated that they moved from there in XXXXX 1998. They also provided completely different versions of what they did about these problems in their interviews. According to XXXXX, they "notified police". In contrast, XXXXX stated that they "Did not [emphasis added] notify the police". However, they later included new allegations in their PIFs that they had also received death threats, both in telephone calls they personally answered and also in the messages left on their telephone answering machine. Neither of them had previously mentioned such threats. It is not unreasonable to have expected that both of these claimants would have provided a consistent version of these events in their interviews with Canada Immigration, in their PIFs, and also in their testimony.
Although the claimants did file some documents9 that they claimed to relate to the incidents in Tres Rios, they were not given any weight because the claimants' evidence was not credible about what happened to them. As well, the documents themselves do not confirm those incidents, nor were they independently proven to be truly genuine.10
The claimants next moved to Guadelupe, another residential area of the capital city, San Jose. There was no evidence that their sexual orientation created any
problems for them to obtain such new accommodation. It also proved to be a satisfactory residence for them because they lived there for successive years until they came to Canada. In addition, it was also noted that the claimants' sexual orientation had not prevented them from achieving personal goals of a good education (including a university scholarship) and steady employment during the time that they lived in Costa Rica.
In addition, there was no credible evidence that they had experienced any problems in that new area of San Jose where they lived until the end of XXXXX 2001. In their Immigration interviews, neither of them had mentioned having received a death threat in a telephone message there in 1998. It was first mentioned only later in their PIFs, in which they stated that the threat greatly concerned them. If so, it was again not credible that they would not have recalled such a serious threat in their earlier interviews. Although XXXXX, in his oral testimony, did mention minor problems they had experienced with their neighbours, the panel does not give that evidence any weight. No specific allegations about even minor problems with their new neighbours were made previously in their interviews with Canada Immigration. His PIF only mentioned some questions they were asked by their neighbours shortly after they moved there, but no specific problems or concerns about their neighbours were mentioned after that time. They chose to not move from that location during those subsequent years. If they were having any problems with their neighbours in Guadelupe, it is reasonable to have expected that they would have taken the opportunity to mention those specific problems earlier, but they omitted to do so. It was also relevant that XXXXX testified that he thought their neighbours in Guadelupe did not even know they were a gay couple. This is contrary to their allegation that they are both visibly gay and from the time they began to live together, they were identified as a gay couple to the general public and suffered on-going discrimination.
The claimants' evidence was also not reliable about the alleged incident that occurred in XXXXX 2000 in downtown San Jose. It was late at night in a downtown area when they alleged that two police officers attacked them and stole their money. They both gave differing versions of what actually happened to them on that occasion in their interviews with Canada Immigration, in their Personal Information Forms, and in their testimony. According to their PIFs and their testimony, they were robbed, beaten and sexually assaulted. However, in their interviews with Canada Immigration, they only alleged that they were robbed and called derogatory names. They provided no satisfactory explanations for their joint failure to mention at that time that they were sexually assaulted. XXXXX was also unable to explain why he had not previously mentioned that they were beaten. Those were allegations of serious mistreatment that they both experienced together. It is reasonable to expect that they would both have provided a consistent and complete account of this incident from their first interview onwards. Their failure to do so simply added to the conclusion that their evidence was not credible about their mistreatment in Costa Rica.
Immediately after this incident, the claimants said that they had gone to the closest police station to make a report. Their evidence was also not consistent about what actually happened at the station. XXXXX said the young police officer laughed at them when he realised their sexual orientation and told them to go home without taking a formal report. However, it is noted that in the interview with Canada Immigration, XXXXX simply stated that the police "gave no importance to what happened".
The claimants testified that after the incident with the police in XXXXX 2000, they were forced to totally change their lifestyles in various ways because of fear. However, it is also noted that neither of the claimants mentioned previously in their Personal Information Forms that they were in fear or had to change their lifestyles during that period of time after the XXXXX incident. Although XXXXX testified that they were in hiding, the evidence was clear that they both continued to work at their existing jobs. He even had to admit that he was actually working full-time at two different jobs while he was living in Guadalupe
and he continued to do so until he left Costa Rica. It was noted that he had not fully disclosed this employment information in his PIF, although he was required to do so. The panel does not find that they were living in fear or in hiding after XXXXX 2000.
These claimants provided reports11 of attacks on several transvestites in Costa Rica. Only one of those incidents occurred after 1998. It is not clear just what the motive was for any of those attacks and whether they were related at all to their sexual orientation as transvestites. Although the claimants say that their friend (Minor) was not a transvestite, the panel prefers the news report, which clearly states that he was. Those reports also indicate that the police (OIJ) are investigating the incidents. In any event, these claimants admitted that they are not transvestites.
There was also an extremely long delay before the claimants left Costa Rica. There was no credible evidence they had any further problems of any kind in the intervening thirteen months between the alleged incident in XXXXX 2000 and their departure in late XXXXX 2001. The panel is not satisfied that the incident they related in XXXXX 2000 actually occurred. Certainly, if it had occurred and they were living in fear as they alleged, that lengthy delay before they left Costa Rica was grossly excessive. That delay not only adversely affects the credibility of their evidence, but it also indicates their lack of any subjective fear.
In addition, it was also noted that XXXX only obtained his passport in XXXXX 2001. It was in XXXXX 2001 that XXXXX first applied for a student visa in order to take a six-month education course in Canada. As previously mentioned, it was disturbing that he gave inaccurate information to the visa officer at the Canadian Embassy in San Jose. He also did not provide complete information later when he completed his PIF. Those actions further damaged his credibility.
There were further delays. As of XXXXX 2001, both claimants already had passports. As Costa Ricans, they did not require visitors visas to travel to Canada. In spite of that, they still delayed their departure further until the end of XXXXX 2001. There was a further delay once they were in Canada before they initiated their refugee claims. They failed to advise Immigration at the airport here that they had fled from Costa Rica and come here to seek refuge. Instead, they waited for another six weeks longer before they notified Canada Immigration in mid-December that they wished to make refugee claims.
The claimants did not provide satisfactory explanations for any of those lengthy delays. They were in a unique position to leave Costa Rica for Canada much earlier than they did. As citizens of Costa Rica, they are nationals of one of the few countries in Latin America not required by Canada to obtain visitors' visas to travel here. The claimants are also intelligent and well educated. Even more surprising, XXXXX already had a Costa Rican friend in Canada who had already been granted refugee status here in 2000. XXXX was in communication with this person on a regular basis from Costa Rica. However, both claimants alleged that they did not know anything about how to make a refugee claim in Canada when they left Costa Rica. They also said that it was not until a month after their arrival here that they were first able to locate this friend. XXXXX claimed that he did not bring this person's address in Vancouver with him from Costa Rica. He also testified that after they did contact him, there was a further week's delay before they found out from him about how to initiate a refugee claim.
There were a number of reasons why the panel did not accept their explanations for this lengthy delay as reasonable. If these claimants fled from Costa Rica because they were in such fear after XXXXX 2000, it is completely implausible that they would not have ensured that they brought that friend's contact information with them. They also had ample time prior to their departure to have made the necessary inquiries with their friend, allegedly already a successful refugee claimant here, so he could offer them advice in advance of their departure
about the opportunity to make refugee claims here immediately upon their arrival. It was implausible that they would not have inquired with him before their departure. XXXXX also testified that they notified officials at the airport here upon their arrival that they had come here as tourists. He initially claimed that they did not mention that they were here to seek refuge because were afraid of the officials here and did not trust them, just as they did not trust Costa Rican officials. When he was challenged as to why they would have even come here if they already believed that Canadian officials could not be trusted, he then retreated from his previous allegation. This further damaged their credibility. Those further delays were completely excessive and were additional indications of their lack of subjective fear in Costa Rica.
The panel also considered the documentary materials on Costa Rica that were filed in these claims. According to the U.S. Department of State Country Reports12:
Costa Rica is a long-standing, stable, constitutional democracy. ...
The government generally respected the human rights of its citizens, and the law and judiciary provide effective means of dealing with individual instances of abuse...but reports of police abuse of authority or misconduct decreased during the year. ...
An effective mechanism for lodging and recording complaints of police misconduct exists. The Ombudsman's office serves as a recourse to citizens that have complaints about violations of their civil and human rights and about deficiencies in public and private infrastructure. It investigates complaints and, when appropriate, initiates suits against officials.
Unlike their comments concerning other countries in Latin America, the U.S. Department of State Country Reports does not mention problems concerning sexual orientation in Costa Rica.
In addition, other documentation that the panel finds helpful, particularly the documentation dealing with events from 1998 onwards, indicates that the situation in Costa Rica concerning sexual orientation has improved considerably in recent years. According to comments13 from the Director of the Agua Buena Human Rights Association in San Jose, (a group working to improve the situation of the gay, lesbian and transgender communities in Costa Rica), he was:
...unaware of any cases involving gay men being harassed, assaulted, raped or extorted to pay a bribe by police.
He also stated that:
I find that the situation for adult, urban gays has changed quite dramatically in the past several years. Personally, at this point I know dozens, and, less intimately, hundreds of gay and lesbian couples, who are living in San Jose, have good jobs, and a variety of receptions from their families, reacting from rejection to tolerance to support and closeness.
If you are talking about being able to live comfortably, there are relatively few problems for gay and lesbian couples in the urban area, and discrimination is not a government or police policy. There is a kind of 'live and let live' attitude here. Gays and lesbians here share apartments and homes, have good jobs, and can go out to any one of 25 bars and discos, five to ten gay-friendly restaurants, and maybe 50 to 100 other gay-friendly businesses. And same-sex couples go all the time to any restaurant in any part of the city, with no problems whatsoever.
The Supreme Court outlawed bar raids three years ago, and ordered in 1997 that the government provide the new AIDS medication to 500 people, most of them gay men. Also, there is a new law that outlaws discrimination based on sexual orientation.
My overall impression is that Costa Rica has become, with some exceptions, a relatively good place, in comparison to other Central American countries, for many, but not all, gay and lesbian people.
In addition, other, more recent materials indicate a similar positive situation. For example, homosexual acts between consenting adults are legal in Costa Rica.14 Another publication indicates that:
The gay scene in Costa Rica is also beginning to blossom. In San Jose, you can choose among any of a dozen downtown bars and clubs, four saunas, an Internet café and more than a handful of gay-friendly restaurants, hotels, and other businesses.15
The claimants alleged that they were attacked by police officers in XXXXX 2000. None of the documentation covering the period of time from 2000 up to the present indicates that there have been any reports of attacks by the police in Costa Rica against persons because of their sexual orientation.16 It is reasonable to assume that in an open, stable democracy such as Costa Rica, where human rights groups and groups advocating for the rights of sexual minorities operate freely, that reports of such incidents, would be well-known and well-publicised if they had occurred, particularly in San Jose. The lack of such information is another factor in the panel's assessment that the claimants' evidence is not credible.
These claimants alleged that they only went to the police on that one occasion in 2000 when they spoke to a young officer. When they did not receive any satisfaction from him, they did nothing further. They did not attempt to report this incident to any higher police or government official. They also completely failed to seek assistance by reporting this incident to any human rights group or to any gay advocacy group. According to that U.S. Department of State Country Reports:
Various human rights groups operate without government restriction, investigating and publishing their findings on human rights cases. Government officials are cooperative and responsive to their views.
They also failed to seek assistance and redress from any governmental agency or organization. Noticeably, they failed to approach the office of the Ombudsman. Country Reports also states that:
The Ombudsman's office is part of the legislative branch, ensuring a high degree of independence from the executive branch. The law provides for the functional, administrative, and judgmental independence of the Ombudsman's office.
Another very recent document17 indicated that:
The Ombudsman of Costa Rica (Defensoría de los Habitantes) includes persons with a "distinct sexual preference" (con distintas preferencias sexuales) as one of the various vulnerable groups that face or could face a violation of their rights (10 Apr. 2002). The Ombudsman reports that its Special Protection Directorate, with a team of eight lawyers, assists vulnerable groups to achieve full enjoyment of their rights before state institutions and within society (ibid.).
The latest report on the "Lesbian, Gay, Transgendered and Bi-Sexual (LGTV) Population" of the Special Protection Directorate available to the Research Directorate indicates that a complaint raised by the owner of the hotel taking part in the international gay and lesbian festival, regarding the "discriminatory attitudes" (actitud discriminatoria) of local government officials, was "favourably resolved" (se había ... resuelto favorablemente) by the Office of the Ombudsman (ibid. 10 Aug. 2000).
...
The Ombudsman addressed a complaint made in 1999 by a resident of Alajuela province, who reported police abuse in the form of arbitrary detention, as well as verbal and physical abuse; as a result, the Ombudsman issued a recommendation to the Public Security Ministry asking for: disciplinary action against the police officers involved in such abuse, addition of sensitivity training at the National School of Police, and a special effort top involving the Alajuela police command and other institutions under the Ministry's jurisdiction for more inclusive practices (ibid.).
That same document also noted that :
...there are various organizations in Costa Rica that fight for the rights of sexual minorities, some of them focusing on specific subjects and some of them dealing with more general matters. (ibid. n.d.c.) The source lists some of these government institutions and non-government organizations: In government, although a number of bodies can help protect rights if these are threatened, the most prominent ones are the Ombudsman and the Constitutional Court; among the non-governmental organizations, the most prominent ones are ...Agua Buena....
The issue of state protection is important because there is a presumption that a state can protect its citizens. If the claimants' evidence had been accepted as credible regarding that incident in XXXXX 2000, they made only one initial attempt to seek redress and then did nothing more. The onus on the claimants is to provide "clear and convincing" proof of the state's inability to protect. These claimants have clearly failed to meet that onus. The documentary materials are clear. There are institutions available to assist them, even if every case brought forth may not be successful.
The documentary evidence indicates clearly that there are rights available to homosexuals in Costa Rica and those rights have been improving since the early 1990's. This continuum of improvement has been primarily achieved through legal means and governmental institutions, including the Ombudsman and the Constitutional Court. It does not mean there might not be problems for some gay or lesbian individuals in Costa Rica in the future. However, the panel does not accept that these claimants made even the minimal attempts to seek redress.
As previously noted, their evidence was unclear and unreliable about what happened in XXXXX 2000 and the panel cannot rely upon it. Even if the panel accepted their evidence as credible that they had been victimized in that one incident, it was caused by two rogue police officers. Clearly, their actions did not involve carrying out any aspect of state policy. It is clear that Costa Rica and its' governmental institutions are opposed this type of abuse and do attempt to provide redress whenever such incidents are brought to their attention. It was unreasonable for these claimants to not properly seek protection. The level of democracy in a country indicates the level that a claimant must go to seek protection. In this case, Costa Rica, as "a longstanding, stable, constitutional democracy", requires them to do much more than they claim to have done. As the Federal Court of Appeal stated in Kandenko:
When the state in question is a democratic state ... the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the
police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the courses of action open to him or her.18
According to the claimants, the only people they told in Costa Rica about that XXXXX incident were some of their closest friends. After observing these claimants during the hearing, neither of them appeared to be persons who would be too intimidated, incapable or unwilling to seek redress. Their inaction was completely unreasonable in view of the options for redress that were available and accessible to them. They did not rebut the onus that reasonable state protection19 was available to them in Costa Rica, rather than leaving to seek protection abroad.
The Convention refugee definition is a forward-looking concept. If these claimants should return to Costa Rica in the future, there is nothing more than the merest possibility, certainly not a "serious possibility"20, that they would suffer persecution for any Convention reason, including their sexual orientation.
The panel has also considered whether the claimants are in need of protection under section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. It was not argued that the claimants would be personally subjected to a danger of torture in Costa Rica and there was no evidence to support such a finding. Although it was argued that they would personally be subjected to a risk to their lives or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if they should return to Costa Rica, the panel finds that there is no "serious possibility" of that occurring. They also have reasonable state protection available to them in Costa Rica.
CONCLUSION
After having considered all of the evidence, including counsel's oral submissions, the panel determines that these claimants are not Convention refugees. In addition, they would not be personally subjected to a danger of torture or to a risk to their lives or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Therefore, the panel rejects the claims of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX to refugee protection.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX alleges that she is a 17-year-old citizen of Sri Lanka and resident of the Colombo area. She claims to have a well founded fear of persecution at the hands of male Sinhalese neighbors and Sinhalese men in general because of her ethnic background and her gender. In addition, she claims to be a person in need of protection as a person at risk of losing her life or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Sri Lanka.
THE EVIDENCE
The Federal Court of Appeal states in the Maldonado1 decision that when a claimant swears to the truthfulness of his or her evidence, a presumption exists that that evidence is true unless there is a good reason to conclude otherwise.
The Federal Court of Appeal has given further direction to the RPD in Rajaratnam2 in which it states:
A refugee claimant is not, therefore, absolved of the duty of telling the truth. The tribunal hearing his evidence is entitled to disbelieve him and to base its decision on that assessment, but is required to give reasons for a finding of lack of credibility in 'clear and unmistakable terms.'
In the decision of Shahamati,3 the Federal Court of Appeal states:
Contrary to what has sometimes been said the Board is entitled, in assessing credibility, to rely on such criteria as rationality and common sense.
The claimant gave evidence at the hearing, as did her mother, XXXXXXXXXXXXX (by telephone from Sri Lanka). There are good reasons for disbelieving some parts of the evidence. The portions of the evidence found wanting are set out in the following synopsis of the testimony and review of the documentation filed.
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
The claimant's identity has been established by her own evidence and by means of a valid Sri Lankan passport4 issued in her name.
Ms. XXXXXXX and a half years of age. She gave evidence under oath and in what she described as her first language, English. At the time she completed her Personal Information Form (PIF)5 she had 10 years of education. She last attended a Catholic girl's school at the XXXXXXXXXX. She has never worked.
Her mother XXXXXXXXXXXXX and two younger brothers, age 15 and 8, remain in Sri Lanka. The claimant's father, XXXXXXXXXXX, is a landed immigrant in Canada and acted as the claimant's designated representative.
The claimant alleges that she is a member of a small ethnic minority group in Sri Lanka known as Burghers. According to a publication from the Institute of Peace and Conflict Studies (IPCS),6
Burghers are a miniscule but important ethnic group in Sri Lanka. They are descendants of children of Portuguese and Dutch marriages with Ceylonese.
The claimant alleged that Burghers are identifiable in Sri Lanka because they have lighter skin and speak English as their first language. She alleged that Burghers are harassed because they are considered to be very low caste.
The panel accepts that the claimant is Burgher. However, the documentary evidence filed does not indicate that Burghers are considered low caste, nor does it indicate that Burghers are subjected to discriminatory treatment. The report from IPCS states that the "...community is non-controversial and has not been marginalized."7
The claimant alleges that from an early age she could not use public transport to go to school because she was constantly harassed by young Sinhalese men in her neighbourhood. She states in her PIF that "...all the girls in our school were harassed from time to time but it was particularly bad for girls who were Burghers."8 In about 1997 or 1998 a Sinhalese man grabbed her breasts while she was walking through a market. She states that this would not have occurred had she not been Burgher. Sometime in 1998 the claimant was kissed by her cousin while she was at the home of her aunt. She did not appreciate the advance.
The claimant complains of being the target of name calling in her neighbourhood because she was Burgher. Some chickens she and her siblings owned were killed, according to her, by Sinhalese. These same persons are also alleged to have taken her dog.
The claimant states in her PIF that a young Burgher girl she knew was taken away by some Sinhalese men who gave her alcohol and took nude pictures of her.
On one occasion a Sinhalese man came looking for the claimant outside the grounds of her school. A friend of the claimant's told the man that she was not there. The claimant raised this incident as an example of the harassment she faced by Sinhalese men. When asked if she let her teachers at the school know of this event, she stated that she did not. Her reasons were that she was embarrassed, and that even if she told her teachers they could not help her. The panel does not accept the allegation that the teaching staff of a girls' convent school would not, on the balance of probabilities, protect her from unwanted attention from males in the near vicinity of the school. She cannot allege a lack of assistance from this source if she never sought it. In any event, the claimant alleges that she told her mother of the incident, but her mother never told the nuns. Her mother's evidence contradicts this version of the story.
The claimant's mother allegedly received phone calls from Sinhalese men who demanded money. The claimant alleged that because her father worked in Canada these men assumed the family was rich. No evidence was given that money ever changed hands.
The claimant alleges in her PIF that in August 1999, to get away from the harassment, the family moved from Dehiwala to Attidiya. Both locations are suburbs of Colombo. The claimant did not change schools, but continued to attend school. When asked why the family did not change schools to further cut ties with her old neighborhood, the claimant answered that she could change schools but it would be really hard at the mid-term point. In the panel's view, if the claimant and her family moved to flee persecutorial treatment, they would have taken the obvious (but not onerous) step of changing schools.
The claimant alleges that the harassment got worse after the move. Her mother and an aunt who lived with her received threatening phone calls. The key incident in the claim occurred after the move to Attidiya.9
One day about three in the afternoon, five or six Sinhalese men came to our house. I hid under the bed but I could hear the men ask my mother where I was. They said that they would take me away and rape me and that she would never see me again. They finally left when they did not find me but my mother and I remembered what had happened to XXXXXX and we took their threats very seriously. After this incident, my mother did try to go to the police but the police said that they would warn the Sinhalese men. However, the harassment continued.
At her hearing, the claimant stated that her mother told her that the men were drunk when they barged into the house. When asked why these men acted in this manner, she replied that it was because her family was low caste Burghers whom these men said did not belong in Sri Lanka.
She did state at one point in her testimony that her father and grandmother in Canada had no idea of the problems she was facing in Sri Lanka. When asked why this was the case she stated that she and her mother thought the problem would go away. As well, her father and grandmother could do nothing as they were far away in Canada. Again, her mother's evidence differs on this point. She did confirm that her mother went to the police to complain of the incident.
The claimant stated that it was her intention to return to Sri Lanka when she first came to Canada. She did not decide to stay until after she had received several extensions on her Canadian visitor's visa.10 She did so because she heard from her mother that the harassment in Sri Lanka continued. She alleged that although her antagonists originally wanted her to leave Sri Lanka, once she left they demanded that she return so that they could attack her. Their announced intention was to rape her.
The claimant has visited Kandy, a major city in south central Sri Lanka, with her mother. In fact, her mother comes from the Kandy area and has relatives living there. The claimant alleged that her protagonists in the Colombo area would find her in Kandy, as one of them knows a lot of people in Sri Lanka. In any event, she alleged that as all Sinhalese men were of the same ilk, the problems would repeat themselves. The claimant stated that there was nothing stopping her mother from moving to Kandy. Mrs. XXXXXX was not working in Colombo as she and her children were supported by remittances sent by her husband.
DOCUMENTATION
The claimant presented a one page fax document11 of what are alleged to be police reports about some of the incidents she described. The claimant noted that the originals were with her mother. A fax had been sent because the claimant was in a hurry to obtain the documents. When asked if the originals could be mailed, the claimant stated it was possible. The fax document as translated is difficult to decipher and is of an irregular composition. The name of the complainant is given as XXXXXXXXX, a name unknown to the claimant or her mother. The nature of the complaints are given as: "abuse and threats" and "threat." It contains what appear to be three dates: "2000/XXXX," "2001.XXXX," and "2001.XXXX." No where on the form does the name or address of the police force that issued the document appear, nor the address of the complainant.
Late in her evidence the claimant's mother stated that the document sent to her daughter was one page but contained three separate complaints. She asked for a copy of the report from the main event of the home invasion, but as she did not know the report number the police would not give it to her.
Fax documents are as susceptible to manufacture and modification as photocopies. This consideration alone diminishes the weight that can be given this document. The originals were allegedly available long before the date of the hearing but were not sent. This also raises concerns about the documents' authenticity.
The claimant presented no documentation on country conditions suggesting that Burghers suffer discrimination of a persecutory nature. The document noted earlier in these reasons indicate that Burghers are neither controversial nor marginalised.
The documentation does indicate that violence against women is a serious problem in Sri Lanka.
XXXXXXXXXXXXX
Mrs. XXXXXX gave evidence over the telephone from Sri Lanka. She described the incident when the five men entered her home, demanding to know where her daughter was so that they could rape her. She stated that the men were in the house for about a half an hour. She knew the names of several of them and knew where they were from. She described the men as being drunk, banging on doors and walls, and shouting obscenities, all the while looking for the claimant. For some reason, they did not discover the claimant hiding under the bed, one of the more obvious places a person would hide. The witness simply said the men never went into the bedroom where her daughter was hiding. The incident ended when the owner of the house who lived next door came to see what the disturbance was about. The witness was asked if she sought police protection after this incident. She stated that she went to the police, who arrested the men concerned. Her evidence was that the men were taken to the police station and warned not to make further threats. The witness stated the police helped her on this occasion because she paid them. She alleged that despite the warning the harassment continued after the men were released. She alleged that the men paid the police to leave them alone. She stated she heard this from another police officer. She herself did not have the money to pay the police each time help was needed.
She did state that her husband and mother-in-law knew about this attack at her home well before the claimant came to Canada. This is contrary to the claimant's evidence. The probative value of this aspect of the evidence is severely diminished due to the contradiction.
Mrs. XXXXXX also noted that after the incident in which a man asked for her daughter at her school, she stopped sending the girl to classes. School staff contacted her to find out what the trouble was and she told them what happened. Again, this contradicts the information given by the claimant.
Mrs. XXXXXX stated that she could move to Kandy, but her children were not used to living in that area. A Burgher girl, according to her, can not live peacefully anywhere in Sri Lanka. Her daughter would suffer because there was no man to protect her.
XXXXXXXXXXX
The claimant's father's situation in Canada is in dispute. According to the claimant, he never applied to sponsor her to emigrate to Canada because he could not afford the processing fees.12 According to documents filed by Canada Immigration, when he was landed in Canada on XXXXX 1991, he indicated that he was single and had no dependants other than his mother who was accompanying him.13 The claimant was not asked about this allegation at the hearing and Mr. XXXXXX was not called as a witness.
ANALYSIS
Counsel for the claimant argued that two of the Immigration and Refugee Board Chairperson's guidelines applied in the circumstances of this case: "Women Refugee Claimants Fearing Gender-Related Persecution"14 and "Child Refugee Claimants: Procedural and Evidentiary Issues."15 The panel has considered these guidelines in coming to its decision.
Credibility
The panel agrees that some of the discrepancies in the evidence are explainable by the relative age and maturity of the claimant when some of the events occurred. A child of 11 or 12 years of age cannot be expected to have the same degree of recall as an adolescent of 17. However, not all of the discrepancies can be explained by this factor alone. For example, I do not accept the claimant's evidence that her father was not told about the home invasion and attempted gang rape for the reasons she alleges. Her mother's evidence was that he was told. This discrepancy calls into question whether the incident occurred as described.
As well, it is my view, that allegation that her antagonists want her to return to Sri Lanka to attack her, lacks rationality and common sense. That they would announce such a demand and their intention is simply not plausible or credible.
Delay in Leaving Sri Lanka and in Claiming Refugee Status
The claimant was allegedly the target of an attempted gang rape sometime between August and November of 1999. She did not apply for a visa to leave Sri Lanka until XXXX 2000, and did not leave the country until XXXXX 2000. She appeared to be in no hurry to leave Sri Lanka.
It is difficult to understand what of any significance changed while the claimant was in Canada. She had allegedly been the victim of an attempted gang rape by known assailants. Ongoing police protection was allegedly unavailable. It is unclear what other incident could be required to spur her to seek protection. If she and her parents truly believed these men were responsible for such an attack, she would have had no reason not to have claimed refugee status much earlier. I find the delay in leaving and seek protection indicate a lack of a subjective fear of persecution or risk of harm.
Internal Flight Alternative
The claimant and her family could move to Kandy. There is no evidence beyond speculation that her protagonists could or would follow her there. A blanket statement that all Burgher girls are unsafe throughout Sri Lanka at the hands of Sinhalese men is not supported by the country documentation. In my view it would be reasonable for the claimant and her family to relocate.
No credible case was made that the claimant was at risk of losing her life or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Sri Lanka. In any event, she could move to Kandy and face no more than a mere possibility of risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
DECISION
For all these reasons, I find that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection and I therefore reject this claim.
"Kurt Neuenfeldt"
Kurt Neuenfeldt

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Division with respect to the abandonment proceeding in the refugee claim of XXXXXXXXX (the claimant) a 22 year old citizen of China. Oral submissions from counsel were heard on July 2, 2002 via teleconference and the matter was reserved for decision. Pursuant to section 191 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) this matter was dealt with under the new legislation.
THE ISSUE
The only issue to be determined is whether the claimant's refugee claim should be declared abandoned pursuant to section 168 of IRPA and Rule 58(2) of the Refugee Protection Division Rules.
BACKGROUND
The following is a chronology of events pertaining to this claim.
1. The claimant arrived at the Vancouver International Airport on March 21, 2002 and made a refugee claim. The claimant was determined eligible by a senior immigration officer, (SIO), issued a conditional departure order and referred to the Immigration and Refugee Board on the same day. The claimant was provided a blank Personal Information Form (PIF) in person on the same day. The claimant had left no address with Citizenship and Immigration Canada and there was no counsel of record at the time the claim was referred to the Refugee Protection Division.
2. On March 27, 2002 the Refugee Protection Division in Vancouver received a faxed letter from claimant's counsel, Mark Fromkin, Barrister and Solicitor, seeking the Port of Entry (POE) notes for the claimant that are normally provided to the Board by Citizenship and Immigration Canada and seeking a one month extension of time for the claimant to file his completed PIF. Accompanying counsel's letter were a Notification of counsel, a Notification of address and an Application for a Change of Venue to Toronto. All three forms were signed by the claimant. No decision was taken by the Board in regard to the extension request and on April 23, 2002 the Board wrote to counsel reminding him that the claimant's PIF was due on April 25, 2002. On April 23, 2002 the Board wrote CIC requesting a copy of the POE notes.
3. On April 22, 2002 the Board received a faxed letter from claimant's counsel again seeking an extension of time to file the PIF and again seeking the POE notes. On May 14, 2002 the Board wrote to counsel to advise him that an extension of time to file the claimant's PIF had been granted to May 20, 2002. The Board's letter further indicated that should the PIF not be filed by May 20, 2002 a Notice to Appear for the commencement of abandonment proceedings would be issued.
4. A completed PIF was not received from the claimant by May 20, 2002 and a Notice to Appear for an abandonment proceeding on July 2, 2002 was issued to the claimant and counsel on June 6, 2002. On June 5, 2002 the Board wrote to claimant's counsel disclosing the requested information from the Minister.
5. A completed PIF was received from the claimant on June 18, 2002. The abandonment proceeding was held by teleconference with the claimant and counsel's agent in Toronto and the panel and interpreter in Vancouver.
ANALYSIS AND CONCLUSION
Having reviewed the whole of the record and considered the evidence of the claimant and the submission of counsel in this matter, the panel concludes that the claimant has failed to provide a satisfactory explanation for the delay in submitting his PIF and I am not satisfied that there are sufficient reasons to establish that the claimant has not abandoned his claim.
At the hearing, counsel for the claimant was represented by an agent, Hart Kaminker, Barrister and Solicitor who made a submission that the claimant failed to file his PIF within the required timeframe because claimant's counsel was awaiting a copy of the Port of Entry Notes from the Board. Counsel's agent further stated that the claimant was ready to proceed with his claim and never intended to abandon his claim. When counsel was asked if he intended to bring forward evidence from the claimant in the matter he responded that he did not.
I am not satisfied with the explanation of the claimant. Rule 6(1) stipulates that the completed Personal Information Form must be filed no later than 28 days after the claimant received the form. This provision is the same as the provision contained in the Rules of the Convention Refugee Determination Division which were in force at the time the claimant's refugee claim was referred to the Board and it is clearly set out on the front page of the PIF. There is no provision in the Rules for the Board to automatically or necessarily extend the time for filing of the PIF until the claimant or the claimant's counsel receives the CIC Port of Entry notes from the Board.
I accept that the claimant may, on the day of the abandonment hearing, have been ready to continue with his claim. However, while I give weight to this factor, I do not consider that the mere submission of a completed Personal Information Form nearly four weeks after it was due and the presence of the claimant at an abandonment proceeding is in itself sufficient to establish that the claimant has not abandoned his claim. Indeed, should I decide otherwise in this case, such a decision would make a mockery of the timelines set out in the CRDD and RPD Rules.
If the claimant wished additional time, beyond the more than four weeks already extended, it was open to him to seek a further extension but he failed to do so until the day of the abandonment proceeding. As I have mentioned, at the abandonment hearing the claimant did not provide an explanation beyond the submission of counsel's agent that counsel was awaiting the POE notes.
I understand why counsel wrote the Board seeking the POE notes. Indeed the Board sought and disclosed the POE notes in the most expeditious manner possible. However, I do not find that the absence of such notes, in and of itself, provides sufficient reason to delay the filing of the claimant's PIF within the required timeframe nor do I find that there is an obligation on the part of the Board to provide POE notes to counsel prior to the expiration of the PIF filing period. The claimant's obligation to file the PIF within the required timeframe is mandatory and in the absence of an extension of time granted by the Board, the claimant cannot simply decide not to file the PIF in a timely fashion. It is always possible for the claimant to file amendments to the PIF if necessary, but it is not open to them to unilaterally decide to file the PIF late and expect that no consequences would follow..
The record indicates that the claimant did little or nothing to advance the prosecution of his claim until after he had received a notice for the abandonment hearing. I do not consider that the claimant has acted to prosecute his refugee claim with the vigour that can be reasonably expected of someone seeking Canada's protection.
The filing of the claimant's PIF was not done in compliance with the timeframes that are clearly set out in the documents provided to the claimant by CIC or in compliance with the extension of time provided by the Board. The record indicates that at the time the claimant was determined eligible by CIC, the claimant signed a declaration stating that he fully understood the nature and effect of the documents provided to him. These documents included a blank PIF and a Notice to Appear, both of which, clearly stipulate the 28 day time frame. In addition, the claimant was represented by experienced counsel from March 27, 2002, nearly 30 days prior to the date the completed PIF was due at the Board.
DECISION
The claimant has failed to comply with Rule 6(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Division Rules. The claim of XXXXXXXXX is therefore declared abandoned pursuant to Section 168 of IRPA and RPD Rule 58.
"Richard Jackson"
Richard Jackson

The claimant failed to file his Personal Information Form (PIF) on time, even after receiving an extension of time. A completed PIF was not filed until after a Notice to Appear for abandonment proceeding was issued. At the hearing, counsel for the claimant stated that the claimant failed to file on time because counsel was awaiting a requested copy of the Port of Entry Notes from the Board, and that the claimant was prepared to proceed with his claim. The claim was declared abandoned. There is no provision for the Board to automatically or necessarily extend the time for filing the PIF until the claimant or his counsel receives the Port of Entry Notes, and the absence of the Notes did not in itself provide sufficient reason to delay filing the PIF. The filing of a completed PIF before the abandonment hearing and the presence of the claimant at the hearing was not in itself sufficient to establish that the claimant had not abandoned his claim. The record indicated that the claimant did little or nothing to advance the prosecution of his claim until after he had received a notice for the abandonment hearing. The panel did not consider that the claimant acted to prosecute his refugee claim with the vigour that can be reasonably expected of someone seeking Canada's protection. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the "claimant") is a 42-year old citizen of Guatemala. She claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of government agents who wish to extract information from her with respect to dealings made by her late husband.
Death squads allegedly persecuted the claimant's family in the 1960s because of their perceived political opinion. When her parents died, care for her was turned over to her father's friend who later raped her. In 1973, when she was only 14 years old, her stepfather's grandson also raped her. She bore a child from this rape and lived with him in a common law relationship. She bore three more sons from this relationship.
In XXXXX 1995, seven men, allegedly members of the government forces G-2, barged into their home one night demanding that they turn over to them the cocaine they claimed the claimant's husband had in his possession. They fired bullets at the claimant, at her husband, and at her son XXX and later, at their two dogs. As a result of this incident, the two dogs died and XXX lost his sense of hearing. The claimant's husband subsequently died of complications from the bullet wounds after three years (in 1998).
Several other men came looking for them during and after they were released from the hospital, but they were able to evade them by going into hiding in various places, including moving the whole family to El Salvador where they lived illegally. When the claimant's husband's health worsened, they returned to Guatemala where he eventually died.
At the funeral, two well-dressed men allegedly approached the claimant with a remark that "the first one had died, so she should not play the fool". When she inquired as to the meaning of his remarks, the man stated that she "should know" what they were talking about.
At the first sitting, the claimant further disclosed an incident that occurred on XXXXX, 2000 which she had been allegedly never told anyone else, this information withheld even from her counsel. Because she seemed highly emotional as she was about to recall this traumatic incident, and also because the incident she was disclosing was new to her counsel, the panel decided to adjourn the hearing to enable counsel to discuss this new evidence with the claimant.
At the second sitting, the claimant described the details of the XXXX, 2000 incident. According to her, while she was waiting for a bus at the Quatepeque market, two men grabbed her and forced her into a van, covered her head with a small bag that contained powdered insecticide, and tied her neck with the string of the bag forcing her to inhale the insecticide. They demanded her to tell them "who the others are". When she replied that she did not know, they raped her and kept hitting at her feet causing them to be battered so badly that up to this date, she has no nails on her feet. They then left her in a dark isolated street at 2 am and threatened that they will again force her to reveal the information they wanted by abducting one of her children.
When the claimant arrived home that morning, her face was so badly swollen and her body so badly battered that her children did not even recognize her. The following day, the claimant left Guatemala for El Salvador with her four children. The claimant proceeded to Mexico from on XXXX, 2000, arriving in the United States on the same day. She made her way to Canada arriving on October 31, 2000. She made her refugee claim ten days later, on November 11, 2000.
After the claimant arrived in Canada, unknown persons reportedly grabbed her eldest son XXXX, but he managed to run away from them.
Analysis
I find the claimant's evidence, with respect to her being a victim of persecution from persons seeking information from her late husband which they believe she possesses, to be credible. There were no major contradictions, inconsistencies and implausibilities in her evidence with respect to the harm she fears other than her omission of the XXXX 2000 incident. The omission of the XXXX 2000 incident has been explained to my satisfaction. Her demeanour in recounting the XXXXX 2000 incident and the psychological report quoted below corroborates the fear she alleges.
However, when Ms. XXXXX began to speak of her torture, she became extremely distraught and had difficulty relating the details. Her respiration accelerated, she began to tremble and wring her hands, and she often looked at the floor as if in a daze. She also had a facial expression of fear when recalling the bag placed over her head and required frequent breaks to catch her breath and compose herself. During this period, her tone of voice became low and shaky. It was evident that she had to make considerable efforts to disclose details of her torture in Guatemala.
Given the traumatic nature of the torture, it is not surprising that Ms. XXXXX had difficulty disclosing the details to the lawyer or during the hearing. Because she suffers from PTSD, she avoids any thoughts or conversations associated with the trauma. Individuals who suffer from PTSD try to distance themselves and avoid disclosing details for fear that their emotional display may be too overwhelming for them to control. Therefore, when Ms. XXXXX attempts to recall and speak of the torture, she is overwhelmed by feelings of profound fear and anxiety. Her fear was evident even in the non-threatening environment of my office where she began to relive her trauma as she disclosed it.
I believe Ms. XXXX would emotionally collapse if she were compelled to return to Guatemala.1
I, therefore, accept that the claimant was and continues to be a victim of persecution. However, for reasons below, I do not accept her allegations that her perpetuators are agents of the government.
When asked if she knew exactly who was constantly harassing her and her family, the claimant at first stated that she believed that they were government G-2 forces. When asked what was the basis of this allegation, the claimant replied that this was what they told her husband and her when they came barging into their home on XXXX 1995. However, when asked why the government authorities would continue to harass her and her family given that her husband is now dead, she replied that she does not know why. She told the panel that she had on several occasions, inquired from her husband, even at his death bed, what it was that the men wanted from him. According to the claimant, her husband replied that it was better for her not to know anything, as things would be worse if she knew. He then asked for her forgiveness, warned her that the threats would continue, and advised her to run away from Guatemala.
The claimant submitted as evidence a newspaper clipping describing what happened when the alleged government agents came barging into their home in 1995.stated that:
Four members of the family two under age are under attack with gun fire when they were sleeping in their house. This happened in the town of Tecun Uman San Marcos....2
All the neighbours from the green colony, they told the authorities what happened at 2:00 in the morning on Thursday. The bandit's faces were covered with masks and it was very impossible to get a good description of what they looked liked.3 [emphasis added]
Nowhere in the article was there any indication that this was a government raid. In fact, the article described the attackers as "bandits" with their faces covered with masks. I do not find it likely, on a balance of probabilities, that the article would call the attackers bandits if they were really government agents. I also do not find it likely, on a balance of probabilities, that the government agents, if they were truly acting on official government orders, would be dressed up like bandits, with masks covering their faces.
I also do not find it plausible that government agents would speak in vague terms, such as "the first one had died, so do not play the fool" and to have replied "you know what we are talking about" when she consistently inquired as to what they mean and what information they wanted from her. On a balance of probabilities, I find that government agents would more likely inform her of her husband's involvement and why they believe her husband has the information they wanted. I find that, had they told her the details of her husband's likely illegal dealings, she would have believed that she was helping the government in their pursuit of the law and she would have likely told them who he used to hang around with, if she could not specifically name the people they wanted to know.
Neither do I believe that government agents would attempt to abduct her eldest son in Retahueleu and then do nothing after he had managed to run away from them. In my opinion, the actions of her persecutors are more typical of criminals rather than government agents. I therefore find that, on a balance of probabilities, her fears are from common criminals demanding to know details of her late husband's transactions, specifically, who her late husband had been dealing with. Accordingly, I find that her fears do not have any nexus to the grounds in the Convention definition.
Risk to Life and to Cruel and Unusual Treatment and Punishment
Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) states that:
97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
i. the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themselves of the protection of that country,
ii. the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,...
Accordingly, I have to assess whether the claimant faces a risk to her life or to a treatment or punishment that is cruel and unusual.
In assessing the risk, I have considered what standard of proof to be applied: whether to use the standard of proof of a "reasonable chance or serious possibility", or a higher standard. The Act is silent as to the appropriate standard of proof to be used. I note that the CIC Guidelines issued for Post-Determination Refugee Claimants in Canada (PDRCC) Reviews, the precursor of the section 97(1)(b) provisions, set the standard of proof at "less than a clear probability, or even a balance of probabilities, but greater than a mere possibility."4
In my opinion, the standard of proof to be used is that set out in Adjei5, i.e., whether the claimant faces a "reasonable chance or serious possibility" of a risk to his or her life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. I consider it to be the logical choice as it is consistent with the standard of proof for establishing a well-founded fear of persecution under the Convention. Both the Convention ground and this ground deal with a prospective risk of serious human rights violations and the harm contemplated under section 97(1)(b) is no less serious than the harm to be protected against under the Convention. Therefore, in my opinion, a claimant should not have to establish the prospective risk to a higher degree of certainty than under the Convention.
In addition, there is a compelling argument that the standard of proof should be consistent among the three grounds as all grounds deal with a prospective fear of human rights violations. In fact, the U.K. Immigration Appeal Tribunal in Kacaj6 noted that the various expressions used in reference to the legal test for asylum cases, namely "reasonable chance," "substantial grounds for thinking" and "serious possibility" were taken to refer to the same degree of risk as a "real risk." In addition, it noted the practical difficulty of applying two legal tests to the same set of facts in a given hearing.
Therefore, I have used the standard of proof as set out in Adjei7 as the standard that should be applied under section 97(1)(b).
Given the continuous and relentless pursuit of extracting information from the claimant, I find that there is a serious possibility that the claimant faces a risk to her life or to a cruel and unusual treatment should she return to Guatemala. However, in order for the claimant to be determined a person in need of protection, she must meet all the elements of the definition, meaning that there is no State Protection and/or an Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) reasonably available for her.
State Protection
The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act requires that for a claimant to be determined a person in need of Canada's protection, he should be able to provide "clear and convincing" evidence of an absence of state protection.
The claimant has not made any report or denunciation of the harm she experienced in Guatemala to any agent of the government because she believed that her perpetuators are government agents. Under these conditions, I find her actions of not availing the protection of her state to be reasonable.
The test given in Villafranca8 is as follows:
"...where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens from terrorist activities, the mere fact that it is not always successful at doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that the victims of terrorism are unable to avail themselves of such protection.
The questions before me are: Are there "serious efforts" being made by the Guatemalan government to protect its citizens? Does the Guatemalan government have effective control of its territory? The documentary evidence states:
In many cases, the prosecutorial and judicial system was unable to ensure full and timely investigations, fair trials, or due process. Arbitrary arrest and lengthy pretrial detention continued to be problems. Judges and other law enforcement officials are subject to intimidation and corruption. In May the U.N. Special Rapporteur for Justice noted a deterioration in the security of justice sector workers. Threats against judicial personnel, journalists, witnesses, labor organizers, and human rights workers heightened public insecurity. Parallel investigations, the obstruction of justice, threats, and intimidation also were traced to groups related to the Government. The MINUGUA noted that the majority of human rights violations were the result of the failure of the state to investigate and punish those who break the law. An estimated 15 percent of the violations derive from the obstruction of justice, particularly by police officers whose only punishment was to be rotated away from assignments where there were problems. Efforts to reform the judiciary continued; however, impunity remained a serious problem. 9
The Government achieved convictions in a few important cases involving past human rights violations; however, most human rights cases remained pending for lengthy periods without being investigated or languished in the courts as defense attorneys took advantage of the inefficient judicial system and filed numerous baseless motions and appeals to delay trials.10
During the year, the Supreme Court ordered the Prosecutor's Office to conduct a new investigation into the 1993 murder of newspaper publisher and former presidential candidate Jorge Carpio Nicolle and associates. Suspect Francisco Ixcoy Lopez, former Civil Defense Patrol member, remained at large, despite the fact that the Carpio family had located him and informed the authorities of his whereabouts. The criminal case remained open, but the Prosecutor's Office made no efforts to advance the case and the victim's family withdrew the charges. The case before the IACHR for the Government's failure to provide justice remained pending. The family of Jorge Carpio also requested the IACHR send the case to the Inter-American Court, since they believed that justice was not being served in the Guatemalan courts. The Court accepted the petition in November. It is estimated that the Court may call as witnesses 20 or more former military officers and civil patrollers, as well as high-level government officials. 11
While some high profile cases, such as the 1998 assassination of Bishop Juan Gerardi, saw the arrest and conviction of the perpetuators of the crime, the appeal process has bogged the whole justice process down. I am therefore satisfied that a poor widow like the claimant at bar would not be able to avail of the protection of her state.
Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
I have considered whether the risk faced by the claimant is limited to part of the country and whether there are other parts of the country, reasonably accessible by the claimant, where the claimant would not face a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
The evidence is clear that the perpetuators appear to be relentless in pursuing the claimant in order to obtain the information they believe she possesses. When the claimant could not be located, they attempted to abduct her eldest son who lived in Retahueleu, about forty-five minutes from Quatepeque where she lived. While it is true that the claimant can buy time by staying with her other children in Santo Tomas (three hours from Quatepeque) or San Antonio (two hours by bus), I find, given time, they would likely hear that the claimant had return to Guatemala should she return today. I find it likely that they would again harm her in order to obtain the information they appear to indefatigably want.
Accordingly, based on the evidence before me, I find that there is no IFA reasonably available for the claimant.
Conclusion
For all the above reasons, the Refugee Division determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection.

Having listened to the testimonies of the claimants, I do not find that the adult claimants, XXXXXXX and XXXXXX, have persuaded me that Canada should offer them protection. It is not that they would not be happier here in this country that over the period of a few decades has become a veritable paean to multiculturalism. The claimant is Chinese, the wife is Spanish - Toronto for example would be an ideal place for them. It is simply this: their difference in ethnicity causes them no more than harassment or personal inconvenience in Costa Rica and difficulties in their families, even on a cumulative basis. It does not cause them harm; it does not cause them persecution.
Let me here briefly give their background. XXXXXXXXX is a Chinese born in Vietnam in 1955. He came to Costa Rica to work in his uncle's restaurant in 1980. His family was the only Chinese family in Cartago. He began dating XXXXXXXXXXXX and married her in XXXXX 1989. The marriage caused great tension in the families. It also created dissension in the small community. In 1995, the family decided it best to go to China, where they stayed on a yearly residential permit. Forced to leave in 2000, they decided to come to Canada.
It is the situation of the minor boy, XXXXXX, that causes me great concern. I decided that it was important that XXXXXX testify at the hearing.
He was very quiet, very soft spoken. He told me of the lonely life he had led at school. He never had a friend to call his own. As was the only Chinese student, he would be called names and teased mercilessly. The children beat him up and spat on him because he was not one of them - he was not "really" Costa Rican.
There were days when it became so difficult to go to school that he would lock himself in his washroom and cry. He did not like the day that waited outside for him. He did not like people he would have to meet. And when school ended, he would come home crying, not understanding why the other kids had been so cruel to him. I could see that the simple act of recalling his school-life in Costa Rica caused him deep personal anguish.
I asked him about his school in Canada and his eyes lighted up. He would have gone on talking about his Canadian school if I had allowed him to do so. And then I brought him back to reality.
I asked him how he felt about a possible return to Costa Rica. A crest-fallen look replaced the sunshine on his face. A look of ineffable sadness entered his eyes. And he uttered just one word, a remarkable word because he was a boy so young in years. He answered "Suicide."
Was his school experience persecutory? From the lordly perch of an adult, one could say it was not. The reason for such a view is, of course, that the Convention refugee definition and its evolving law is mostly about adults.1
"Persecution" - the single most important concept in refugee law takes adult situations into account. For example, a series of detentions in prison is deemed to be persecution.2 This is because the adult cherishes freedom. The regime of rights that adults have developed is in response to adult needs, the unjust denial of which is tantamount to persecution.3
I believe, however, that the term "persecution", needs to be made relevant to the world of the child as well. In a prior decision,4 I have written thus about minors under seven years of age
In literature on child development, especially on children up to seven years of age, one need amongst the many mentioned is repeated constantly. It is the child's need for the love and attention of parents. The greatest fear of a child of five, it is mentioned, is of losing the mother. Thus for a child of five, the prospect of going to jail is of little consequence; it is the prospect of losing the mother that matters. The fear of persecution, as far as the five-year old is concerned, is the fear of losing the mother.
Having had a look at the minor claimant, a minor who is sixteen years of age, it is clear to me that peer rejection had, in his particular circumstances, caused him intense pain. That pain cannot be dismissed as trivial. It ought not to be devalued simply because it is not traceable to an adult cause. Pain is integral to persecution. The children who reviled this boy, who spat upon him, who pushed him around were as much agents of persecution, from a child's perspective, as a policeman beating a prisoner is from an adult's point of view. It is not only of the pain they cause that we speak about. It is also the long-term effects of peer rejection. An article on child development5 has this to say,
Given the significance of friendships to children, imagine what it would be like to spend over 40 hours a week in school and after-school programs with lots of other people your own age, but to have few of them like you or want to be with you...Peer rejection in childhood often brings with serious emotional difficulties. Rejected children are frequently discontent with themselves and with their relationships with other children. Many of these children experience strong feelings of loneliness and social dissatisfaction. Rejected children also report lower self-esteem and may be more depressed than other children. Peer rejection is also predictive of later life problems, such as dropping out of school, juvenile delinquency and mental health problems.
My finding: the minor claimant suffered persecution at school by reason of his ethnicity. His fear of persecution is well-founded for the same reason. He is determined a Convention refugee. I accept his claim.
However, it is my finding that neither of is parents have provided me with sufficient proof to conclude that they are either Convention refugees or persons in need of protection. Accordingly, I reject their claims.
