These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Division with respect to the joined claims to be Convention refugees and/or persons in need of protection made by 41-year old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (hereinafter referred to as the "claimant"), his 39-year old wife, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX ("XXXXXX"), their three minor children ("minor claimants") namely, the elder daughter, 13-year old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX ("XXXXXXX"), the younger daughter, 9-year old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX("XXXXXXX"), and their son, 7-year old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX ("XXXXXX"), all citizens of Colombia. The minor claimants' father, XXXXXX, was their Designated Representative.
The claimant alleges fear of persecution from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrillas because of his perceived political opinion. He states that in 1998, he wrote a letter "Letter from a citizen to the guerrillas" where he told the guerrillas to give up their violent means of trying to achieve their political agenda. The claimant concluded his letter saying:
It's a time to think. We still have this rich and beautiful country in a condition that it could be rebuilt without violence. And if one could work in peace anywhere, there will be work for everyone and so we will be able to live in peace. There is no doubt that we all fit in here and there is enough for everyone.1
He stated that, in spite of his attempts to have this letter printed in a major newspaper, it was only printed in a local, limited circulation, newspaper called "XXXX XXXXX" in XXXXXX, 1998. He also made photocopies of this letter, circulated about 5,000 of these letters to anyone he knew or met and posted it in public places.
In early 2000, he saw a television program where the host invited citizens to write a letter to the guerrillas. He then sent his letter to them via an e-mail address provided by the television station. According to the claimant, he believes that many other citizens of Colombia also responded by sending e-mail letters.
In March 2000, the claimant allegedly received a call at his apartment from someone who identified himself as FARC, telling him that "people with big mouths had to keep them closed and that he should say goodbye to the world".
In XXXX 2000, an attempt was made to kidnap the claimant's children. A man in a white car came to the apartment complex and told the porter that he was there to pick up the XXXXXX children. It so happened that this was not a day in which the children were going to school, as they had a doctor's appointment. Thus, when XXXXXX went down to meet the persons in the white car, the man left the complex upon seeing XXXXXX. XXXXXX then gave instructions to the porter that henceforth, the children are not to be allowed to leave the complex unless accompanied by her or the claimant. The porter was also instructed not to give anyone information on whether they were or were not home.
That same night, the caller stated that even if they did not succeed that time, that they would succeed the next time. After this, the claimants went out of the apartment only if it was necessary. The children were taken to the schools and picked up by either XXXXXX or the claimant.
Two weeks later, someone came to the apartment complex asking the porter for the children. The porter, as told, did not give out any information about their whereabouts.
In June 2000, two strange men, again in a white car, came to the children's school and called XXXXXXX by her name. XXXXXXX was then waiting for their mother to pick them up. XXXXXXX was inside the school grounds playing. XXXXXXX ran inside the school building and left only after her mother arrived and when she was assured that the white car was gone.
That evening, the claimant received another call, telling him to say goodbye to XXXXXXX.
In July 2000, the claimant noticed a motorcycle following him, but luckily he was able to lose it by running through red lights.
Thus, on XXX, 2000, the claimant abandoned his business and took XXXXXXX with him to Miami. XXXXXX took the other children to a friend's house. However, after two weeks, the callers managed to track XXXXXX down at their friend's place. At first they would hang up, then in August 2000, they identified themselves as being from the FARC.
XXXXXX then joined the claimant in Miami. They filed an asylum case in the USA, but were advised to go to Canada instead. On May 1, 2001, the claimants came to Canada where they made refugee claims at the border.
Analysis
I found the minor claimant XXXXXXX testimony with respect to the kidnapping attempts to be credible. As it was only in a mid-hearing conference that the suggestion to call XXXXXXX to testify was made, I find her testimony quite compelling given that it was spontaneous and not likely coached. She testified in a direct and straightforward manner and her testimony was consistent with her father's evidence. There were no contradictions and implausibilities in her evidence. I also found XXXXXXX and XXXXXX demeanour when XXXXXXX was relating the kidnapping attempts to be consistent with one who has experienced the attempted kidnapping (or in the case of XXXXXX, with one whose daughter had experienced these attempts). I, therefore, accept that the minor claimants are victims of attempted kidnapping.
However, for reasons to be given below, I do not find persuasive the claimant's evidence that these kidnapping attempts were made by FARC for the reasons he has given, i.e., his open letter and/or his e-mail sent to the guerrilla.
The letter was published in XXXXX, 19982 in an obscure local newspaper. Yet, no harm was made to the claimants until XXXXX 2000, more than two years after its publication. When asked for an explanation as to why it took FARC so long to respond to his letter, the claimant stated that, maybe, they only learned of this letter after two years. I do not accept this explanation, as it is not consistent with the documentary evidence on the level of sophistication that FARC currently possesses3 with respect to their intelligence and communication networks. I do not believe that it would take FARC more than two years to find out about the existence of a letter, nor do I believe that it will take two years for FARC to react on a given letter.
The claimant further explained that the delay in reprisals from the FARC could be their reprisal to his e-mail in early 2000. I reject this explanation because the claimant's e-mailed letter was a response from a call to the general public. There is no evidence that other e-mail senders were similarly harmed. According to the claimant, he believes that many people had sent e-mail letters to FARC as well. The claimant, however, is not aware if any of the other e-mail writers experienced any reprisals from the FARC.
There is nothing in the documentary evidence indicating that any of the e-mail writers were similarly harmed. The call to write letters was a public announcement aired on television. It is reasonable to expect that had there been adverse repercussions against the e-mail writers who had responded to this call, that these repercussions would have been reported in the media. In connection with the failure of the documentary evidence to mention what one would normally expect it to mention, we are guided by the Federal Court of Appeal decision of Adu4 that states:
...The "presumption" that a claimant's sworn testimony is true is always rebuttable, and, in appropriate circumstances, may be rebutted by the failure of the documentary evidence to mention what one would normally expect it to mention.
As stated above, the claimant's open letter was printed in an obscure newspaper with limited local circulation. Its impact upon its readers, especially after more than two years, appears to be minimal. Its message of wanting peace and ending violence is no different from the sentiment of most Colombians, including the leaders of the FARC themselves. In an interview with a Canadian journalist, FARC Commander Raul Reyes5, stated:
...despite the attitude of the oligarchy, the CARC-EP has never stopped raising the banner of a political solution to the national crisis. True peace is born of living together with tolerance, fundamental human rights, job security, housing, medical attention, good public services, education, mutual respect, and a proud stance against imperialism. This above all is the deepest desire of the people.
Because of the above reasons, I reject the claimant's evidence that the FARC will now harm the claimant in retaliation for his letter made in 1998 and/or his e-mail made in early 2000.
I believe, on the other hand, XXXXXXXX testimony with respect to the several attempts to kidnap her and her siblings except that I have no persuasive evidence that the persons attempting to kidnap the children are from the FARC.
In addition to my reasons stated above for not finding that the FARC would seek reprisals against the claimant for his open letter, I do not find it likely that the FARC would give up its kidnapping attempt just because the children's mother were present. In all instances, the abductors reportedly fled when they saw XXXXXX --- at the lobby of their apartment and at the entrance to the school. The FARC is known to have kidnapped children even in front of their parents.
Further documentary evidence talks about many child abductions by the FARC in order to train them to be child soldiers6. While the minor claimants do not necessarily fit into the typical profile of children being recruited as child soldiers (i.e. rural, indigenous, poor children), I still considered this possibility in my analysis. If it were FARC's intention to forcibly recruit the XXXXXX children to be soldiers, would not the then 11-year old XXXXXXX be the better recruit than the then 8-year old XXXXXXX? Yet, according to the claimant's evidence, the caller specifically identified XXXXXXX as their target.
I find, on a balance of probabilities, that the kidnapping attempts were not made by the paramilitary units. The only logical abductors, therefore, who may have attempted to kidnap the children were common criminals. The documentary evidence states:
Eduardo Delgadillo, a researcher who authored the study "Kidnappings in Colombia" told IPS the armed groups carry out the abductions for political ends and extortion. But he indicated other causes have led to an increase of kidnappings perpetrated by groups of common criminals.7
On a balance of probabilities, I find the agents of persecution likely to be common criminals. Therefore, I find that there is no nexus between what the claimants fear and the grounds in the Convention definition. Accordingly, I cannot find the claimants to be Convention refugees.
Risk to Life and to Cruel and Unusual Treatment and Punishment
Given the persistence of kidnapping attempts against the minor claimants, I find that there is a serious possibility that they will be kidnapped should they return to Colombia. The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) states the following with respect to persons who could be determined to be in need of protection:
97 (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
i. the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of that country,
ii. the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
iii. the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
iv. the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care.
Given the above mandate, I have assessed the risk that the minor claimants face should they return to Colombia.
In assessing the risk, I have considered what standard of proof to be applied: whether to use the standard of proof of a "reasonable chance or serious possibility" or a higher standard. The Act is silent as to the appropriate standard of proof to be used. I note that the CIC Guidelines issued for Post-Determination Refugee Claimants in Canada (PDRCC) Reviews, the precursor of the section 97(1)(b) provisions, set the standard of proof at "less than a clear probability, or even a balance of probabilities, but greater than a mere possibility."8
In my opinion, the standard of proof to be used is that set out in Adjei9, i.e., whether the claimant faces a "reasonable chance or serious possibility" of a risk to his or her life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. I consider it to be the logical choice as it is consistent with the standard of proof for establishing a well-founded fear of persecution under the Convention. Both the Convention ground and this ground deal with a prospective risk of serious human rights violations and the harm contemplated under section 97(1)(b) is no less serious than the harm to be protected against under the Convention. Therefore, in my opinion, a claimant should not have to establish the prospective risk to a higher degree of certainty than under the Convention.
In addition, there is a compelling argument that the standard of proof should be consistent among the three grounds as all grounds deal with a prospective fear of human rights violations. In fact, the U.K. Immigration Appeal Tribunal in Kacaj10 noted that the various expressions used in reference to the legal test for asylum cases, namely "reasonable chance," "substantial grounds for thinking" and "serious possibility" were
taken to refer to the same degree of risk as a "real risk." In addition, it noted the practical difficulty of applying two legal tests to the same set of facts in a given hearing.
Therefore, I have used the standard of proof as set out in Adjei11 as the standard that should be applied under section 97(1)(b).
I note that the country documentation shows the prevalence of lawlessness in Colombia12 and that Colombia has been dubbed the "number one kidnap capital in the world". The documentary evidence states the following:
MOD figures indicated that approximately 200 children were killed due to the conflict during 2,000. Children suffered disproportionately from the internal conflict, often forfeiting opportunities to study as they were displaced by conflict and suffered psychological traumas.13
According to UNICEF, approximately 25,000 children --- 16,000 of them between 8 and 12 years of age --- are victims of sexual exploitation.14
Colombia is a source country for trafficking in women and girls to Europe, the United States, Asia and other Latin American countries.15
The issue here is whether there is a serious possibility that the minor claimants will each be subjected personally to a risk to their lives or to cruel and unusual treatment. While the qualifiers "cruel and unusual" are not defined in the Act, jurisprudence from cases dealing with s.12 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms are helpful in determining what kind of treatment is cruel and unusual. In R. v. Smith16 standards such as treatment or punishment which shocks the conscience was found to be cruel and unusual.
Treatment that is inhuman or degrading has been equated with cruel and unusual treatment.17 Inhuman treatment has been described as premeditated, applied for hours at a stretch and causing, if not bodily injury, intense physical and mental suffering. Degrading treatment has been described as arousing in its victims' feelings of fear, anguish and inferiority capable of humiliating and debasing them and possibly breaking their physical and moral resistance.18
According to the above documentary evidence, children who are kidnapped will be deprived of education, will be subjected to death, rape, prostitution, girl trafficking, and psychological trauma. I find this treatment to be inhuman and degrading as it shocks the conscience and can be considered to be equivalent to cruel and unusual treatment.19 It is also a risk to life.
The Convention on the Rights of the Child 199020 states the following:
Article 6: State Parties recognize that every child has the inherent right to life.
Article 37: State Parties shall ensure that
(a) No child shall be subjected to torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Neither capital punishment nor life imprisonment without possibility of release shall be imposed for offences committed by persons below 18 years of age;
The binding authority of the above international covenant is clearly enunciated in the IRPA legislation that states the following:
3. (3) This Act is to be construed and applied in a manner that ...
(f) complies with international human rights instruments to which Canada is a signatory.
Clearly, the kidnapping of the minor children will expose them to the possibility of degrading, inhumane and cruel treatment --- a breach of the international covenant on the rights of the child. I, therefore, find the minor claimants to be persons in need of protection.
With respect to the adult claimants, should any of their children be kidnapped and harmed, the question before me is, will they themselves be subjected to a cruel and unusual treatment or punishment as a result of this harm? In answering this question, I note Mr. Justice Lamer's statements in R. v. Smith21 that the criteria usefully synthesized by Professor Tarnopolsky in an article entitled "Just Deserts or Cruel and Unusual Treatment or Punishment? Where Do We Look for Guidance?"22 can provide guidance. The criteria mentioned are:
* Is the punishment such that it goes beyond what is necessary to achieve a legitimate penal aim?
* Is it unnecessary because there are adequate alternatives?
* Is it unnecessary to a large segment of the population?
* Is it such that it cannot be applied upon a rational basis in accordance with ascertained or ascertainable standards?
* Is it arbitrarily imposed?
* Is it such that it has no value in the sense of some social purpose such as reformation, rehabilitation, deterrence or retribution?
* Is it in accord with public standards of decency or propriety?
* Is the punishment of such a character as to shock general conscience or as to be intolerable in fundamental fairness?
* Is it unusually severe and hence degrading to human dignity and worth?
I find the adult claimants to be caring and loving parents. They both manifested a deep concern for their children's security and well being. The adult claimants restricted the minor claimants to only activities of the school or those that are deemed necessary and in places where there are only relatives and friends. After the first kidnap attempt, they cancelled the bus pickups for their children. Instead, they made sure that one of them brought their children to school and picked them up from school. Shortly only after the second try to kidnap XXXXXXX, the claimant took her away to Miami. The claimant is a self-employed businessman and XXXXXX is a Coordinator of a corporation. They both gave up an established profession and a good income to come to Canada to risk starting all over again.
Should any of their children be kidnapped and harmed, the adult claimants will likely suffer severe psychological trauma. The mere recounting by XXXXXXX of the kidnapping attempts at the hearing brought emotional distress upon their parents. XXXXXX in particular could not contain her sobbing. If the adult claimants returned to Colombia and find any or both of their daughters kidnapped, they will both be tormented by the reasonable belief that their daughters, once kidnapped, will face the risks of murder, rape, of being forced into prostitution, or of being psychologically devastated. These, in my opinion, are treatment that meets three of the guiding criteria suggested by Mr. Justice Lamer above, namely, a) that the treatment is against public standards of decency or propriety, b) that the punishment is of such a character as to shock general conscience and, c) that it is unusually severe and hence degrading to human dignity and worth.23. Hence, I find the adult claimants also face a serious possibility of risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. They are therefore also persons in need of protection.
State Protection
Before a claimant can be found to be a person in need of protection, he or she must be able to meet all the elements of the definition which include an assessment of State Protection and an Internal Flight Alternative (IFA). The following documentary evidence24 describes the inability of the state to have effective control of its territory against armed insurgents and armed criminals.
The government continued to face serious challenges to its control over the national territory, as longstanding and widespread internal armed conflict and rampant violence --- both political and criminal --- persisted25.
I, therefore, find that there is clear and convincing evidence before me that the state is unable to protect the claimants.
Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
I have also considered whether the risks faced by the claimants are limited to part of the country and whether there are other parts of the country, reasonably accessible by the claimants, where the claimants would not face a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. However, based on the evidence before me, I find that there is no internal flight alternative for the claimants because most common criminals in Colombia have extensive contacts and networks all over the country. Once declared to be a target, they will manage to find the claimants in other parts of the country. This is exactly what happened when XXXXXX took the remaining children to XXXXXX XXXXX (a friend) home on XXXXX, 2000 after the claimant and XXXXXXX left Colombia. Two weeks after they went into hiding, the perpetrators phoned, looking for them. I, therefore, find that IFA is not reasonably available for the claimants.
Conclusion
For all the above reasons, the Refugee Division determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are persons in need of protection.

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX for refugee protection.
The claimant is a thirty-five-year-old citizen of Guyana. He bases his claim on his fear of crime and violence in Guyana.
In order to be determined to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that their removal to their country of nationality would subject them personally (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Identity
The claimant's identity is established by the certified true copy of his passport which was forwarded to the Board by the Immigration department1 and a new passport issued by the Consulate General of Guyana in Toronto which he presented at the hearing.2
Credibility
The claimant's testimony was credible and trustworthy. He was honest and straightforward and did not embellish his claim.
Evidence
The claimant does not wish to return to Guyana. He stated that crime and violence affect everyone's life and have increased dramatically in the three years since he left his country. He fears that because he is Indo-Guyanese he will be harmed by criminal elements from the Afro-Guyanese population. He stated that Indo-Guyanese, are more often the targets of the criminal element as they are more affluent. He also stated that the police themselves have been beaten by bandits and that several police officers have been killed in the past few months. He is concerned that if he returns to Guyana, he will be perceived as being wealthy because of having lived in Canada and that this will lead to his being robbed.
Analysis
The panel finds that the claimant fears general levels of crime and violence. Although the claimant states he is at risk because he is Indo-Guyanese, the documentary evidence indicates that not only Indo-Guyanese are at risk of violent crime, but all persons living in Guyana are at risk.3 The Indo-Guyanese are the group who are most often targeted for robbery as they are the most affluent of the two major racial groups.
The police in Guyana are facing a very difficult situation with the increase in violent crime but the documentary evidence indicates that the police do not discriminate with respect to the protection they offer Guyanese citizens.
A Response to Information Request4 states that in the view of the Guyana Human Rights Association (GHRA):
"The police do not discriminate on grounds of race or political affiliation in its handling of complaints and crimes. There were concerns about police bias based mostly on political affiliation or ethnicity before 1992, but the situation as regards equality of rights and freedoms has constantly improved since then, and the police are now perceived to be neutral on questions of ethnicity and political affiliation. However, there is a serious problem with violent crime, which has been steadily increasing in both numbers and violence. In Guyana, a country of some 750,000 inhabitants, about two violent home invasions take place every week, and most of the victims are Indo-Guyanese victims. The increase in violent crime is attributed mostly to illegal drugs and persons seeking to finance their consumption. The disproportionate victimization of Indo-Guyanese is attributed to their proportionally grater affluence, since they are a major component of the business and trading 'class', and many are relatively prosperous farmers."
It continues:
"The police response to violent crimes has been inadequate; rather than an ethnic or political motivation for this incapacity to cope, it is widely perceived that the police force does not have the necessary manpower, training and salaries to ensure an effective action against the increasing crime."
The claimant is Indo-Guyanese and it is the party that represents the Indo-Guyanese, the PPP that is in power and has been since 1992. The President is Indo-Guyanese. While the security forces and the police are made up for the most part of Afro-Guyanese, the government has attempted to recruit more Indo-Guyanese into the security forces but has met with little response. Most Indo-Guyanese prefer business, farming or professional careers. The government has made efforts to reduce racial tension. The government has sponsored various forums for discussion of racial problems and supported the work of NGO's that deal with these concerns.5 There is no evidence to suggest that the government has turned a blind eye to the serious problem of violent crime. On the contrary, the government is formed by the party that represents the Indo-Guyanese and the evidence indicates it is attempting to protect its constituents.
The persons the claimant fears are criminals and he fears general levels of crime and violence. It is a serious problem faced by all citizens of Guyana. I find that Indo-Guyanese citizens are not discriminated against by the police and are not less likely to receive protection than other citizens of Guyana.
In order to be determined to be a Convention refugee, a claimant must establish that he has a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of their race, religion, nationality, and membership in a particular social group or political opinion. In this case, the harm the claimant fears is not based on one of these grounds but is instead based on a fear of the general levels of crime and violence prevalent in Guyana today. I find that the claimant has not established a connection or nexus to one of the grounds of the Convention refugee definition.
With respect to his fear of a risk to his life, any risk that he may face is similar to that of other citizens of Guyana, as he fears a risk of random indiscriminate violence. The claimant has not established an identifiable risk that is distinguishable from that of the general population as required by section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Act. I find that the claimant fears a generalized risk, one that is faced by all citizens of Guyana. There was no evidence lead to support a finding that the claimant faces a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture.
Conclusion
The Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee, nor is he a person in need of protection. The panel rejects his claim for refugee protection.
"Fay Sims"

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the refugee protection claim made by XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (a.k.a. XXXXXXXXXXXX), a 29-year-old citizen of Jamaica. The hearing for this claim was held pursuant to section 170(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act1 (IRPA) on December 4, 2002, at Toronto, Ontario.
He is alleging the need for protection because he fears drug dealers upon return to Jamaica.
In order to be determined to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that his removal to his country of nationality would subject him personally either, (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
The claimant stated that in XXXXXX 1999 two known drug dealers from Ocho Rios approached him with the request to sell marijuana, as he was a bartender in a holiday resort and had access to tourists. He told them that he would consider the request; he was approached again and denied their offer. They started to threaten him and he went to the police station to report the threats. It was suggested that he should accept the offer and that there was nothing that could be done to help him. Two other constables, who are the claimant's friends, but who were not working in the station when he reported the threats, cautioned him that constables at the station could be in cohoots with the drug dealers, and to be careful. When the drug dealers approached him again, he was able to persuade them to wait in order for him to care for his sick mother, but went into hiding instead. The claimant knew at that time that he was approved to come to Canada as a farm worker and stayed in hiding until his departure on XXXXX 1999. He stated that the drug dealers are still coming to his mother's house threatening to "get him" because he reported them to the police.
Analysis:
Identity:
The claimant's passport and other identity document's were available, therefore I accepted his identity and nationality.
Credibility:
I assign the benefit of doubt to the claimant's story about recruitment attempts and threats by drug dealers. He provided persuasive documents showing that he worked as a bartender at the resort during the period in question. It was established that the letter from Constable XXXXXX2 had to be given weight; both he and XXXXXXX are constables in Jamaica.3 The claimant did not present me with contradictions, omissions or embellishments and his story is plausible in the Jamaican context.4
I also find that the issue of delay is not applicable in this case, as the claimant was not aware that he could claim for refugee protection when he arrived in Canada. He thought that refugee status would only be granted to persons with political problems. He had made alternative arrangements because he feared returning to Jamaica and did not want to be deported. He married a Canadian citizen. However, she disappeared before a sponsorship application materialized and he had problems getting a divorce in order to marry his common law Canadian wife, with whom he has a child. A second sponsorship application is now in process. The claimant asked for refugee protection in July 2001, after he came to the attention of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) due to a police investigation, which was discontinued.5
IFA and State Protection
I find that this claim has to fail because of availability of an internal flight alternative (IFA) and, in so finding, I am guided by Thirunavukkarasu6 and Rasaratnam.7 I further find that there is adequate state protection8 within the IFA.
The claimant stated that there is no safe place for him in Jamaica and that these two drug dealers are moving up and down the coast and have criminal connections everywhere, which might be plausible. However, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that every police station in the country is on the "take" and that he would not receive protection from these two criminals anywhere else. His own evidence shows that not every constable in Jamaica is corrupted; his friend who wrote the letter in support of his claim is an example. Proof of lack of state protection must be clear and convincing9 and it is not for our court to establish a high standard of state protection for other countries. Reality has to prevail. Protection may not be perfect,10 and a test of whether the system is adequate considering the circumstances of this case has to be applied.11
The International Narcotics Control Strategy Report 1999,12 indicates that the Government of Jamaica together with the Jamaican Constabulary takes drug trafficking serious and has taken steps to protect citizens against organized crime. It tries, for example, to curb police corruption. During 1999, 32 police officers were arrested for criminal violations, and seven were charged with drug-related offences. In September 1999 the police commissioner transferred the entire 91-member special anti-crime task force because of allegations that some members were involved in unprofessional and possible criminal conduct.13 However, it is noted that more needs to be done to root out corruption.14 The Government of Jamaica prosecutes individuals who by reliable evidence are linked to drug-related activities.15 I find that there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the claimant's complaints about threats from the drug dealers would not be taken serious in any constabulary outside Ocho Rios.16 Therefore, there is not a serious possibility or reasonable chance of serious harm should the claimant relocate within Jamaica.
Having considered the totality of the evidence, the relevant statutory provisions and jurisprudence, I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. Therefore, the Refugee Protection Division rejects the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (a.k.a. XXXXXXXXXXXX) for refugee protection.

These are the reasons of the Refugee Protection Division with respect to the claim of XXXXXXXXXXX to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. The claimant is a twenty-two year old citizen of Trinidad and Tobago.
In order to be determined to be either a Convention refugee or a Protected person, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that their removal to their country of nationality would subject them personally either, (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Basis of the Claim
The claimant came to Canada and the United States in the summer of 1998 on a vacation with her mother. She was eighteen years old. While they were in the United States, her mother married an American citizen and decided to remain there. The claimant returned to Canada with an aunt and has been here ever since.
The claimant does not wish to return to Trinidad, as she believes her only option is to return to live in the family home where she had previously lived with her mother. This house is home to her grandmother and six of her mother's siblings. One of them, an uncle, is a cocaine and crack user. The uncle's use of drugs caused innumerable problems for the family, as he would steal from them to obtain money to buy drugs and his unsavoury friends would come to the house. The claimant stated she would have to return to the family home as she has no other place to go. She stated it is difficult to find a job in Trinidad and that if she did find one, it would not pay enough for her to be able to live on her own. She stated she had no other family member to go to.
Identity
The Department of Immigration provided a certified true copy of the claimant's passport to the Board. Identity is therefore established on a balance of probabilities.
Analysis
The claimant's reasons for not wanting to return to Trinidad are financial. She does not fear any person or persons. She does not fear she will be persecuted or harmed for one of the reasons or grounds set out in the Convention refugee definition. The grounds are race, religion, nationality, and membership in a particular social group or political opinion. She is not a member of a particular social group as her situation is not innate or unchangeable. Any difficulties that she would face returning to Trinidad would be based on her economic position and the fact that she is now alone while she had lived with her mother previously. While her situation could be difficult, it is not persecutory nor does it place her at a risk of torture or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
The claimant has not established a nexus or connection to any harm she may fear and a ground of the Convention Refugee definition. Nor has she established a risk of torture or a risk to life or a risk of cruel or unusual treatment or punishment.
The Refugee Division determines that XXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. The panel rejects her claim to be a protected person in Canada.

XXXXXXXXXXXXX, a 64- year-old citizen of Syria and his 56-year-old wife, XXXXXXXXXXX, claim to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of Muslim moneylenders because they are Christians. In addition, they claim to be persons in need of protection because they are at risk of losing their lives or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Syria.
ALLEGATIONS
The male claimant alleges to be a contractor who financed the construction of apartment buildings by borrowing extensively from private moneylenders against the security of the apartments and the claimants' home. Commencing in 1997 the Syrian economy fell into recession and according to the claimants the apartment buildings and their home plummeted in value. After the lenders called in their loans and foreclosed on the apartment buildings and their home, the claimants remained indebted to the moneylenders in the amount of 3.5 million Syrian pounds. According to the claimants, they were penniless and that not even a lifetime of work would generate enough income to repay their debt.
The claimants allege that on at least 3 occasions armed security forces threatened them and their adult children with death if the debt was not repaid. On the final occasion, the male claimant was dragged from his home to the offices of the moneylenders. According to the male claimant an armed security officer put a gun to his head and threatened to kill him and his son if the money remained unpaid. On the single occasion that the male claimant sought the protection of the police, he indicates that he was rebuffed.
Fearing for the lives of their son and daughter, the claimants allege that they made arrangements for them to leave Syria. A second daughter who remains in Syria is afforded some protection, according to the claimants, by reason of having assumed her husband's surname. Having ameliorated the risks to their children, the claimants fled to Canada.
DETERMINATION
The panel finds that the claimants are persons in need of protection in that there is a serious possibility that they will be subjected personally to a risk to their lives or to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Syria.
ANALYSIS
The panel finds that the claimants have failed to establish a link between their fear of persecution and any of the five Convention refugee grounds; accordingly, the claim is being considered under section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the "Act").
The claimants' identities as nationals of Syria are established by the testimony and the supporting documentation, namely, the claimants' passports and their Certificates of Birth and Baptism.
The male claimant testified on behalf of himself and his wife. The panel finds that he was a credible witness and therefore believes what he has alleged in support of their claims. He testified in a straightforward manner and there were no relevant inconsistencies in his testimony or contradictions between his testimony and the other evidence before the panel.
The central issue in this claim is whether the claimants would be subjected personally to a risk of the harm contemplated by section 97(1)(b) of the Act, namely, a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, should the claimants return to Syria. The Act, however, is silent as to the appropriate standard of proof to be used in assessing the risk of harm as contemplated by section 97(1)(b).
The panel is of the opinion that the standard of proof as set out in Adjei1 and as applied to the Convention refugee definition is the standard that should be applied under section 97(1)(b) of the Act. Both the Convention grounds and the grounds under section 97(1)(b) deal with prospective risks of serious human rights violations and the harm contemplated under section 97(1)(b) is no less serious than the harm to be protected against under the Convention. Therefore, a claimant should not have to establish the prospective risk of harm under section 97(1)(b) to a higher degree of certainty than under the Convention. Accordingly, the panel has applied the Adjei standard to the facts of this claim.
Having regard to the foregoing, the panel finds that there is a serious possibility that the claimants would be subjected personally to a risk to life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment should they return to Syria.
The evidence reveals that the claimants are unable to repay a sizeable debt to money- lenders. In retribution, their lives and the lives of their children have been threatened by armed security officers. The claimants have responded to these threats by sending two of their children out of Syria. The consummation of these vindictive threats is, on a balance of probabilities, likely, given the moneylenders' interest in setting a visible example to those who fail to pay their debts. The panel finds that there is a serious possibility that such treatment will recur and that the claimants will be killed should they return to Syria.
A further issue is whether the Syrian security forces acted on behalf of or on the directions of the moneylenders.
The panel finds that the Syrian security forces do act in concert with the moneylenders.
The testimony revealed that the moneylenders use Syrian security force members to collect bad debts and to intimidate debtors and their relatives. The documentary evidence makes it clear that the powerful role of the security services extends beyond security matters, that they operate outside the legal system and that their members commit serious human right abuses.2 The panel finds, on the balance of probabilities, that the security services do act on behalf of the moneylenders and that the moneylenders are sufficiently financed to enable them to bribe security members.
The question arises as to whether the state can provide the claimants protection from the moneylenders.
The panel finds that state protection is not available.
The male claimant allegedly sought protection from the authorities on one occasion but it was summarily denied. The panel finds that, given the security forces act in concert with the moneylenders, the state would not protect the claimants should they return to Syria.
Finally, at issue is whether an internal flight alternative is available to the claimants. The panel finds, on the balance of probabilities, that there is no internal flight alternative for the claimants.
The evidence indicates that the moneylenders have ties with the state security forces.3 Under those circumstances, it is more likely than not that they have the ability to use their security forces contacts to track down the claimants anywhere in Syria.
CONCLUSION
On the basis of the foregoing, the panel concludes that XXXXXXXXXXXXX and his wife, XXXXXXXXXXX, are persons in need of protection and therefore the panel accepts their claims for refugee protection.

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division with respect to the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Jamaica, for refugee protection.
Summary of Alleged Facts
The claimant is a 29-year-old woman from XXXXXX, Jamaica. She originally came to Canada in October 1992, to attend the funeral of her great-grandmother. Her father, three brothers and a sister as well as some aunts and uncles all live in Canada and are Canadian citizens. Her father attempted to sponsor her but because she was already nineteen years of age at the time she was turned down. She remained in Canada illegally, eventually applying under the Humanitarian and Compassionate program in 1998. She was refused on December 19, 1998, the decision-maker finding that "her H & C grounds do not warrant favourable consideration. No unusual, undeserved or disproportionate hardship would be caused were she to leave Canada and apply from abroad".1 This decision was reviewed in November 2000 and again refused, the officer finding that the claimant's mother, her primary caretaker, remained in Jamaica and again that the claimant had not "become established to the point where it would cause her undue and disproportionate hardship to leave Canada and seek an immigrant visa in the normal legislative manner" (Ibid). This last refusal led to the current claim to refugee status, a last effort to remain in Canada.
The claimant fears returning to Jamaica because of the violence and crime that obtain in that country and because she anticipates that she might have difficulty finding a job as the economy is not thriving.
Analysis
In order to be determined to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or that her removal to her country of nationality would subject her personally either (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
At the outset of the hearing, the panel explained that the nexus put forward by counsel, namely, "member of a lower income group" did not conform to the criteria of particular social group set out in the Ward2 decision. The member explained that "lower income" is not an innate or unchangeable characteristic, neither is it fundamental to one's human dignity. The member therefore was not able to find that the claim had any nexus to the Convention refugee definition. She said that she was prepared to hear the claim taking into consideration the new consolidated grounds found in section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, which make allowance for claims with no nexus.
The panel was satisfied that the claimant is who she says she is having seen the claimant's original passport, issued in Canada on October 28, 1998 when her old passport expired, and the copious notes in the CIC material (Exhibit M-1). The issues that remained to be dealt with were: 1) credibility 2) delay in claiming, and 3) well-foundedness including agent(s) of persecution, the harm feared and protection.
The claimant testified to being in ongoing contact with her mother in Jamaica. Her anxieties about what might happen to her if she returned to Jamaica come from what she has heard from her mother and other individuals about the general situation there. She testified to having grown up in the neighbourhood of XXXXX known as XXXXX, a lower-income neighbourhood where robberies and other crimes including shootings go on and where the criminals more often than not go unpunished. She testified at one point to having, in her words, "basically been raped" when attacked by five young men when she was fourteen. No mention of this incident was made in the claimant's Personal Information Form3 (PIF). When asked why, she stated that she didn't think she had to, she just decided to tell the panel member on the spot. She testified that she didn't tell her mother at the time nor since. The panel does not believe this incident occurred. It believes the claimant put this in to attempt to bolster her claim. The panel simply does not believe a 14-year-old who had been assaulted and raped would not have told her mother. Everything about the claimant indicates a positive caring relationship with her mother. Nor did the claimant offer a satisfactory explanation for omitting this information from the PIF. The rest of her testimony was purely speculative: she might have to go back to school to get a job, she no longer has friends in the neighbourhood and might be more vulnerable as someone who is a stranger and has lived abroad for so long.
The claimant could not name any specific individual or group who might be interested in her. The panel has no evidence before it to indicate that she fears anyone in particular. Neither does it have evidence to indicate that what she fears is more than a vague generalized concern about crime that would be shared by any individual in a society such as Jamaica where crime and violence are indeed very high. As such, it would fall under section 97(1) (b) (ii) of the Act4 and not entitle her to advance a claim based on a risk to life, there being no evidence of a danger of torture in this case. The claimant was asked why she could not live and work elsewhere in Jamaica, i.e. outside of XXXXXXX. She was unable to answer other than to say she would need a reasonable income. The panel does not find this a satisfactory explanation. The panel recognizes that Jamaica is a small place. As it does not find the claimant to have established that she faces a well-founded fear of persecution or a risk to life in XXXXX an IFA does not really come into play.
Having considered all the evidence before it, the panel finds that the claimant has not established that she would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground nor a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual punishment nor a danger of torture should she return to Jamaica. The panel therefore rejects the claim to refugee protection of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.

She claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of her membership in a particular social group, namely women who refuse to follow traditional practices, and on her perceived political opinion. On the former ground, she fears persecution at the hands of members of her own and her husband's family, from whom no state protection is available. On the latter ground, she fears persecution at the hands of agents of the government of Zimbabwe.
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, 4, a citizen of Zimbabwe, claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution based on her identity as the minor female child of her parents. She fears persecution at the hands of her grandparents, from whom state protection is unavailable to her and at the hands of agents of the government of Zimbabwe.
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, 30, the male claimant, also a Zimbabwean citizen, claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of his political opinion. He fears persecution at the hands of agents of the government of Zimbabwe.
Summary of allegations, principal and minor claimant
The principal claimant alleges that, in 2000, her then husband, XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, facing persecution for his political beliefs, disappeared. As a result of his disappearance, she was forced into a levirate marriage with his brother by her own and her husband's parents, following tradition. Her prior refusal to comply and pleas to police for assistance met with no success.
Her new husband proved to be a brutal man who mistreated her emotionally and physically, issuing death threats against her and once even holding a knife to her throat to force her submission to him. Fearing for her life and her daughter's well-being, she took the child into hiding until arrangements were completed for their departure from Zimbabwe.
Summary of allegations, male claimant
The male claimant alleges that, because he was a member of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) and was employed by a well-regarded non-governmental organization (NGO) doing community-related work, he received death threats and became the target of government agents. He escaped the fate of five MDC members who were killed by fleeing into hiding, having been tipped off by community members. At this point he lost contact with his family. Government agents tracked him down and beat him to unconsciousness. MDC members rescued him and took him to a hideout where he remained until they completed arrangements for his departure from Zimbabwe.
Determination
The Refugee Protection Division determines each of the claimants to be a Convention refugee because each has a well-founded fear of persecution.
Preliminary matters
As a preliminary matter, I note that the principal claimant acted as designated the representative of the minor claimant after establishing that she was the child's mother and would act in her best interests.
I note as a further preliminary matter, that the principal claimant and the minor claimant arrived in Canada and claimed Convention refugee status prior to the male claimant. Their Personal Information Forms1 (PIF) identified him as husband and father, respectively and indicated that his whereabouts were unknown. The three claims were joined after the male claimant made his claim.
I note that neither of the two counsels (one representing the principal and minor claimants and the other the male claimant) objected to the joinder. I note as well, that, after the joinder, no separate file screening form for the male claimant had been prepared and that his counsel triggered his Notice to Appear by calling the Division to advise that he had received none. Counsels had not disclosed all the relevant documents concerning their clients to each other and appear not to have contacted each other in that regard. Nevertheless, with the cooperation of counsel and the assistance of the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) in arranging the photocopying of numerous documents and counsels being allotted time to peruse them, the hearing was completed.
Finally, I note that written observations from the RPO were received by the August 26, 2002 due date, with written reply by counsel for the principal and minor claimants being received on August 30, 2002, and a document requested from counsel for the male claimant was received August 23, 2002.
Analysis
In considering the claims of the principal and minor claimants, I have borne in mind the Chairperson's guidelines regarding female2 and minor claimants.3
The determinative issues in this matter are the identity of the claimants, including political identity for the male claimant and the subjective and objective bases for a well-founded fear of persecution for all three claimants.
Identity: Principal claimant and minor claimant
Based on their valid passports, I accept that the principal claimant4 and minor claimant5 are who they say they are and are citizens of Zimbabwe. Based on the minor claimant's birth certificate,6 I accept that the principal claimant and minor claimant are mother and daughter.
In light of the principal claimant's passport indication that her occupation is civil servant and her University diploma in Education7 I am satisfied that she was as she stated, a teacher employed by the Zimbabwean Ministry of Education.
Identity, male claimant
Documents corroborative of the male claimant's identity,8 including his Certificate of Birth,9 school documents,10 his university diploma11 and his photo ID national identity card,12 Zimbabwe National Registration13 are before me. Based on them, and a balance of possibilities, I accept that he is who he says he is and is a citizen of Zimbabwe. I accept based on the principal claimant's credible testimony that she and the male claimant were married in a XXXXX 1998 traditional ceremony. I also accept, based on the minor claimant's birth certificate14 and the observable familial similarity, that he and the minor claimant are father and daughter. Further documentary corroboration of the male claimant's identity is a letter tendered post-hearing confirming his employment.15
The male claimant tendered no documentary evidence of his MDC activism. He was knowledgeable about MDC and its activities in his stated constituency. However, without the principal claimant's corroborative evidence in this regard, certain credibility concerns canvassed below might have led me to question whether his knowledge came from direct experience. For the reasons below, I am satisfied that the male claimant was an active opponent of the government of Zimbabwe, based on the principal claimant's PIF mention of his political persecution.
I accept that, when the principal claimant signed the PIF in October 2001, she had no expectation of seeing the male claimant again, having had no word of him for over a year and a half. She makes no allegation that either she or her daughter risk persecution because of his political activities. Rather, she bases her claim on gender, including being forced into a levirate marriage because of her then husband's lengthy disappearance. I read her mention of the male claimant's political problems as incidental, included solely as a possible explanation for his disappearance. Given the circumstances of their claims, I see no other benefit of such mention to her or her daughter. I accept, based on her PIF narrative, and a balance of probabilities that the male claimant was an active government opponent. As well, I accept that he was an MDC activist, based on the principal claimant's credible oral evidence.
Credibility, principal claimant
In my view, the principal claimant was a credible witness. Her oral and written stories were, on balance, mutually consistent.
I accept that she remains very angry with the male claimant, missing for 1 1/2 years, for not somehow contacting her in Zimbabwe to let her know he was still alive and that she blames his failure to do so for the persecution that befell her. I accept too, that she knew nothing of his arrival in Canada until a mutual acquaintance advised her of it; that they have always lived separately here and that she has no intention of reuniting with him.
The principal claimant did hesitate when asked whether her fear of persecution might be removed if she and the male claimant together presented themselves to their parents. In my view, her hesitation was not evasion but rather resulted from her deliberating about the appropriate response, since she had already put aside all consideration of reconciliation or reuniting with him. I found her manner of testimony to be generally straightforward, particularly in light of the claims being heard together.
I accept as reasonable her explanation that she went to South Africa in search of her missing husband after being told that he was there and, failing to find him after two months, returned to Zimbabwe, the problems with his family having not yet surfaced. Her evidence in this regard was detailed and, to my mind spontaneous. I believe her. In my view, her return did not constitute reavailment.
The principal claimant was able to offer a satisfactory explanation for the significant discrepancy with the Port of Entry notes.16 Her forced marriage, her fear of her own and of her husband's family, including his abusive brother, now her husband, are omitted in the story recorded by the Immigration Officer. The principal claimant's explanation for the omission was that, although she had attempted to communicate her whole story, the Immigration Officer advised that it was too long and that the claimant could fill out the details for her claim after seeing a lawyer. I find her explanation reasonable for the following reasons. The Immigration Officer has noted as the first item in the claimant's account the claimant's separation from her husband and the difficulty of raising a child alone. I find this to accord with her oral evidence of ostracization as a means of forcing levirate marriage. I do not doubt that the account the principal claimant gave the Immigration Officer was long and complicated or that the story might have been confused given the claimant's exhaustion after traveling for hours with a 3-year old. I note that the Immigration Officer has attempted to assist by posing questions to the claimant. However, I note as well, that all of the questions regarding Zimbabwe relate to the claimant's relationship with her husband. I am satisfied that these key omissions are the result of the context of the interview rather than an attempt to mislead on the part of the claimant or inaccuracy on the part of the Immigration Officer.
I find credible the principal claimant's testimony that, with her husband's disappearance, her attempts (noted earlier) to find him and with no word of him for 11/2 years, he was presumed dead by her and his parents. Her evidence regarding her forced marriage to the claimant's brother was detailed and, to my mind, credible. Furthermore, her evidence regarding the customary practice of levitate marriage in Zimbabwe is consistent with the documentary evidence.17 It shows18 that, despite legal prohibitions, women are still vulnerable to entrenched customary practices, including the forcing of a widow to marry her late husband's brother.
Moreover, I am satisfied that the threat of ostracization by both families if she refused the levirate marriage was effective because of the economic consequences for her and her daughter. The documentary evidence19 reports that women married under customary law are not allowed to own property jointly with their husbands. Although the claimant was employed as a teacher, I accept that this posed insufficient security for her as the mother of a young child. The documentary evidence shows escalating violence against teachers by government agents20 and increasingly widespread economic chaos. I find the claimant's testimony credible in this regard.
As well, the documentary evidence21 is supportive of her allegation that she was unable to gain protection from her new husband's brutality. Spousal abuse is reported as endemic in Zimbabwe with society generally accepting of it and police not responding to women's requests for assistance.22
In light of all of the above, I find the principal claimant to be a credible and trustworthy witness. I believe her account.
Credibility, male claimant
Numerous credibility and plausibility concerns remain in my mind about the male claimant's evidence. For example, I find not plausible his testimony that, because he did not want to jeopardize her safety, he failed to get word to his wife of his welfare. He spent his lengthy time in hiding on the outskirts of Bulawayo, the city where she lived. He was in contact with MDC members who were apparently sufficiently competent in underground work to hide him and then to get him out of the country. I do not know why he did not send some sort of message to her, but I find not credible the reason he gave.
Nor am I satisfied that his emergence in Canada only weeks after his wife and daughter arrived in this country was entirely coincidental. To my mind, his testimony that he did not know they were in Canada before he came to this country strains credulity.
However, there was one aspect of his testimony about which I have no doubt, namely that his wife will not forgive him and will not reconcile with him. His evidence in that regard was blurted out and his repeated supplications that it should be possible to put the past behind them lent credence to his testimony about their relationship, in my opinion.
Regardless of my outstanding concerns about the trustworthiness of the male claimant's testimony, I have accepted that he is who he says he is; that he was an MDC member and an anti-government activist.
Objective basis for a well-founded fear of persecution, principal claimant
In my opinion, the principal claimant has established an objectively well-founded fear of persecution on a Convention ground. As noted earlier, the documentary evidence is supportive of her allegation that forced levirate marriage is a customary practice in Zimbabwe and that state protection is unavailable to her either from her parents, her in-laws or from her abusive second husband.
I have accepted that she will not reconcile with the male claimant, who because of his failure to contact her, she holds responsible for her past persecution. However, even in that unlikely event, no evidence is before me that the stipulated agents of persecution would change their minds about the legitimacy of her levirate marriage.
Given all of the foregoing, I find her fear of persecution in Zimbabwe to be objectively well-founded.
Objective basis for a well-founded fear of persecution, male claimant
For the following reasons, I find the male claimant has established an objectively well-founded fear of persecution based on his political opinion. The documentary evidence23 reports state-sanctioned attacks by government supporters such as war veterans and members of the ruling ZANU PF party against political opponents and perceived opponents, with army and police lending assistance to those conducting such violence and knowingly permitting such activities. The documentary evidence shows numerous instances of such attacks particularly on members of the opposition MDC, including beatings and torture24 and violent beatings resulting in death.25 I have accepted that the male claimant is an MDC activist. In my view, his fear of persecution by reason of his political opinion is objectively well-founded.
Objective basis for a well-founded fear of persecution, minor claimant
I find the minor claimant has established that her fear of persecution as the minor female child of her parents is well-founded on an objective basis. I accept the principal claimant's evidence that the minor claimant was at risk of emotional harm because of the brutality of the step-father with whom she and the principal claimant were forced to live lest they be ostracized from both families. The documentary evidence reports the deprivation suffered by women in such circumstances26 and the dire consequences suffered by children who are without economic support.27 Moreover, as the daughter of a government opponent and a member of MDC, the documentary evidence28 shows that the minor claimant is at risk of persecution at the hands of government agents.
In my opinion, each of the claimants has an objectively well-founded fear of persecution on a Convention ground. I conclude that there is more than a mere possibility of persecution were any of the claimants to return to Zimbabwe.
Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines XXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXX to be Convention refugees.

In order to be determined to be either a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that their removal to their country of nationality would subject them personally either, (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
These are the reasons with respect to the claims of XXXXXXXXXXXXX, 22-years-old and her common-law partner, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, 23-years-old. They are both citizens of Argentina, and claiming the need for protection as they have a well-founded fear of persecution on the basis of being threatened by the female claimant's father. I have taken the Gender Guidelines1 into consideration before rendering a decision in this claim.
The female claimant stated that her father mistreated her when she was growing up. She ran away when she was 17-years-old and lived with her mother, who had left her father when the claimant was a small child. The claimant testified that her father tried to have her returned to his care, however, the courts granted her mother custody in XXXX 1997 and her father received order to say away. The judge in her case also recommended psychological treatments. The claimant declared that her father did not obey the court order and continued to threaten her and her mother. They moved a few times but the father would trace them by threatening other relatives. The male claimant testified that the female claimant's father threatened and attacked him after they lived together. He stated that they moved out of Buenos Aires shortly before coming to Canada to live with one of his relatives, however, the female claimant's father found them. The claimants stated that they waited until the female claimant was 21-years-old, and could obtain a passport without the consent of her father, in order to join her mother who had left for Canada earlier and had claimed for refugee status together with many other relatives. The claims were rejected. The claimants stated that her father was protected by the police, because he was their friend, and therefore, state protection was not available for them.
Analysis:
Identity:
The certified true copies of both claimants passports are on file,2 therefore, I accepted their identities.
Credibility:
I find that the credibility of the two joined claims was tainted because of the failure to present relevant documents and significant omissions in the testimony. In addition, the claimants did not establish clear and convincing evidence that state protection would not be forthcoming. I have taken the following into account; that the claimants are young; their education background as stated in their Personal Information Form (PIF) (even though they chose not to submit any education documents in support of this statement); communication is through an interpreter; and cultural differences.
Documentation:
The claimants were asked why they did not produce documents, such as their national identity cards, education documents or the court order, which allegedly was issued in reference to the female claimant in 1997. The claimants indicated that they did not see any necessity for producing any documents from Argentina, as such documents would not be of value in Canada and they had their passports to establish their identity. They insisted that no documents they possessed would be relevant to their claims. Regarding the court documents, the female claimant stated that she tried to obtain them without success. She dismissed the question with a very brief reply and did not offer any further information about her efforts to obtain documents, which allegedly put her under protective court custody in 1997. Claimants cannot always be expected to produce corroborating documentation in support of their claims, however, here the claimants did not provide the basic information such as where they lived in Argentina, or their education background. They did not offer further explanation why they could not produce their identity cards or similar documents, even though both have many relatives living in Argentina. In addition, the female claimant's mother, together with her uncle and other relatives claimed for refugee status before the claimants, which is an indication that the claimants were aware of the onus they had to fulfil. I find that the claimants only produced their passports because their claim is not based on the truth.
Omissions:
Both claimants omitted from their PIF narratives that they moved to the province before coming to Canada because they feared the female claimant's father who traced them and threatened the family they lived with. The male claimant omitted from his PIF narrative that her father with two other men attacked him and broke his nose; that he was attacked and stabbed with a screwdriver on another occasion; and that he was threatened with a gun at his sister's home. He also omitted to state in his PIF narrative that he required medical treatment for his broken nose. They explained that they were advised at a centre for Spanish speaking person to keep their PIF narrative short, as they will have an opportunity to explain their situation at the hearing. As the claimants did provide details, such as the male claimant's dog that was outside the house and started barking loudly,3 I find their explanation not persuasive and trustworthy. Why mention that a dog is barking, but omitting that one is stabbed with a screwdriver. If brevity was recommended by the centre, then why mention that the female claimant lived jwith different aunts with Buenos Aires,4 but not point out that both claimants had to move to the province. I find that the omissions indicate that the claimants tried to embellish their claims during the oral testimony.
State Protection:
In M.C.I. v. Kadenko, the Federal Court of Appeal held that,
When the state in question is a democratic state ... the claimant must do more than simply who that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the courses of action open to him or her.5
I find that it is not sufficient in the context of Argentina to show that state protection is not available, because members in one police station refused to help. There must be more. Argentina is a federal constitutional democracy with an executive branch headed by an elected president, a bicameral legislature, and a separate judiciary. In 1999, voters elected President Fernando de la Rua in generally free and fair elections. After major protests in December he resigned and was succeeded briefly by three interim president before the Legislative Assembly elected Eduardo Duhalde to serve out the remainder of the de la Rua term.6
I recognize that the human rights record of the police in Argentina is not perfect;7 however, documentary evidence shows that the Government of Argentina has undertaken serious measures to combat inter alia, graft, corruption and professional misconduct within the police forces, with considerable success.8 I find that the claimants did not take steps reasonable in the circumstances to seek a solution to their alleged problems in Buenos Aires, before seeking international protection in Canada. Complaints about assaults, physical or psychological mistreatments by any member of a family can be registered before a judge competent in family affairs with a request that preventive measures be taken under the federal government promulgated law No. 24.417.9 The law is not perfect as there are no apparent sanctions for those who fail to comply with the terms of the court order.10 However, there are victims assistance centres established by the Province of Buenos Aires which deliver programs and services,11 which can be approached for help. The claimants declared only the station close to their father's residence can provide help, however, a judge placed the female claimant under protective custody and issued a restraining order against her father in 1997. I find that the claimants offered evasive and partly incoherent explanations why they did not register a complaint at a court or accessed any other help. I find that there is adequate state protection available for persons who find themselves in the claimants alleged scenario. Their testimony of unavailability of protection reinforces that their claims are not built on the truth.
I recognize that none of the credibility concerns raised herein are sufficient on its own to negate the claim. However, in my opinion, the cumulative effect of all of them is such that I do not have sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence upon which to base a determination that the claimants are Convention refugees12 or persons in need of protection.
Therefore, the Refugee Protection Division rejects the claims of XXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXX for refugee protection.
