XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the claimant, alleges that she is a 27 year-old citizen of Nigeria. She claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of her deceased husband's son and of her own family members by reason of her membership in a particular social group, namely women subject to forced levirate marriage.
Summary of Personal Information Form allegations
The claimant alleges that the death of her father in 1985 resulted in her XXXXX 2000 forced marriage in a traditional ceremony to XXXXX, a much older man, to whom her father had promised her in compensation for a loan. In XXXX 2001, her husband died and his son, XXXX, an influential man, insisted that the claimant marry him since the loan was not re-paid.
Mr. XXXXX insistence that she undergo circumcision, his physical mistreatment of her and threat of death if she did not comply with his wishes and her realization that he had the support of her family led her to flee into hiding in XXXX City. There she found assistance at a church whose pastor reported her difficulties to police. They, however, refused to intervene on the basis that her problems were domestic and cultural matters. The claimant remained in hiding until arrangements were completed for her to leave Nigeria.
Determination
I find the claimant to be a Convention refugee because she has a well-founded fear of persecution in Nigeria on a Convention ground.
Analysis
The issues in this matter which were identified at the outset of the hearing are credibility, personal identity and the objective basis for a well-founded fear of persecution, including state protection and internal flight alternative. In considering this claim, I have borne in mind the Chairperson's guidelines on female refugee claimants.1
Credibility
In my opinion, the claimant was a credible witness. While she was very reserved in answering questions, often giving monosyllabic or short responses, even to questions posed by her own counsel, I find that her manner of testimony may reasonably be explained by an observable natural reticence rather than an attempt to evade or dissemble.
The claimant was able to explain to my satisfaction her possession of certain identity documents that raised both credibility and identity concerns. Documentary evidence2 shows that documents found on the claimant at the port of entry included a Canadian Certificate of Landing, a Canadian social assistance card and a TD Access bankcard.3 The three documents are all in the name of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX.4 I accept, on a balance of probabilities, the claimant's explanation that these documents were furnished by the contact person in Canada of the agent who accompanied her to Canada and upon whose advice she depended in matters relating to her departure from Nigeria, travel to and arrival in this country. I accept that she has no other knowledge of their origin. The claimant carried her own birth certificate5 and identified herself to the examining immigration officer in her own name.6 I accept that the false documents were provided by the agent's Canadian contact and that their sole utilization on the claimant's behalf was as travel documents.
At the port of entry, the claimant was in possession of education documents7 and a birth certificate8 in the name of XXXXXXX. As is indicated below, she provided post-hearing documentary evidence9 of her own graduation from the same university as her brother. I find reasonable her explanation that, in her rush to leave, she inadvertently grabbed the education documents of her twin brother instead of her own.
I find the claimant's evidence regarding treatment by her family and by Mr. XXXXXX to force her levirate marriage to him to be internally consistent. In my view, her evidence is consistent as well with her signed, written statement to the interviewing immigration officer.10 I believe her story that members of her own family and her deceased husband's son were intent on forcing her to submit to a levirate marriage to him, following Edo cultural norms in Ewu, Edo State.
Identity
The identity documents tendered by the claimant at the hearing had certain apparent deficiencies. Her student photo identity card11 was unsigned by the registrar. The date given in the university letter of her graduation12 differs from that given in her Personal Information Form (PIF) as does the name of the university.13 For that reason, the hearing was reserved pending the receipt of further documents that were received post-hearing.14
I find the claimant to be who she says she is. I am satisfied that the claimant is a citizen of Nigeria and an indigene of Edo state, based on a balance of probabilities, having considered her testimony and the documentary support of her certificate of national origin.15 Furthermore, I am satisfied, for the same reasons, that the claimant's tribal affiliation is Edo from the Ewu area16 of that state.
I accept that XXXXXX University, where the claimant began her university studies in 1998, was re-named XXXXXXXX University and that she graduated from that institution in 2001, based on the letter received post-hearing from the university.17
Objective basis for a well-founded fear of persecution
For the following reasons, I find the claimant's fear of persecution to be objectively well-founded.
She described to me scars she bears as a result of Mr. XXXXXXX beatings. Her testimony in that regard is supported by a doctor's letter18 in which he confirms that the scars he observed are consistent with her story of having been beaten.
The documentary evidence is in my view supportive of her evidence of levirate marriage in Nigeria. It shows that marriage in Nigeria is governed by customary law, by Islamic law and statutory law.19 I have accepted that levirate marriage is a traditional Edo practice in the home area of her family and of Mr. XXXXXX, namely Ewu in Edo State. There is no evidence before me of laws proscribing forced or levirate marriage in Edo State. The documentary evidence20 quotes a representative of the Widow's Development Organization who states that she cannot provide information specific to Edo widows as her work is focused in Enugu State. However, she offered the general comment that there are no federal or state laws prohibiting leviration in cultures where forced marriage is practiced. The documentary evidence reports that police and government authorities do not get involved when a woman refuses since they treat it as a family matter.21 I find the documentary evidence22 to be supportive of her claim that even when the assisting church pastor reported the claimant's situation to police in XXXXX City, Edo State, police cited family matters as the reason for refusing assistance to her. I accept that state protection is not available to her in XXXXX City.
Lagos was canvassed as a possible internal flight alternative. While the city's sheer size might make it difficult for the claimant's family or Mr. XXXXXX to find her, the claimant's testimony, which I have found credible, was that she has no friends there to whom she might turn for emotional or financial support. The church, whose members afforded her brief protection in XXXXXXX City and arranged for her departure to Canada, has no branch in Lagos. Moreover, although the claimant has a university degree, she has no work experience. Given the above, internal flight to Lagos is not, in my opinion, a reasonable option open to the claimant.
In light of the evidence before me, I find on a balance of probabilities that the claimant has established an objectively well-founded fear of persecution. I conclude that there is a serious possibility of persecution were she to return to Nigeria.
I find XXXXXXXXXXXXXX to be a Convention refugee because she has a well-founded fear of persecution on a Convention ground.
"S.E. Kitchener"

These are the reasons for the positive decision of the Refugee Protection Division with respect to the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXX (the minor claimant), 16 years and 8 months of age, a citizen of Romania, to be a Convention refugee and a person in need of protection.
The minor claimant arrived in Canada on August 30, 2001 and claimed to be a Convention refugee on September 11, 2001 by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution on the grounds of her membership in a particular social group, namely, abused children.
On June 6, 2002, XXXXXXXXXXXX, the minor claimant's paternal uncle was designated as her designated representative. At the onset of the hearing on August 13, 2002, the panel asked and was duly informed that the minor claimant intended to proceed without counsel. Therefore, the panel explained the Convention definition and the new consolidated grounds and the hearing process in detail. The designated representative decided the minor claimant to give testimony under oath. He also testified.
Identity
At the onset of the hearing, the panel accepted that, on a balance of probabilities, the minor claimant was who she claimed to be and a citizen of Romania based on the copy of her passport1 stamped "certified true copy" by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC). There was no evidence before the panel that the passport was fraudulent or obtained fraudulently. Possession of a national passport creates a prima facie presumption that the holder is a national of the country of issue, unless the passport itself states otherwise,2 which it did not in this case.
Allegations
The minor claimant testified that she feared her father if she were to return to Romania.
The panel finds that a major portion of her evidence was internally and externally inconsistent. She failed to provide reasonable explanations for most of these inconsistencies, creating further inconsistencies. The panel finds that her testimony was exaggerated to boost her claim. Therefore, minimum weight was assigned to her testimony.
The minor claimant alleged that her father, an alcoholic, routinely beat her as well as her mother and her other siblings. She missed school several days per week. Her father chased and threatened them with a knife, and locked them in the house on many occasions. She came to Canada to visit her grandmother.
In support of her allegation, the minor claimant provided a medical certificate.3 The panel assigns no probative value to this document. Firstly, to the naked eye, the date of issue appeared to be altered. The designated representative was unable to provide a reasonable explanation as to why this was done. He stated he was surprised and had not realised it.
Secondly, the minor claimant was unable to provide a reasonable explanation regarding the omission from her narrative of the incident mentioned in the medical certificate. Although she explained that she had mentioned it in the Romanian version4 of her narrative, the Romanian version, which was reviewed at the hearing by the interpreter, did not mention it and the visit to the doctor.
Furthermore, the panel gives no probative value to the certificate from the Ministry of the Interior, dated XXXX, 2002. This is written on a ripped piece of paper with no letterhead. The panel finds that the content of the letter is not logical. It states that the minor claimant "has filed several complaints with this police department against her parents, regarding domestic violence." It is not reasonable to expect the Romanian police to have registered several complaints by a minor in the absence of an adult. Additionally, it is not reasonable to accept the minor claimant to have filed a report against her mother when her testimony revealed that on many occasions she tried to protect her mother from her father's abuse.
The panel gives no probative value to the letter from Romania District of XXXXXX, dated XXXXX, 2002, written on a paper without a letterhead which is normally associated with official letters, and an address, after the minor claimant's arrival and sent by her mother. The content of the letter appears to be self-serving indicating that "there are no placement centres or shelters for children and minors victims of domestic abuse, violence or mistreatment."5
The panel finds these documents to be self-serving, created for the purpose of the hearing.
The designated representative's demeanour during his testimony displayed a genuine concern about the minor claimant. He stated that he was aware that his brother abused his wife, however, he did not know and was surprised to hear after his niece came to Canada that his brother beat her as well. He called his sister-in-law and she confirmed the beatings.
The panel finds persuasive the designated representative's belief that his niece was a victim of domestic violence and child abuse. Accordingly, benefit of doubt is given to the designated representative's evidence whose statements were coherent and plausible. The panel finds that, on a balance of probabilities, the minor claimant was a victim of child abuse.
Analysis
Notwithstanding whether the minor claimant's past experiences amount to persecution, as Pratte J., stated in Mileva:6
... the question raised by a claim to refugee status is not whether the minor claimants had reason to fear persecution in the past, but rather whether he at the time his claim is being decided, has good grounds to fear persecution in the future.
To assess whether the minor claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution so as to satisfy the definition of Convention refugee, it is necessary to examine the subjective fear and its objective basis. Mr. Justice Heald, in Rajudeen states:7
This court, as well as the Supreme Court of Canada, has made references to the subjective and objective components necessary to satisfy the definition of Convention refugee. The subjective component relates to the existence of fear of persecution in the mind of the refugee. The objective component requires that the refugee's fear be evaluated objectively to determine if there is a valid basis for that fear.
In evaluating the forward-looking aspect of the minor claimant's subjective fear and the objective evidence, the minor claimant stated that if she were to return to Romania, she feared violence by her father.
The independent, international and NGO documentary sources8 indicates that Romania is a constitutional democracy with a multiparty. The Government generally respected the rights of its citizens; however, serious problems remained. Child labour was a problem and trafficking in women and girls for the purposes of forced prostitution was another problem.
Additionally, the documentary evidence9 indicates:
...the Government administers health care and public education. There are no perceptible societal patterns of abuse against children. Nevertheless, large number of impoverished and apparently homeless, but not necessary orphaned, children can be seen on the street of the larger cities.
In line with the European Commission to establish a single authority that would be responsible for setting appropriate standards for all childcare institutions, the National Agency for the Protection of Children's Rights was established in July 2000. It is directly subordinated to the Prime Ministers and is responsible for the elaboration, co-ordination and monitoring of reform policies. The Agency is in charge of ensuring that agreed standards and levels of care for several childcare services have been established and agreed by the order of the President of the Agency.
According to documentary evidence10 , in Romania domestic violence is on the increase and there is no organised state-run network for victims of domestic violence. Children are the most affected by domestic violence. A joint study by the world Health Organisation (WHO), UNICEF and the World Bank found that almost half of the 1,556 families surveyed beat their children and 38 percent humiliated or verbally abused them. According to the study, almost one in 10 Romanian children have been sexually abused and about half of the country's 5.1 million children suffer from severe neglect. According to Ioana Popescu, psychologist, many children are prevented from going to school and forced to work, take care of siblings or beg.
According to the same documentary evidence, faced with the rise in domestic violence, local authorities are trying to cope with the situation. The newly appointed Minister of Justice, Rodica Stanoiu, the first woman in such a position, said,
... domestic violence should be treated as a separate offence under the criminal code, now subject to changes under a reform package of the justice system. However, Romania has yet to align its legislation to Western standards in its bid to join the European Union.11
Having considered all the objective evidence, while the panel is mindful and does not minimise all the positive steps taken by the Romanian government to improve the situation of the children in Romania, it is not persuaded, that at the time of the hearing, the recent government's actions in this respect amount to "serious efforts" to protect the victims of domestic and child abuse.
DECISION
In view of the foregoing, given that the definition is forward-looking, the panel finds that in the circumstances of this case, the age and the sex of the minor claimant, there is sufficient "objective basis" to support the minor claimant's "subjective fear" and there is more than a mere possibility12 that she would face persecution if she were to return to Romania.
For these reasons, the Refugee Protection Division determines that the minor claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, is a Convention refugee. The panel accepts her claim for refugee protection.

In order to be determined to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimant would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that their removal to their country of nationality would subject them personally either (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
These are the reasons with respect to the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX a 49-years-old citizen of Argentina. He is claiming the need for protection as he has a well-founded fear of persecution because of his perceived political opinion, which gives his claim a nexus to a Convention ground.
Counsel's post-hearing submissions dated October 21, 2002 and October 29, 2002, have been taken into consideration before rendering a decision in this claim.
The claimant testified that he rented a room in his house to a Mr. XXXXXXX, a prominent member of the Radical Party, who used it for occasional political meetings. The claimant stated that, because of this arrangement, he was persecuted by supporters of the Peronist Party and had to flee his country.
Analysis:
Identity:
The copies of the claimant's identity documents are included in Exhibit M-1 and therefore I accepted his identity as a citizen of Argentina.
CREDIBILITY
Caselaw shows that a panel may reject testimony which is uncontradicted if that evidence does not accord with the probabilities affecting the case as a whole. In this respect, the British Columbia Court of Appeal stated in Faryna v. Chorny that.
In short, the real test of the truth of the story of a witness in such a case must be its harmony with the preponderance of the probabilities which a practical and informed person would readily recognize as reasonable in that place and in those conditions.1
The Federal Court of Appeal, also has pointed out in Orelien that.
[O]ne cannot be satisfied that the evidence is credible or trustworthy, unless satisfied that it is probably so, not just possibly so.2
I find that the above applies to this claim. Before making a credibility assessment in this case I have taken the following into account: the claimant's age (49-years-old); his educational background (he has 7 years of primary school education); communication through an interpreter; and cultural differences. However, for the following reasons, I find that the brevity of the Personal Information Form (PIF) narrative, combined with the lack of documentation, which could have been reasonably forthcoming, and signs of tailoring the evidence, taint the credibility of this claim. I find that the posthearing disclosure, dated October 29, 2002, of handwritten letters and typed notes, is an attempt to bolster this claim for protection.
The PIF Narrative:3
Caselaw establishes that all relevant details should be provided in the written Personal Information Form4 (PIF) narrative which was not done here. The gist of the claimant's explanation indicated that he wanted to provide further details in his oral testimony and then added significant evidence such as the events of August and November 2001. As the claimant was given an opportunity to amend his PIF at the beginning of the hearing before swearing to its accuracy, I find the oral additions not persuasive or trustworthy. The claimant was represented by experienced and competent counsel, and he should have let counsel know well in advance of the hearing that amendments or even additions to his PIF were necessary, which I gladly would have accepted, but nothing was forthcoming.
Documentation:
I took into account rule 7 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules and the Commentary to that rule, when coming to the following findings. The claimant bases his fear of persecution on a relationship with a Mr. XXXXXXXX. After perusing the documentary evidence submitted in this claim, I find that there is insufficient evidence before me to conclude that a Mr. XXXXX exists. The claimant submitted a handwritten note from a XXXXXXXX, which was included within a letter from his family, in support of the existence of such a person. I find that this note cannot be used as an indication that this claim is built on the truth. The note and the accompanying correspondence could be written by anybody, including the claimant. It is also noted that the name of Mr. XXXXX is spelled differently in the signature of the note and in the narrative. As the claimant stated that Mr. XXXXX was a prominent and well known elected government official who was in charge of XXXXX, either as the XXXXX or XXXX, I find there is no reason why the claimant would not have submitted either newspaper articles or party publications where Mr. XXXXXX name was mentioned. Mr. XXXX allegedly offered his support and friendship in the note, dated June 14, 2002.5 As support and friendship was available, why not have his family members approach him and ask for a statement on either party or government letterhead, which could have been verified by the Research Directorate of the Immigration and Refugee Board (DIRB). However, nothing was forthcoming, even though the claimant used the additional time after the hearing to submit documentation, including handwritten letters from his family and typed cryptic threats, which are undated and unsigned. I find this late disclosure not persuasive or trustworthy, as stated earlier in this reason, they could have been written by anybody. The letters were supposedly written long before the hearing (the handwritten letters are dated February 26, March 28, May 20 and June 14, 2002).6 The claimant provided insufficient testimony at the hearing of the existence of these letters and the written threats. If this material was available before the hearing, why not state it, as he did regarding the existence of the deed for his house.
The Hospital Stay:
The claimant was asked about his hospital visits. Orally he first stated that he did not go to the hospital, only his wife went. Then, after it was brought to his attention that the port-of-entry notes contained his statement of four or five visits,7 he shifted his testimony and declared that he went together with his wife, but her injuries were more severe than his. Later on, in redirect, he repeated the port-of-entry statement of four or five visits. He explained that he did not understand the question. I find that the claimant's many versions of his replies indicate that he was not truthful, and not, that he did not understand the question.
I recognize that none of the credibility concerns raised herein is sufficient on its own to negate the claim. However, in my opinion, the cumulative effect of all of them is such that I do not have sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence upon which to base a determination that the claimant is a Convention refugee8 or a person in need of protection.
Having considered the totality of the evidence, the relevant statutory provisions and jurisprudence, the Refugee Protection Division rejects the claim for protection. Therefore, XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is determined not to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the claims of 41-year-old XXXXXXXXXXXXX, the principal claimant, his 37-year-old spouse XXXXXXXXXXXXX, and their three children, 18-year-old XXXXXXXXXX, 17-year-old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and 9-year-old XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. The principal claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXX was appointed the designated representative for the two minor claimants, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. All of the claimants are citizens of Guyana. The claimant's base their claims for refugee protection on the grounds of risk to life because of increased criminality and violence in Guyana.
The evidence consisted of the oral testimony of the principal claimant and his spouse, their Personal Information Forms1 (PIFs), and documents submitted by the claimants,2 by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC),3 and by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO).4 Observations from the RPO were also considered. The claimants were not represented by counsel.
The issue before the RPD is whether, based on the evidence adduced at the hearing, the claimants are Convention refugees or persons in need of protection, as defined in sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IPRA). In order for the claimants to be determined Convention refugees or persons in need of protection, the evidence must establish that the claimants would face a serious possibility of persecution for a Convention ground or must establish that their removal to their country of nationality would subject them personally either (a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or (b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
A number of issues were identified at the beginning of the hearing. These included: 1) identity, 2) nexus, 3) delay, 4) re-availment, 5) agents of persecution, 6) state protection, 7) the consolidated grounds, and 8) credibility concerns arising from the claimants' evidence. While all the issues were canvassed, the panel finds that the determinative issue in these claims was state protection.
For the reasons provided below, the panel finds that the claimants did not discharge the burden of proof for establishing that they are Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.
TESTIMONY AND ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimants presented their passports issued by the government of Guyana. There were no birth certificates for the children or marriage certificate for the parents. Nevertheless the panel accepts that they are who they claim to be and that they are citizens of Guyana.
Credibility
There were no credibility concerns arising from any of the claimants' testimony. The oral testimony was consistent with the PIF. The questions were answered in a spontaneous manner. The panel noted the emotional distress expressed by the principal claimant as he recalled an incident in his youth when his father was attacked by Afro-Guyanese.
NEXUS
Based on the PIF narrative as well as the oral testimony of the principal claimant and his spouse, the panel finds that the claimants fear criminal activity in Guyana. The principal claimant recounted multiple experiences of random robberies and threats to his life because he is seen as a successful businessman. Additionally, there was continued harassment and threats directed at him and members of his family by a neighbour, XXXXXXXXX. The panel finds that the evidence failed to establish that there is a link between the basis for the claimants' fear and a Convention ground. Accordingly, the panel finds that there is not a nexus.
Re-availment
The principal claimant made two trips alone to Canada on holidays in 2000 and 2001 respectively. He spent time in the Toronto/Mississauga area. Then he returned to Guyana although he claimed that he had been experiencing problems since the early 1990s. The panel does not find it reasonable that some one who feared for his life and that of his family, would leave his family in Guyana while he came to Toronto to look around for two weeks on two occasions. The panel finds that the re-availment undermines the principal claimant's subjective fear of persecution in Guyana.
Delay
The claimants arrived in Canada on December 23, 2001 but did not file a claim for protection until two months later, in February 2002. The explanation given for the delay was that the principal claimant did not know what to do and so relied on a friend to help him. When CIC was eventually contacted, the principal claimant was advised by mail that as of January 15, 2002, CIC no longer mailed out the forms to refugee claimants. Given that the claimant had been in Canada in August 2001 and had spent time in the Toronto area looking around, it is not reasonable to believe that if he were really fearing persecution that he could not have used some of the time to find out what steps he needed to take in order to obtain protection in Canada. By his own testimony, the principal claimant is someone who had taken initiative in Guyana to leave farming when he encountered problems and move to another place and start a business. He and his family had obtained multiple Canada Visitor Visas (CVV). According to the principal claimant, he closed his business in XXXXX 2001 and came with his family to Canada with the intention of staying. That being the case, the panel does not accept the claimant's explanation for the two-month delay in filing a claim as being reasonable for someone with a well-founded fear of persecution.
Agents of persecution/state protection
The principal claimant testified that he fears Afro-Guyanese who have stolen his farm produce, robbed his grocery store, held him up at gun-point and threatened him and his family with death. His family fears the harassment and threats levelled at them by their neighbour, XXXXXXXXX. The principal claimant stated that he went to the police about forty times to report various incidents and that the police responded on about ten of those times. He could not identify the persons who robbed the store, robbed him in person or held him up at gun-point. However, when he reported the problems with his neighbour, the police came and investigated. Following one of these investigations, XXXXXX was arrested and there was a court hearing. The Magistrate released XXXXX with a warning for him to desist from his threatening and harassing behaviour. Nevertheless, the behaviour continued and on a number of occasions when the claimant or his spouse called or went to get the police, XXXXXXXXX would hide or run away so that he could not be found when the police arrived.
The documentary evidence5 states the following:
in Guyana there is a serious problem with violent crime which has been steadily increasing in both numbers and violence. The increase in violent crime is attributed mostly to illegal drugs and persons seeking to finance their consumption. Most of the victims are Indo-Guyanese. The disproportionate victimization of Indo-Guyanese is attributed to their proportionally greater affluence, since they are the major component of the business and trading "class" and many are relatively prosperous farmers.
The police response to violent crimes has been inadequate; rather than an ethnic or political motivation for this incapacity to cope it is widely perceived that the police force does not have the necessary manpower, training and salaries to ensure an effective action against the increasing crime.
However, as per Villafranca,6
a guarantee of protection for all citizens at all times is not to be expected. Nor is protection perfect. Where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens, the mere fact that it is not always successful will not justify a claim that the state is not providing protection.
On a number of occasions, when the claimants were able to identify the individual who was harassing and threatening them, the police responded, investigated and arrested the individual in question. In other instances, the principal claimant was the victim of random robberies, attacks and threats and he could not identify the persons who perpetrated the crimes. Furthermore, sometimes he would be warned by the criminals not to report the crime to the police or else his family would suffer. In these instances, the principal claimant testified that he was scared and so did not report these particular incidents to the police. The principal claimant took other steps to obtain protection. He testified that he went to see a Mr. XXXXXXX, who was an Assistant XXXXXXXX at the Police Headquarters, in order to report his problems and seek greater protection. This was not forthcoming because Mr. XXXX told him that neither transportation nor police were available. Considering the claimants' actions and police response in the light of current social conditions in Guyana, the panel finds that state protection is available.
Consolidated grounds
The panel finds that the claimants face a generalized risk arising from increased criminal activity in Guyana. That risk is one of random criminality which falls outside of a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual punishment by virtue of s.97 (1) (b) (ii), as it is one faced generally by others in that country. In the instance where it seems that the claimants have been personally targeted by their neighbour, state protection is available. Accordingly, the panel finds that the claimants do not face a reasonable chance or a serious possibility of a risk to their life or of a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
No evidence was presented that would lead the panel to find that the claimants would be subjected personally to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of the Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture.
Determination
The minor claimants and older daughter relied on the testimony of their parents. Because the parents' claim failed, so do the claims of their children.
For all the above reasons, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are not Convention refugees nor are they persons in need of protection.
"Kamala-Jean Gopie"

APPLICATION TO RE-OPEN
These are my reasons for decision on an application to reopen the claim of XXXXX XXXXXXXX (the "claimant") to be a Convention refugee.
The claimant's claim was declared Abandoned on June 24, 2002 by Notice of Decision dated September 18, 2002 (the "decision"). By Notice of Motion dated October 15, 2002 (the "application"), the claimant applied to have his claim re-opened. The grounds and facts upon which the application is based are set out in the application, an affidavit of the claimant dated October 15, 2002, and written submissions of counsel dated October 15, 2002. For the purpose of these reasons, I do not repeat the contents of all of that here. However, I have considered all of it and all of the rest of the evidence on the claimant's file before me.
For the following reasons, I am not persuaded that the claimant's claim should be reopened. The highest relevant legal authority before me, Longia1 suggests that all decisions of the CRDD (now the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)) are final. The power to reopen a claim hinges solely on whether a claimant has been denied natural justice.2
For the following reasons, I am not persuaded that the claimant has been denied natural justice in the abandonment proceedings under review. The claimant admits that he received prior personal notice of the abandonment ("show cause") hearing scheduled for June 24, 2002. Furthermore, that notice specifically warned the claimant as follows:
You failed to provide the Immigration and Refugee Board with your completed Personal Information Form within 28 days after the date on which you were served with the Personal Information Form.
. . . a hearing into your failure to provide your completed Personal Information Form within the period provided for the filing of your PIF will take place on June 24, 2002 . . .
If you fail to appear at that time and place to explain why your claim should not be declared abandoned, the Refugee Division may declare your claim to have been abandoned.
It is true that the claimant did file the Personal Information Form (PIF) by the time of the show cause hearing, doing so five days before, on June 19, 2002. However, this was over two months after the PIF was due, a lengthy delay that would certainly call for explanation, even more so given the fact that the narrative turned out to consist of less than 100 words. Moreover, the claimant had been clearly notified that the issue at the show cause hearing was going to be the reason as to why the PIF was late and that the claimant himself had a personal obligation to appear to provide the explanation. The claimant's language is English and he does not require an interpreter. Thus it cannot be said that the claimant was without any fault in choosing not to attend the proceedings.
The claimant as much as admits this in his application material, but blames his failure to attend on bad advice he received from his previous counsel. However, as claimants are responsible for proving their claims and retaining counsel of choice to that end, claimants bear all loss caused by counsel error, except when counsel's negligence is so gross and obvious that it has shaded over a very high threshold into that rarely seen black territory known as incompetent counsel denial of natural justice. Clearly, that is not this situation: counsel incompetence is neither explicitly alleged nor clearly proven by the claimant in the application,3 and there is nothing before me to suggest that the claimant has sued previous counsel, or intends to. Finally, if the RPD were to accept these excuses in these circumstances, it would lose control of its own process. Claimants must never be led to believe their counsel may excuse them from their obligation to attend hearing dates.
Any allegation that the claimant may have a well-founded claim is irrelevant to this motion. The issue here is not whether the claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution. The issue is whether the claimant has been denied natural justice. For all of the previously stated reasons, I am not persuaded that this claimant has been.
For all these reasons, the claimant's application to reopen his claim is dismissed.
"Joel A. Bousfield"

XXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are citizens of Costa Rica and are married to each other. They claim to have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of membership in a particular social group. In addition, they claim to be persons in need of protection as persons in danger of being tortured or at risk of losing their lives or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Costa Rica.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimants allege the following.
One evening, around 7 o'clock, XXXXXX heard a knock on the door. She opened the door slightly to find a "normal looking man" standing outside. He wanted some information on properties for sale in the area. Since the development was a new one and since the main office had closed, XXXXXX was willing to give the information. She opened the door. No sooner had she done this than the man rushed in. He produced a gun and told her to go to the washroom. Once there, he pushed her inside. Then he robbed the house, along with an accomplice.
Following the robbery, XXXXXX went to the OIJ (Organismo de Invetigacion Judicial), a special investigation unit, to file a report along with her husband XXXXX. They gave the police the serial numbers of some of the electronic alliances that had been stolen. XXXXXX also identified her attacker from the scores of photographs she was shown.
A year passed. Then a letter arrived for the claimants to show up at the Penal Court. There they were informed that the police had been unable to find the thieves. They were asked if they would agree to close the case. They agreed to do so. However, a few days later they were informed that the Penal Court judge had decided that since a weapon was involved in the robbery, the case would not be closed.
Around November 2001, XXXXXX began receiving threatening calls at work. The caller asked that the robbery charge be withdrawn, otherwise the claimant would be killed. XXXXXX received six or seven calls in the next few months. XXXXX received three or four calls during the same period. He was urged to get his wife to withdraw her complaint to the police.
One day in December 2001, as the two claimants were walking down a street, a car sped down the street towards them. They were able to jump out of the car's path but barely.
In January 2002, three men wearing masks came up to XXXXXX as she was opening the front door. They forced her inside the house. One of the men whom she recognized to be her original assailant in spite of his mask told her to withdraw the robbery charges. She told him she had tried to, but the police had not co-operated. He began molesting her. She does not know what this might have led to but for the chance return of her next-door neighbors. She began screaming and the three men ran away.
The two claimants then moved to XXXXXX mothers home where they stayed for a few weeks before leaving for Canada.
ANALYSIS
Counsel made it very clear that they were not seeking recognition as Convention refugees.1 They were, however, asking to be accepted as persons in need of protection. This is what the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act states about persons in need of protection:2
97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
(a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themselves of the protection of that country.
(ii) The risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) The risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) The risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care.
The provision with respect to torture, as laid out in Section 97 (1) (a) does not apply. No state agent is involved directly or indirectly in the alleged harm, as required by Article 1 of the Convention against Torture.3
With respect to Section 97 (1)(b) I agree with counsel that the claimants' fear is not of criminals in general but of one criminal in particular. I do not, however, agree with her contention that state protection was not available to the claimants.
Following Ward,4 a presumption of adequate state protection exists in every claim unless there is "clear and convincing evidence to the contrary." In my view, the claimants have not presented such evidence. The evidence I have before me states rather that "the law and judiciary provide effective means of dealing with individual instances of abuse."5
With respect to a claimant's obligation to go to the state for protection, the Federal Court of Appeal has held in Kadenko6 that
When the state in question is a democratic state...the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the sources of action open to him or her.
The claimants fell far short of what was required of them in terms of seeking protection, considering that Costa Rica is a long-established democracy.7 The claimants went to the police once, when they were robbed. They did not go to police when more serious incidents occurred i.e. when the threatening calls were made or when the speeding car nearly killed them or when the female claimant was assaulted. It is simply not enough for them to say that everyone in Costa Rica knows that the police cannot do anything. If they went to the police for a robbery, they ought to have gone to the police for serious matters. Their neglect in doing so cannot be used to condemn the police.
DETERMINATION
Accordingly, I reject the claims of XXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX for refugee protection.
"Harindar Aulach"

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX alleges he is a citizen of Afghanistan. He alleges he fears persecution because of his political opinion and his membership in a particular social group - the Hazara ethnic group.1
The Federal Court of Appeal states in the Maldonado2 decision that when a claimant swears to the truthfulness of his or her evidence, a presumption exists that that evidence is true unless there is a good reason to conclude otherwise.
The Federal Court of Appeal has given further direction to the CRDD (now RPD) in Rajaratnam3 in which its states:
A refugee claimant is not, therefore, absolved of the duty of telling the truth. The tribunal hearing his evidence is entitled to disbelieve him and to base its decision on that assessment, but is required to give reasons for a finding of lack of credibility in 'clear and unmistakable terms.'
In the decision of Shahamati,4 the Federal Court of Appeal states:
Contrary to what has sometimes been said the Board is entitled, in assessing credibility, to rely on such criteria as rationality and common sense.
The claimant admitted during his hearing that he gave false evidence to the panel. There were documents filed by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration that were in conflict with his story. After close analysis of the testimony and documentation filed, it is my conclusion that there are serious reasons for doubting the claimant's credibility in material areas.
The claimant alleges in his Personal Information Form (PIF)5 that he was born in , Afghanistan on XXXXX 1970. He is well schooled, with 15 years of education, including what he describes as a "B.Sc." He is unmarried. His mother, father three sisters and four brothers were all residents of XXXXX, but with the exception of one sister who lives in Iran, he alleges current whereabouts are unknown. He alleges he has worked as a XXXXX since leaving school.
According to his PIF, from XXXX 1998 until XXXX 2000 he lived in Islamabad, Pakistan. However, he had no status in Pakistan during that period. He alleges he left Pakistan in XXXX 2000 and arrived in Canada two days later. He made a claim to refugee status immediately upon arrival in Canada. The identity documents he had when he fled Afghanistan were an international driver's licence6 and an Afghani identity card.7 Originals of the documents were provided to the panel.
The basis for his claim as alleged in his PIF is as follows. The claimant's father, a businessman, had always been active in the Hazara and Shia community. He also gave his financial support to the Islamic Unity Party, a party supported by the Hazara. Both the claimant and his father attended meetings for the party held in their mosque. The claimant's cousin and friend, XXXXXX, was also active in the Islamic Unity Party.
Several Response to Information Requests filed at the hearing confirm that Hazara speak a type of Persian or Farsi, and are adherents of Shia branch of Islam. The documents also confirm that the Islamic Unity Party is a Hazara political organisation.
At his hearing the claimant added that he too donated money to the Islamic Unity Party but had not been as active as his father. When he was asked why he did not mention this information in his PIF, he stated he had written things down as well as he could remember. One of the exhibits includes the claimant's hand written statement in Farsi8 which when translated into English became the narrative statement in his PIF (question 37). Donations to the party are not mentioned in that statement.
In his PIF the claimant states that in XXXXX 1998, the Taliban attacked and beat the claimant in the XXXXX shop where he worked. He was beaten so badly it took him four days before he could return to work. When they beat him they told him that he should stop his activity in the Islamic Unity Party or he would be jailed or killed. A short time later the Taliban came to the claimant's home, demanding to see him. Since he was not home, they beat the claimant's father and took him away. The claimant's father has not been heard from since.
When the claimant came home that particular evening, his mother told him "...that Taliban took my father and they beat them up and forced her to reveal the whereabouts of her son."9 The claimant alleges he was shocked by the turn of events and immediately decided to flee to Pakistan. He did not stay in Kabul to look for his father or assist his family. There was no indication what impact his father's disappearance had on the rest of his family. The claimant alleged that his attempts to contact his family from Canada had been unsuccessful.
In his PIF he states that for his entire time in Pakistan he was in Islamabad.10 In his hearing he stated that he was moved first to Peshawar, where he stayed for 18 months, and then went to Islamabad. At his hearing he stated that the reference to two years in Islamabad was an error.
At his hearing the claimant confirmed that he worked for XXXXXX. He filed a letter from that firm to confirm his employment from August 1998 until February 2000.11 The letter contains some odd phrasing, in that it states he was employed as "a product Incharge."
According to his PIF, the claimant's cousin XXXXXX also fled to Pakistan where he continued to work against the Taliban. At his hearing, he stated that XXXXXX had left Afghanistan one month before he did.
He states in his PIF that in February 2000 he found out that XXXXXX was killed by the Taliban in Pakistan. The claimant decided the country was not safe for him and he eventually fled. He stated at the hearing that he went from Peshawar to Islamabad, where he made arrangements to leave Pakistan. He added that he paid a smuggler $10,000 to get him out of Pakistan. He did not care where he went. It was the agent's choice to send him to Canada.
The claimant alleged at the hearing that he was given a false passport to travel to Canada. He did not know the country of issue. He did not know what airline he used for his travels. He did not know what countries he passed through. He did not know if any of the people he saw at one transit stop were Chinese.
He did remember that before he left Pakistan the agent told him needed a large number of pictures. Two distinct photographs were taken. It was unclear at the hearing how many copies of the two pictures were produced, either 16 or 24. He did not know what the need was for so many pictures. He alleges he kept eight copies of one of the pictures for himself.
The claimant alleged that the smuggling agent went with him through the baggage check-in at the Islamabad airport. No one questioned the claimant or the agent. The claimant alleged that he had no idea which airplane to go on. He was simply told "Just follow the people. Wherever they go, you go with them."12
The following exchange took place between the presiding member and the claimant.13
Q. So you had no idea what plane you got on?
A. No.
Q. And you had no idea where it was going.
A. No.
The claimant alleged that his only interest was to get out of Pakistan. When asked how he knew the plane was not simply going to another city in Pakistan, he replied that he did not know as he had never flown before.
He then alleged that he never looked inside the "blue" passport at any time during his travels to Canada. The claimant alleged he got of the airplane after a six and 1/2 hour flight and entered an unidentified country. No one asked said anything to him beside "welcome." He was then asked what he would have answered had someone asked him his name. He replied:14
I don't know what I would have done. I mean the smuggling agent only gave me the passport at the time when I boarded the plane.
When asked why he did not simply open the passport and read the name in it he replied that he had panicked.
The claimant then said the plane landed in Dubai. He alleged in his evidence that no one asked him any questions when he entered the country. By apparent coincidence or chance he ran into a number of associates of the smuggler. The first told the claimant to go to sleep, and not be concerned with where he was. When the claimant woke up, this person told him that he was in Dubai. Next the claimant went outside the airport and met up with another person who was an associate of the smuggler. This person took him to a room for the night. Next morning he boarded a plane without speaking to anyone, and flew to an unknown city, carried on to another city, changed planes, and travelled on to Canada.
The panel stated at the hearing that the claimant was an incredibly lucky person, and was able to do something almost no one else is able to do. He was able to travel half way around the world, never be asked a question and not know who he was or where he was from.
At this point in the hearing a short mid-hearing conference was held. After conferring with his counsel, the claimant continued to give his evidence. He told the panel that he had been lying about how he travelled from Pakistan to Canada. He alleged he did so on the instructions of the smuggling agent. The agent told him that if he told the truth about his travels the agent would be found out by the police. The agent allegedly told him not to 'rat out.' Nowhere in the evidence does it appear the agent threatened the claimant with harm.
The claimant alleged the true story was that he left Pakistan using a Moroccan passport with a tourist visa for Dubai. In Dubai, he met a representative of the smuggling agent who took the Moroccan passport and gave him a different passport. The agent told him the new passport had a 'genuine visa' and that no one was going to bother him. The replacement was, according to the claimant, a photo-substitute Afghani passport under the name XXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
Prior to the hearing, the claimant was asked to consent to enquiries being made about him in the United Arab Emirates under three different names, including the name XXXX XXXXX XXXXXX. Counsel for the claimant advised the Board that the claimant would not consent to such a search under aliases. The letter from previous counsel states "My client categorically denies that he used any of the names mentioned."15 This refusal to allow a search under the assumed name may have been an attempt on his part to follow his agent's directions. However, it may also have been an attempt to hide the claimant's activities in the UAE.
The claimant went on to state at his hearing that the agent told him to board a plane for Bahrain. He was told there would be a half hour stop-over after which the plane would go on to Hong Kong. When he arrived in Hong Kong he states he was questioned about his identity, but was allowed to continue on to Canada. He allegedly destroyed the Afghani passport on the plane on the instructions of the agent shortly before it arrived in Vancouver.
DOCUMENTS
Two identity documents were presented by the claimant. One is an international driver's licence.16 According to the claimant it was issued in 1996 in Kabul by the Taliban regime after it took over the government earlier that year.
He was asked why he obtained the international driver's licence. He stated that because of the danger and the restrictions on travel for Hazara, he thought it might come in handy somewhere. He alleged that when he applied for it, he had to turn in his internal Afghani licence. The claimant also stated that in Afghanistan people use an internal driver's licence.
When it was pointed out to the claimant that the English portions of the document are full of spelling errors, he replied that when the Taliban took over the government, they fired all the civil servants and would not accept anything from the past. He was asked why the licence makes no reference to the word 'Islam' in its title, he replied that the Taliban can do whatever they want because they are illiterate.
The claimant did not provide a plausible explanation for surrendering his domestic driver's licence if he continued on in Afghanistan from 1996 until 1998. It is of note that the document, allegedly issued by the Taliban government, states that it is issued by the "Republic of Afghanistan." In my view, the document can be given little weight due to its highly suspect contents and the fact that it was allegedly issued by the Taliban but makes no reference to their Islamic republic.
Another document presented by the claimant is an identity booklet.17 The claimant stated he obtained it so that he would have ready proof of his age and carried it with him while he lived in Afghanistan. The issue date is 1985.
It is difficult to reconcile his use of this document with his earlier statement that pre-Taliban documents were not recognized. In any event, this document notes in a line entitled "Nationality" that he is a Hazara. The first page of Response to Information Request AFG27852.E18 sets out the various documents issued by the Afghanistan from April 1973 to 1992. The claimant's document complies with the sample for the 1978 to 1987 period. What is noticeable about the document is that is shows almost no signs of wear, despite it being approximately 17-years-old and a document the claimant says he regularly carried with him.
Another document filed by the claimant is a letter from the TAA Afghani Association XXXXXX XXXXXX dated 14 March 2001. It states that the claimant is indeed an Afghan national. This conclusion was reached after members of the organisation interviewed the claimant, among other things verifying his language and accent to be consistent with being an Afghani national. The authenticity of the associations letter of endorsement was verified with that organisation, as well as the methods by which it conducts its identification interviews.19 I accept the materials from the Afghani Association XXXXXXXXXX as having probative value. I find that the claimant is an Afghani national.
Another letter20 indicates that the claimant is a member of the XXXXXXXXXXX, and has attended prayer and religious meetings since September of 2000.
The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration participated in the hearing to the limited extent of filing documents. One package of documents consisted of materials prepared by an Immigration Examining Officer, Denise Kilpatrick.
Ms. Kilpatrick begins her Declaration by stating that she examined the claimant on 22 August 2000, the date he arrived in Canada. She goes on to state that through subsequent contact with overseas visa offices, new information came to light "demonstrating that XXXXXX has multiple aliases and current immigration proceedings in process."
The information she received indicated that the claimant had been living in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) since 1997, not Pakistan, as he had told her. This was established, according to her, by his application for a Canadian visitor visa issued on XXXXX 2000 from the Canadian Embassy in the UAE. The Declaration contains a photocopy of his application and several photographs attached to it. Although one of the three photocopies of the photographs in the attachment to the Declaration is of poor quality, two are clearly pictures of the claimant. The application is under the name XXXXXXXXXX, the alias the claimant first categorically denied using and then later admitted to using for his travel from Du Bai in the UAE to Canada. The form states that he was born in XXXX on XXXXX1971. It also notes his passport number is XXXXX, and that he is the owner/manager of a XXXXX factory. It states he had been in the UAE from March of 1997.
The records kept of his contact with the Canadian Embassy in Abu Dhabi are of note. The entry for "SCC 20-Jun-2000" is as follows:
Afghani national. Businerss (sic) owner. 3yrs in UAE. Going to explore and assess Canadian market for future business.
Applicant was refused a CVV from here last year (XXXXXX). Did not admit to this in application. Conflicting info as stated that he has been in UAE since 1997 while in previous application stated period as 7 yrs.
Questionable intentions. No credibility.
Do not recommend approval.
The entry for "XXXXXX 2000" is as follows:
Has applied for immig visa thru Damascus in XXXXX. Yet to be screened. To go to CDA Prob due to EN2 Appln for exploratory trip/attend seminar. Seems to have good business. Wonder if alone in business or with parents/siblings. Lack of admission to prev refusal in '99 and inconsistent info certainly raises concerns. Pending interview with JWM. Will have to be called as send info by courier. To NMA to advise. Then to ALF for Narvit 5 working day waiting period. [Emphasis added]
The entry for "XXXXXXX-2000" is as follows:
Says 3 yrs in UAE. Claims said 7 yrs prev because he had included time in Iran. Says took XXXXX degree from '90-'94 in XXXXX Univ and then worked 2 years in trading company in Tehran. Says all of his family (parents and 8 siblings) reside in Afgan. Says is only owner of business here. Says average income from bus is 20 K AED per month. Claims going to CDA for 7-10 days to investigate possib. Of starting business. Subj speaks English fairly well. Says he was refused CVV last yr. Claims made mistake about quest re being refused CVV.
Have decided to give BOD and issue CVV as seems to be legit businessman who is trying to immigrate by normal channels. Has decent savings. No adverse info recd from Narvit.
The notes from the CVV application go on to note that a visa was issued on XXXXX 2000.
I understand these interview notes to indicate that 'JWM' met the person applying for the visa at the Canadian Embassy on XXXXX 2000. The claimant's pictures would have been on the file. There is no suggestion in the notes that the photographs were of a different person. Some of the other details of the claimant's background recorded by 'JWM' fit with what the claimant has said. There are eight siblings in the family. The claimant and the person in the application both have XXXXX degrees. However, the claimant says in his PIF that he got his degree in Kabul while the CVV applicant stated he got his degree in Tehran.
A second document attached to Ms. Kilpatrick's Declaration is an application for permanent residence submitted to the Canadian Embassy in Damascus. The document was received by the Embassy on XXXXX 2000. It repeats some of the information in the Abu Dhabi CVV application. It was submitted under the name XXXXXXX. The claimant's picture appears in a partial copy of an Afghani passport included with the application. The passport21 indicates it was issued on XXXXXX 1997. It gives the claimant's date of birth as XXXX 1971. Two stamps in the passport indicate it was extended by the Embassy of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. The passport also contains a residency permit effective from XXXXX 1997 until XXXXX 2000.
The claimant was asked how a passport issued in 1997 could contain a photo that the claimant alleged was taken three years later. He said he had no idea - the smuggler did what he did.
Finally, the Kilpatrick Declaration notes that personel from XXXXXXXXXX Airlines had notified her that "XXXXXXXXX," born XXXXXX 1971, travelled from Hong Kong to Vancouver on XXX XXXX 2000. The individual had a passport with the number XXXX and a Canadian Visitor's visa, issued on XXXXX 2000.
The claimant again categorically denied making an application for a Canadian visitor's visa in the UAE or an application for permanent residence in Canada through the Canadian Embassy in Damascus. His only explanation was that he did not know what the smugglers might have done with the extra pictures taken of him.
In my view, the preponderance of evidence suggests the claimant was living in the UAE for a number of years, and applied for a Canadian visitor's visa after he applied for permanent residency. His evidence to the contrary is not credible.
Counsel for the claimant filed a number of documents on current country conditions.22 The material suggests the situation in Afghanistan is unstable and confused.
ANALYSIS
The claimant has shown himself to be willing to mislead the panel as to his travels from Afghanistan to Canada. Only after being confronted with the incredibility of his testimony did he tell what he described as the real story of his travels. Categorical denials of his use of alias proved to be untrustworthy.
The evidence from Canada Immigration that suggests the claimant was not living in Afghanistan when he says his father disappeared or when he and his cousin were allegedly forced into exile.
Counsel for the claimant suggested in his submissions that there were credible reports of staff in some Canadian visa offices abroad producing fraudulent travel documents. However, there is no persuasive evidence before the panel that any of the materials submitted to it from Canadian visa offices in the UAE or Damascus were produced by fraud. Counsel also noted that there was no logical reason for the claimant to enter Canada with false documents when he had been issued a valid visitor's visa from UAE. There is one explanation that is of note. He could not claim in Canada that he was fleeing persecution from Afghanistan if he had been living peacefully in the UAE for many years.
Counsel for the claimant also argued that the claimant had lied about his travels to Canada because he was told to lie by his smuggler. However, the claimant put forward no credible or persuasive explanation for why he would choose to follow the smuggler's instruction and thereby risk the consequences of lying to this tribunal.
After reviewing all the evidence, I find that the claimant is probably an Afghan national of Hazara ethnicity. However, I find that he was not in Afghanistan during the relevant time periods he claims to have been in his PIF, but had been living outside Afghanistan for many years. I find that he did not flee Afghanistan for Pakistan in 1998 after the disappearance of his father as he alleges. I accept as credible the evidence of the Minister's Representative that he was living in the UAE at that time.
As noted, the situation in Afghanistan remains unsettled. However, in my view this does not in itself give rise to a well founded fear of persecution for this claimant. His fear is of a generalized nature. He has no recent history or profile in Afghanistan that suggests he faces more than a mere possibility of persecution.
DECISION
For all these reasons, I find that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee.

The claimant XXXXXXXX seeks a determination pursuant to s. 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act1 (the "Act") that she is a Convention refugee. She claims a well-founded fear of persecution based upon membership in a particular social group; in particular as a family member who has witnessed the murder of a loved one.
ALLEGATIONS
The following is a synopsis of the claimant's story taken from her Personal Information Form (PIF)2 and supplemented by the evidence at her hearing.
The claimant is a 32-year-old citizen of China. She and her husband owned and ran a chicken farm in XXXXX. On XXXXXXX, 1995 they sold all their chickens and had a lot of money on hand. That evening a gang of five Hunanese criminals burst into the house and killed her husband. They accomplished this by using the butt of a knife to stuff mosquito netting down his throat as far as the middle of his chest. He suffocated. At the time, the claimant was with her husband and their daughters who were aged two and five. The children witnessed this event. All had been gagged and tied. Eventually the eldest daughter wriggled herself free and the police were called.
The police investigated the incident and a few months later had the claimant come and positively identify three of the five criminals. They were locked up and remained in detention until the claimant left for Canada on XXXXXXX, 2001. The other two were never caught. Beginning in 1997 and lasting until she left the claimant, although moving frequently, received telephone calls from a person she presumed to be one of the two criminals who had not been arrested. This person threatened to kill her if she gave testimony against members of the gang. She never did, but that was because she had never been asked by the police to do so.
The claimant reported these telephone calls to the police, who told her that they did not have sufficient manpower to provide protection, rather they advised her to not go out at night and to lock her doors.
DETERMINATION
Although counsel argued that the claimant was a Convention refugee he did not argue s. 97 grounds. The panel has not considered the Convention refugee grounds as it has determined that the claimant is a person in need of protection under s. 97 (1) (b) of the Act. The panel found her to be a credible witness. In arriving at this determination the panel has considered all the evidence submitted, including the claimant's identity, her testimony at the hearing, and counsel's submissions.
ANALYSIS
Risk to Life or Risk of Cruel Treatment
s. 97 (1) (b) of the Act states:
97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally...
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail
themselves of the protection of that country,
(ii) the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country
and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless
imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide
adequate health or medical care.
Central to the analysis of this case is what harm is feared by the claimant. Clearly it is a risk to her life, given what was done to her husband, or at the very least a risk of cruel treatment - once again given the manner in which her husband was killed. Either of these constitutes a violation of a fundamental right, namely the right to security of person.3 The agents of harm are the remaining uncaptured members of the Hunanese gang that killed her husband.
The Hunanese gang members want to stop the claimant from testifying against them for the murder of her husband. This is a risk faced specifically by the claimant but not generally by members of the population of China. It brings her within the ambit of s. 97 (1) (b).
State Protection
In Ward, the Supreme Court of Canada articulated the "rationale underlying the international refugee protection regime" as follows:
The international community intended that persecuted individuals be required to approach their home state for protection before the responsibility of other states becomes engaged. For this reason, James Hathaway refers to the refugee scheme as "surrogate or substitute protection", activated only upon failure of national protection... ..4
The Supreme Court underscored that the issue of whether the state is able to provide protection from persecution is as follows:
Absent a situation of complete breakdown of state apparatus, such as that recognized in Lebanon in Zalzali, it should be assumed that the state is capable of protecting a claimant.5
The Supreme Court held that this presumption may be rebutted where the claimant "provides" or "advances" "clear and convincing proof" or "clear and convincing confirmation" of the state's inability to protect.6
The claimant has the onus of rebutting the presumption that her state is capable of providing protection. As for the quality of protection to be afforded by his state, while the Supreme Court has made reference the protection being "effective",7 it is also clear that:
No government that makes any claim to democratic values of protection of human rights can guarantee the protection of all of its citizens at all times.8
What is the situation with the claimant? She has gone to the police who have told her that they cannot protect her. They did not state that they could not protect anyone. In fact, an effort was made by these police to apprehend the criminals. They were, in fact, successful in apprehending three of the five. However, it is the other two who threatened her and as to these the police told the claimant they could not protect her from them.
What standard of protection could she have reasonably expected? Twenty-four hours a day protection in a country of 1.2 billion people where criminal gangs run into the tens of thousands would be expecting too much. However, as counsel for the claimant pointed out, no effort was made to protect this claimant. No watch was set up, no telephone tap was suggested; rather she was, in effect, told to fend for herself.
In Mendivil,9 the court held that while a state may be able to protect most of its citizens it may not be able to protect a specific individual.
The Board members do not appear to have considered the possibility that persons specifically targeted, who may qualify as members of a particular social group, might still have good grounds for fearing persecution when a state is capable of protecting ordinary citizens but incapable of protecting members of that particular social group.10
Here is such a case. The state has actually stated that it cannot protect this individual. Upon a consideration of the present claim the panel finds that this claimant has advanced "clear and convincing proof" of China's inability to protect her in order to rebut the presumption that China is capable of providing protection.
Internal Flight Alternative
In the panel's view this gang has demonstrated that it could track her down wherever she moved. It is clear, given the death penalty that is frequently meted out to convicted criminal gang members, that the gang would have a serious interest in keeping this woman quiet. Perhaps, it is only her frequent moving about that prevented their success. Because of this the panel finds that the claimant does not have an internal flight alternative where she could be safe.
CONCLUSION
The panel found the claimant to be a credible witness. As a result, the panel is of the opinion that there is more than a mere possibility that should the claimant be returned to China there would be a risk to her life pursuant to s. 97 (1) (b) of the Act.
For the reasons given and upon consideration of the whole of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection pursuant to s. 97 (1) of the Act.
"Michael A. Ross"
