XXXXXXXXX, age 46, is a citizen of China. He alleges a well-founded fear of persecution based on his membership in a particular social group. Specifically, he fears persecution as a practitioner and follower of Falun Gong.
The hearing was held on his claim on July 3, 2002. Final submissions were received from his counsel on August 1, 2002.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant entered Canada illegally in June 1998 to join his second wife, XXXXXXX, who is the sister of his first wife. Ms. XXXXX is a Canadian citizen and had returned to China in 1995 to marry Mr. XXX. She then returned to Canada and tried to sponsor Mr. XXXX admission to Canada, but Canada Immigration refused that application. As he wanted to be with his wife, the claimant came to Canada and lived here without status for 3 years, until he made his refugee claim in June 2001.
In 1999, the claimant began practicing Falun Gong to help him cope with health problems related to the stress of being in Canada illegally and unable to work. Initially he practiced with others in XXXXXXX Burnaby. From XXXX 1999 until XXXX 2001, the claimant and his wife lived in XXXXXXX on Vancouver Island. There he practiced Falun Gong on his own. In XXXX 2001 they returned to Vancouver and the claimant began to practice with others and participate in public Falun Gong activities.
As a committed Falun Gong practitioner, the claimant fears persecution in China. His counsel referred to country documentation which shows the Chinese government has been engaged in a serious crack-down on Falun Gong since 1999, which has included very harsh treatment of Falun Gong leaders and practitioners.1
DETERMINATION
I find the claimant does not have a well-founded fear of persecution in China based on his involvement in Falun Gong. Therefore, I find the claimant is not a Convention refugee. As well, I find the claimant is not a person in need of protection.
ANALYSIS
I find the claimant took up Falun Gong to establish a basis to stay in Canada. I find he does not have a strong commitment to Falun Gong, and could easily give it up if he returned to China.
Prior to arriving illegally in 1998, the claimant tried to enter Canada through sponsorship by his second wife. Canada Immigration denied that application as they said it was a sham marriage. Canada Immigration said his second wife had divorced her husband in Canada to marry the claimant for financial gain. She had been living in Canada and returned to China for a very short time to marry the claimant. She then returned one day after the marriage to Canada. Although Ms. XXXXX married the claimant and tried to sponsor his move to Canada, Canada Immigration said she continued to live with her ex-husband. After the sponsorship application was refused, the claimant entered illegally and remained here without status until 2001 when he made a refugee claim.
I do not accept that the claimant tookup Falun Gong in 1999, prior to the ban on Falun Gong in China. There is nothing to confirm his story that he began Falun Gong at that time. He said he started doing Falun Gong exercises for health reasons related to his illegal status and inability to work. However, he never saw a doctor for his health problems so, again, there is nothing to confirm his story. Further, at the hearing he admitted he had worked illegally in Canada in 1998 and 1999, so he was not without a job or income at that time. Finally, he admitted he also worked in XXXXXXXXXX. He said he practiced Falun Gong from 1999 to 2001 on his own in XXXXXXXXXX. Again, there is nothing to confirm this story. Given the claimant's clear history of entering a marriage that Canada Immigration has called a sham, and then coming to Canada and remaining here illegally for 3 years, I do not accept his story that, once here, he began the practice of Falun Gong starting in 1999 for health reasons. There is nothing to confirm his involvement in Falun Gong prior to July 2001. Further, he did not make a refugee claim until 2001, although if his story is true, he could have made a claim much earlier. I find it much more likely that the claimant tookup Falun Gong when he returned to Vancouver in 2001, in order to create a basis for a refugee claim.
The claimant says he practices Falun Gong regularly, attends other Falun Gong activities and has read the Falun Gong books. He says Falun Gong has improved his physical condition, given him more direction in his daily life, and causes him to do good things for others. He says Falun Gong teaches him truthfulness but, upon questioning, he admitted he had lied to Canada Immigration about his employment history in Canada and the existence of his step-son XXXXXXX. He could not explain why he had not been truthful. The claimant was asked about his step-son, XXXX, who was born in 1997. The claimant said his wife's ex-husband was the father of XXXX. When asked why his wife had a child with her ex-husband after she had married the claimant, the claimant said he did not know as he did not ask his wife about it. He said he and his current wife had decided not to have children until his status in Canada was resolved. This is not a credible story. The claimant claims to be married to his second wife, yet she subsequently had a child with her ex-husband and the claimant claims to know nothing about that. His evidence is supportive of the Canada Immigration conclusion that his current marriage is a sham. It also shows the claimant is not following the truthfulness principle of Falun Gong.
The claimant says he is involved in other Falun Gong activities, but listed only one such activity in his Personal Information Form (PIF).2 At the hearing, he listed other events he had attended since he filed his PIF. This reinforces my opinion that the claimant is using Falun Gong as a means to stay in Canada, and has tried to improve his claim by increasing his involvement in Falun Gong activities prior to the hearing. He had a photograph of himself taken at a XXXX 2002 demonstration, but was unable to say who had taken the photograph. He said he did not know other people at the demonstration and just asked someone for a photograph of himself. I find all the evidence shows the claimant has used Falun Gong to construct a refugee claim, and does not support his story that he is a committed Falun Gong practitioner.
When asked if he was concerned that he might have come to the attention of the Chinese authorities for his involvement in public demonstrations in Vancouver, the claimant said no. He said he had never given his name or other I.D., so he had not been identified for his involvement. He said he did not think he would be targeted for his Falun Gong activities in Canada. He feels he would be persecuted in China for practicing Falun Gong there. However, according to his story, he practiced Falun Gong alone in XXXXXXXXXX for two years. Thus, it seems the claimant can practice Falun Gong by himself without the need of any public display or involvement with others.
In summary, I find the claimant does not have a strong connection to Falun Gong. It is not like a religion for him, as he made no reference to any spiritual aspect. He said it helped him do good things, but the only examples he could provide were helping a person with his wheelchair and donating money on one occasion. The health benefits he has experienced are relatively minor, as he never had serious health problems. There is nothing to confirm his evidence on this point. Thus, I conclude the claimant is not part of a particular social group of committed Falun Gong practitioners who should not be expected to give up their commitment to/and practice of Falun Gong. The claimant is using Falun Gong to try and establish a way to stay in Canada. Nothing he said made me think he would continue to practice Falun Gong and face persecution if he returned to China.
CONCLUSION
Based on all the evidence and submissions and the above analysis, I find the claimant not credible about his history, involvement and connection to Falun Gong. He has not been truthful with Canada Immigration in the past, and I find that he was not truthful in his refugee claim. As a result, I find there is not more than a mere possibility the claimant would be persecuted in China because of his Falun Gong activities, or will face a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or will face a danger of torture if he returns to China.
Therefore, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection.
"Thomas Kemsley"

These are the reasons in the claim to refugee protection of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of the United States of America. Although this claim was filed under the provisions of the former Immigration Act1 it has also been considered under the provisions of the new Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.2
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS
The claimant says that three of her children, now all adults, have been alienated from her due to the various actions of both individuals and state and private agencies in the United States over the past decades.
When her daughter, XXXXXX, was nine years of age in 1977, she was taken from her custody by a court order and placed in the care of an agency. Her son, XXXXX, has been in conflict with the criminal justice system in the United States since he was fifteen years of age. He has repeatedly experienced prolonged hospitalisation in various mental institutions for ongoing paranoid schizophrenia. Her other son, XXXXX, has had ongoing problems related to drug and alcohol addiction.
All three of her children continue to reside in the United States. XXXXX lives in New Jersey, and XXXXX and XXXXX live in Washington State.
DETERMINATION
The panel determines that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible or trustworthy evidence to find that she is either a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
ANALYSIS
Although Mrs. XXXXX was unrepresented by legal counsel at the hearing, she voluntarily proceeded to personally present her case. She filed considerable documentary materials in support of her claim. Those materials reflect that she has already repeatedly and extensively litigated similar actions regarding her children in various levels of the court system in the United States. In some of her applications, legal counsel represented her. However, in most of the actions, she was capable enough to have represented herself.
She has initiated claims in the local courts of New Jersey and other states. She has also litigated her claims in the federal court system, including both the United States District Court and the United States Courts of Appeal, in both the District of Columbia and in the Ninth District (West Coast). In addition, on XXXXX, 2000, the claimant's action for relief was denied by the United States Supreme Court.3
The claimant appeared to be a concerned woman who was attempting to remedy wrongs that she believes have occurred to her and her children over the past three decades. From her own evidence, she suffered from problems relating to alcohol and some psychological problems in her younger life. Her twin sons, XXXXX and XXXXX, were born in 1963. She described them as hyperactive children and difficult for her to raise.
It appears that her daughter, XXXXXXX, has a learning disability and may also suffer from developmental disabilities. Shortly after XXXXXXX birth, the claimant voluntarily gave her into foster care for some five years. Thereafter, XXXXXXX was only in her custody for some two years before she was taken away, this time under a court order. The claimant has not had any direct contact with her since that time.
Another adult daughter, XXXXXXX, spoke by telephone to XXXXXXX in 1999. Although XXXXXXX told her that she was her sister and wanted to meet with her, her overture was
rebuffed. XXXXXXX has also shown no interest in having contact with the claimant. Her unsuccessful and repeated litigation in various courts have been motivated by her wish to regain custody of XXXXXXX, as she believes that her daughter was taken away from her by illegal or improper means.
In her most recent legal action that she undertook in the Superior Court in Newark, Essex County, New Jersey, the Court dismissed her claims and, because of her numerous previous legal actions, barred her from filing further lawsuits in that Court without prior judicial approval4. All of her various other lawsuits and appeals, including the U.S. Supreme Court, have also been repeatedly dismissed.
Her two sons, XXXXX and XXXXX, have lived in Washington State since the 1980's. XXXXX has a history of mental illness and is currently a patient in the XXXXXX Hospital in XXXXXXX, Washington. He has been a repeat patient at that institution for prolonged periods of time. It would appear that he has been an involuntary patient, who was committed under various court orders, because of his inability to function outside of an organized, institutional setting. The claimant has had sporadic contact with XXXXX. Most recently, she admitted that he had failed or refused to speak to her when she telephoned him at that hospital. According to Mrs. XXX, the problem is that XXXXX cannot function for any length of time on his own and outside of a structured setting. When he cannot cope, he has been repeatedly hospitalized. She believes that he actually needs one-on-one care, treatment that she claims is not available to him in the United States. She believes that his condition may improve if he is allowed to come to Canada to live with her, rather than continue to be incarcerated in that system in the United States.
Her other son, XXXXX, now receives a disability pension as a result of his alcohol and drug problems. She also has limited contact with him. The claimant herself was frank in admitting her own past problems. She was apparently homeless herself on and off from 1979 until 1985. She did work for nine years at the XXXXX Hospital in New York City until she retired in 1997. She is now receiving a pension from the United States government.
According to Mrs. XXXXX, she came to Canada for two reasons. Her main reason was to try and make proper arrangements for XXXXX' care. The other reason was because she was never able to get a proper place to live in New York City. In Canada, she believed she would not continue to be persecuted as she had been in the United States, where her rights as a parent had been denied. She wanted to start a new life here because she feels that her past life experiences have been unfair to her in the United States and Canada feels calmer to her.
When she filed her Personal Information Form (PIF)5, the claimant originally alleged that her refugee claim was based upon her race and her membership in a particular social group, as a low income African American. Prior to the hearing, she indicated that she no longer wanted to make her claim under those grounds and she advanced no evidence in support of them at the hearing. Instead, she proceeded with a claim of indirect persecution from mental torture inflicted upon her by the mistreatment, harassment and imprisonment of her children. In effect, she expanded her claim to include the consolidated grounds of the new Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and claimed that she was a person who was in danger of torture, as well as a person who faced a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
As previously mentioned, the claimant filed voluminous materials relating to her past court proceedings in the United States. It would appear from those documents that she has alleged that past improprieties were committed by certain officials relating to her daughter, XXXXXXX. In addition, she believes that XXXXX has been improperly treated as a criminal, when he is a person only suffering from on-going mental problems.
The panel has considered the claimant's case and also considered the situation in her country of citizenship. The United States is an advanced democratic country with a well-established legal system. The claimant has already had the greatest opportunities to pursue her claims under the statutes of those various jurisdictions and in the local, state and federal courts. There is no evidence that there is any conspiracy by any government officials against her. It would appear that the courts have found that she has not been able to establish that state authorities have carried out their duties regarding her children in a manner that is not lawful, even if she strongly disagrees with their actions.
The panel notes the decision of the Federal Court of Appeal of Canada in Satiacum6, concerning the legal system in the United States. Satiacum dealt with a refugee claim initiated by a citizen of the United States, who alleged he faced persecution after he was convicted there of a number of criminal charges. Although his refugee claim ultimately failed, the Court dealt with the question of state persecution in the context of a democratic state's judicial processes. The Court stated:
In all but the most extraordinary circumstances all the events leading up to a prosecution and all of the events of a trial in a free and independent foreign judicial system must be taken to be merged into the judicial process and not open to review by a Canadian tribunal. Extraordinary circumstances would be those, for example, which tended to impeach the total system of prosecution, jury selection or judging, not discreet indiscretions or illegalities by individual participants which, even if proved, are subject to correction by the process itself.
The Court also stated:
In the absence of exceptional circumstances established by the claimant, it seems to me that in a Convention refugee hearing, as in an extradition hearing, Canadian tribunals have to assume a fair and independent judicial process in the foreign country. In the case of a non-democratic State, contrary evidence might be readily forthcoming, but in relation to a democracy like the United States contrary evidence might have to go to the extent of substantially impeaching, for example, the jury selection process in the relevant part of the country, or the independence or fair-mindedness of the judiciary itself.
It was also mentioned by the Court that:
Again, in the absence of proof by the refugee claimant, Canadian tribunals must assume a fair trial. The notion of a fair trial in a fair and independent judicial system must make allowance for the self-correcting mechanisms within the system, e.g., the trial judge's control over the excesses of the participants, and the control of the appellant courts over any errors of the trial judge.
In this claim by Mrs. XXXXX, none of the credible evidence substantially impeached the legal processes to which her children have been subjected. Over the last three decades, the claimant, both with and without legal counsel, has continued to pursue her remedies for redress in all levels of the court system in the United States.
Mrs. XXXXX genuinely feels that she has suffered unfairly because of the past actions of individuals and organisations concerning her children. She came to Canada because of that dissatisfaction with the United States and also as a result of her inability to attain proper living accommodation in New York City. She decided to try and make a new life for herself here. She received advice that one way to attempt to stay in Canada was to make a refugee claim and she did so. However, the evidence she has presented has failed to establish a causal link between her past treatment and the Convention definition. She has had full access to a fair and independent judicial process in the United States over a long number of years.
Obviously, it was very clear that Mrs. XXXXX's primary concern is for her three children, who are still in the United States. As a mother, she feels frustrated with her inability to retain a close relationship with her children. All of her children, undoubtedly, have had and continue to have serious personal problems. It is clear that it was her intention that if she could remain lawfully in Canada, she could then arrange for appropriate care for them here. Then, she hoped to rekindle a close relationship with her children. However admirable her intention may be, there is no nexus to any Convention ground in her claim and she is not a Convention refugee.
In addition, there is insufficient evidence to find that she is a person who is in need of protection under section 97(1)b of the new Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. She would not personally be subject a risk of torture in the United States, as it is defined in the Convention Against Torture. There is also insufficient evidence that she would personally be subject to a risk to her life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in the United States.
Although Mrs. XXXXX would like to stay in Canada, her ability to do so is not within the jurisdiction of the Refugee Protection Division. She may wish to pursue other possible remedies that may be available to her to remain here and not return to the United States. She is obviously a sincere individual, who is concerned about her children's welfare. This has been exhibited by her many past efforts to seek legal redress on their behalf.
CONCLUSION
Having considered all of the evidence, the panel determines that this claimant is not a Convention refugee because there is less than a "serious possibility"7 that she has a well-founded fear of persecution if she should return to the United States. In addition, there is also less than a "serious possibility" that she is a person in need of protection.
Therefore, the panel rejects the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX to refugee protection.

These are the reasons for the decision of this panel in the claim for refugee protection of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of the United States of America.
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS
The claimant fled from the United States of America and came to Canada in 1996 after he was charged in the state of Wisconsin in 1995 with three criminal offences involving marijuana. Before leaving the United States, he obtained identification in the name of a deceased person, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. He entered Canada as a visitor under that name. He subsequently travelled on a number of occasions outside of Canada on vacation and then returned here on a US passport in the name of XXXXXXX. He married a Canadian citizen in 1999. His wife then applied to sponsor him for permanent residence. After the authorities here discovered his true identity, he was arrested in 2001. He then made his refugee claim.
DETERMINATION
The panel determines that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of refugee protection. There is also no credible basis to his claim.
ANALYSIS
The first issue to determine was whether there was a nexus to a Convention refugee ground in this claim. It was put forth on behalf of the claimant that there was a nexus by way of an imputed political opinion. In this regard, it was important to determine if the claimant faced persecution or prosecution in the state of Wisconsin, U.S.A. There, the claimant currently faces three charges involving marijuana: manufacture, delivery and failure to affix tax stamps. Are they validly enacted laws of general application in the state of Wisconsin?
In considering that aspect, the panel notes that in Zolfagharkhani:1, the Federal Court of Appeal stated :
...some general propositions relating to the status of an ordinary law of general application in determining the question of persecution.
The Court also stated that:
...an ordinary law of general application, even in non-democratic societies, should ... be given a presumption of validity and neutrality, and the onus should be on a claimant, as is generally the case in refugee cases, to show that the laws are either inherently or for some other reason persecutory.
The claimant failed to provide sufficient evidence to establish that laws dealing with the manufacture or delivery of marijuana or other similar laws enacted by a democratic body have any intent but to achieve general societal benefit. Such laws must, on their face, apply to all sectors of the population without being targeted at specific groups within that population. There was insufficient evidence to find that these criminal laws only target certain groups.
Another question to determine is whether the claimant would be punished for a breach of a law that does not violate human rights and does not differentiate, either on its face or in its application, adversely on a Convention ground. One other consideration is whether the claimant's actions might contravene criminal laws in which the enforcement or punishment of such laws might infringe upon human rights and adversely differentiate between individuals. All national states, including inferior levels of government within a national state, have the right to enact laws that contribute to the functioning of the state and its subordinate organizations. Violation of a law which regulates behaviour implies that there will be a commensurate penalty for the violation of that law. It is not because of this claimant's political opinion that such laws conflict with his activities. In that sense, such criminal laws are neutral and not persecutory.
According to the claimant, the only evidence to support these charges would appear to be information provided to the Wisconsin authorities by an individual who was involved in that criminal enterprise. That individual, XXXXXXXX, subsequently pleaded guilty and was sentenced to prison. XXXXX apparently wanted to obtain revenge because the claimant had started a relationship with a woman who had been romantically involved with XXXXX. The claimant alleged that he had no involvement whatsoever in that criminal enterprise. His brother approached XXXXX after he was released on parole and obtained an affidavit from him. In the affidavit, XXXXX attested that he had wrongly and falsely implicated the claimant in the crimes. According to the claimant, the Wisconsin authorities have, to date, indicated that they still intend to proceed with his charges.
The claimant conceded that he has the right to a jury trial on those charges. It is clear that he also has the right to apply to have reasonable bail set before his trial. He also has the right to have legal representation at all steps in the criminal proceedings against him in the state of Wisconsin. Based upon the evidence advanced before this panel, it would appear that there is no reasonable evidence upon which a jury could convict him of such offences.
There was much made of the penalties that the claimant might face if he is convicted. It is noted that two of the charges carry a maximum jail term of ten years and a minimum jail term of one year. However, it is also noted that on both charges, a jail term is not mandatory because, as an alternative, a fine may be imposed in lieu of any imprisonment. The third charge has a potential penalty of a fine or imprisonment, with no minimum penalty required. According to the evidence, any criminal penalties that might be imposed (in the very remote possibility that he would be convicted of any of these criminal offences in Wisconsin) only provide for a possible lengthy period of imprisonment as a maximum punishment. In that sense, there was insufficient evidence to find that laws of general application, such as the laws at issue in this case in the state of Wisconsin, are persecutory because their penalties are not disproportionate to the objectives of the laws.
The claimant speculated that he would be detained for a lengthy period of time before his trial. He also speculated that he would suffer harm if he was sent to jail after a conviction for any of these charges. Evidence was presented of abuses that have occurred to some inmates incarcerated in some of the various components of the vast American prison system. However, this claimant would only be liable to being tried and sentenced according to the laws of the state of Wisconsin, as there was no evidence presented that he currently faced any other outstanding criminal charges in the USA, either at the federal, state or local level. There was insufficient evidence presented to find that there is anything more than the merest possibility that he might suffer harm if he was imprisoned or detained in a prison facility operated by the state of Wisconsin.
As previously noted, the claimant's allegations are based primarily upon speculation on his part as to the likelihood of being imprisoned or convicted. The evidence before the panel would indicate there is only the merest possibility that he might be convicted. There is also nothing more than the merest possibility that he might suffer any harm from the penalties, whether they are fines or imprisonment, which might be imposed upon him after conviction.
As far as the allegations that the claimant might not receive a fair trial if he returned to the state of Wisconsin, the evidence is also deficient in that regard. The claimant admitted that he did not know if there was a lack of judicial independence regarding the campaign in the United States against the use of illegal drugs. There was certainly no evidence that there is any such lack of judicial independence in the state of Wisconsin. At most, he faces trial under a democratic state's functioning legal system, where he has a full right to a public trial for his criminal charges before a jury of his peers and an independent judiciary. He does not face any penalty that is disproportionate to the offences charged. He also has the right to appeal the outcome of his trial. There is no more than the most remote possibility that he might face treatment in prison, before or after his trial, that could be harmful or persecutory.
On the issue of a fair trial and the overall legal system that the claimant may face in Wisconsin (or elsewhere in the United States of America); the panel notes the decision of the Federal Court of Appeal in Satiacum.2 In that decision, the Court said:
In all but the most extraordinary circumstances all the events leading up to a prosecution and all of the events of a trial in a free and democratic foreign judicial system must be taken to be merged into the judicial process and not open to review by a Canadian tribunal. Extraordinary circumstances would be those, for example, which tended to impeach the total system of prosecution, jury selection or judging, not discreet indiscretions or illegalities by individual participants which, even if proved, are subject to correction by the process itself.
There is certainly nothing in the evidence in this claim to place it within the "extraordinary circumstances" envisaged in Satiacum for finding state persecution in a democratic state's judicial process.
In Satiacum, the Court also stated:
In the absence of exceptional circumstances established by the claimant, it seems to me that in a Convention refugee hearing, as in an extradition hearing, Canadian tribunals have to assume a fair and independent judicial process in the foreign country. In the case of a non-democratic State, contrary evidence might be readily forthcoming, but in relation to a democracy like the United States contrary evidence might have to go to the extent of substantially impeaching, for example, the jury selection process in the relevant part of the country, or the independence or fair-mindedness of the judiciary itself.
The Court continued:
Again, in the absence of proof by the refugee claimant, Canadian tribunals must assume a fair trial. The notion of a fair trial in a fair and independent judicial system must make allowance for the self-correcting mechanisms within the system, e.g., the trial judge's control over the excesses of the participants, and the control of the appellant courts over any errors of the trial judge.
In the panel's view, none of the evidence produced substantially impeaches the process in which the claimant is being sought by the state of Wisconsin. There was no evidence that the authorities there had any improper motivation in their dealings with the claimant. Charges were laid against him by the Wisconsin authorities only after evidence was provided by his alleged accomplice, XXXXX, who later admitted his own criminal involvement and was sentenced to a term of imprisonment. There was no evidence that XXXXX ever tried to appeal his sentence because he considered it to be excessive or improper. After serving one-third of his sentence, he was released on parole. Although the claimant alleged that the affidavit from XXXXXXXXXXX was presented to the requisite prosecution authorities in Wisconsin by his lawyer there, he said they have still refused to drop the charges. It was reasonable to have expected that he would have provided some evidence from his Wisconsin lawyer that such was the case, but he did not do so.
In any event, his trial can only proceed once the claimant is within the jurisdiction of Wisconsin. At that time, the authorities there will undoubtedly have to reconsider their intention to proceed with these charges. Unless they do have other evidence to present of his guilt, they would appear to have an overwhelming burden to overcome in obtaining a conviction against him, as their only witness has repudiated his previous accusation. He has now attested that he incriminated the claimant to seek revenge against him and he did so at a time when he was under duress.
It is clear from the evidence before the panel that there is no imputed political opinion involved in this claim. As such, there is no nexus between the credible evidence and the Convention definition. At most, this claimant is a victim of a personal vendetta initiated solely by Mr. XXXXX
As noted in the Handbook of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees:
Persecution must be distinguished from punishment for a common law offence. Persons fleeing from prosecution or punishment for such an offence are not normally refugees. It should be recalled that a refugee is a victim - or potential victim - of injustice, not a fugitive from justice.3
From the evidence before this panel, Mr. XXXXXX is clearly only a fugitive from justice and nothing else. He was not fleeing from persecution in the United States of America.
A further indication that the claimant was not fleeing persecution concerned the lengthy delay before he sought refugee status. It was some five years after he fled from the United States and not until after he was apprehended by the Immigration authorities here in 2001 that he first made known his claim to Convention refugee status. According to him, he made no efforts to seek (or to investigate) refugee status here prior to his apprehension because he felt safe here using that assumed name. It is reasonable to expect that a person who has fled from their country, allegedly with a well-founded fear of persecution, would seek permanent protection in the first foreign country in which he resides. The panel prefers to find that this claimant's inaction for a period of some five years before he sought such protection is clearly indicative of his lack of any subjective fear of persecution in the United States of America.
The panel has also considered, under the new provisions of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act4, whether the claimant is a person in need of protection. Does he face a danger of torture, or is he a person facing a risk to his life, or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment? After a consideration of all of the evidence, the panel finds that there is much less than a serious possibility that this claimant is such a person in need of protection.
CONCLUSION
Having considered all of the evidence, there is much less than a "serious possibility"5 that this claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution for any Convention refugee reason or that he is a person in need of protection, whether from a danger of torture or a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
The panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee nor is he a person in need of protection. In the panel's opinion, because there was no credible or trustworthy evidence on which it could have made a favourable decision, it is appropriate to also make a finding of no credible basis6 in the circumstances of this claim.

The claimant faced criminal charges involving drugs. The Refugee Protection Division found that the laws under which the claimant was charged were validly enacted laws of general application. The claimant had the right to reasonable bail, to counsel and to a jury trial. The man who implicated the claimant in the offences now claimed that he had done so falsely, on the basis of a personal grudge. It appeared that there was no reasonable evidence upon which a jury could convict the claimant. If he was convicted, the penalties which he faced - between one and ten years' imprisonment - were not persecutory as they were not disproportionate to the objectives of the laws. The claimant's fears of the harm he might suffer in jail were purely speculative. There were no extraordinary circumstances in this case which would justify a finding of persecution in a democratic state's judicial process. There was no nexus between the claim and the Convention definition. The claimant was a victim of a personal vendetta. The claimant's five-year delay in making a refugee claim was inconsistent with a subjective fear of persecution. There was no credible basis for the claim, and the claimant was not a person in need of protection. RPD VA1-03216, Clague, September 17, 2002.

These are the reasons for the decision in the matter of XXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
The principal claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, is a 47-year-old citizen of Mexico who claims he is a person in need of protection in that he claims to be at risk of losing his life or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment and punishment in Mexico.
His wife, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, is a 47-year-old citizen of Mexico. She also claims she is a person in need of protection in that she is at risk of losing her life or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Mexico.
Their daughter, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is seven years of age. Her father, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, was the Designated Representative for his daughter.
ALLEGATIONS
The allegations are essentially that the principal claimant was a member of the police force in XXXXXX, Michoacan. He had the rank of XXXXXX, from 1982 to 1986, participating in the XXXXX Program to fight narco trafficking and auto theft. He was based in XXXXXX, Apatzingan and worked there and in the Pacific area, and the mountains of XXXXX. In this capacity he participated in different operations and clashes with narco traffickers.
From 1986 to 1991 he worked with the XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the XXXXX, as a criminal investigator investigating primarily thefts and homicides. He worked with the XXXXXX until 1991 when he became an informant also known as a Madrina for the XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the XXXXXX. As a Madrina he used the names XXX and XXXXXX, and his job was to infiltrate the gangs that smuggled merchandise from the United States into the Federal District (in the XXXXXXXX) and to inform when and where contraband was to arrive. He also investigated arms smuggling and acted as an intermediary to get to the gang leaders. He worked at pubs, brothels and other places, and informed to the authorities so that they could take action, when a crime was about to take place.
Sometimes he would report the gang leader but the gang leaders would pay large sums of money to corrupt police officers for their release. The job was a very dangerous one, but it was one that he did willingly because he felt morally obligated to fight the war against drugs.
In XXXXXXX 2000, on his last assignment, he was retained by the XXXXX of XXXXXXX in the office of the XXXXXX, XXXXXXX, with whom he had assisted in several previous investigations. He was asked to infiltrate the distributors of cocaine in XXXXXX. Initially he refused because XXXXXX is his hometown, and many of those implicated were people with whom he had grown up and known for many years. Because he was offered a substantial amount of money (5,000 U.S.) he decided to accept this last position. It was his plan to move with his wife and child to a farm that he had purchased some years previously, and to stop this dangerous job of being a Madrina.
In late XXXXXX 2001 he informed Ms. XXXXXX of five cocaine houses which were distribution operations, where they were located, and the names of the people involved. Fifteen days later there was an operation where the army, the XXX and the state judicial police stormed into the houses and arrested people in three of the five houses. Large quantities of cocaine and money were seized. The claimant does not know how many people were arrested but believed that at least four had been detained.
A short time later two of the leaders were freed he believes, as a result of having paid a police bribe. It is his view that they would not have been released otherwise. These two men were known colloquially as XXXXX and XXXXX. He began to be very concerned information would be leaked to these two leaders that he was the informant, particularly because he was known to the people in XXXXXX, his hometown. He noticed that cars without licence plates were near his farm, which caused him concern. He asked the police XXXXXXX to offer him some protection because of his vulnerability, given he was involved in the arrest of XXXX and XXXXX. The police XXXXXXXX refused to offer him police assistance and the claimant became fearful that if he insisted on and received police assistance, corrupt police would simply turn him over to the narco traffickers for their own personal profit.
When he advised Ms. XXXXXX what was happening she said that she could not help him officially because he did not exist to her. However, she agreed to meet him in a park and gave him $750 U.S., telling him to move to the United States until things calmed down. (The claimant spoke to his wife and left the country four days later fearing that he would be killed as an informant).
It is his view that he would be killed by the narco traffickers as an example to others who might be inclined to inform on drug dealers. He believes that the narco traffickers have the financial resources necessary to purchase information through police and other state agents who have access to state information resources. In this way, if he became employed, sought medical treatment or voted anywhere in Mexico, he could easily be located and killed. It is his position that the narco traffickers remember for a very long time, the trails of others, that caused in difficulties for them. As a former XXXXX and informant, he would be viewed with contempt by the narco traffickers and believes that they would not forget him, until he was killed.
His wife claims that before her husband left he warned her that he was going to have to leave the country. He also told her to obtain passports for she and the daughter, in case they had to leave to join him at some time. His wife did not find this unusual because the claimant would be gone on assignment sometimes two and three months at a time. He did not explain to the claimant what he did for a living and it was not until the hearing that the claimant heard the word Madrina used in reference to her husband's activities. She became visibly upset during the hearing when she realized the danger, she and her daughter had been placed, as a result of her husband's job.
The claimant was approached on three occasions. In XXXXX of 2001 three or four men came to her home. They were armed, and they refused to identify themselves. They wanted to know her husband's whereabouts. The second was at the end of XXXXX 2001 when she and her daughter were waiting for a bus. Two men got out of a car and enquired about her husband's whereabouts. She told him that she had lost contact with her husband three months before. They told her that they were not going to stop until they found her husband and it would be better for her to co-operate with them. They threatened that if she did not co-operate with them they would hurt her where it hurt most, with one of them patting her daughter on the head as the threat was uttered.
She reported this to the judicial police and Public Ministry Office in XXXXXX and told them that she was being followed by men who were looking for her husband. She told them about the threat and they said that there was nothing that they could do to help her. They mocked her and told her that this was a risk faced by the spouse of a former XXXXXXX. They also made enquiries about her husband's whereabouts and she told them that she did not know where her husband was, which was the truth.
Later, in XXXXXX of 2001, on her way to work a truck stopped and four men got out of the vehicle. Two of them approached her calling her by name and told her that she had to accompany them. One of them grabbed her by the arm and tried to push her into the truck. She managed to break free and ran towards her home. At this time the men grabbed her by the hair and she started to scream but they pulled her, resulting in bruising to her body. Because this was her home neighbourhood, several people in the area started trying to help her, shouting for the police and creating a general fracas. The men fled at this point and the claimant was too afraid to report this incident to the police. She contacted her husband through his sister, XXXX. Her husband told her to leave as soon as possible and that his mother would arrange for travel tickets. She quit a job of 20 years as a XXX and left the country with her daughter on XXXXX, 2001.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimants' identity as nationals of Mexico was established by their testimony which was forthright and credible on this point and by the supporting documentation filed, namely, authentic international Mexican passports for all three claimants. Additionally, electoral cards, a transit card and identification from the Secretary of Education were filed to establish the claimants' identity. I am satisfied that the claimants possess acceptable documentation establishing their identity.
Harm Feared
The claimants allege that if they return to Mexico they would be killed or beaten so severely as to be hospitalized. I find that the kind of risk alleged by the claimants is a risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment described in section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
The claimants testified in a very forthright and candid way. They point to the situation of other Madrinas who have been killed or beaten for informing on narco traffickers. The fact that the female claimant was grabbed and an attempted kidnapping took place has caused them to be very concerned about their safety. Justifiably so, in my view.
Risk of Harm
In addition, there is a serious possibility that the claimants will be either killed or seriously injured should they return to Mexico. They have been threatened personally by individuals who have been provided information about the fact that the claimant is an informer.
The realization by the principal claimant that the narco traffickers are vengeful and ruthless is, on the balance of probabilities, likely to result in grave risk to his life, given their interest in setting a visible example of those who inform on narco traffickers. The documentary evidence suggests that traffickers in Mexico form a large, well-organized group sufficiently well-financed to be able to bribe police officers, and would want to safeguard the viability of such an established network by ensuring that their credibility as traffickers is not undermined by informants like the principal claimant.
State Protection
I agree with the principal claimant that the state will not protect him should he return to Mexico. It is obvious from the evidence that the local police are on the payroll of the criminals. We have evidence at Exhibit 9.1 The specific question asked for this case was for information about a drug seizure of cocaine in XXXXXX involving the state judicial police and the Attorney General of the Republic, Procuraduria General de la Republica (XXX) including number of arrest charges and whether those arrested were released.
The Response to Information says as follows:
Without mentioning a specific date a report by XXXXXX disclosed to the arrest of seven persons at the "XXXXX" market in the historical centre of XXXXXX (XXXXX 2001). The Federal Judicial Police (Policia Judicial Federal, PJF) confiscated 60 "grapas" (local unit of measurement of cocaine) and one ounce of cocaine. (ibid.).
The commander in charge of the investigation, XXXXX XXX XXXXX, said the operation took "some 50 minutes" (unos 50 minutos) as PJF agents arrested seven persons, (including three women and one minor), for selling various quantities of cocaine (ibid.).
Moreover, the same report states this was the second anti-drug operation in the municipality of XXXXXX since XXXXXX 2000. (ibid.). In the XXXXX seizure, the Mexican Amy in collaboration with the Attorney-General of the Republic (Procuraduria General de la Republica, XXX) and the Attorney-General of Justice(Procuraduria General de Justicia, PGJ), searched approximately 15 houses (ibid.). In 11 of the houses searched the agents discovered drugs, arms, communication equipment and counterfeit money (ibid.)..
At Exhibit 10 the claimant has provided a photograph of himself in XXXXX uniform dating back to 1986. However, he does not have any other photographs more recent, to confirm the fact that he was, in fact, a XXXXXX. I accept his testimony is credible and I accept that he was initially a XXXXXXX, and then later, a XXXXX.
At Exhibit 12 counsel filed a document from the World Policy Papers entitled "Democracy and Human Rights in Mexico" by Andrew Redding from 1995.2 At page 25 of that document I read the following:
A further source of abuse is the widespread use of covert agents known as Madrinas ("godmothers"), or meritorios ("deserving ones"). Though often heavily armed these agents are kept off the books. Because they do not act in an official capacity they can be used to circumvent the law. The judicial police use them to do their dirty work, then deny any responsibility. The fact that Madrinas are not on a regular payroll also fosters corruption. Since they cannot be paid out of the public funds they are often paid out of the proceeds of drug busts or protection money supplied by drug traffickers and other criminals.
Furthermore, in reviewing the Federal Court Trial Division's decision in Zhuravlvev3 Judge Pelletier held that:
Where the evidence, including the documentary evidence situates the individual claimant's experience as part of a broader pattern of state inability or refusal to extend protection, then the absence of state protection is made out. The question of refusal to provide protection should be addressed on the same basis as the inability to provide protection. A local refusal to provide protection is not a state refusal in the absence of evidence of a broader state policy to not extend state protection to the target group. Once again, the documentary evidence may be relevant to this issue. There is an additional element in the question of refusal which is that refusal may not be overt; the state organs may justify their failure to act [page 18] by reference to various factors which, in their view, would make any state action ineffective.
The Refugee Protection Division must, therefore, assess the bona fides of these assertions in light of all the evidence.
In this case a persistent failure to take action, while not necessarily justifying a finding of a lack of state protection, does require a close examination of the reasonableness and bona fides of the police action, particularly where a citizen's right to internal movement is limited.
In this case the claimant submits that his right to internal movement is limited by virtue of the accessibility of the police to his personal profile.
It is my view that the issue of state protection will very often turn on the credibility of the claimant. Where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, as in Mexico, and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens, the mere fact that it is not always successful in doing so may not be enough to justify a claim that the claimants are unable to avail themselves of such protection.4
While it is clear that Mexico is in effective control of its territory, we need to analyze further whether the protection to be offered to this claimant is effective in this case. I accept the claimants' evidence as credible. Having done so, I accept that he has a subjective fear.
In this case the subjective fear of persecution and risk combined with the state's inability to protect the claimant and his family, creates a presumption that his fear is well-founded. Additionally, we have information about particular groups who are at risk in Mexico, including members of the judiciary and informants.
I, therefore, agree with the claimants that the state will not protect them should they return to Mexico.
Internal Flight Alternative
I find, on the balance of probabilities, that there is no internal flight alternative for these claimants. As they have stated in their testimony, the narco traffickers have ties with government officials who provided them with information with respect to both the claimant's whereabouts and his role as an informant. If the narco traffickers are this well organized it is more likely than not that they have the ability, as the claimants suggest, to use government and police contacts to track he and his family down and ensure that he is punished for his reporting of their activities and informing the police of a drug bust, in advance, resulting in a substantial loss of revenue. The claimants would essentially be living in hiding in other parts of Mexico, making IFA unreasonable in the circumstances.
There was a substantial loss of income and drugs for which the claimant will be forced to atone. His family is also at risk by virtue of the high incidence of kidnapping in Mexico. We read that the kidnapping situation in Mexico is second only to Colombia. It is not difficult to accept the possibility that the young, minor claimant could be kidnapped as a way to ferret out the principal claimant so that he can be made to suffer for being an informant. Given the veiled threat made to Mr. XXXXXX about the daughter XXXXXXX, this fear is justified.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis I conclude that XXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are persons in need of protection. I, therefore accept their claims for refugee protection.

The principal claimant feared drug or narco traffickers. He and his family feared that if they returned to Mexico, they would be killed or severely beaten. The Refugee Protection Division found that the claim involved a risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment within the meaning of section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. There was a serious possibility that the claimants would be killed or seriously injured if they returned to Mexico. Given that the local police are on the payrolls of criminals, state protection would not be available to the claimants. They did not have an internal flight alternative (IFA) as the drug traffickers had the ability to use government and police contacts to track them down. The principal claimant's family was also at risk by virtue of the high incidence of kidnapping in Mexico. The claimants were persons in need of protection.
